PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1)to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2)not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3)to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and

(4)to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including: re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley (from 182 citizens), Mr Dawkins (from 212 citizens), Mr Grace (from 289 citizens), Mr Lee (from 336 citizens), Mr Newell (from 241 citizens), Mr Price (from 293 citizens), Mr Snow (from 977 citizens) and Mr Snowdon (from 319) citizens.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect from many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 44 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 76 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 15 citizens) and Mr Truss (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 52 citizens) and Mr Reith (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bradford (from 66 citizens) and Mr Newell (from 360 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National University Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of the following citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill 1992 introduced by Senator Tierney passed unopposed through the Senate on 8 October 1992.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to debate this Bill at the earliest possible opportunity and ensure its passage through the House so that the autonomy of the Council of the Australian National University may be reinstated, together with full control over the funding of its Schools, including the John Curtin School of Medical Research.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Kemp (from 155 citizens) and Mr Langmore (from 22 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that certain persons wish to change the National Flag of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that no change to the National Flag of Australia be made without a full referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and seek to practise the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles, draws to your attention that the practice of abortion as generally carried out in Australia is:
1.Sin against God (Job 1 v 21);
2.Sin against His word as contained in the Holy Bible (Exodus 20 v 13);
3.Against the welfare of this nation (Proverbs 14 v 34);
4.A contradiction of the Parliamentary Prayer (Matthew 6 v 10).

Abortion as generally performed is murder to destroy life, not to save it. No nation can usurp or defy God's rights with impunity. For the Government to continue supporting this wickedness is to invite God's righteous indignation and judgment upon our nation.
Abortion is not just a political, social nor economic issue. It is a serious Moral issue.
Your petitioners therefore as in duty bound, pray and ask the Honourable House, that, as a matter of righteousness and urgency, Medicare funding of Abortion be terminated as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the house that we the undersigned affirm our absolute support for the Australian Flag and express our sincere disappointment that the flag has recently been denigrated within and outside of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request the House to affirm its support for the Australian Flag and ensure that under no circumstance the Australian Flag be changed.

PETITION.TITLE: Pathology Collection: Childers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the shire of Isis in the State of Queensland draw to the attention of the House that the Pathology collection room in the rural town of Childers may be forced to close on February 1st 1993 as a result of new legislation enacted in 1992.

Should this occur, citizens of the ageing population of Childers, with no access to public transport, would suffer the hardship of travelling 56 kms to the nearest Pathology service in Bundaberg, often while unwell.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House takes those steps necessary to ensure that the population of the Isis Shire not be disadvantaged by the loss of a Pathology Collection Service.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they strongly oppose any change to the design of the existing Australian Flag and should the Federal Labor Government pursue its agenda to change the design it calls upon it to first hold a referendum of the Australian people.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House meets the requirements of this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your electors and citizens are suffering grievously from the compulsion to pay excessive and widely variable rates of interest on loans which we have been or will be obliged to accept in order to purchase a home, and

That we ask the Parliament to make a new law before 31 December 1992 which will prevent any Bank or Financial Institution from charging an effective annual interest rate in excess of eight per cent in respect of loans or mortgages the purpose of which has been, is, or will be the procurement of a dwelling for habitation by the borrower and his or her immediate family.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition is from the undersigned residents within the Electorate of Griffith who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and belong to a universal fellowship of Christians. We uphold the Bible as the inspired infallible Word of God providing instruction for every facet of life regardless of change in social attitudes or standards.
We therefore respectfully draw to the attention of the House that the law of God is being violated daily by the present Family Law Act in so far as:

PETITION.PARA: (a)Adultery is not recognised as a basis for divorce. The Lord Himself said "But I say unto you, that whosoever shall put away his wife, except for cause of fornication, makes her commit adultery, and whosoever marries one that is put away commits adultery." (Matthew 5 v 32)

(b)De facto relationships are placed on an equal footing to marriage. These relationships are adulterous and against scripture. "It is good for a man not to touch a woman; but on account of fornications, let each have his own wife, and each woman have her own husband." (1 Corinthians 7 v 1-2)

PARA.TAB: We further humbly remind the House that Government is of God and therefore responsible to uphold the sanctity of marriage as the providential bond of all moral order in the world and be committed to the preservation of the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Family Law Act be amended so that:

PETITION.PARA: (1)Adultery is reinstated as a ground for divorce and
(2)De facto relationships are treated as illegitimate at all levels of Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1.The service being provided for mail deliveries through the Princetown Post Office and Store be retained.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that Australia Post takes into account the concerns of the Princetown Community that the present mail service continue to originate from Princetown in its present state.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Television: Asia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that:

PARA.TAB: the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia. Apart from an initial grant from the Government it is intended to finance this venture by the introduction of corporate sponsorship.
the Government intends to alter existing broadcasting legislation to allow this to be done.

this course of action would set a precedent which, in our view, would introduce pressures of corporate funding into the ABC and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster in its vital role as Australia's main disseminator of news and information at a time of unprecedented concentration of media ownership in this county.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitions therefore ask the House either:

PARA.TAB: to ensure that the proposed Asian service be wholly funded by Government
OR that the proposed Asian service not commence until Government funds are available.

PETITION.TITLE: Genetic Engineering
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: We citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth draw to the attention of the House, our concern at the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. Along with the unknown consequences to the Earth's natural life forms and environment, in order for Individuals and Multi National Companies to patent and own the food resources of the world.

We request you to pass laws prohibiting the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. We want you to protect Humanity from the patenting and owning, by Individuals and large Corporate Bodies, of unnatural life forms.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who are not only believers in the Lord Jesus Christ but have a common interest in relation to the absolute authority and recognition of God's word as contained in the Holy Bible. Your petitioners draw to the attention of the House that the requirement of God's Law is completely disregarded by the Family Law Act in that adultery is not allowed as a basis for divorce.

The Lord Jesus Christ Himself said "whosoever shall put away his wife except for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery and whosoever marrieth her which is put away committeth adultery" (Matt 19 v 9).

At the commencement of each session of Parliament pray is made, part of which is stated "Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven", and your petitioners humbly pray that this be put into practice by amending the Family Law Act to reintroduce adultery as a ground for divorce.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House

that with more than 10 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit but substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to

act to ensure that Australia maintains a viable processing industry based on our rural industries and that tariffs remain in place as long as other nations use non-tariff measures, tariff protection, etc.;
stop imports of goods that are supported by subsidies and other non-tariff or dumping measures to Australia; and
restore profitability to our farms and factories, employment opportunities to our citizens and to provide a future for our youth and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sumitriptan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Ballarat draws to the attention of the House that hundreds of migraine sufferers have been denied easy access to a new effective and safe migraine treatment known as Sumitriptan.

This treatment, which has been approved by the Australian Drug evaluation Committee, has been rejected for inclusion on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. The tablets cost about $30 each and consequently will be out of reach for most sufferers resulting in migraine sufferers enduring unnecessary pain and inactivity. The drug is widely used overseas, approved in at least 23 countries and has an 80 per cent success rate.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take urgent steps to ensure that Sumitriptan is listed on the PBS.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia is humbly presented. Each is a believer on the Lord Jesus Christ and accepts the authority of God's Holy Word in the Scriptures. Consequently their lives are lived in accord with the commands of the Lord Jesus and His apostles, especially the apostle Paul.

Your petitioners have signed this petition in view of drawing the attention of the House to the responsibility that rests upon it. The Parliament of Australia exists at the will of God (see Romans chapter 13) and further, in prayer to God at each session seeks direction to act in accord with that Will. Further, your petitioners supplicate God that Parliament may be maintained for the good of all men.

Your petitioners as in duty bound draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Medicare funding of abortion, as generally practised in Australia, is in no way in accord with that Will. When abortion is practised life is destroyed. What is destroyed is a God given life. (See Job chapter 1 verse 21). The Medicare funding of abortion is supporting and facilitating actions that are directly flouting the Will of God.

Your petitioners restate that in this matter of abortion there is a heavy responsibility resting on the Parliament of Australia. They therefore in duty bound pray that The Honourable House will treat Medicare funding of abortion as a moral issue which outweighs all social and economic and political considerations. Your petitioners further pray that The Honourable House will act to discharge this moral issue by terminating the Medicare funding of abortion without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House:

That about 28,000 unborn babies are being killed in Victoria annually, and that a total of about 750,000 have been killed in Australia since abortion item 6469 became part of the Medicare benefits schedule in 1975.
Most abortions are performed on healthy unborn babies for reasons of convenience and most of the procedures are funded by the Australian taxpayer through Medicare.
Your petitioners therefore ask the house to terminate Medicare funding of abortion in Australia by supporting the Abortion Funding Bill of 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, I present the Committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled The Family Law Act 1975: aspects of its operation and interpretation, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those honourable members present or watching the telecast of proceedings can see the extent of the documentation I have laid before the House today. The report's submission to the Senate by the Chairman on Tuesday predated the presentation in the House today. There were 1,031 submissions received by the Committee. The publication of these submissions, the Hansard reports in regard to the deliberations on them at public hearings and the report itself, containing 120 recommendations, are now before the House.

PARA.TAB: In my long period in this Parliament, nearly 27 years, I have not served on many parliamentary committees. I am not one who has the same high regard for parliamentary committees as the overwhelming majority of senators and members of the House have. I allow myself the luxury of dissenting from the general opinion on the worth of committees. At the time that this Committee was formed I was shadow Attorney-General and I felt that perhaps it was proper that I serve on this Committee. I have to say that it has changed my attitude to the work of parliamentary committees to some extent; not totally but to some extent.

The work of the Committee can be seen in the wide ranging recommendations that are contained in the report. There are, as I said, 120 recommendations covering areas such as—I am relying on recall here rather than reading from the report—the role and the effectiveness of the Family Court Counselling Service, Marriage Guidance and Family Mediation, disputes in relation to children, enforcement of Family Court orders, matrimonial property, the consideration of superannuation, the cost of proceedings, the adversarial nature of those proceedings, et cetera.

The work of the Committee in the short period of time that it functioned was, quite frankly, prodigious. In an area such as this, where different people may be thought to bring different views to bear on the institution of marriage, it has produced a report that is endorsed by all members of the Committee, with only three elements dissented to by one senator, namely, Senator Spindler. It became apparent to me that all members of the Committee approached their work with great diligence and with a very heavy presumption in favour of the institution of marriage, and with the aim to see that those who go through the tragedy of marriage breakdown are given consideration. Some of the Committee members have experienced that, whereas others have had the tragedies played out before them in their electorate offices, because there are very few areas of government jurisdiction on which members of parliament, certainly members of the House of Representatives, receive more representations alleging unfair or inequitable treatment.

I was extremely impressed with the way in which Committee members approached their tasks. I was more impressed, if I may say so to members of the Government, with the work of the Chairman, Senator McKiernan. Prior to this Committee inquiry, I knew of Senator McKiernan and his well honed leftist views. I knew of him also because of the slightly different order of clothing that he tends to wear, in terms of its colour and design. But I have to say that I have not been more impressed with the diligence, the fairness and the objectivity of any member of parliament in approaching a task.

One of my colleagues practised in the field of family law prior to entering this Parliament, and halfway through the deliberations of this Committee he remarked to me that even by that stage Senator McKiernan was so on top of matters relating to the Family Law Act that his knowledge would have exceeded that of most practitioners in the field. I would affirm that. That knowledge, together with the fairness and the objectivity with which the Committee's hearings were conducted, meant that it was a distinct pleasure to work with Senator McKiernan.

I think it unlikely that the Government will be returned at the next election. I am probably not doing Senator McKiernan any service by saying this, but I think if the Opposition were to lose the next election and Senator McKiernan were not a member of the Ministry then the Government would be flawed as a consequence. That probably means the end of Senator McKiernan's chances!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the kiss of death.
—I can see the right wing in the chair already machinating.
—I think it is interesting that the honourable member for Kooyong has cast doubts upon the outcome of the next election.

—Not at all. I took a leaf out of the book of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who was speculating the other day on the woes that would befall Australia—babies would be bitten and the plague would descend upon us—if the Opposition were elected to government. It is quite clear that it is possible to propagate the hypothetical in this arena. My own confidence in the election of the Opposition is not diminished by anything I have said about Senator McKiernan.

PARA.TAB: The members of the Committee too have worked assiduously. We would not have had this report had it not been for Senator Brownhill. He pressed for the establishment of a committee and, as a result of his efforts, the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act was established. The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) brought faith and diligence to his work, and my fellow practitioner in the law, Senator Reid, contributed so much from our side. They all made up a very effective committee, along with members of the Labor Party who, as I said, brought their own views to the Committee, irrespective of political philosophy.

The members of the Committee were aided by a hardworking staff who dealt with over a thousand recommendations, with a number of changes in personnel. That staff assisted us greatly. I do not want to cover all the areas that Senator McKiernan has. His speech in presenting the report and the report itself should aptly stand on their own. However, there are a couple of matters that I wish to mention.

I have indicated the breadth of the recommendations that have been made and the matters that have been covered by the Committee. For example, the family law at the moment covers de facto property disputes where children are not involved. We have recommended no change in that area. But in other circumstances, where the Family Court does not have jurisdiction and the law is covered by the law of the State in which the couple resides, a number of inequities are apparent and there is confusion of the law throughout Australia.

We recommended a reference of powers from the States to allow the Family Court to hear these disputes, but we believe that separate legislation should be drafted for these matters to be settled, and that they not be covered by the Family Law Act. We did that quite deliberately, because all members of the Committee believed that the section in the Act that affirmed the principle of marriage should remain, as an aspiration for marriage as an institution. We felt that matters involving de facto situations should be covered by separate legislation. All members of the Committee were in favour of separate legislation, rather than these matters being covered by the Family Law Act itself. We were cognisant of wishing to settle inequities by the reference of power from the States and of having separate legislation.

Speaking as a lawyer, I was shattered by some of the submissions that came before the Committee with claims of outrageous charging by some law firms. We heard about some shocking examples of overcharging. However, I was satisfied at the end of the day that the majority of legal practitioners did not engage in such misuse of their position. We have recommended a new costing system and the greater use of costs orders, particularly where it is apparent that one party has unnecessarily prolonged proceedings. There are a whole range of matters on which I could speak, but I must allow time for other honourable members to speak this morning, so I will be brief.

With regard to property disputes, we have made recommendations for special consideration to be given to farming properties, where we heard evidence of some frightful injustices. We have recommended that pre-nuptial contracts be taken into consideration by the courts in considering the division of property. There are many more points I would like to make. I enjoyed making, or seeking to make, a contribution from time to time on this Committee and I commend the Committee and the Chairman. I believe that the community, if the law is amended in accord with the recommendations that are down here, will have a better system of family law in a tragic area, which is made even more tragic in the midst of unemployment in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) for his remarks about the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. I would like to congratulate the Chairman, Senator Jim McKiernan, and the honourable member for Kooyong for their contribution to the Committee. Irrespective of the remarks by the honourable member for Kooyong about Senator McKiernan's aspirations, or deserved position in the Ministry, I believe he was a fantastic Chair of this Committee, and without him we would have been hard put to come up with the results that we have achieved. It also behoves me to thank the members of the Committee who worked with Senator McKiernan and the honourable member for Kooyong on this report.

PARA.TAB: It was a Committee of disparate views. I think anybody who has an understanding of the complexities of family law and the importance placed on the institution of marriage, and of the concern that exists in the community and in the Parliament about the rate and result of dissolution of marriage in Australia, would understand that it was not an easy committee to chair or even to be on. But the members of the Committee, despite their differences, brought to the report and to the consideration of the matter their very sincere and genuine attempts to resolve these sorts of problems in a most equitable and just fashion.

The report will allow access to affordable, just and similar law by Australians who are unfortunate enough to be experiencing the dissolution of a relationship or a marriage. As a Committee member, I wanted to be sure that the result of the Committee's deliberations would allow Australians to be treated equally when they happen to be in the unfortunate circumstance of dissolving their marriage or relationship. The children of the marriage are the prime factor and the Family Law Act recognises that at the present time.

The Committee took great pains to look into the question of de facto relationships, where children were not involved, because these relationships and the property settlements of these relationships are not able to be covered, under present law, by the Family Court. We had long discussions, as was mentioned by the honourable member for Kooyong, about whether the matter should be put to the Family Court or whether it should remain as it currently is—with access to a separate court, the Supreme Court. The Committee decided in its wisdom—I think, quite rightly—that such matters should be considered by the Family Court, as it has the expertise to deal with them. In that way, people who have not been married, but who have had a relationship similar to marriage, will have their property settled in the same way as people who were married. I believe this enhances the institution of marriage, not detracts from it. I think it is a wise decision of the Committee and I certainly hope that the Government picks up that recommendation.

There was some initial disagreement in getting to that point. However, I think we were all very happy with the decision that we would have a separate piece of legislation which would cover the property settlement of people who were in de facto relationships, as opposed to having that covered by the Family Law Act and altering or amending it to achieve that end. The situation of people in a de facto relationship is problematical, and we received very strong submissions on the matter.

My experience in the matter of marriage dissolution is very limited. Fortunately, I have not experienced it; however, I am the product of a family that has had that sort of dispute. There are many people in Australia who have an interest in the outcome of this Committee's deliberations. I believe that we have brought our best endeavours to the report and that the report should be commended. It is a report of which we, as a Committee, and as a Parliament, can be proud; especially given that there was little dissent in the final recommendations and that those areas of dissent were fairly specialised.

The other concern of the Committee was that there be a reduction in litigation. A group of people other than the marital partners being involved, especially where there might be monetary gain to be made by extending the proceedings, does not always assist the niceness of the result for the two parties and their children.

Mediation counselling was canvassed considerably by the Committee and, indeed, by the submissions that were made to it. We have come down with good recommendations in that area. Most Australians will be pleased to have enhanced access to mediation counselling before making final agreements or settlements on property and even in relation to children. We have taken seriously the concerns of a large group of people in the community, including the male members of families who feel that they are not getting just access to their children. We have also considered the question of females quite properly. This is a good report. I hope and trust that the Government will accept its recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in commending to the Parliament the report entitled The Family Law Act 1975: aspects of its operation and interpretation. The Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act was faced with a very daunting task. I can only echo the sentiments expressed by other members of the Committee, the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock); and Senator McKiernan, in his tabling speech to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I emphasise that this Committee operated extremely well. Given the task, it operated certainly beyond my expectations. I did not think that it would operate this well or that the outcome would be so positive. The fact that there is only one dissenting report on relatively minor matters which do not take away from where the Committee was going—there was simply a view that some stronger wording should have been used—is quite remarkable. We had people from very different viewpoints, both social and philosophical. To draw all this together and to come up essentially with a unanimous set of recommendations speaks volumes for the Committee Chairman, its Deputy and all the members of the Committee.

Prior to my election to parliament I was a solicitor, practising to a certain extent in family law. I cannot say I ever particularly enjoyed that area because, at the end of the day, I knew that the clients in a number of the cases would walk out from the proceedings extremely unhappy. That had a certain amount to do with the system and the law but, at the end of the day, we were talking about people at the low point of their lives, where the major relationship of their life had failed. They were in dispute, in many instances, about the custody of their children or about property that had been acquired over some years through joint effort. Inevitably, in those circumstances, people were going to find the whole process extremely difficult.

We should bear in mind a couple of things and these are borne out by the report. Fortunately, most people, even through these difficult circumstances, do manage to resolve the matters fairly amicably. Very few end up darkening the doors of solicitors or the court in absolute terms and that is a very good thing.

In as much as this report continues to emphasise that legal proceedings should, in the end, be a last resort, and that we should be concentrating on the concept of alternate dispute resolution, that is a very positive development. Ironically enough, it was really one of the founding principles of the Act. It was always meant to remove this conflict from the formal court system. That is why a special court was set up in the first place. Over time, I think that has been lost sight of.

In as much as we have refocussed the attention on alternate disputes resolution, and canvassed the idea of including in the education system some better understanding of what is meant by a marriage, and given emphasis to the concept of marriage guidance, all these things are very positive. Inevitably, where disputes cannot be resolved, some matters will end up with an arbiter or judge having to make the final decision. We have looked at the issues that attract the most criticism and controversy regarding the operation of the court.

In the area of property, what the Committee has essentially done is return the law to the position prior to the High Court decision in Mallet's case: in practice, there should be a starting point of a fifty-fifty division of property, which can be modified, given the particular circumstances of a marriage, by means of a limited discretion on the part of the court. I think that people accept the principle that marriage is a joint partnership; that property is generally acquired through joint effort; and that a fair starting point is a fifty-fifty division, with the individual circumstances of each relationship then being taken into account. That is a very useful restatement of what I think should have been the principle which has become a bit clouded through some judicial decisions. That is a positive change.

Another area about which I, as both a practitioner and a member of parliament, receive constant complaint is the enforcement of some court awards, particularly in the area of access. We have tackled how to make them work better, and I think the recommendations are workable and should be endorsed.

In the area of custody, we have again emphasised as paramount the interests of the children. We have made some changes in the way that should work, particularly by spelling out what guardianship means and what one can expect in being awarded guardianship, as opposed to custody, of a child. They are very important issues. I could talk for a great deal of time, but I do not want to take other members' time. I commend the members and secretariat of the Committee for a job well done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot rise to speak this morning with any real sense of pleasure or pride or feeling of satisfaction. Having said that, I hasten to add that this has nothing to do with the work of the members or the secretariat of the Joint Select Committee. Both groups worked tirelessly to produce the report being tabled in this House this morning entitled The Family Law Act 1975: aspects of its operation and interpretation. I commend Senator Brownhill; Senator McKiernan, the very able leader of the Committee; and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who also made an extremely valuable contribution. I also commend the other members of the Committee; the Secretary of the Committee, Robina Mills; David Wallace, the consultant; Fiona Taylor, who assisted ably in the running of the Committee; and, not least, Lesley Cowan, who very capably and ably assisted with the administration of the Committee, with the help of another lady in the secretariat by the name of Donna.

PARA.TAB: My deep regret is that we had to conduct the inquiry at all. The sad fact is that, every year, more than one-third of—or well over 40,000—Australian marriages end in divorce. That is not a very happy situation to be confronting this country. Many marriages which began with tender love and rich expectation now lie in ruins. Marital breakdown is always a tragedy: it contradicts God's will and frustrates his purpose; it brings husband and wife the acute pains of alienation, disillusionment, recrimination and guilt; and it precipitates in any children of the marriage a crisis of bewilderment, insecurity and often anger.

I am making a few comments about the sociological reasons for the growth in the divorce rate because of the very grave problem confronting us and some of the matters touched on in the recommendations of the report. The sociological reasons for the growth in the divorce rate are many and varied. They include the emancipation of women—a term I use very advisedly—and changes in the pattern of employment with both parents working. There is the pressure on family life exerted by unemployment—an aspect which is being seen to a great degree at present—and by financial anxiety. Of course, a prime factor is the provision of easier divorce brought about by the current Family Law Act.

However, undoubtedly the greatest single reason is the decline in Christian faith in the West, together with the loss of commitment to a Christian understanding of the sanctity and permanence of marriage—I say that in terms of the petition in the prayer that the Speaker read this morning that asks for divine guidance—and the growing non-Christian assault on the traditional concept of sex, marriage and family.

For this reason, I am very happy that the Committee exercised a considerable amount of wisdom in its evaluation of the whole concept of marriage. In section 43, the Family Law Act says one of the main responsibilities of the Act and of the court is to promote the good health and the well-being of marriage. That is why we elected to exclude de facto relationships in terms of property disputes from the Family Law Act and instead recommended that there be a separate Act.

Very strong recommendations are made in the report for an increase in counselling and marriage education. Recommendation 25 is that the Commonwealth Government substantially increase funding for community education in relation to the rights and responsibility of marriage and parenthood, effective parenting, communications and dispute resolution skills, and anger management. These are all things that contribute unnecessarily to the huge number of marriages dissolved in this country every year. Research indicates very clearly that three-quarters of marriages that fail in Australia today do so because of benign neglect, not because of malicious intent, so the essence of recommendation 25 is very real.

Recommendation 26 says that particular attention should be given to the further development of schools based education programs which provide basic education in the areas set out in recommendation 24. The reason for that recommendation is that we know a lot of valuable instruction is given in the weeks and months prior to a marriage. However, the Committee felt—as many people feel—that at that time the couple believe the marriage is going to last forever; they are starry eyed and there is not a real understanding of the complex difficulties and situations that can develop in a marriage. The Committee is overwhelmingly supportive of the need for a lot more community education and for a lot more understanding of the difficulties and the problems that face people in a marriage. It believes not only that there should there be skills training in schools and a substantial increase in marriage education and marriage counselling but also that post-marriage enrichment courses should be available readily in our communities, not here and there spasmodically in different parts of the country but on an organised basis. That would give strong emphasis to the need to support the whole concept of marriage as a very rich union of two people. We hope that over the years such support will help bring a greater commitment to marriage.

It is my deep wish and concern that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) take on board the recommendations of the Committee which refer to the funding of marriage counselling and marriage education courses. I hope that he will take special note of that and will not wait until the next Budget, and that there will be a substantial contribution made to take into account the dreadful effects of the high divorce rate in this country today.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are those costs to the community?

—The honourable member for Kooyong asks about the costs to the community. We often hear that there are generous amounts being made available for marriage counselling by the Government—around $19m over a three-year period—yet every year, the cost to the community, to the taxpayers, in raw funds, runs to around $3,000m. That is $3 billion; it is just astonishing. One's mind boggles to think that here we are, spending huge amounts to increase the modern concept of better ambulances at the bottom of the cliff but we are doing nothing about building fences along the top to reduce the tremendous impact that broken marriages have.

PARA.TAB: One could go on and argue for another 10 minutes or so on other aspects outside the terms of reference of this inquiry such as the no fault clause. Whilst it could be argued that it has been of great benefit in many areas, it has contributed, I believe, in a major way to the very tragic situation confronting us today. This Committee looked into serious matters that relate to the most critical area of our community today—that is, the promotion of strong, stable marriages and strong, stable families. I commend, in particular, recommendations 25 and 26 to the Attorney-General and to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that I have a very short time to address this particular subject. I was the last member to join the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. It was not only a pleasure, but also a privilege to serve with such good and cooperative members, as well as the Deputy Chair, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and Senator Jim McKiernan, who was the Chair. The Committee, especially, was always more than cooperative in any questions that one wanted to ask about the previous handlings of the public meetings that had been held. As the new member, I can only thank the Secretary, the secretariat and the other members for the cooperation which they gave to me in my short time with that particular Committee.

PARA.TAB: One of the items that really stuck out was the issue of de facto relationships. I believe that we covered most of the points that were asked of us. The Committee, of course, did not produce all of the results that all of the witnesses wanted us to, but we certainly proceeded a long way along the pathway to satisfying the many demands that were placed upon the Committee in its deliberations. For that, I must say again that it was a privilege to be a part of the Committee. I hope to serve on it when it is introduced in the next Parliament, assuming that I will be here. I thank the House for the time to address the subject.
Motion (by Mr Peacock) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Russia and the Ukraine

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Russia and the Ukraine from 14 to 22 April 1992. This report is the result of, dare I say, a high profile visit by members of this Parliament to the independent nations of Russia and the Ukraine. In fact, it was the first Australian parliamentary delegation to visit those countries since they obtained their independence following the collapse of the Soviet Union.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I would like to do is to thank the other members of this Parliament who were part of the delegation. I wish to thank the deputy leader—the honourable member for Moncrieff( Mrs Sullivan)—the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), and my colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson). At all times they had a very constructive attitude and we all participated in the many meetings and discussions with great diligence and enthusiasm. Some parliamentary delegations every now and again experience hiccups due to the pressure of overseas travel but in this instance that did not happen. It was a great pleasure to have worked with my colleagues and with Bertha Williamson from the Speaker's Office and John Dyer, who both helped to ensure the visit was a success.

Because of the momentous changes that are taking place following the collapse of the Soviet Union, the visit was really a great opportunity for us to learn about the history which is being made in both Russia and the Ukraine at the moment. During our short visit it was not possible for us to gain a complete understanding of the momentous changes that are taking place, but we were able to have many informative discussions with people who were very high up in municipal, regional and national governments, as well as industry representatives, in those two countries.

I would like to mention in particular a number of meetings which the delegation had with people such as the chairman of the St Petersburg Council of People's Deputies, the Chamber of Commerce in St Petersburg, and the manager of the Kirov engineering plant. At the Committee's request our hosts agreed to reorganise the program so that members of the delegation could lay a wreath at the war cemetery in St Petersburg. That was a very moving experience for all of us.

In Moscow we had the opportunity to meet two deputy chairpersons of the Russian Supreme Soviet, including Deputy Chairman Yarov, who led the delegation from Russia to Australia a little over 12 months ago. It was a great opportunity for us to see the Congress of People's Deputies in session. Honourable members would be aware that it is due to meet again next week, when momentous events might again take place and determine perhaps a different direction for the Independent Federation of Russia. Given the momentous changes that are taking place in that country it was a great opportunity for us to see the Congress in action.

We had an opportunity to see free speech in operation in Russia, with some of the deputies being quite critical of the Government and the operation of the Congress. There is no doubt at all that there was quite a deal of free speech in that chamber while we were there.

During our visit to the Ukraine we had the honour of meeting President Kravchuk, the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Defence of that country, and the Chairman of the Kiev Council of People's Deputies. We also visited an agricultural complex that the honourable member for Lyons might like to expand on in his contribution.

While we were in the Ukraine we had the opportunity to discuss a very important issue: the whole question of nuclear disarmament. At the very time the delegation was in the Ukraine, events were unfolding which allowed us to obtain quite important information about the future of the Ukraine's tactical and strategic nuclear weapons. We were in those countries at a very important time and I think those of us who had the honour to be part of that delegation learnt a great deal.

I would like to thank in particular the Australian Ambassador to Russia and the Ukraine, Mr Cavan Hogue, his wife, and the staff at Australia's post in Moscow for their great help and assistance. In particular I wish to thank the first secretaries, Francesca Beddie and Clare Birgin, who helped educate the delegation on both Russia and the Ukraine. All the members of the delegation would like me to thank them for their assistance.

In addition, the delegation would like to thank the Presiding Officers of the Russian Federation Supreme Soviet, Mr Nikolai Ryabov and Mr Ramazan Abdulatipov. We express our appreciation to them for their generosity and kindness. Also, we are very indebted to one of the deputy chairmen of the Soviet of Nationalities, Mr Vitaly Syrovatko, who perhaps the honourable member for Lyons might mention later in his contribution.

We would like to thank also the Chairman of the Supreme Rada of the Ukraine, Mr Ivan Pliusch. The members of their staff who accompanied the delegation throughout our visit were helpful at all times and worked very hard to ensure that all of the meetings and discussions were successful.

In particular, I would like to thank our three translators, Mrs Irina Nikonorova and Mr Dimitry Pankov in Russia, and Svetlana Vysotsky in the Ukraine. Without good quality translators it would have been very hard for those of us from English speaking backgrounds who have not learnt Russian or the Ukraine.

Having made those comments, I will finish and allow other members of the delegation to make some comments. It was certainly an honour to have served with all of the members of the delegation, not to mention spouses, such as Ros Burr, who is in the gallery at the moment, who were also able to contribute to the success of the visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conscious of the fact that this debate will conclude at 10.30 and that two other delegation members present in the chamber want to speak, in addition to the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and me. I do not intend to reiterate all of the things that the honourable member for Dobell, the leader of the delegation, said. I fully support his comments and wish to make a couple of comments of my own.

PARA.TAB: It was actually my first trip to what is known as the Russian Federation, but I had visited the Soviet Union some 18 months earlier. It was quite fascinating to see the changes that had occurred in that time. The great thing that we had the opportunity to see was the enormous drama of democracy establishing itself in a country as diverse as Russia.

The honourable member for Dobell mentioned that we visited the Congress of Deputies, which was something in itself. If you want to get a lesson in how to be a Speaker of parliament, Mr Deputy Speaker, I advise you to go there and watch the person in the chair. There are 1,000 members, only four microphones, and the Speaker has to decide who gets the call, as the members queue up at the microphones. The debate that we witnessed was the one on the naming of this new country, as to whether it was to be the Russian Federation or Russia. In true committee style they went for both: Russian Federation-Russia. They will, of course, forever be referred to as Russia outside their country, just as the Soviet Union was always referred to as Russia.

I will touch very briefly on a couple of items that the honourable member for Dobell did not have time for. The Russians were very kind to us. In fact, if anything, they killed us with kindness, and did not altogether understand that members of parliament want some opportunities for down to earth experiences when they travel. We were extremely well looked after. We were kept in a dacha which was in the complex of dachas where Gorbachev had once stayed and which included a dacha for Stalin, although he never stayed there. I was very pleased to know that, because it was an eerie feeling to know that there was a dacha for Stalin in the same complex. We travelled in the limousines.

I was a little bit of a nuisance because I kept asking to visit Arbeat Street. That is a very famous tourism street, but it is more than that. I went there more than once on the previous occasion that I visited Moscow and found it extremely fascinating and engrossing. It is a stretch of road for pedestrians only, with the artists and artisans of Russia, a very large number of whom are very young, selling their wares. The experience of walking along Arbeat Street gives an insight into the present temperament of Russia, particularly that of the young people, and into Russia's potential.

I was one member of the delegation who did something quite different. At a time when the delegation was fulfilling a very important engagement, I was given the opportunity of meeting the only woman Minister in the Government, the Minister for family affairs. A meeting was arranged, although she was extremely busy in the Congress at the time, and a number of women deputies also joined in. I was accompanied on that visit by Ros Burr, the wife of the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), and by Maureen Walsh, the wife of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson). Both those ladies, who are very politically alert and intelligent, contributed a great deal to a discussion which consisted of very rapid-fire and very intense exchanges of information. Certain undertakings were made by me, on behalf of the delegation, to follow up the discussion in a number of areas.

Russia needs a great deal of help in establishing itself, a great deal of advice, and a great deal of guidance, because it has been such a closed society for so long. It has not been open to outside ideas, and it is trying very hard to catch up with, despite enormous problems.

Our visit to the Ukraine was highly significant. We were the first parliamentary delegation to visit the Parliament of the Ukraine. It was quite fascinating, particularly after Russia. We were treated extremely kindly and looked after very well. It was unfortunate that our visit was so brief. One feels that there is a great deal one could see in the Ukraine which would tell an Australian a lot about history and a lot about the pitfalls of the human condition.

I would like to thank John Dyer, the Secretary, who worked hard, as he always does; our Russian hosts; and the staff of the Australian Embassy in Moscow, who gave excellent support and looked after us very well. I hope that our visit gave them some opportunities to make contacts and learn things for which embassy officials often do not have the opportunity unless they are with a parliamentary delegation. I would also like to thank the interpreters, who were excellent.

Finally, I would like to thank the honourable member for Dobell. This was as happy a delegation as I have ever travelled on overseas. It was a very happy delegation, despite its being a very strenuous trip. We had had 10 days at an IPU comference in Cameroon, under fairly difficult conditions, prior to the delegation going to Russia and the Ukraine. It was a long visit, and in many ways a very stressful one physically, but it was an extremely happy one. I pay tribute entirely to the leader of the delegation for that. I welcome the opportunity to say these few words on the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the previous speakers in thanking John Dyer, Bertha Williamson and the Australian Embassy staff overseas. In the latter case it was very reassuring to see their relationship with authorities in both Russia and the Ukraine at a time when the issue of Australia's relationships with the Ukraine are causing some tension in this country amongst the Ukranian community. It was worth while seeing that they had certainly embedded themselves in those societies, were recognised as knowledgable, and were respected.

PARA.TAB: I was particularly thankful for the opportunity to go to the Ukraine. In the last census there were 4,000 people in Reid who defined themselves as coming from countries otherwise not defined, and 1,028 who described themselves as coming from the USSR. That description obviously includes a significant number of Ukrainians. The seat of Reid in Sydney encapsulates a lot of the institutions of the Ukranian community: St Andrews Church, the Ukranian Youth Organisation, the club, the women's hall, the Orthodox church in the electorate of Granville and another one on the boundary.

That trip to the Ukraine and Russia presented me with the opportunity of raising with Ukranian authorities and the Australian Embassy some concerns of the community in Sydney, most particularly postal delays and difficulties in getting access to visas and fulfilling immigration requirements because of the need to visit Moscow. In the interim, Australia has established closer ties with the Ukraine. On the Australian front, Zina Botte has been appointed as the consul.

When we visited Russia and the Ukraine it was a period of great tension, particularly—as the leader of the delegation mentioned—over the question of nuclear weapons and strategic weapons in general. In retrospect, probably things have not improved except on those fronts. We see a tremendous outbreak of racial and ethnic difficulties within the former Soviet Union. Some of the people the delegation met no longer hold the positions they did at those times. The Prime Minister of the the Ukraine and a number of the Ministers in the Yeltsin Government have been displaced.

That is typical of the problems that we saw when we were there: the great difficulty of moving from the previous fairly tight economic restrictions to the market economy; the feeling that inflation is becoming a major difficulty for the people; and the question of distribution. The Soviet Union directed certain industries to particular republics, and now those republics that do not have those particular industries are dependent on others or the outside world. They do not have anything in that field. That is typified by the Ukraine's dependence on the Soviet Union's attempt to establish ties with Iran and Iraq in regard to oil.

Matters that we did raise were of concern in the international press. In the Ukraine there have been reports of a growth of anti-semitism and a concern about the future of the Crimea, and it was worth while having a meeting with the Human Rights Commission, which allayed a lot of concerns. It certainly conveyed to us the experience of the Ukrainians themselves within the Ukraine under the Soviet Union's rule, where there was not access to schools, there were no newspapers and there was a lack of language facilities. I think we were reassured that, despite problems, the Ukrainian administration was endeavouring to allay fears of the Russian population in the Crimea. Similarly, there were very real steps forward in regards to human rights, such as the question of religious freedom in the Ukraine and the possibility of people who had objections avoiding military service.

Another matter that we discussed at length was Chernobyl, not only the question of the Soviet authorities covering up the dimensions of the problem but the very grave physical problems that people are suffering. We have recently had the advantage of both a Ukrainian parliamentary delegation and a business delegation coming to Australia, and it was interesting that the person who chaired the commission on Chernobyl stressed to Australian parliamentarians on his visit here their experience and their concerns with the whole question of nuclear development. We acknowledge that their operations are probably fairly backward by international standards, but it is a comment on the massive problems they are suffering as a result of this disaster that he did drive that point home.

The experience of Russia, as I have said, was typified by the growth of inflation and the distribution problems it has. On a personal level, we were given examples of this by our hosts, people who were public servants, interpreters, et cetera, actually looking askance at the fact that we could spend so much, in their terms, on artefacts. To us, these were piddling amounts, very minor amounts, but they just could not appreciate that so much money could be spent on this sort of thing. This typifies the problems they have at the moment. As the price of petrol and the prices of a number of other commodities that have been controlled until now increase, there is a situation where their wages just cannot keep up.

One thing that struck me, particularly in the case of the Ukraine but also in Russia, was the desperate need to get foreign investment, to the point where I think we must have some long term concerns at the penetration and possible domination of their economy by other European powers, most particularly Germany. We have seen in Czechoslovakia the absolute domination of its economy over the last few years by German investment. But there was this sense in the Ukraine that, having abandoned the previous restrictions, needing to strike out and to be genuinely independent, it was, in my mind, perhaps going overboard. The people there had a view that the need for capital was so desperate, it was so necessary to get things moving, that in the short term they were not concerned about who was running the show, and that in the long term poses some difficulties for them.

It was interesting to talk to Russian authorities about their interest in Australia's participation in projects in the Russian far east. I think it is fair to say that that was accompanied by great concern by them at Japanese possibilities there.

In conclusion, I thought that the delegation acquitted itself very well. Whether it be on the question of municipal politics in Kiev, discussions about armaments or ethnic problems, I think the delegation was very balanced. It certainly had the measure to cover all of those policy areas and represented the country well.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the one minute that is now available to me, I congratulate the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) for the way in which he led this delegation and thank the other members of the delegation for the hospitality and the friendship that they showed during the delegation. I assure the House that the way in which the honourable member for Dobell led the delegation presented both this Parliament and the Australian nation in an extremely favourable light to both our Russian and Ukrainian hosts and I think the House ought to be proud of the way in which the honourable member for Dobell led this particular delegation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The time for the debate has expired. The Chair will extend another couple of minutes to the honourable member for Lyons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am grateful for that consideration. From my observations, the economies of both Russia and the Ukraine have been desperately starved of resources over a long period of time. As a result of that starving of resources, particularly for investment capital for industry and infrastructure modernisation, both countries are now far behind the countries of the Western world. It is going to take a long time for both countries to be brought up to modern standards.

PARA.TAB: Russia, in particular, has enormous economic problems to overcome in order to reach a point at which it can compete with Western countries. We are conscious of President Yeltsin's program to establish Russia as a market economy. In my view, a whole new way of thinking by the entire Russian population will be required in order to accommodate a market economy. It will take at least a generation for that process to take place. It was encouraging that at least some of the younger Russian leaders, such as Mr Vladimir Schoumeynko, understood the nature of the problem and the timetable that will be required to bring about this process.

The Ukraine, on the other hand, could be on the verge of becoming a major European economy. It has vast agricultural and mineral resources and there is a fierce determination amongst the people to make the Ukraine a strong and independent country. In my view, the Ukraine will become a major European economy within a period of 10 to 15 years. When that occurs, much of the Ukraine exports, in particular agricultural exports, will directly threaten some of our Australian markets.

I am grateful for the extension of time. I would like to thank Mr John Dyer and Miss Bertha Williamson for their encouragement and support of the delegation and, particularly, I would like to thank our Russian and Ukrainian hosts for the way in which they provided friendship and hospitality to the delegation.
Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Dr Theophanous:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I have pleasure in addressing the Committee's interim report entitled Counting the vote on election night. The report addresses part of the Committee's current inquiry into the conduct of the 1990 elections, part 2, and the preparations for the next Federal election. The issues covered in the interim report are expected to come before the Parliament in the near future. Accordingly, the Committee decided to provide the Parliament with its views before the proposed changes came before the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: In reporting on the conduct of the 1990 Federal election, the Committee was critical of the time taken to finalise the House of Representatives result, which was not known until four days after the election. The Committee made several recommendations aimed at speeding up the House of Representatives result, including better access for scrutineers to monitor the preferences.

In responding to this recommendation, the Australian Electoral Commission has proposed a provisional two-candidate preferred distribution to be conducted by polling officials in each polling place on election night. Honourable members will recall that a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act of 1918 was introduced in the Senate on 15 October this year. Clause 22 of the Bill deals with the scrutiny of votes in the House of Representatives elections. An addition to section 274 of the principal Act is proposed to provide for:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a scrutiny of such preferences (other than first preferences), on such of the ballot-papers, as are required by the direction . . .

This allows for the provisional two-candidate preferred distribution if so directed by the Australian Electoral Officer for the State or Territory. No details are provided in the Bill regarding how this is to be done.

PARA.TAB: Details of the new election night procedure were provided in three submissions from the Australian Electoral Commission. Certain aspects of the procedures caused some concern, including proposals for transmitting the result, the process of identifying the candidates to receive provisional preferences, and access for scrutineers.

In relation to transmitting the House of Representatives results, the AEC's original preferred position was to hold the results of the primary count until the two-candidate preferred result was available. The two results were to be transmitted at the same time to the national tally room, thereby providing a final and more accurate result than could be achieved using the previous procedure.

While welcoming the promise of a more accurate result on polling night, the Committee could see no reason for creating a nexus between the primary vote result and the two-candidate preferred result. This topic was explored at length in two public hearings, during which the Committee took evidence from AEC officials regarding the arguments for creating the nexus. The Committee was not convinced that there was any good reason for holding back the results of the primary count. In fact, there is an expectation, reasonably held, by the public and candidates that results will be broadcast as soon as possible.

Accordingly, the Committee has set out in some detail its recommendations for counting the vote and transmitting the results. The procedures described involve transmitting the primary vote results on a booth by booth basis as soon as they are available, and sending the two-candidate preferred results in three batches, also identifying booths. We recommend that, while the two-candidate preferred distribution is being conducted, other polling officials will conduct a Senate count which should be transmitted to the national tally room on completion.

The procedures which we have outlined in this report accord with the AEC's submission No. 26, which is a letter from the AEC dated 12 November. I also add that the net result of these arrangements will ensure a very speedy dispatch of the primary vote, followed by the two-party preferred or two-candidate preferred vote being transmitted when the tally in each division reaches approximately 10 per cent, then 40 per cent, and the final or nearly final figures for the night.

The Committee believes that the recommended procedures, together with the advances made in computerised divisional offices, will provide a more accurate result on election night than has ever been possible. Not only will there be a more accurate decision by the end of counting on the night, but the advances should also facilitate the earliest possible transmission of a primary vote; so that, in 1993, Australian electors will have quicker advice of the primary vote than was the case in 1990 or, for that matter, in any previous election.

The Committee has visited the Australian Electoral Commission and inspected the computer screens that will be available in the national tally room on polling night. The program prepared by the AEC provides a great deal of information. Commentators on the night will have available a most powerful inquiry tool, if they take the time to study the program devised by the AEC. On another matter, because the Australian Electoral Commission is to conduct an actual, albeit provisional, distribution of preferences on a two-candidate preferred basis on polling night, it will be necessary for two candidates to be identified before this exercise can commence. This is a departure from previous elections.

The new arrangements raise the question of how the two preferred candidates are to be selected, and what the political consequences of such a selection process might be. The Committee was concerned about an apparent imprimatur being bestowed on these two candidates by the AEC. Such a situation is incompatible with the AEC's need to not only be impartial but to be seen to be impartial. In addition, an apparent nod from the AEC might be open to political abuse and could, in an extreme situation, affect the outcome. The Committee has addressed these problems by recommending that the selection be based on all relevant objective data, and that the identities of the two candidates for each division be kept confidential until the close of voting.

The interim report also deals with access for scrutineers in polling places. This is a topic which will interest all honourable members in this place. In the Committee's view, scrutineers should be recognised by polling officials as having an important part in the democratic process, and we have recommended that all officials be made aware of this.

The Committee wishes to thank the Australian Electoral Commission officers for their advice on the technicalities of the election night system, and for their willingness to consider the Committee's concerns in relation to the planned procedures. I am pleased that a number of those officers are present with us today in the gallery. We believe that the recommendations in the report will provide a more accurate result than in previous years, on election night, and will satisfy the needs of the public and candidates in the most timely and efficient way.

The Committee, as part of its ongoing review of the 1990 election report, will consider a range of issues which no doubt will touch on some of the matters raised by the High Court decision yesterday. Whilst that is not the subject of the interim report before the Parliament today, in the minute or two available to me, I will make a couple of brief comments. It is no doubt a question which the Committee will want to consider in some good detail and with some good advice.

Of course, there are two aspects of the High Court decision. One deals directly with the question of office of profit under the Crown, and the other deals with the question of dual citizenship. I must say that, having had an initial reading of the judgment, the decisions concerning office of profit under the Crown come as no great surprise. Many people involved in perusing this area of the law, or involved directly in its application, would not have been too startled by the findings of the High Court in that matter.

However, it is fair to say that the decisions of the majority in respect of the dual citizenship question have raised a number of questions and concerns. On reading the judgments, I must say that I was attracted to the views of Justices Deane and Gaudran and to their comments with respect to what constitutes a reasonable act of relinquishing a citizenship in circumstances where that is not able to be done. It is an important issue which is obviously very current. It will be given very careful consideration by the Joint Committee.

In conclusion, I sincerely thank the members of the Committee for their cooperation in speedily putting together this interim report. The assistance of the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), and other members of the Committee in providing such a speedy report is appreciated. Finally, I give a special thanks to the Secretary of the Committee, Judy Middlebrook, without whose assistance it would not have been possible to compile this report. It certainly would not have been possible to have it presented in the Parliament in such a timely manner for the House to consider its contents in relation to the Bill currently before the Senate. I commend the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments in regard to Counting the vote on election night. Of course, it is a day on which the focus has been put on the electoral processes in Australia. One of the first comments I would like to make is that because of its electoral processes Australia is held in very high regard around the world as a democratic, free and open country. It is very important for us, as a parliament, to realise the significance of the processes which we already have in place in this country to provide for the election of people to the Parliament, without too much rancour or debate. Of course, yesterday's decision by the High Court does put the focus on the importance of that process so that we can have good government, so that we can be confident that the people running this country have been elected by a very open process, and so that people are aware of the procedures necessary.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, I look forward to having a look at—as the Chairman has indicated—some of the implications, and at how those issues raised by the decision yesterday can be resolved in the future. It is important that there be certainty that any person in Australia with the right credentials can stand for election to this Parliament, knowing that there will be no backtracking in the future, as has occurred with the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary). If we can do that well—and I do believe it will be possible for us as a country to find a way through that, as we have with other problems in regard to electoral matters in the past—it will only enhance our standing as a free, democratic country which has officers that run the elections with objectivity and with a professionalism which is unparalleled anywhere else in the world.

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has a goal to ensure, to the best of its ability, that there is an outcome on the night of the election; that the job is done efficiently and effectively; that the Australian public is able to obtain voting results on the night; and that it is able to get that information as quickly as possible. It is important for members of this Parliament and interested people in the community to look at the proposals which we are recommending in this report, to carefully scrutinise them and to understand the implications of the comments which are made.

In putting together the report, Counting the vote on election night, I certainly appreciated the help from the Australian Electoral Commission officers. There are a few difficult issues to be resolved, partly because members of parliament are not necessarily technical experts in some of these fields.
