In a committee where members of the Parliament are seeking the advice of senior people in the administration of a particular department, it is important that there be a trusting and good relationship so that the information can come out.

I certainly appreciated the willingness of the Electoral Commission to work with us over some of those difficulties. There is no doubt that the outcome is a good one. It is a mark of the way in which committees should operate and senior people within the bureaucracy should respond and be positive about the questioning. I appreciate that and I think it bodes well for any future discussions we might have about yesterday's decisions.

This report will give us a more accurate picture on the night. That, of course, comes from two things which are operating: one is the extra technology which we can now apply to the electoral process and the speed at which things can happen; the other is the change in the way the Electoral Commission plans to operate on the night. That will benefit those members of the Australian public interested in the polling results. They will get a quicker and more accurate picture by the end of the night than they would have got at previous elections. Also, those people standing as candidates and wishing to be members of this Parliament will get a much clearer indication as to whether they will be elected.

I recommend that people look through this report. I raise one area where there is still some concern—that is, the two-party preferred candidates selected and so on. There is a need to be conscious that in some electorates there are three major parties—in some instances there are four major candidates. It will be difficult on the night to determine where the two-party preferred votes will go. I recognise that and I think many members of the Committee do.

Even though this report has put forward proposals which will be beneficial in the counting of votes and which will give everybody a much clearer view on the night, we have to recognise that, in any close election, even these procedures will not necessarily tell us on the night of the election who the government will be; there are postal votes and other votes which come in after polling day. If it is a very close election, we will not necessarily get a result on the night. We all desire a result on the night, but that is not always possible. We ought to be clear that that is not the fault of the administration of the Australian Electoral Commission. We need to appreciate that. I do not want to take all the time remaining. I understand that the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) would like to speak for a couple of minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to commend to the House the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I am a member of the Committee, but I know the Chairman of the Committee and other speakers will adequately cover matters in the interim report so I want to concentrate on the judgment of the High Court yesterday in the case of Sykes v. Cleary and others. I want to defend the High Court. Despite some criticisms from parliamentarians, the High Court got it right; anyone who reads the judgment of the Court will see that it got it right on both counts.

PARA.TAB: Regarding the definition of the term `office of profit', as far back as December 1990 the Committee produced a report after hearing evidence of opinions, dating back to 1909, that the Attorney-General had received relating to the matter of `office of profit'. Members of parliament were warned then of the minefield that lay in the definition of the term. Sad as it is, all the opinions really go to the conclusion the High Court reached that Mr Cleary did hold an office of profit under the Crown.

The argument really is whether the relevant period is the time of nomination or the time of declaration of the poll, and the High Court has decided, six to one, that the relevant period is the time of nomination. I agree with that and I believe the High Court judgment speaks for itself. It means that senators cannot remain in the Senate and run for the House of Representatives and then resign from the Senate prior to the declaration of the poll. It means that members of the House of Representatives cannot run for the Senate unless they resign prior to nominating.

I give a warning to public servants that their resignation needs to be accepted by the Governor-General in Council, or the Governor in Council as far as States are concerned, because their resignation is not effective until it has been accepted by the Governor in Council or the Governor-General in Council. I warn them that they need to dispose of their office of profit prior to nominating; that is indisputable.

I turn to the matter of citizenship, which appears to have raised the ire of a number of members of parliament. Again I defend the High Court. I can see the reasoning behind the majority judgment of Justices Mason, Toohey and McHugh, supported by Justices Brennan and Dawson, whereas Justices Deane and Gaudron come down in favour of Mr Delacretaz and Mr Kardamitsis and say that they took reasonable steps.

We need to bear in mind that we appoint judges to the High Court to interpret the Constitution. I am not on my feet to defend the Constitution: if people have got any criticism of the Constitution that is fine; I have got some. But it is unreal to criticise the High Court, the members of which have been appointed to interpret the Constitution, when there is no doubt that the majority judgment is interpreting what is in the Constitution. The majority decision has some difficulty on the question of citizenship. At page 17 the justices say:

However, the critical words in s.44(i) do not permit this Court to adopt the approach which has been taken by international law. Here the question is different: is the candidate a subject or citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or citizen of a foreign power? And, as already stated, at common law, as in international law, that question is to be determined according to the law of the foreign State concerned.

But, there is no reason why s.44(i) should be read as if it were intended to give unqualified effect to that rule of international law. To do so might well result in the disqualification of Australian citizens on whom there was imposed involuntarily by operation of foreign law a continuing foreign nationality, notwithstanding that they had taken reasonable steps to renounce that foreign nationality. It would be wrong to interpret the constitutional provision in such a way as to disbar an Australian citizen who had taken all reasonable steps to divest himself or herself of any conflicting allegiance.

SPEECH.PARA: What the High Court has basically said is that unfortunately in this case Mr Delacretaz and Mr Kardamitsis did not do enough. True it was that they took oaths of allegiance to Australia; and, indeed, at the time they took those oaths of allegiance during citizenship ceremonies they renounced their previous allegiance to Switzerland and to Greece. The unfortunate position is that the majority judgment of the High Court points out that in both Switzerland and in Greece there are procedures under which citizens of those countries can take steps to relinquish that citizenship. What they are saying is that people need to go that next step.

PARA.TAB: I think it is wrong to criticise the High Court in terms of this judgment in the way that some of my colleagues have. Some might not agree with it, but it is a pretty overwhelming judgment. What I say to members of parliament—and, indeed, to the members of public—is that I think the High Court decision is right. If people have got any gripes, it is with the Constitution. I want to state on the record that I regard this High Court as probably the best constituted High Court since Federation, but it is bound by the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with the couple of minutes that are left I want to make a couple of comments on the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Counting the vote on election night, because it has caused me some concern. I note that it is an interim report, and I have had a conversation with the Deputy Chairman of the Committee about it. My fear is that in some electorates in Australia the recommendation of choosing two candidates will cause more problems than it solves. I hope that the Electoral Commission might take some advice on how it proceeds on this. Reading between the lines, while the Electoral Commission clearly was helpful to the Committee, it was a bit rigid on a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: I instance my own seat of Moncrieff. There are certain parts of Australia that are genuine three-party electorates. When I stood for Moncrieff in 1984 it was believed that the National Party of Australia would win Moncrieff. My own private assessment of it—one that I did not discuss at the time—was that it would come down to Democrat preferences. In the event, on election day we discovered that the Democrats had given their preferences to the National Party—a subject about which I shall say more on another occasion, when I have the chance. That would have seemed to have confirmed that the seat would be won by the National Party. The early returns supported that. There were booths in my electorate that had as few as 100 voters and there were other booths that had more than 5,000.

Obviously, the first 20 or so results that came in were from the small country booths, and they favoured the National Party. It was when the results from the 5,000 plus booths came in that the Liberal Party won Moncrieff, and won it clearly. Those results did not come in until between 8.30 and 9 o'clock at night. I think it would have taken a fairly brave Electoral Commissioner to have said, `This seat will be won by either the Liberal Party or the National Party', given the state of the opinion polls at the time. They did not indicate that the Labor Party was in decline. There was, in fact, a 2 per cent swing against the Labor Party in Moncrieff when the results were counted.

I have risen briefly to say that I understand why this is an interim report, and I hope that a further report will come out and that some proper attention will be paid to those three-party electorates. They are not few in number. There are several in Queensland and several in New South Wales in the coming election. We could have a quite disastrous miscasting of results in cases where the preferences of parties such as the Democrats do not do what on paper they appear they would do, and it may be a close election. I say that as one of the members of this Parliament in that position.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Government take action to ensure that all Australians have access to the Industrial Relations Commission to protect their award wages and conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and I were driven to putting this motion before the House today by the scenes of mass protests by the working men and women of Victoria against the most oppressive anti-worker legislation that has been introduced anywhere in this country for many years. The Kennett Government, in abolishing award conditions, such as leave loading, and in destroying the award system has demonstrated a contempt for Victorian workers and their families.

PARA.TAB: As a Queenslander, it is disturbing to hear the Premier of Victoria embrace Joh Bjelke-Petersen as his role model in industrial relations. Like Jeff Kennett, Joh Bjelke-Petersen proposed the abolition of leave loading in 1987. Thankfully, he was removed from office before he could deliver on this threat. Another source of a feeling of deja vu is the fact that the penalties on individual workers of $1,000 and trade unions of $50,000 are identical to those introduced by Bjelke-Petersen in his continuity of supply legislation in 1985. Like Bjelke-Petersen, Jeff Kennett is seeking to brand the working men and women of the State as criminals. He is allowing to develop a situation where these workers face the prospect of a criminal conviction, if they dare to take industrial action against their employer.

Jeff Kennett's legislation and the industrial relations policies being advanced by those opposite go far beyond anything that even Bjelke-Petersen would have dreamed of. On the day of that strike in Victoria, this House debated the issue, and once again those opposite sought to blame all of Australia's problems on the ordinary workers and the trade union movement. If there is one group in Victoria that is above blame for the problems faced in Victoria, it is the average workers in that State. But how did the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) describe the 100,000 Victorian citizens who took to the streets in outrage at what the Kennett Government had done? They branded people as militants, simply acting on the demands of some trade union leaders. Those opposite are not really interested in genuine work place reform; all they want to do is attempt to blame all of Australia's problems on Australian workers and the trade union movement.

Australian workers and their representatives in the trade union movement have shown admirable restraint over the past decade, as we all well know. This Government's industrial relations policies are based on a principle that, when workers make a contribution to increase productivity and efficiency, they should be rewarded for their contribution. Clearly, with such a bloody-minded government in power in Victoria, the Victorian industrial relations system no longer provides workers in that State with adequate protection.

Workers and their unions in Victoria need every assistance to transfer, where possible, to a Federal award, to ensure that their rights and conditions are protected. I welcome the news that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is in the process of preparing some legislative framework for this to occur. The Federal industrial relations system allows flexibility in working arrangements for both workers and employers, without reducing hard fought for wages and conditions of those workers. Of course, Federal award coverage would offer little protection to Australian workers in the unfortunate event of the coalition gaining office in this country, which becomes less and less likely every day.

The policies of those opposite represent a throwback to the master-servant relationship of the early nineteenth century. Workers in traditionally strong trade union areas, such as Ipswich and my electorate of Oxley, will be hit hardest by the industrial relations policies of those members opposite—policies which would result in lower wages and the taking away of hard won conditions. The policy launched by the honourable member for Bennelong amounts to a full frontal attack on the Australian trade union movement and its members. It strikes at the very heart of everything that the Labor movement has fought for over the past 100 years.

A Liberal-National Party government, under the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), would be the most extreme right wing government in Australia's history, surpassing even the worst excesses of the Bjelke-Petersen regime in Queensland. A century after the shearers strike of 1891, workers have the right to expect certain basic conditions of employment such as penalty rates, sick leave and overtime for the hours they work. One hundred years after their political ancestors sent troops out with gatling guns against the working men and women in western Queensland, the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong are seeking to take these hard won conditions away from those workers.

Fightback and Jobsback do nothing to create employment. These policies would only mean lower wages, higher prices and higher taxes for the average Australian worker. It is good to see that two honourable members opposite who are going to speak on this motion are from Victoria. The workers of Victoria will show them what they think of them in the next election, too.

The policy positively encourages employers to force their workers out of awards and to make workers accept employment contracts and substantially cut wages and conditions of employment. The Industrial Relations Commission would face an uncertain future under the coalition. The Leader of the Opposition favours abolishing it while the honourable member for Bennelong is cynically prepared to accept its retention in the short term so that he is able to push through cuts in wages and conditions. What does seem certain, however, is that the demise of the IRC would only be a matter of time under the Leader of the Opposition. The Industrial Relations Commission provides to workers in weak bargaining positions protection from exploitation, and exploitation is what happens if you do not have a decent industrial relations commission to protect the average Australian worker. Average Australian workers know that and at the next election they will be making it known particularly to the two honourable members opposite I mentioned, who have small margins in their electorates.

While the coalition will probably not abolish the Commission immediately, it would certainly attempt to limit the role of the Industrial Relations Commission, undermine the award system, abolish national wage cases and reduce unions' ability to represent their members, which is a democratic right. The replacement of the IRC with individual employment contracts would result in a return to the atmosphere of confrontation that characterised industrial relations in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The only way that many disputes could be settled would be through taking action in the courts.

To their credit, though, several major employer groups have already recognised the industrial relations nightmare that would result from this policy. The Metal Trades Industry Association has made it quite clear that it is opposed to the Opposition's plan to encourage companies and employees to move outside the framework provided by the IRC, as it recognises that such a policy would result in an explosion of legal costs. Bob Herbert, the Victorian Director of the MTIA, was reported on page 5 of the Herald-Sun on 24 June 1992 as saying this about the Opposition's industrial relations policy:

SPEECH.PARA: The worst thing they could do now is remove the tribunal. This would throw employers and employees to the legal wolves. The inevitable outcome of moving away from a system of making and endorsing awards and agreements by industrial tribunals to one where `common law' agreements apply is to provide a field day for litigation, with the costs being borne by the employer.

Those opposite say that their policy encourages workers and employers to negotiate directly with each other, so that they can bypass trade unions and the Industrial Relations Commission. But under the policy proposed by those opposite the odds in such negotiations would be firmly stacked in the employers' favour. There would be absolutely nothing to stop an employer offering a worker a simple choice—either accept reduced pay and conditions or take the sack. Under common law, which would operate in the absence of an industrial relations commission, a worker dismissed for refusing to accept a reduction in working conditions would have no redress as this would not constitute an unfair dismissal. We need only look at what has happened in New Zealand to see what happens to workers when a central industrial relations commission is taken out of the picture.

PARA.TAB: Mr Broadbent interjecting—
Mr Charles interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The New Zealand industrial relations system is a system that honourable members opposite have embraced fully as a model for Australia. The honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Corinella interject, because they know that they will not be here after the next election; we all know that.

PARA.TAB: Under the Employment Contracts Act, the Bolger National Party Government abolished all industrial awards and established a new system of individual employees bargaining employment contracts with their employers. While employees are free to nominate to bargain on their behalf agents whom employers have to recognise, under the legislation employers are under no compulsion to negotiate with them. What sort of set-up would that be? If he feels so disposed, an employer can insist on negotiating with each individual employee. Such a system clearly gives the employer all the advantages.

It should come as no surprise to anyone that an analysis of the first 260 contracts lodged with the New Zealand Department of Labour under the new system found that just over half of the employees have had their ordinary time real wages frozen or suffered pay reductions of up to 30 per cent because of the abolition of penalty rates.

The conservative parties have long styled themselves as the guardians of the Australian family, but what a lot of rubbish that is. When they attack the working conditions of Australian workers, they attack families—it is families which are hardest hit. The children of those workers are probably affected the most. Honourable members opposite know that, but I fully understand why they will not admit it.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy reveals this to be one of the most cold-hearted and cynical claims ever to be made by an Australian political party. I doubt that the Opposition thought for a moment about the effects that its industrial relations policy would have on average Australian families, because it simply does not care about the average Australian family. All it is worried about is looking after the rich and the well-off.
Mr Broadbent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corinella keeps interjecting here because he knows damn well that he is on his last legs as the honourable member for Corinella. He will be a oncer, like the honourable member for La Trobe. The simple fact is that people reject honourable members opposite because of their terrible industrial relations package. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—We will certainly not be agreeing to the ridiculous motion we are debating. The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) gave us a very hurried rendition of something he had written out in anticipation of a debate. I doubt that he really has any will or any intestinal fortitude to debate the issue. He rambled on at some length about the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) and me being oncers and about our not being back here again. I can assure honourable members that, in the interests of all Victorians, we will return.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Oxley waxed eloquent about such issues as protection and exploitation and all of the great phraseology and terms that came out of the 1880s and the 1890s. The honourable member for Oxley refuses to believe or agree that we are, in fact, at the dying end of the twentieth century, not the nineteenth. It is time that he and his side of politics woke up to the fact that there is a new way in the world and that Australia is really very isolated.

The honourable member for Oxley ought to recognise that his contributions today did not take account of some one million Australians out of 17 million citizens all together, including our children, I might add, who have no jobs. All of his talk about protection and exploitation is meaningless to those people without jobs, because they have not the employment they need to succour their families and to make a decent life for themselves in their country.

Let us talk a bit about deregulation. Deregulation is really what our side of politics has been talking about now for a number of years with respect to the industrial relations debate. It is an important issue, because Australia has had an unnatural concentration on industrial relations. It reminds me of an editorial in the Australian Financial Review some months ago, which said that Australia has an unnatural obsession with industrial relations in terms of the international debate, and that our debate has been unusually vociferous and unhelpfully preoccupied with the centralised institutional structures of industrial relations, rather than with performance in the workplace.

Today we are talking about performance in the workplace. The Government side of politics would have us believe that we need this myriad of rules and regulations; we need formalised structures which are written down in the Bible in order that people can have jobs and can have incomes and working conditions. The rest of the world is not like that. I defy honourable members opposite to read any of the newspapers or journals of all the other OECD nations or of our trading partners and find comparable rhetoric with respect to this matter of industrial relations. The rest of the world does not have the obsession that we seem to have in this country with how people will be paid and how they will relate to their work.

Honourable members opposite are, in their ACTU driven debate, together with the club which has been in existence for so many years—consisting of powerful employer groups, powerful unions and a quasi-judicial body, the AIRC, sitting in the middle—setting wages and conditions of employment for millions of working men and women in Australia without any recourse to, and without any consideration whatsoever of, the imperatives of the workplace itself.

When we look at the New Zealand experience, despite what the honourable member for Oxley had to say, we see one that has been very positive. There were, before New Zealand, only two nations in the world which utilised our model of a completely centralised system with a quasi judicial body sitting the middle as a so-called arbiter of industrial relations issues. The rest of the world has found other mechanisms. The rest of the world has allowed working people and employers to work together to find outcomes that suit them, that allow them to be efficient in their work place, and that produce positive productivity outcomes.

The New Zealanders woke up a few years ago and changed their system. They went further than we propose to go and they abolished their central umpire and, believe it not, the world did not come to an end. The Council of Trade Unions in New Zealand established, on the day that the Employment Contracts Act came into being, what it called a `sweat line'. It was a telephone number that everybody around the nation could ring to tell the people at the Council of Trade Unions these horrible stories of exploitation. They were to report how employers were ripping off their employees, how they were reducing their wages, how people were going to have to work for slave wages, how they were losing their penalty rates and how this centralised structure was being destroyed.

What happened as a result? The Council had to shut down the sweat line because, unfortunately for the Council, it did not get any telephone calls. Why? It was because today modern management knows that in order to be productive, in order to be able to export, in order to be able to supply the demands of people in the community for products and services it has to find a cooperative way to go about it. It needs to find a mechanism for sharing the benefits from the enterprise.

What the enterprise produces is products and services that people want, and at the end of the day there is some money left over. If there is not any money left over then the business will close. If there is money left over at the end of the day, that money is shared between those who take the risk and those who work in the enterprise.

In that respect, management and employees are as one. They all share the cake that the enterprise produces. It is that mechanism of allowing employees and employers, at their place of work, to decide the best mechanism for them to achieve positive outcomes that we in this nation must move to if we are to have any chance of success in the future.

The Government's formula has failed. Those one million unemployed out there hanging around the necks of the honourable member for Oxley like dead albatrosses attribute that failure to the Australian Labor Party not providing them with any jobs. Make no mistake about it, the citizens in this nation know that the ALP is a tired old failed government. It has no more answers and it certainly has no answer in the prescriptions of the honourable member for Oxley.

The honourable member for Oxley says, `Let us continue with what we have done for 100 years', but that is not working in the context of today's society. Then he talks at great length about Victoria. I guess he did not read today's newspapers which say that the citizens of Victoria are just as happy with Mr Kennett and company at present as they were on 3 October when they elected the Liberal and National Party coalition to government in the State of Victoria.

There may be a bit of industrial disruption led by a few old dinosaurs like our friends John Halfpenny and Bill Deller, the ex-communist and current Trotskyite. They are great leaders for the people of our nation. We really do not believe in communism, do we? We believe in democracy. Even honourable members opposite would agree that the philosophy of communism is well and truly dead and yet they want to retain the worst of the system which utilises centralised prescriptive formulae for working men and women rather than allowing them choice.

That is what it is all about: it is about freedom of choice. But no, honourable members opposite want to say to every clerk in every shop, every factory and every business around this nation, `You all do exactly the same work. You are in the same economic circumstances. Therefore, you must be paid the same and you must have exactly the same working conditions and the same restrictive work practices'.

That brings to mind the enterprise that first brought me to Australia, the Nabalco project at Gove. That project started in 1971, and since then 144 restrictive work practices have been developed in that one process industry. That is 144 in 20 years. It is a nonsense, is it not? We have to get beyond that. We must work together at an enterprise level to bring some productivity to this nation. We must give incentives to people to establish new industries, new businesses and productive enterprises which will allow us to export, and to replace more of those goods which are imported today. We must give some hope to those 1.8 million Australians who are underemployed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to second this motion today. As we have said in this House many times before—and we will repeat it across Australia right until the election day—the next election will be the most important election we have had since the Second World War. It will highlight the massive philosophical differences and rifts that exist between honourable members opposite and those in the Australian Labor Party. There is no doubt that the words of Ben Chifley will continue to echo across the decades: Labor stands for the people and Labor stands opposed to those who would take advantage of the people.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition intends to throw the employed off unemployment benefits after nine months. It intends to abolish centralised wage fixing and to force people to negotiate as individuals, with the knowledge that after nine months as unemployed people they will get no benefits. With the Opposition's $3 an hour minimum wage for young people, turning its back on the training guarantee levy, and wiping out the superannuation levy, what we are going to see is people begging for jobs.

As I have said before, this fight started over 100 years ago in this country. The reason why we embrace passionately the belief in central wage fixing is that our forefathers came to this country to make sure that their kids would get a better go than they did in the coalmines and factories of England. That is what this is all about. That is why we passionately believe in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh dear, oh dear.

—I am happy to shed some tears. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) comes from America. He should remember the Triangle fire in America; he should remember the Dred Scott case. One could spend hours talking about the philosophies that drive those on the other side of this House. We remember well in Queensland that it was not until 1906 that the slavery system in the sugar industry was abolished. I hate to think what would happen in my area with the fruit and vegetable industry if unemployment benefits were abolished after nine months and people were working for $3 an hour. We need only look at the results of the case of the Gazal company on the Gold Coast, where a parasite is trying to take money out of the pockets of workers, claiming that he can only survive on the sweatshop conditions in Asia.

PARA.TAB: We only need to look at APPM in Tasmania or the pastoral industry across Australia and, indeed, in Queensland, where people are breaking the law and being praised by the United Graziers Association for doing so, to see that the New Right is alive and well. What it is about is taking money out of the pockets of Australian working men and women.

There are eight million people working in this country today, almost two million more than when the Australian Labor Party came into power. We have seen a reduction in unit labour costs of some 10 per cent. We are now leading the world in growth. We have the lowest inflation rate of the OECD countries. We have achieved the lowest level of interest rates for 20 years through cooperation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and through bringing people together.

If the Opposition ever gets into government and institutes its policies it will divide this community as much as the people were divided in the 1920s and 1930s. If it is a case of those that have and those that have not, then the price we will pay as a country is one that will take many years to rectify. What demonstrates even better the viciousness of the Opposition's philosophy is that not only does it embrace the Reaganites and the Thatcherites, not only does it want to throw the unemployed off benefits after nine months, not only does it want to destroy award conditions, but it then wants to put a tax on food and clothes, it wants to tax the kids when they go to the tuckshop, it wants to tax their breakfast, it wants to tax funerals—all at 15 per cent.

In regard to the nonsense about low income workers being better off, the Opposition intends to reduce the bottom rate of tax from 21 to 16 per cent, but then it wants to put a 15 per cent tax on all their consumption, which basically means they will pay 10 per cent more in tax, not less. Every time any retiree takes his money out of the bank he will pay 15 per cent on every dollar that he uses. Even a widow who has to pay someone to mow her lawn will have to pay the tax.

That is the philosophy embraced by the Opposition. It is unfortunate we have only a few minutes to debate this in the House today, but we will be debating it right across the length and breadth of this country. The mining industry, the miners, the waterside workers, the pastoral workers and everyone else across this country will reject that philosophy, because they know what its about. Already we have seen Hammonds gaoled on two occasions in south-west Queensland for breaking the law, and those opposite and the UGA have praised him for breaking the law of the land. Worse still, in closing I would like to quote from the shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who was quoted in the Age on 19 October as saying that pensioners should not have to queue up with the riffraff when they go to social security offices. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) that his own Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now for two days refused to debate the state of Australia's parlous economy with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). One could say he had wimped out; but perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, you could tell the member for Moore (Mr Filing) that I do not need any help with those sorts of remarks. I would love to see the Prime Minister come into this place and face the Leader of the Opposition and make a statement.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) brought New Zealand workers into the debate. The facts are that New Zealand workers' wages have risen one-half of one per cent. What has happened in Australia under Labor in the last 12 months? We have gone down one per cent. Do not tell me about what is happening to workers in New Zealand. Their benefits are being increased.

Let me say something for the benefit of the young people who are listening to this debate and have heard the tripe that those opposite have put forward. I do not want to be faced in the streets of Melbourne or across Australia with signs that say, `No ticket, no start. Unless you join this group of people you will not be allowed to work on this site'. I want to change that. I want people to have reasonable access to opportunities for work. I do not want to see the bankruptcies by the thousand that have been created by this Government—by `the recession we had to have', as the Prime Minister said when he was Treasurer.

Under this Government the most used things in this nation in the last three years have been tissues. They have mopped up the tears of the 680,000 children who live in households where there is no breadwinner—where the family is on unemployment benefits because of the Government's recession. They have mopped up the tears of the one million people who have had to go home to their families and say, `Today I have lost my job due to the recession we had to have', or the one million people who are underemployed. The honourable member for Hinkler said, `We have got eight million people employed', but they have got two million either underemployed or unemployed.

We want opportunities for enterprise bargaining. This motion states that Australians have access to the Industrial Relations Commission. That is exactly what our shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has said. The opportunity is there to have access to the Industrial Relations Commission. The opportunity is there for employees to deal with their employer if they so choose. The opportunity the Labor Party is putting forward for enterprise bargaining is there under our policy. There are none so blind as those that cannot see, like the member for Oxley and the honourable member for Hinkler.

Having looked at the results of the Newspoll this morning on Jeffrey Gibb Kennett that said `Kennett's approval rating rises', they should know that all those people marching up and down the streets meant there were 3.5 million workers that stayed at their workplace and said, `I want to keep my job, and I am prepared to suffer for the recession that we had to have'—the way that all those in private enterprise have had to suffer, as was said by the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). He will retain his seat at the next election, I might add. If he does not, I will not. The results of the polls that we have read in the paper today point out that the Victorian community is very pleased with what is happening in Victoria.

The other night on Lateline we saw the Prime Minister—and the honourable member for Hinkler must have been disgusted—and he had no answers. In Michelle Grattan's words, not mine, he had no answers; he had run out of excuses. In my words, he has backed into more corners than Lionel Rose, but there is one difference: Lionel Rose came out of his corners. But the Prime Minister sat there with a quivering lip to the point where Kerry O'Brien laughed at him. Surely those opposite read the paper the other day which said that, because of the recession we had to have, throughout the 1980s under their administration the difference between the haves and the have nots grew. They should be ashamed of themselves.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! The time for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate wil be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)condemns those responsible for the killing and maiming of innocent women and children in Bosnia and Herzegovina;
(2)supports any action the UN proposes to take to bring about a cessation of hostilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina;

(3)supports UN Security Council Resolution 781 banning all military flights in the airspace of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the UN's decision to station monitors at airfields in the territory of the former Yugoslavia;

(4)urges the Government to request the UN to consider whether it is humane to continue to restrict the legitimate Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina from purchasing weapons to defend its sovereign territory;
(5)abhors the practice of "ethnic cleansing" which is occurring in Bosnia and condemns those responsible; and

(6)requests the Government to give urgent consideration to increasing its aid to the area in order to assist neighbouring countries with the temporary resettlement of refugees and displaced persons as a result of the war.

It is appropriate that once again today this Parliament should be debating and discussing what is happening in the former Yugoslavia. It is also appropriate today that we should note—coincidentally, bearing in mind that this motion has been on the Notice Paper for some time—that we have Dr Vesna Bosanac visiting Canberra. She is a noted ex-prisoner of war and survivor of the siege of Vukovar. Dr Bosanac is here to promote the cause of peace in her homeland of Croatia and to inform Australians of her experience during and after the siege of Vukovar. Dr Bosanac has already had the opportunity to meet this morning with the members of the Australia-Croatia Parliamentary Group. My colleagues the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who is the chairman of that group, were with her earlier this morning.

PARA.TAB: Dr Bosanac has, of course, an amazing story to tell in that she occupied a pivotal role as Director of the Vukovar Medical Centre from July 1991 until its capture by the so-called Yugoslav army and Serbian paramilitary forces on 19 November 1991. Dr Bosanac had the task of keeping the hospital functioning during the 86 days in which the town of Vukovar was levelled by bombings. She is also here to appeal—and my motion, in part, makes a similar appeal—to Australia and to the world community to increase its aid effort to that particular part of the world. We welcome her and we trust that her appeal will be successful. She is a paediatrician, and her particular interest is in children. It is the children of this part of the world who are being hurt so much by the fighting that is going on.

At present the number of refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Republic of Croatia is around 230,000. Two-thirds of them are children. The need there is great. Already the resources of the Croatian Government are stretched to the extreme to handle these particular refugees. The need at this time of the year is even greater because winter is upon them. There is a need for food, particularly for infant formulas and powdered milk. There is a need for medicine and hygiene supplies—particularly bearing in mind the medical necessities for children.

The break-up of the former Yugoslavia, which we have discussed in this place on a number of occasions, has been a great tragedy. It has brought terrible devastation and suffering to hundreds of thousands of people. There are those who have become refugees or displaced persons and those who have had their families shattered by the death of a loved one or, worse in many respects, the death of a child. Ironically, I suppose, many of these people that the honourable member for Moore and I saw over in that part of the world just a couple of months ago must now question whether the iron fist of communism was better than what they have now.

I believe that the motion that I have had the privilege of moving here this morning deserves the total support of this Parliament, and I am sure that it would have the total support of this Parliament. Although Australia is far removed geographically from the part of the world we are talking about, I believe that we do have a legitimate interest. Australia is active in world affairs and is, of course, an active and respected member of the United Nations.

We also have substantial ethnic communities from this part of the world—Croatian, Serbian and Macedonian communities as well as some from many of the surrounding countries. I must say that to their great credit these communities have maintained a peaceful coexistence here in Australia, but that is not to say that feelings do not run deeply between them. Unfortunately, they do. I have in my electorate of McPherson substantial Croatian and Serbian communities and unfortunately they do not talk to each other. Personally, I have been able to develop friendships within both groups, but the Serbian community was naturally very suspicious of my role as vice-chairman of the Australia-Croatia Parliamentary Group. I have had no hesitation all along in supporting Croatia, in its move for independence and in its early days and troubled days, such as they have been, as an independent nation.

The focus of the war in the former Yugoslavia for some time has been on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The London conference on the former Yugoslavia focused attention on this particular area and sought solutions to the conflict. Unfortunately, as we look back three months or so to that conference at the end of August, very little seems to have resulted. If anything, the situation has deteriorated since the London conference. My colleague the honourable member for Moore and I were in London at the time and we noted that the Prime Minister of Great Britain, John Major, said, `In this room are the people who can stop the war', but they did not and they have not.

As I said earlier, things have been made worse at this particular time of the year. Not only is there the fighting but there is now the inclement weather which is an integral part of life in that part of the world. There is an estimate that as many as 750,000 people face starvation. This is not famine ravaged Somalia in the Horn of Africa; this is the heart of Europe that we are talking about here this morning. The prospect for the people in that part of the world is starvation. We must question why this is being allowed to happen. As the Minister says, we ought to question it. This motion calls upon this Parliament not only to recognise the extent of the problem but to fully support the United Nations in its efforts to do something about it. In fact, it calls upon the United Nations to do more to stop the fighting.

We must applaud the United Nations for what it has done. The United Nations is stretched across the world in peacekeeping operations and aid operations and its resources are stretched, yet in an area like the former Yugoslavia we saw the difficulties it has operating where there is a full scale war going on. We have the United Nations protection force there attempting to stop the fighting at the same time that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is attempting to help the people. It is a very difficult situation, almost an impossible one. There is fighting in Bosnia and, sadly, even between the Muslims and the Croatians. Serbian forces have seized two-thirds of Bosnia, and the apparent falling-out between Croatians and the Muslims must place some question mark over the position of Bosnian President Izetbegobic.

There has been an international outcry over the ethnic cleansing in Bosnia. The motion we are discussing this morning makes particular reference to that cleansing and calls upon us to deplore that. Ethnic cleansing is clearly occurring, not only in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in Croatia. We note that the United Nations has appointed a special commission to investigate ethnic cleansing, and to investigate the atrocities which have been carried out. We support that particular move and this Parliament will support it.

The need for increased aid is obvious. In some respects, the timing of the presidential election in the United States could not have been worse. Fortunately, President-elect Clinton has made some very positive statements about his attitude to a solution in the former Yugoslavia. We may well expect him to do more than President Bush was moved to do in the heat of the election campaign. The latest United Nations actions have been to impose a naval blockade, and we welcome that action as well. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

—I am happy to support this motion. I moved a motion earlier in this House on Bosnia-Herzegovina that referred to the recognition issue and also to some of the questions raised in this motion. In reflecting on the events in Bosnia-Herzegovina, I go back to my visit to Sarajevo at the beginning of December last year. I attended the first national conference of the ruling Muslim party, and had discussions with President Izetbegobic. At that time, I became somewhat alarmed about the potential for a huge bloodbath in Bosnia-Herzegovina. In fact, I issued a statement in Zagreb, and when I returned to Australia, warning of the potential crisis in Bosnia-Herzegovina. I said in that statement that political action on the part of the international community was necessary to prevent bloodshed in Bosnia-Herzegovina.

PARA.TAB: As usual, we saw very little political action. There was a total failure of the European Community's political dimension to do anything about the Croatian crisis and the clearly bad omens about what would happen in Bosnia-Herzegovina, and of course those things happened. The European Community has virtually rendered itself incapable of any hopeful action in relation to the matter. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) mentioned the conference in London. There was lot of optimistic talk at that. Mr Major made various pronouncements and various agreements were reached. The reality is that nothing has happened. If ever there has been a dramatic illustration of the failure of European policy, it is in this whole question of the former Yugoslavia and, in particular, the sadness of Bosnia-Herzegovina.

I have seen Bosnian refugees throughout Europe; I have seen camps in Hungary, Slovenia and Croatia. When one sees, as I have seen, what these people have been through and hears the stories that they tell, one wonders how far humanity has progressed since the time of the Nazis. There are terrible stories of atrocities. There are stories of innocent people being butchered, of groups of people being lined up and shot, of people being decapitated and of gross tortures. These things should not be occurring at this point in the twentieth century, and especially not in Europe. I do not think the plight of these people has penetrated sufficiently into the international consciousness. We ought to be doing as much as we can.

I know that honourable members from both sides of this House raise these issues at every opportunity. I recently went with a delegation to the Middle East, where I asked a number of questions. What can be done about Bosnia-Herzegovina? What are the Muslim countries doing about Bosnia-Herzegovina? There is a lot of talk. The United Nations has made a number of resolutions and tried to do some things, but it is not enough. The sorts of atrocities that occurred in March, April, May and June are still going on. Something has to be done about this crisis. The United Nations says it has many other problems to deal with and that it does not know how to achieve a political solution in Bosnia-Herzegovina. It is true that the kinds of solutions that were possible last year, before the outbreak of the violence, before the outbreak of the war, are much more difficult to achieve now. Finding a political solution is more difficult now because it is hard to get people who have been involved in the slaughter of each other to live together.

However, a solution must be found, and we need to exercise a lot more effort at the diplomatic level to force people to the negotiating table to discuss a real solution. It is not good enough to say that the people in that region just want to kill each other. That has not always been the case. It is not true, especially in Bosnia-Herzegovina, which, until the recent outbreak, was a model of the three peoples living together in peace and in harmony. Intermarriage between Croatians, Muslims and Serbians was at a very high level for three different ethnic communities. Yet we have a situation where that harmony has been broken down and destroyed by the outside interference of the Government of Mr Milosevic in Serbia.

Let me make it clear that I do not condemn the Serbian people. However, I do condemn the Government of Serbia and especially Mr Milosevic. It is about time Mr Milosevic heard the voice of his own people, resigned and got out because of his disgraceful behaviour, not only in this case but in Croatia and elsewhere. There could have been a peaceful, sensible dissolution of the former Yugoslavia, in the interests of Serbia as well as in the interests of Croatia and of Bosnia-Herzegovina. Instead of that, there has been terrible ongoing war. There is no doubt that the prosecution of that war could not have taken place if it were not for the huge armed military presence of Serbia and the enormous amount of weaponry which the Serbian Government provided to one side in the conflict.

The reality is that there are forces in Serbia that are in favour of peace. A lot of the Serbian people have been killed, a lot of them have suffered, and those voices for peace in Serbia need to be heard. We ought to encourage a solution in Bosnia-Herzegovina, whatever it may be. Some ideas have been put forward, of which the formation of cantons is one. Certainly, some way forward needs to be found for these people to live together, and for the sovereignty and integrity of Bosnia-Herzegovina to be respected.

One of the most disturbing things about all this has been the perception throughout the Muslim world that, in fact, because the Bosnian people are Muslim, the rest of the world, especially western Europe, has not been prepared to help them. Let us hope that there is no truth in that allegation; let us hope that it has nothing to do with the fact that these people are Muslim. In order for that perception to be overcome, it is necessary for the international community, especially the United Nations, to take a stronger position.

What is at stake in relation to Bosnia-Herzegovina extends far beyond Bosnia-Herzegovina; it extends to the whole question of the integrity of the various religious groups in the world in terms of dealing with crises of this kind. Just as Muslim nations should not support any Muslim nation carrying out activities that are contrary to human rights, Western nations should not support any Christian nation carrying out activities that are contrary to human rights simply because the other people are Muslim. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow on from the comments made by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). He is one of a group of honourable members and senators in this Parliament who for a long time have been calling for more attention from Australia and other nations to solve the current conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) commented, we have a most bloody and bitter war with civilians being attacked mercilessly by troops. We visited Sarajevo at the end of August this year and they are in fact in the hills surrounding the city indiscriminately firing mortar shells and missiles into the city at civilian targets. Probably the most tragic part of our visit to Sarajevo at that time was the visit to the children's ward at the hospital. In the intensive care unit we were able to see some of the terrible injuries that have been suffered by young innocent children. They have been hit, maimed, injured and killed by this indiscriminate shelling and firing by those cowards in the hills surrounding the city.

Unfortunately, I find that sometimes our attitude towards this is coloured by what we see on the television. Night after night on the television we see these images of horror and warfare and bloody, bitter fighting. After a while we become a little bit immune to it; after a while it becomes surreal in its effect on our consciousness. It just happens and we accept it as being part and parcel of our world and, because it is so far away from us, it has little consequence on the affairs of our own nation. But that is not the case. As the honourable member for McPherson has rightly said, in the middle of Europe in the 1990s, war, killing, torture and maiming of innocent people are going on right under the noses of the rest of the civilised world. To be frank, it is a disgrace that the rest of the world has given so little attention and has taken so little trouble to try to resolve this crisis.

The honourable member for Calwell looked back to the 1930s in European history and reflected on the connection between the behaviour in the 1930s and the behaviour we are witnessing in Bosnia-Herzegovina at the moment. Of course, one can well ask, with the benefit of hindsight, how during the 1930s the rest of the civilised world—those that paid attention to what was going on—allowed the killing, torturing, maiming, aggression, invasion and occupation to go on unchecked, until in the end the world forces launched a war against that aggression and that uncivilised behaviour and defeated and destroyed the dictators responsible for all of the things occurring during that time.

I mention the children's ward because that probably was the most poignant of the various incidents that occurred during our visit to Sarajevo. It is probably the strongest image I carry in my mind from that time because they were innocent children. One child we saw there had lost a leg, the other had been badly injured and there were substantial groin injuries, all caused by a mortar shell. The child was five years old—the same age as my young son. When it comes to this level of violence, then the lack of attention and the lack of action by the rest of the world becomes a disgrace.

Last Saturday in Perth we had a very large function to raise money to send wheat and flour to Croatia to help feed some of the refugees who have fled from Bosnia-Herzegovina into Croatia. At this time there are 630,000 displaced persons and refugees within Croatia, which is just one of the neighbouring countries that has had refugees come into it. I wish to commend the actions of those people in Perth on Saturday. In a small way I made my own contribution of a tonne of flour. I would like to see that sort of effort expanded so that we can take pride in the contribution Australia can make to relieve the suffering of the people who have been displaced or have had to flee Bosnia and Herzegovina. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), but first I want to refer to a parallel matter. In a similar debate I made some comments on allegations of the Greek Government's perceived efforts to break the embargo on Serbia. As a result, of course, I received a letter from the Greek diplomatic representatives in this country denying those allegations and I do accept their word. Similarly, I hope that they can give great reassurances on allegations, not from Skopje but from a significant number of Western journalists, that their country's current deep interest in stopping aid to Serbia through blocking Macedonian access to the port of Thessaloniki is in fact crucially related to the embargo on Serbia and is not part of the campaign to deny Macedonia recognition by the European Community in December. I accept their word that they are not being systematically part of a process to aid Serbia because they see it as an ally against Macedonia and for other reasons. As I say, I hope similar remarks can be made by them with regard to this latest action against Macedonia.

PARA.TAB: The earlier speakers have accented the failure of the United Nations. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) made a very important point that there is a great danger in the Arab world, the Middle East, thinking that the failure of the United Nations, when compared with other momentous activity, could be taken as an area of discrimination as there has not been the same intensity of interest in solving this problem as has been displayed in other events. At the same time, I disagree with the honourable member for Calwell when he says that the Arab world has only been talking and they should be doing more. What are people saying the Arab world should do? Certainly, if it took unilateral action to send in its own troops the rest of the world would condemn that and I do not think that would really assist the situation. I do not think that the Arab countries are any more guilty than the rest of the world or that they can be accused of only talking, as the honourable member for Calwell said. In this country, we have seen great efforts by the Muslim community, Muslim Aid Australia in particular, in raising money and produce for the beleaguered people in Bosnia.

The motion has a number of points, one of which deals with the question of ethnic cleansing. We would not deny that the actions of the Serbian army and of Serbian rebels in Bosnia and parts of Croatia have been horrendous. But, despite the unpopularity of saying it, I think we have to make clear that the situation is now deteriorating with recent activities by both Croatian irregulars and elements of the Croatian army.

I refer to a report on 8 November in the Manchester Guardian which speaks of the town of Prozor. Its population of 15,000 has been forcibly reduced; 5,000 Muslims have been forced out of the town. At the time of the report, they did not know where they were, whether they would be shipped up the road or forced to run to the mountains and so on. But it was a clear indication that both Croatia and Serbia are trying to exploit the situation for their own advantages. The report says that as a result of this activity by Croatians, every window in the Muslim quarter had been smashed or machine-gunned, the brickwork of Muslim houses was blackened, and the sickly smell of fresh fires was hanging in the damp air. It refers not only to Croatian regular forces but also to those who wore identification related to the Ustashi.

Let us condemn Milosevic; let us condemn the Serbian armed forces for the way in which they are handing over their arms to irregulars, to local Serbians, as they depart from these areas. At the same time, I think we have got to be very vigilant about not having a one-sided dimension to this debate, and I do not think that any of the previous speakers have. We speak of the arms embargo; we speak of a series of failed conferences, and a series of failed activities by the European Community and the United Nations. The ending of the arms embargo is, of course, one matter that must trouble us.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House congratulates the Government on the innovative and constructive policies it has implemented to assist the tourism industry, including (a) increased funding of $15 million to the Australian Tourist Commission, (b) increases in the amortisation and depreciation rates applying to tourism accommodation building and plant and equipment, respectively, (c) the aviation reforms which are improving the competitiveness of the aviation sector and (d) the higher policy focus given to the industry by the creation of the Department of Tourism and the elevation of tourism to Cabinet representation.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is one of this country's fastest growing export industries. In 1991-92, it earned $8.2 billion in foreign exchange, more than any other single commodity including wool, wheat and coal. It is also a vital domestic industry, worth about $17.9 billion. Together, the international and domestic tourism industries are responsible for about 5.4 per cent of gross domestic product and employ 449,000 people, or 5.9 per cent of the work force.

PARA.TAB: With the policies this Government has put in place, tourism will generate another 200,000 jobs over the remainder of this decade, or more than one in six of the new jobs created during that time. While other industries have fully felt the impact of the worldwide economic downturn, tourism has remained a strong and growing contributor to the Australian economy. Foreign earnings from tourism actually increased during the 1991-92 financial year by over 13 per cent on the previous year, and they now account for 11 per cent of total export earnings. Total inbound tourism for the first eight months of this year was 11 per cent higher than for the same period last year, continental Europe, Japan, and the rest of Asia all recording increases in excess of that 13 per cent growth rate.

This level of growth has not occurred by accident, but is attributable in some measure to the long term support which has been given to the industry from this Government—support which the industry has, of course, duly recognised. Not only has tourism been raised to Cabinet representation status, but a series of policy changes have been announced which demonstrate the commitment this Government has to the development of tourism. This was made very clear in the release in June of this year of the national tourism strategy called Tourism, Australia's passport to growth.

The strategy is the first attempt by any Australian government to detail the role and function of tourism within the Australian economy; to map out its growth prospects; to identify those government policies which impact on the growth potential of tourism; and to outline medium and long term policy objectives that help to fulfil the potential contribution of tourism to our national wealth. Since 1983, the level of funding provided for the promotion of Australia overseas by the Australian Tourist Commission has been increased from around $10m to $76m this financial year. This includes an extra $10m for 1991-92, announced in the One Nation statement earlier this year.

Also in that statement the Government announced additional measures to assist the development of the tourism industry or, more appropriately, to put in place economic conditions within which the tourism industry could thrive. These measures included an increase in the amortisation rate for tourism accommodation buildings from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. This level of write-off more accurately reflected the effective life of traveller accommodation in a 24 hours a day, seven days a week industry. Changes announced in the One Nation statement to aviation policy also had an impact, and other reforms by the Government of the aviation sector have combined to produce a more competitive fare structure, with resultant benefits for the travelling tourist public.

In the 1992-93 Federal Budget, tourism was also recognised with a provision of $1.9m over the next four years to develop eco-tourism in forested areas and $6.2m over two years for the construction of cultural centres at Uluru and Kakadu national parks. I am pleased to note the $12m which was allocated to refurbish the rolling stock of the Indian Pacific railway, which has its headquarters in my seat and over the next decade has the potential to provide one of the great tourism attractions of the world, competing with the great railway journeys, including the Trans-Siberian and the Paris-Istanbul. This would take the form of a railway trip around the coast from Cairns to Perth, going through Adelaide on to the Indian Pacific railway system, which would be an enormous attraction for international tourists.

Tourism has also been a major beneficiary of the $350m local capital works program announced in this year's Budget, which itemises tourism infrastructure projects as being eligible, and these are being carried out in regional centres throughout the country. In my own electorate of Adelaide, where councils have received about $10m, a considerable amount of tourism related infrastructure is presently being undertaken by local councils, and last week it was my great pleasure to visit a number of these councils in order to hand over the cheques for the initiation of these projects.

It is estimated that by the year 2000 there will be 6.8 million international visitors to Australia annually, bringing approximately $18 billion in foreign earnings into this country, and anything which jeopardises the future projects and prospects in this exciting industry are to be avoided. So it is with some regret that I have to refer to the fact that the Opposition is vigorously pursuing a proposal which could have a devastating impact on the tourism industry. Under the Opposition policy, every single tourism product would be hit by goods and services tax, which would be imposed on hotels, motels, domestic air fares, bus fares, rail fares, restaurant meals, tourist guide charges and so on. It is no wonder that the tourism industry has been up in arms against the introduction of a GST.

To add insult to injury, it appears that the work that the industry itself commissioned through Ernst and Young is being ignored, just as the recommendations of the joint coalition-ATIA committee were committed to a circular file by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Not content to ignore the tourism industry, the Leader of the Opposition took the opportunity at the Australian tourism industry national conference in October to berate the tourism industry for the quality of its submission, and to accuse it of being little more than a `vested interest'. What did the Ernst and Young report say that the Leader of the Opposition chooses to ignore? It said among other things that accommodation prices would rise by up to 13 per cent, restaurant prices by 14 per cent, alcohol prices by 8 per cent and so on.

But there are also other implications of a GST oriented policy which the Opposition needs to acknowledge. For example, it is obvious that the coalition had not realised that jet fuel used by large planes in the aviation industry is exempt from fuel excise, making the GST rebate worthless. As a result, the tourism industry finds itself facing a 10 per cent increase in domestic air fares. To take another example, it is pretty clear that the coalition had not grasped the fact that about 85 per cent of tourism businesses are already exempt from payroll tax and so get absolutely no benefit from its proposed abolition.

These oversights are regrettable, but perhaps more regrettable is the fact that the Leader of the Opposition and his treasury spokesman have not been prepared to redress them. This is unfortunate not just for the tourism industry but for the economy and the country as a whole. As I have said, we are expecting 200,000 new jobs in tourism by the end of the decade. These are jobs that are much needed, particularly in an export oriented and very efficient industry, and that job growth will be more difficult to achieve with a 15 per cent goods and services tax imposed upon the industry.

So it is with some regret that we find the Leader of the Opposition saying with respect to the industry that we do not want Australia to be, as he calls it, a giant Japanese hotel. No wonder that one of the leading lights of the Victorian industry, Ron Eades, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest concern of the tourism industry is that the proposed GST would be a disaster.

We find such criticisms being made across the board. For example, the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia criticised the Opposition's proposed GST when its managing director, Len Taylor, said that ITOA would continue to wage its campaign against the proposal and would be pressing for offshore sales to be zero rated.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, the Australian Federation of Travel Agents has warned the industry that the GST would increase domestic travel costs by up to 12 per cent. The AFTA chief, John Dart, claimed the tax could make overseas holidays far more attractive to Australians than domestic holidays. Also, the Ernst and Young report found that the GST could raise accommodation costs by up to 13 per cent.

Understandably, the tourism industry is very critical of this proposal. It is regrettable to see that an industry that has been forging ahead so effectively, and under our policies will continue to do so during the coming decade, should be threatened by such unthinking policies.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), with his somewhat superior intellect, could fall into the trap of just regurgitating the information that has been put out as government propaganda. I have to pick up his point about what was alleged to have been said in the Ernst and Young report. It is clear he has no awareness at all of the actual report. In one section of it, Ernst and Young admitted:

SPEECH.PARA: The report does no more than analyse the impact of the indirect tax component of the `Fightback!' package. It does not take into account many of the other parts of the package, notably, changes to the industrial system, the effects of an open skies policy and the impact of the income tax cuts.

These three key elements of Fightback were not even considered. At the same time there is a Treasury minute of 27 November 1991 which estimates that significant savings will be made in various industries as a result of the Fightback changes to indirect taxes. They include savings of $376m by air transport, $361m by the entertainment industry and $318m by restaurants, hotels and clubs. These reductions in cost will have a significant impact on the tourism industry but these facts were not even considered by Ernst and Young.

PARA.TAB: So far as the much vaunted ATIA report is concerned, it was purportedly to be a joint report with the Federal coalition. In fact, at no time did the coalition or its spokesman endorse the contents of the report. Further, the report did not consider many of the reforms that it had been charged to cover.

The Fightback package does indeed offer a great deal to tourism and I ought to know because my electorate is very much a tourism orientated electorate. I refer not only to that part of my electorate which is located on the Gold Coast, but also to the fact that Mount Tamborine and a very substantial part of the Lamington National Park and the Lamington Plateau are also in the electorate of Moncrieff. It also spreads out into the hinterland and includes the very beautiful country areas around Beaudesert and through nearly to Boonah.

Therefore, tourism is a major issue in my electorate and one with which I am familiar. I wholeheartedly endorse the Fightback package and all that if offers to the tourism industry, a growing industry. I note also in passing, although I have not the time to dwell on them, the comments that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide, made about the importance of tourism to the Australian economy. I endorse those comments, and the Gold Coast is very thankful indeed for the rise in international tourism. If it had not been for the rise in international tourism over the last 12 months, the Gold Coast would have had the backside out of its pants because domestic tourism has dropped alarmingly due to this Government's policies. As a consequence we have very dramatic rates of unemployment on the Gold Coast, not all of which can be ascribed to interstate migration. I welcome the Fightback package because the abolition of the seven specified taxes will have a very dramatic effect on the tourism sector.

As I have already said, the Federal Treasury has estimated savings through Fightback of more than $1 billion for key sectors of the tourism industry. That estimate is now 12 months old. Importantly, the abolition of petrol tax for private users will cut the cost of petrol by 19c a litre. As we have said many times, that is a saving of $11 each time the average family car is filled. That saving will bring domestic travel back within the reach of average families. The general lift to the economy that the Fightback package will give will also bring back domestic tourists.

In that context, one has to at least look at the abysmal failure of this Federal Labor Government to spend money on roads, which are a major part of the infrastructure of tourism. The Gold Coast now has a permanent population in excess of 300,000 people. At peak holiday time, that population is increased by between 250,000 and 300,000 people. Yet the Federal Government will not spend the proper amount on roads for the amount of road usage, both on highways and on major road systems, within this area which earns major amounts of overseas income. This lack of money spent on roads also affects domestic tourism.

Under Fightback, business users will save 26c or 27c a litre on their fuel. That will have great implications for tourism for a large country such as Australia and, in particular, for a large State such as Queensland. A major Queensland coach company, for example, would save $1.953m in fuel taxes alone, and added to that would be a $100,000 saving from the abolition of sales tax on tyres and a $125,000 saving for parts and maintenance. So, under the Fightback package, that one coach company would save $2.178m in costs. Further, a Whitsunday air charter company estimated that it would save $67,500 on its avgas bill of $217,500—a saving of 31 per cent.

Those examples of savings make a nonsense of what has been said about the effect of the GST on tourism. The savings for both domestic and international tourists on their costs in Australia will be enormous. The impact of the GST will be very small indeed. There are very few countries in the world to which one can travel that do not have some sort of consumer tax.
