Those of us who have had the good fortune to travel overseas will be aware that those taxes exist, but they certainly do not stop overseas travel from Australia. They are not going to stop overseas travel to Australia.

The arguments that are being proposed here in Australia are exactly the same ones that were put forward in New Zealand when it introduced its GST. However, New Zealand did not abolish fuel taxes, payroll taxes and all those other taxes. All it did was a straight swap between GST and income tax, and it has not had any negative effect at all on New Zealand tourism. The tourism industry there now admits that it was wrong in asking for an exemption. It accepts that the GST should be applied across the board, and that compensatory measures such as extra expenditure on the promotion of tourism are necessary. That, of course, is promised in the Fightback package.

As far as the great hoo-ha about hotel and motel accommodation is concerned, those hotels and motels would be free from the 20 per cent tax that applies to many of the items that they buy now. I heard a very misguided and, I suspect, Labor Party inspired person on radio talkback in Queensland say recently, `Ah, but the restaurants are going to have to pay 20 per cent on their food, and all these other ingredients'. Everything is fully rebatable if it is a cost of industry. GST is added and paid effectively only at the end point on a much lower cost base. Ministers have talked in Question Time about the cost of toothpaste, but they omit to say that it has a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on it, as do so many things, including the items that are required to the tourism industry.

The tourism industry is essentially a small business industry. The Government points out, properly, that a large number of entrepreneurs in the tourism industry do not pay payroll tax. That is because they own `mum and dad' motels. They are very small businesses. However, they will benefit very substantially from Fightback's $13 billion cut in income tax, and other encouragements that will be given through changes to the capital gains tax arrangements and the superannuation arrangement. They will benefit enormously. They are suffering terribly under the capital gains tax regime, for one, of this Labor Government.

The Jobsback package has been welcomed by the tourism industry. The voluntary employment agreements will make it possible to recognise that tourism is a seven-day a week, 24-hour a day industry, particularly on the Gold Coast. It is no good people talking in terms of the old 9 to 5, five days a week system. Many of my constituents welcome the opportunity to work weekends and nights. They are married people who take turns to look after their children and keep the home fire burning. That applies to a lot of other industries as well. Under Jobsback, Australian tourism will become more competitive, and that will create jobs in the industry.

There will be international implications as well. Restrictions on international tourist charters for Australia will be lifted to assist the growth to regional destinations and to capitalise on bulk tourist traffic—something that this Government will not consider—and foreign carriers will be licensed to operate to Australian ports provided that Australian carriers have the opportunity to take up reciprocal rights. That will result in savings in the price of international airfares of up to 20 per cent. So this nonsense about our turning away international tourists is just that. It is a heap of garbage. It does not look at the whole picture, just as the Ernst and Young report did not look at the whole picture.

There will be reforms in the structure of the bureaucracy, and we will upgrade the industry. Fightback has many other important implications, both domestic and international—all of which are beneficial, all of which I welcome, and all of which the tourism operators in my electorate welcome when they know the truth and are not fed the lies the Labor Party is telling at the moment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion before the House today moved by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley). The member for Adelaide went through in some detail a number of important measures undertaken by this Government to promote and ensure a future for tourism. It is, as he outlined, one of the major growth industries available to Australia. I do not propose in the five minutes available to me in this short debate to try to canvass those same issues, but rather to talk more directly about the impact of Opposition proposals on tourism with particular reference to Queensland, my home State and the home State of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who has just spoken.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me, having listened to the honourable member for Moncrieff, that she seems to think there are three offsets to the GST impost on tourism. One is the removal of payroll tax. Let me deal with that first. She would know, as would all members of this place, that very few tourist operators in Queensland are of a large enough size to pay any payroll tax at all. The truth of the matter is that most tourist operators in Queensland do not now pay payroll tax. Most people employed in the tourism industry in Australia are not in a position where payroll tax is levied on their employment, so we should dispense with that from the outset.

In all of these debates where the GST comes up there seems to be some weight given by Opposition members to their industrial relations policy. That is a matter which we will debate again and again between now and the Federal election, and time will not allow me to go into it now. When we try to add up the figures, the bottom line of their argument is that the companies and the consumers need not worry about the increased cost that a GST might otherwise impose, because employers will be able to cut their costs. They will be able to reduce their wages so they will have a lower wage overhead. That has got all sorts of social implications. It might even have a few implications for the number of Australians who can afford to have a holiday, if in fact their policies were to be implemented.

The other point that needs to be recognised is the difference between levying a tax on the wholesale price and levying a tax on the retail price. The effect of the mark-up between wholesale and retail is generally accepted to mean that a 15 per cent retail tax is about the same as a 20 per cent wholesale tax. So in those areas where a 20 per cent wholesale tax applies, the abolition of it and its replacement with a 15 per cent tax will not result in any direct benefits.

The sort of optimism in the views put forward by the honourable member for Moncrieff and others opposite is certainly not one shared by the tourist industry. There is ample evidence of that. In fact, Travel Australia: the Australian Tourism Magazine, which is the publication that is the voice of the tourist industry, in August of this year had a front page headline which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism leaders slam Hewson's tax proposals as studies show cost.
It opened that article by saying:

The Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia has slammed the Federal Opposition's proposed goods and services tax (GST) which will apply to Australian tour packages and other tourist services bought overseas.

There should be no misunderstanding about the view of the industry on this point. The industry does not support the Opposition's policy, and that is well documented. The Opposition's shadow spokesperson for tourism, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) knows it only too well.

PARA.TAB: But it is not just something understood by people in Australia. In the Australian Financial Review of November of this year there was a letter to the editor from Mr Geoffrey Lipman, who is the president of World Travel and Tourism Council in Brussels, Belgium. He said:
Taxing tourism, like taxing any other export, will increase its costs and reduce its competitiveness. Tourism demand is sensitive to costs.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an international authority, warning the Australian people in a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review only a couple of weeks ago that we should not adopt a goods and services tax that would be imposed on tourism.

PARA.TAB: Queensland, of course, relies heavily on tourism—and so it should. It is the most beautiful State in the country and has more to offer than anywhere else. But it is important to the future of south-eastern Queensland and of Queensland itself—the honourable member for Moncrieff and I both come from that part of the State—that we do not introduce policies that are going to attack that tourism industry.

In the one minute now available to me, I offer one quick example. I made some phone calls recently about a holiday that I might be able to take on the Sunshine Coast rather than the Gold Coast. A unit costs between $500 and $700. There is very little existing sales tax that goes into that by any measure, under any of the various categories that we are talking about, under any of the seven taxes. The GST will cost an extra $60 to $100 just to pay for one week's accommodation. If I am going to save that money on cheaper petrol that the Liberals say they will give me—although I do not have time to talk about the road user charge—I would need to travel some 3,000 to 5,000 kilometres just to save enough money to cover the extra accommodation cost. That is before I pay for meals; that is before I take the kids out for a modest dinner at the Pizza Hut, which will cost me an extra $5 to $10; that is before I go to a theme park, which will cost me an extra $15. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that I have such a short amount of time in which to make a contribution to this debate. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), was talking about having a holiday on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland. I wonder why he goes overseas so much if the VAT and all those other taxes are so discrediting. Let us face it: Australian tourism is going to benefit from Fightback in every possible way.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tries to compare Australia with the rest of the world and say that we are not worse off. But have we got all of these foreign tourists coming in from economies that are broke like ours? Come off it! What we have got to do is make sure that Australian tourists are given a fair deal and that the Australian tourist industry, which is vitally important to this country, gets the best possible support that it can.

It is worth noting—and it is particularly relevant for the area that I represent on the north coast of New South Wales—that nearly 80 per cent of domestic tourists use their cars for travel. If one also considers the coach operators, the four-wheel drive businesses and the charter operators, one can see that there will be a huge boost for domestic tourism with the abolition of sales tax, fuel excise and with the massive personal income tax cuts.

All that the Labor Government can do is talk about the GST. That is one small part of only a part of Fightback. Quite frankly, I would like to challenge the honourable member for Brisbane and the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) to come and stand alongside the Pacific Highway with me, in Coffs Harbour, and watch the number of people who are driving to and from holiday destinations. Every one of those people will save 19c a litre on every litre of petrol they put into their vehicle, which represents enormous savings for a holiday trip. Of course, they will have a great deal more spare cash in their pockets after the massive personal tax cuts. We are going to give Australians the biggest tax cuts ever seen in the history of this country—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty per cent.

—Thirty per cent, as the honourable member for Dundas says. Many more Australians will be in a job under Fightback, meaning that more people will be thinking about wanting and affording a holiday. With 11.3 per cent unemployment, people are scared stiff. If they have got a job, they are scared stiff about losing it and they are not spending. But when we are in government and Fightback is in place, there will be an increase in confidence, people will not be scared about losing their job and many more people will be getting a job. Indeed, our natural assets and our people are our greatest tourism assets. A smile costs nothing, but Australians do not have a great deal to smile about these days.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Tourism Commission is forecasting 6.5 million overseas visitors by the year 2000. We believe we can achieve 10 million. We want to see growth in domestic tourism as well, helped by Fightback, with average families $38 a week better off, and more to spend on tourism. We have done well in tourism, thanks to the people at the coalface, those people in the industry, those tourist operators and small businesses who labour for long hours under repressive tax regimes. They have done well and deserve recognition, but they deserve the support and the encouragement that they will get under Fightback.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with this failed Labor Government and failed Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for lacking any sense of vision for the future of our nation, for having no idea of how to extract us from the morass of government induced economic failure and social hardship and for lacking the political will to deal with our problems. Day after day the Prime Minister comes into this House and goes out to the television cameras and spends his time dumping on Opposition policies and on the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). This is a Prime Minister who spends his time trying to divert public attention from the hard core issues at hand to issues of irrelevance.

PARA.TAB: I remind the House that the Prime Minister has dumped on our flag, he has dumped on the Queen and he has dumped on our system of parliamentary democracy. He has had a go at the Senate a few times. He constantly spends his time denigrating the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith). This is an unelected Prime Minister who wishes to divert our attention from the hard issues at hand.

I remind honourable members that it is indeed a litany of failure that we address today in this House: one million unemployed, one million Australians who wish to work, who have no work, who cannot find a job; 1.8 million underemployed, 1.8 million Australians who have no job or who have minor part time work or wish to find work but who have not yet registered; 375,000 individuals classified as long term unemployed—that is, they have been seeking work for 12 months or more without success; 600,000 young people with no parent with a job; one-third of our 15-to 19-year-olds who want to work cannot find employment; and 250,000 youth across this nation are classified as underemployed.

Why do we have to go along with this litany of unemployment and hardship? We have an international debt of some $150 billion growing at a rate of $1.5 billion per month. It is not as though we are saving. It is not as though we are creating new industries. We are borrowing from the rest of the world to pay our debts and to pay the interest on our debts while Australians lack work and business lacks any incentive to proceed to develop new industry or new products.

We have static or falling retail sales, and car sales this month are down again. There is a 20 per cent increase in business bankruptcies on last year, and last year was a record. There is a 30 per cent increase in personal bankruptcies on last year, and last year was a record. A report in the Age of Thursday, 19 November says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a bankrupt was declared in Australia almost every 30 minutes in 1991-92. There were 16,780 declared bankruptcies in Australia during the past financial year, compared with 13,000 in 1990-91.

That was a record. There are record numbers of company insolvencies and we have declining investment in new plant and equipment. We have static home building. This is hardly a picture of a healthy and vibrant economy.

PARA.TAB: The Unemployed People's Association said recently that we do have some growth industries in Australia. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: Social security, litigation, bureaucracies, and charities are the fastest growing industries in Australia.

That is an indictment, is it not? There are many parallels between this failed Labor Government federally and the failed Labor Government of the State of Victoria. Victoria was and is bankrupt. The former Victorian Premier and her Cabinet lacked the political will to address the problems, and they were also constrained by their ties to the trade union movement, preventing them from taking the kinds of decisions that were necessary to turn that State around and to create a climate in which investment would be nourished and could grow. Madam Deputy Speaker, I recently received from one of my constituents a letter, a part of which I would like to read to this House. It says:
Dear Mr Charles,

My husband and I were surprised and confused to receive a letter from you as a politician, who is interested in the opinion of the people in his electorate. This has never happened to us in the 40 years of our lives as Australians, and we not only appreciate your action, but feel privileged to, perhaps in some small way, have a say in the future of Australia.
We were Labor voters all our lives, until we saw the hypocrisy and incompetence of Labor and the catastrophic result of their rule.

We now realise our mistake and long for the security and continuity a Liberal government had given us over 30 years, and hope to God that our choice in electing you will bring some sort of balance or order back to this country, if that is at all possible.
The damage Labor has caused is criminal and unforgivable.
They go on then to deal with some of the problems that Labor has caused them as individuals. They end their letter by saying:
It is quite obvious to us that you would have to be a magician to correct the mismanagement of Labor, but it is comforting to know that somebody sincerely tries.
Thank you sincerely for this opportunity.
In the interest of Australia, we wish you luck.

Australia needs more than a bit of luck; Australia needs a vision—a vision for the future. That is what Fightback is all about, and that is what the Leader of the Opposition has brought to this Parliament. He brings to the 17 million people of our nation, employed and unemployed, a vision for the future. He brings a hope for an Australia which can employ its people, which is fair, which treats people equally and with dignity, and which offers a helping hand to those who are unfortunate, but an Australia which is dynamic and outward looking, an Australia which does not spend its time navel gazing and looking at the past, an Australia which sees a hope for a positive future, a dynamic and growing economy and a nation that cares for all of its people in all of their circumstances. That is what Fightback is all about. It is 600 pages of detailed economic and social prescription for the future.

PARA.TAB: But this Government, the Keating Labor Government, has no solutions, no answers, no hope for the future, no prescription and no policies. This Government, tied as it is to the union bureaucracy, will never find the political will to look for the solutions that might save us. Every time it is put to them that there is a proposition they might consider which might help stimulate our economy, as was the case with the goods and services tax in 1985, the Prime Minister and his Cabinet are vetoed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The ACTU has the power of veto over a government. This is a government in partnership with trade unions, as the Kirner socialist Government in Victoria was in partnership with the Trades Hall Council. That partnership failed Victorians as it is failing Australians. It offers no solutions, it offers no hope for the future, it offers no vision, and it offers no prescription for prosperity.
This nation desperately needs a change of government. We need a change of tack, we need a change of direction, and we need real hope for the future. That will be brought by Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), it is evident to me why the polls show that the Australian people find the goods and services tax package proposed by the Liberal Opposition so repugnant. Those polls make very clear just how unwelcome the 15 per cent tax slug is that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) wants to impose on everything. It is totally out of step with what is required in Australia; it is totally out of step with trying to encourage economic recovery; and it is totally out of step with meeting the needs of ordinary Australians. Fundamentally, it misses the point as to where Australia's future lies and what is needed to ensure that we make the most advantage of our potential in this decade.

PARA.TAB: This grievance debate gives me an opportunity to raise the initiatives that the Government is taking to rebuild after what has been an extremely painful downturn in world economic activity. The recession around the world—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on, you induced the recession; first in, last out.

—I will come back to the honourable member for Dundas in a moment; I have a few things to say as far as he is concerned. The key point to be made in all of this process is that throughout this year the Government has taken steps to stimulate economic activity. The honourable member for Dundas has been here for a long while. He was here when the Fraser Government was in power. Whilst there was a recession in 1982-83, we had the spectacle of inflation running at double digit figures under the administration of the Government of the honourable member for Dundas.

PARA.TAB: In this process of coming out of the recession we now have, for the first time in 30 years, a low inflationary setting and a low inflationary environment. This will ensure that we move into a real, sustained recovery, built on productive growth, with the fundamentals moving; with a fiscal stimulus in the economy; and with the sorts of needs that exist in regions like western Sydney finally being addressed.

It is interesting to contrast the approach of the Government—we acknowledge the need to rebuild public infrastructure—with the approach that the Opposition would take on these sorts of issues. Those opposite want to cut $7 billion from outlays. The very people who get hurt in this process of cutbacks in public expenditure are people such as those who have come into the Parramatta electorate after the redistribution of the former seat of the honourable member for Dundas. It is interesting to note the sorts of complaints we are getting today from people who live in some of the public housing in areas such as Dundas and Ermington in New South Wales. Those people believe, quite rightly, that the State Government of New South Wales has basically wound down the maintenance of the public housing stock to deplorable levels.

That is the sort of attitude that the conservatives of this country have towards people's housing and accommodation needs. Those people are basically told, `We're not adding to the public housing stock; we're not going to provide proper maintenance of your properties'. When people complain to me—I had someone from the Dundas Valley area complain to me last week—about the lack of action from the State Government about these matters, they are basically told, `You don't have any rights'. Perhaps they fit into the category of Dr Hewson's renters: they are not regarded as people who have fundamental rights as far as housing and accommodation needs are concerned.

That is precisely what Fightback is all about—completely cutting out public expenditure on key parts of our infrastructure, be it public transportation, housing, health or the various forms of social security. We have to ask what the impact of that will be. Clearly, it goes much beyond just the fundamentals of what the Fightback package is all about; it goes very much to the core of providing a decent quality of life for ordinary Australians—and Fightback is not going to provide any quality of life for those people.

Fightback is not going to do anything. The suggestion that by adopting Fightback there will be adequate housing for the people faced with acute housing needs, crisis accommodation and so on is just a nonsense. Anyone in this place who seriously entertains that proposition is clearly wrong. The position that we have seen adopted by the governments of both Mr Griener and Mr Fahey in New South Wales has fundamentally cut away at the living standards of people in our area. It is a disgrace that that has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be honest, tell them about higher taxes.

—The honourable member for Dundas is quite excited today. That is understandable, considering the way the Opposition is going in the polls. The truth of the matter is that the Opposition's basic approach to all these issues is that we can just have a contraction of the economy. I will mention what occurs, in the circumstances we have today, when there is further and further contraction. The people who get squeezed really hard by that process are those who have the least means to cope with that sort of contraction.

PARA.TAB: That situation applies pretty much across the board in terms of economic activity around the world at the moment. Because of the depth of the world recession, governments are acknowledging that there is a need for stimulus, that there is a need to extend. Indeed, it is economically efficient to be extending the public infrastructure at this time because of the difficulties of the world recession and the way it is occurring. That is the practical value. Look at the United States, look at Japan and even look at what is being done now to try to revitalise the British economy: the model that the honourable member for Dundas and others have always said we should follow. Clearly, it has proved to be a miserable failure and, 10 years after it has been proved to be a failure elsewhere, the Opposition still wants to develop and embark on such a strategy.

It is a strategy that is most unsuitable for Australia. It does the very things that are counterproductive to getting going the industries we need in Australia; industries such as tourism are vital to Australia. They are industries which the Opposition never cared about in its time in government but which have grown dramatically in the time of the Labor Government and they will continue to grow. Even the shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), basically acknowledges that Fightback is a real lemon as far as the tourism industry is concerned. If the Fightback proposals are adopted, all that will happen is that the people in a position to do things to contribute to economic growth will be just turned against.

One of the points important to the economic recovery in Australia is to ensure that our banking system contributes to the recovery opportunities that are developing. I am particularly concerned, when we see the reports of the ANZ and Westpac banks, that we do not reach the situation where those banks do not adopt a strategy that encourages small businesses in particular to get funding to enable them to embark on new projects. I have had a number of complaints in recent days in relation to the actions of some of the banks and their failure to lend for new initiatives that businesses are wanting to take. It is very important that the banks, despite the difficulties they have encountered both here and in some of their international developments, do not adopt an approach that leads them to be too introverted as far as their future and their part in Australia's future are concerned.

The banks need to adopt a view which encourages a situation where they conduct appropriate prudence in their lending activities but, at the same time, they should not deter people who come along with reasonable propositions so that those people find that effectively they are starved of funds to conduct new projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Billions of dollars worth of debt because they abandoned prudential requirements.

PARA.TAB: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! The honourable member for Dundas!
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dundas has a lot of difficulty with economic issues, and that is why he has stuck, throughout his 20-year career here, to all sorts of things outside the economic area. His comments now suggest that that was probably a sound strategy to adopt. In this particular case, what matters is for all banks to develop an approach where they try to ensure that people of Australia get real access to finance, that they are able to engage in new business activity, that they get the value out of that new business activity and that they use that new business investment to contribute to Australia's economic growth. If the banks do that, they will be successful in the future. (Time expired)

—I want to point out that, when an honourable member is called to order, the purpose is not to give somebody else a free shot at the person who is being called to order. Do that and order is a thing of the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that everyone is getting tired as we are approaching Christmas. That sort of comment from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) is indicative of the fact that this Government is into little personal attacks. He knows very well that if I wanted to bring up his little trip down to the dog show last year, with a $5000 cost to the taxpayer, I could probably do that. However, I am not going to sink to the level of the comments that he has made.

PARA.TAB: Is it not absolutely amazing to listen to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott). In the last 12 months, all we have seen is a bit of a nibble at the Opposition's policies. Honourable members opposite attack them where they think it is appropriate and lie about them when they think they might be able to score some political points. What better example than the honourable member for Parramatta, who knows full well that he is not being truthful when he stands up in here and makes comments such as, `There will be a 15 per cent tax on everything'. I am quite happy to come into this place, or go to public meetings or go to Brisbane, the Northern Territory or wherever, and talk about the policies and debate the real issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on down.

—Does the honourable member for the Northern Territory have another dog show coming up? I will come and do some judging for him. We might get there in time, rather than waste taxpayers' money. The honourable member for Parramatta knows full well that there is not a 15 per cent tax on everything.

PARA.TAB: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it does him any credit at all to come into this House and say that there is a 15 per cent tax. He should be saying to this House that there is a tax on some things. If he wants to debate whether that is appropriate, he should do so. If he wants to tell the House that there will be an increase in tax on some things and a decrease in tax on others, he should do so. If he wants to discuss the appropriateness of that, fair enough. But my friend the honourable member for Parramatta should not come in here and then send a speech out to his constituents saying that there is a 15 per cent tax on everything. Why not level with them and tell them what happens when they go into the supermarket now? Why not level with them about the amount of tax they are paying? I am sick and tired of what is coming from the other side of this House—sick and tired of the lies, the deceit and the total lack of vision about what we should be doing in this country. I do not care whether that comes from the front bench or the back bench; members of the Government totally lack vision.

PARA.TAB: We get all sorts of smiles from honourable members opposite when someone slips in a furphy. They say to themselves, `Beauty! We have got away with peddling another lie to the Australian people'. We can see little smirks over there: `Ripper! We have got away with another furphy'. As elected representatives, honourable members opposite are not doing themselves or the people who put them there any justice whatsoever. Quite frankly, I think they should be utterly ashamed of themselves. If they want to debate the policies, do so. But do not come into this place and tell lies about what is going to happen under the Opposition's policies. Why do not honourable members opposite absolutely lay us in the aisles by coming in here one day and telling us what they are going to do for the Australian people? Why do they not come in here and tell the one million unemployed and the small business people, whom they have decimated in the last four years, what they are going to do for them? Honourable members opposite know why they will not do that: they will not do it, because they do not know what to do.

Honourable members opposite are tired, they have run out of any proactive policy making ideas and all they can do is come in here day after day after day and attack a policy that was supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in 1985. But when the fridge door closed in that little motel room in Tasmania and all the grog had been emptied and it was decided by the ACTU that it would not go ahead, the door on room 49 closed and there closed any attempt at taxation reform in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you are grieving about?

—Thank you, I will. It is not often I get a free kick in the grievance debate so I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for the opportunity. I am grieving for the people that he is not representing. I am grieving for the people in the Northern Territory whose position has, under his guidance, gone from bad to worse to hopeless. That is what I am grieving about, and if he wants me to come up next week and have another chat about it then I will.

PARA.TAB: I am grieving about the inactivity of the Australian Labor Party over the last four years. How dare the honourable member for Parramatta stand up in this place and refer to the `painful downturn in the world economy'. What a cop-out. We led the world into this recession but those opposite can bet their bottom dollar we will be the last ones out. A `painful downturn', he said. I am surprised that his tongue did not poke out of his cheek when he was making that comment because the honourable member could not have been serious about it. He knows very well that his Government's policies put us into this recession. It has nothing to do with the world economy.

In the last four years I have not heard one person from the other side say that in 1982-83 something extraordinary happened. We did not get any rain. That was a recession caused by a drought. If honourable members opposite do not believe me they can go back and check through the figures. Do not come in here and act like ignoramuses and state that the policies of the Fraser Government were recessionary. They know very well what caused the 1982-83 recession. Why do they not have the guts to admit that? Why do they not have the guts to admit that it is their policies over the last four years that have caused the economic downturn in this country? Why do they not have the guts to tell the small business community that it could not possibly survive under their interest rates of 25 per cent?

It is just pathetic. They have no vision. It is about time Government members admitted that. If they are to be genuine contenders for government for the next three years, why do they not bring forward policies rather than engage in the old fashioned pork-barrelling that they have been involved in over the last four months?

I turn now to a subject that I would much rather be discussing, quite frankly, and where there is a bit of commonsense and a bit of reality. It concerns the people that I represent and the area where I was born.
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is terrific, well done; the honourable member has really done himself a great deal of credit in the last seven minutes. One of the people I represent is a small business person who has quite rightly, in my view, some very grave concerns about the fact—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Jenkins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give the honourable member for Scullin some indication of what happened. On 9 July 1989 someone purchased an item from this gentleman's business. He received a part payment but then in April 1990 he had to issue a warrant to recover the outstanding money. In May 1991 that money was received. Then, at the end of May 1991, the purchaser became bankrupt.

PARA.TAB: However, this small business person has now received a summons from the bankrupt's estate to go to court and pay back this money which was outstanding. This happened some 14 months after receiving the money. This transaction had been carried out in good faith but this business person, who is now struggling, has been required to pay back the money.
There is an interesting article in one of the Melbourne papers in relation to changes to the Bankruptcy Act. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the previous law the receiver had to go to court to get the money back, but . . . the onus was now on the creditor, when presented with a notice, to apply to court to have the notice set aside.
I believe small businesses in this country are struggling already, and they do not need these sorts of hassles.

PARA.TAB: In the time left to me, I would like to bring to the attention of the House a matter relating to another constituent who was here recently to have a look at the Vietnam war memorial. This elderly gentleman, who is a returned serviceman, was looking at the names when he slipped into the moat under this memorial and very seriously injured himself. He aggravated war injuries. I have written to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), and I know that he will attend to this matter. A serious injury did occur to my constituent, and I would hate to see other veterans and other people who come to see the memorial injured. I believe that a guard should be erected to avoid similar accidents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Brisbane have been particularly concerned at recent attacks launched by the Kennett Government and people on the Opposition benches on their conditions of employment and their opportunity to protect their future conditions of employment. Of course, what we are witnessing in Victoria is a social laboratory which is part of the Opposition's Fightback package. The Opposition, on many occasions, expressed its commitment to the industrial relations package and, in fact, just after the election of the Kennett Government the Opposition's shadow spokesperson pointed out at the National Press Club that the Federal Liberal industrial relations policy was, to quote his words, `identical but for a few commas' with the Victorian Liberal Government's policy. At the same time as the Opposition is saying that workers should have no right to go to an umpire to settle their disputes, to have their wages and conditions determined; at the same time as the Opposition says that right should be withdrawn from all Australian workers; at the same time as its counterparts in Victoria seek to legislate to take away holiday leave loading, take away the loading paid for work out of normal hours, this Opposition has supported a situation in which corporate Australia has been profiteering during a period of great restraint by workers.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to a couple of examples where corporate Australia has clearly gone over the top. It is interesting to note that in some of these cases these same corporate giants are the very people who find some attraction in attacking the rights of workers to have holiday leave loading or to have recourse to an industrial commission. A couple of years ago, when Elders IXL was performing at the top of the charts, in 1988-89 the Elders IXL board decided that executive remuneration packages should be increased. The board increased them in that year—only three years ago now—by 23 per cent. Total director remuneration for the corporate giant, in fact, rose by 10 per cent. Shareholders were rewarded with a return that saw the operating profit of Elders IXL fall by 80 per cent during the same period.

Adsteam is another example in the same period where executive remunerations were totally out of kilter with performance and with what was going on generally in the economy. At a time when Adsteam's stock on the exchange fell to less than 8 per cent of what it had previously been worth, its highest executive fees rose by 57 per cent. So at the same time as it was virtually wiped off the share register there was an increase paid to its highest executives of some 57 per cent. Its top director took a 53 per cent rise in one single year, and that took the top director's salary from $790,000 to a meagre $1.2m. Adsteam's total executive remuneration package rose by 34 per cent.

All this occurred in a climate in which Australian workers, as part of the accord, were limiting their wage claims in the interest of Australia, to ensure that costs were contained and that inflation was able to be maintained not just at a level comparable with our trading partners but in fact at a level now lower than any of our significant trading partners. That sort of event has, regrettably, continued into current times. According to the latest preliminary information published by Cullen Egan Dell, who undertake regular surveys of this matter, in the year to September 1992 total remunerations for senior management rose by 5 per cent. In the last year, senior executives in this country have picked up another 5 per cent for themselves—at a time in which the CPI has grown by less than 1 per cent, at a time in which average weekly earnings have grown by only 3.1 per cent, and at a time when most of their workers, those people paid under awards, have had an increase of only 2.7 per cent. So in the last year, on the latest figures to September, we have corporate Australia taking unto itself double the rate of increase that is provided to its workers and now, championed by the Opposition in this place and by the newly elected Liberal Government in Victoria, seeking to take away some of those pre-existing rights and conditions which workers in Australia had enjoyed.

Long term executive remuneration growth in Australia still remains well above average earnings. Since March 1983, male average weekly earnings have risen by 75.2 per cent, while the base salary earnings for senior management have grown by 135 per cent. Again, executive salaries nearly doubled those of employees over a period of some years. True to its ideology and its concern for the rich, the Kennett Government has followed the same policy in practice. At the same time as it was abolishing annual leave loadings for State awards and ending penalty rates for evening and weekend work, it sought to increase ministerial salaries and, of course, returned the Parliament House dining room to the silver service arena.

Those sorts of duplicitous actions do not go unnoticed by ordinary workers in Australia, and they have not gone unnoticed by the people of Brisbane. Having shown tremendous and commendable restraint for nearly a decade now in their wages claims, to ensure that profitability was maintained and to ensure that inflation was kept at very low levels—historically low levels for Australia, and by international comparison—the people of Brisbane do not accept the situation where the workers have demonstrated such a commitment to our nation and such a degree of self-sacrifice but, at the same time, corporate Australia has had its nose in the trough as far it could bury it in. Some executives have taken so much out of companies, including ones that were going down the chute.

Corporate Australia had no qualms in taking 50 per cent increases in one year out of companies going down the chute. Opposition policy guarantees them the unfettered right to continue to do that at the expense of workers, so that future wage increases for the executives will be funded by reductions in salary and conditions for ordinary workers. That point was not lost on the Melbourne Age, which published an article in April this year under the heading `Recession-proof executives win 12.5% rise'—and that is about right: they think they are recession proof. The article opened by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The pay packets of Australia's most highly paid executives appeared to defy economic gravity last year, rising an average 12.5 per cent as corporate profits plunged and ordinary employees made do with an average increase of 3.1.per cent.

The Age understood it. At the same time as profits were going down, and workers' salaries were barely rising by 3 per cent, what did corporate Australia do? At the top end of town, in the Rolls and the BMW, the people who went off to celebrate the first anniversary of the GST—those people whom you rely upon for the fundamental basis of your support—were taking a 12 per cent increase. Of course, the Tandberg cartoon is not bad, either. It shows the executive addressing the office staff, and the executive says:
You will have to learn to cope with less.
As they walk off, heads bowed and forlorn, the executive, with a grin on his face and a little idea in his mind, says:
Just as I've learnt to cope with more.
That is the sort of Australia that the Opposition would have permeating the country, as part of its Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: It was sad to hear on the news, in the last 24 hours, yet another example of what seems to me to be thoroughly disgraceful actions on the part of executives and boards. Yesterday, I understand, Fairfax shareholders—and it is the shareholders who approved it, so I guess that the methods are correct, although I fail to understand the logic—approved the granting of a $1m dollar, interest free loan to one of the directors.

One has to wonder what the average employee of Fairfax must think about a company that is in difficulty, with workers whose jobs are threatened; workers who are told that they have to change their work habits and become more productive and multi-skilled, and that they have got to do it tough and tighten their belts. At the same time as they have got to do all those things, the old shareholders of Fairfax have said yesterday that they will give a $1m dollar, interest free loan to one of the directors. I repeat, a $1m, interest free loan.

I suspect that if someone waltzed up to a person in the street and said, `Here is a million dollars, interest free. We will make pretty satisfactory arrangements for the repayments', that person would take it. They would be a mug not to, I suppose. But workers do not get that opportunity, and it is duplicitous.

I believe it is high time this Parliament established an inquiry into the level of non-award remuneration in this country. It is time that we had a close look at the types of remuneration, the level of remuneration, and the extent to which productivity and performance are linked to those payments. The Parliament should establish that inquiry. It is about time we started to put an end to the snouts in the trough, ensure that shareholders get a fair return, and ensure that some equity is returned to this country so that the workers' pain is not in vain. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty years ago this nation faced its greatest crisis since the divisive conscription controversies of 1916 and 1917. As the ravages of the world depression engulfed Australia thousands were thrown out of work, evicted from their homes and driven from their farms. A small army of unemployed tramped the cities and the countryside in a humiliating quest for handouts and casual work. Many of the problems now facing Australia bear a striking resemblance to the dilemmas of the Great Depression. Yet, in contrast to the 1930s, there is no world depression. Australia's problems are the fault of the economic vandal, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). In particular, the entrenched structural barriers that have so hindered this nation for almost a century are now widely recognised as major impediments to the national development and a return to prosperity.

PARA.TAB: Australians, in seeking to insulate themselves from the rest of the world, have created a costly cocoon from which it is proving very difficult to escape. The concept of protection all round coupled with a pathological reliance on governments to regulate our lives and make decisions for us is not only unworkable, but will ultimately endanger the nation's living standards and its democratic way of life. Our cocoon will ultimately suffocate us all.

The assertion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that government can bring about economic growth is absolute nonsense, he knows that it is nonsense, and most members of the Government know it is nonsense. All the evidence of recent decades confirms that the best government is the least government. President Coolidge of the US asserted in the 1920s that the business of America was business. That is a philosophy that Australians could well learn from. Calvin Coolidge understood that it is individuals with ideas and energy who create the wealth which underpins a free and democratic society.

While there is no doubt that government has to act to remove the negatives in the business climate, the emphasis must be on allowing free enterprise to do what it does best: create employment opportunities and prosperity. In short, it is not the business of government to be in business. At the same time, however, business must be prepared to assume a much greater degree of moral responsibility for its corporate conduct. There is no doubt that the community is sickened by the appalling excesses of the 1980s, particularly the more blatant instances of individual greed and dishonesty. It is my belief that the unethical and on occasions criminal actions of a few have brought the legitimate business endeavours of many into considerable disrepute, much to the cost of the entire community.

In highlighting the barriers that we have placed in the way of prosperity it is important to recognise that it is the Prime Minister who is directly responsible for the recession we had to have, which is really the depression we did not want. No amount of self-righteous protestation, media lies or attempts to shift the blame to others will prevent his inevitable consignment to the dustbin of history. The bovver boy from Blaxland, the unelected Prime Minister who has thrown a million Australians out of work, is too much of a coward to introduce the structural changes so desperately needed.

When the economic vandal became Treasurer in 1983, Australia's economic problems were severe, and our debt was just $23 billion. Even then the Minister for Finance and great Labor man from Western Australia, Senator Peter Walsh, recognised the problem when he warned:

SPEECH.PARA: The state of our overseas current account is like the impending domestic deficit, one of the most serious problems confronting the new government.

Since then we have had J-curves, tax summits, accords, 16 economic statements, a warning about banana republics, record levels of government waste, cowardice in the face of union blackmail and the ultimate political cop-out: failure to control Labor's runaway debt in Victoria. By 1986, the foreign debt had reached $75 billion, and even the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, had to admit his failure:

If this Government cannot get the adjustments, get manufacturing going again and keep moderate wage outcomes and a sensible economic policy then Australia is basically done for. We will just end up being a third rate economy . . . a banana republic.

Six years later, indebtedness has risen to $160 billion, unemployment is at record levels and Australia is headed for Third World status. The world's greatest economic vandal should resign. The 1980s have exposed all the fundamental weaknesses of Australia, but the Australian Labor Party has done nothing.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately, the whole nation must pay for the outrageous excesses of WA Inc., the State Bank of South Australia, Tricontinental, the collapse of the Pyramid Building Society and Estate Mortgage, and the tragedy of the loss of the people's bank, the former State Bank of Victoria. This was the bank that survived wars and depressions. This was the bank that enabled ordinary families to buy a house and to finance a small business. This was the bank that encouraged thousands of school children to open accounts and begin saving. The State Bank of Victoria survived for well over a century, but it could not withstand the assault from the Prime Minister and the former Premier, Joan Kirner. What had been built up over a century was destroyed by the Labor barbarians in less than a decade.

The catastrophe of the State Bank, the slump in consumer confidence, the serious erosion of State revenue and the mass exodus of Victorians to other States are all problems that could have been easily avoided. They have become problems requiring such drastic solutions that more pain is being inflicted on the community. This is a dreadful situation. In their failure to govern in the interests of all Victorians, Cain and Kirner took the soft option of always borrowing more to cover bigger deficits, instead of reducing wasteful expenditure.

Moreover, throughout its entire period in office, Labor was quite unable to surmount its factional pressures, personal conflicts and domination by the Socialist Left unions—in particular by the Stalinist standover man, the de facto Premier, John Halfpenny. The accusing finger should particularly be pointed at the public sector unions which blackmailed the Government into deals that were overly generous in the so-called good times and which are unsustainably extravagant in hard times.

The results of this dreadful situation are being felt most severely in my electorate of Dunkley. In its laudable efforts to rescue basket-case Victoria from the hands of the receivers, spending cuts have been made in major areas of public spending. It is a tragedy that these cuts include Aspendale Technical School, a school which draws many of its students from my electorate. All those involved—the staff, the parents and the students—are devastated and angry, and so they should be. All this has been forced on the community by the desperate financial catastrophe that has bankrupt Victoria.

It is widely acknowledged that for many decades Victoria has been at the forefront of technical education. Its technical schools, and the dedicated professionals who work in them, have made a major contribution to the continued prosperity not simply of the State, but of the nation at large. The destruction of educational assets and the attack on the nation's intellectual property must be vehemently condemned.

I am glad the various communities are resisting the closure of many schools. They deserve and must have our support. Yet what is the response from the Prime Minister? The economic vandal and his socialist mates are entirely to blame, and yet their indifference to the situation is highlighted every day in this Parliament by the Prime Minister's personal attacks on the Opposition members, his total disregard for the proper processes of parliament and his overwhelming insensibility to the plight of the nation's one million unemployed.
J.H. Scullin, following his election as Prime Minister in 1929, was quick to recognise the enormity of the problems then facing Australians. In an address to this House in early 1930 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must face the position frankly . . . Employment is the barometer of prosperity, and production would be much increased if those who are now unemployed could be placed in useful work.

By any measure the Labor governments of the past decade have been an abject failure. Australia has the potential to regain its lost prosperity. It is one of the world's great democracies. Its people are tolerant and hardworking, and many of them have made major contributions in all fields of human endeavour. The sooner we rid the nation of the economic vandal, the better. I would like now to go over some of the quotes of some of his speeches. In 1983, from the economic vandal himself:
Obviously, the economic policies of the previous—
Fraser—
Government had failed to come to terms with Australia's deep-seated problems . . . 1983-84 holds the promise of considerable improvement and economic performance.
The foreign debt was $23 billion. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Many months ago the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford), and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) accompanied me on an inspection of a local manufacturing unit, RFW Truck Manufacturing, of Chester Hill.
—A good place it was, too.

—As the honourable member opposite commented, a very good operation. Last weekend's Sunday Telegraph detailed another stage in the remarkable career of Bob Whitehead and his company, RFW Truck Manufacturing. Bob, having learned engineering in the RAAF, came back to the Chester Hill-Granville area where he had grown up in a period when it was still possessed of dairy farms and other semi-rural industries. Today his firm is the only remaining company in the Southern Hemisphere that locally designs and manufactures all types of transport vehicles and equipment. At its Boundary Street site, it is Australia's lone integrated truck manufacturing operation. It is fair to say that Bob and I have many disagreements over politics, and we may have different analyses of some of his problems. However, we are in accord about the urgent need for a government purchasing policy that re-emphasises the encouragement of Australian firms in import replacement, the twin to export penetration.

PARA.TAB: In a period of 50 years RFW has provided its product to the mining industry, Qantas, varied railways, the electricity field, the Water Board and the armed forces. A central focus of the operation is a production of over 500,000 parts. These are often the salvation of Australian companies that have otherwise become entrapped in the vicious circle of inferior foreign products that are unable to handle Australia's peculiar conditions. This dependence on overseas suppliers often condemns local purchasers to high price—ransom—unsuitability, and notorious delays in obtaining replacement parts. A team of engineers, blacksmiths, fitters and turners and boilermakers fashion these parts on the site. In the interim they have witnessed the decay and disappearance of many firms that had acted as their own local suppliers.

In those decades, RFW has engineered an amazing collection of products. These include special purpose vehicles, all-wheel drives for heavy-duty operation, bus and coach chassis, electricity and council vehicles and garbage compacters—once again, these are all-wheel drive—and railway road-rail vehicles to run on multigauge rails, to name but a few. They are indeed a novel institution in this country. They perhaps had competitors once, but they have been wiped out in the interim.

I now turn to the specific instance of Mr Whitehead's problem, covered briefly in last weekend's paper. It noted that the Brisbane City Council was about to take delivery of the biggest sewerage suction truck in the world. This suction equipment had been built by the Swiss Kaiser Sewerage Cooperative, acknowledged as world leaders in its field. One would expect that as industry leaders it would recognise pre-eminence in others. Thus, it was on its advice that the Brisbane City Council chose the Sydney based RFW company to build a massive 14-wheel, $2m all-wheel drive truck necessary to carry the new equipment over all terrains.

This recognition does not surprise Bob Whitehead, irascible and brilliant engineer and general manager of the company that bears his initials. Bob knows trucks, and can reel off incident after incident where Australian made goods have proved superior to the most vaunted imported goods. He is an encyclopaedia in the field, and has an enthusiasm and determination that are inspiring. Recently he had a Unimog in his yard. It had broken a front spring. Mercedes Benz's most hopeful prediction was for $800 to give delivery of this part within eight weeks. What is supposed to happen to the company in the interim? In contrast, Bob had a local spring manufacturer make a couple very quickly, and had the vehicle back on the road within a week for the NSW Railways. `The local springs will out-perform the imported rubbish', growls Bob, `and they only cost $300 each'.

In another instance, the Civil Aviation Authority recently bought American airport fire trucks. Predictably, the Department never invited RFW tender. There are already problems with the brakes, which are hopelessly inadequate, and with the front axles, which are breaking. The sad fact of life is that the design quality is not there. Bob Whitehead knows that, when costed on a through-life basis, his products are much cheaper and create jobs in Australia for Australians. Each unit has an Australian material content in excess of 82 per cent and involves 3,000 to 5,000 man-hours.

Last year RFW lost out to Volvo in a contract for trucks in the Hunter Valley coal mines. These are big trucks; per unit, construction costs in the vicinity of $350,000. That did not stop Volvo slicing the cost to $165,000 per unit and naturally cornering the market. Last year Volvo lost millions of dollars in its Australian operations; this style of market penetration must be a factor. The Australian companies simply cannot afford to buy business like this: technically it is not called dumping.

It is interesting that a mine, Nova Coal, in the Hunter Valley has had 10 hours of work out of its Volvo in five months. If the down time cost were capitalised it would make the Australian vehicle appreciably better value. When the overseas manufactured vehicle is operational it will not last because it is built for highways such as we have never seen and not for Australian conditions.

The Stewart and Stevens airport tugs imported from the United States of America by Qantas are another example. RFW has recently had to rebuild the axles on two of them, as wheels fell completely off. Mercedes-ZF axles and transmissions of German origin are being used. One had a universal fail and it was a non-replaceable item, worth $3,600 from Germany. RFW manufactured new axles with replaceable universals for $3,500 each.

BHP, the Big Australian—I note that last evening the honourable member for Kalgoorlie quite correctly raised its very poor track record in this field—bought a Kenworth fully imported from Canada for its Peak Downs mine in Queensland. In the first month the vehicle broke its chassis. Since Kenworth would not honour any warranty and BHP would not pay for the repair, the Australian body builder had to cop the loss. From my own involvement in the Industry, Science and Technology Committee's inquiry into shipbuilding, this studied lack of interest in Australian manufacture is typified in BHP.

However, not all Australian companies are as narrow in their attitudes. ALCOA has always had difficulties with its ingot carriers at its Victorian refinery. The problem is that it uses German machines with hydraulic wheel motors and hydraulic motors do not like heat: the oil boils and they cease to operate. There was no mechanical drive available in the world able to stand up to the constant direction changing. ALCOA asked RFW to look at it and will shortly take delivery of Australian invented and built, mechanically driven equipment. I applaud ALCOA and wish that more Australian firms would follow its lead.

A drilling company in Australia that specialises in long rigs for deep reverse circulation drilling and other complicated and technically difficult wells is Walsh Drilling Brothers. It built its own equipment because it is seeking performance that is not commercially available. It purchased a secondhand six-by-six RFW as a support vehicle and was so impressed with it that when the company needed a carrier for its new large plant it had an eight-by-eight specially built by RFW. I understand the company has been very happy with the choice and I have had the opportunity to see correspondence between it and RFW with regard to its appreciation of the vehicle's performance. It drives like a car and it is earning its keep working in the sandhills around Oodnadatta where it often has to tow other vehicles as well as itself. There have been many offers to buy the rig for cash from envious Americans, but the Walshes say they are too busy to build another one.

We probably still have the best metalwork skills in the world, but unless we re-establish our manufacturing industry, our tool makers, die makers, instrument fitters, machinery and lathe skills, the skills will die out. What we need is a buy Australian ethos and a direction from government that its purchases, both civil and military, must be based on the concept of real through-life cost. Once this commonsense decision is taken, we will quickly see a real growth in manufacturing industry and a basis from which we can export.

In reality, there has to be a greater focus by the Government in its purchasing policies on actually looking at the overall cost of the downtime, the replacement cost and the delays occasioned to Australian industry by the need to obtain these parts from overseas. That, of course, has not been the reality up until now. This company is typical of many others, particularly in the manufacturing sector, that have gone to the wall, that have been sacrificed for the short term solution. I again commend RFW, a significant local employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a person travels through life, he meets up with many people and he is impressed by the work and the activities of certain people. Today, I would like to pay a tribute to the late Robert John Alison, CMG, of Dungog. The town of Dungog and the district are situated within my electorate of Lyne. Over the years I have known Mr Alison particularly well. He was born in 1910 and went to Dungog Primary School, East Maitland Boys High School and the Trinity School at Strathfield in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: After completing his education, he went on the farm as a grazier and a dairy farmer of Dungog. He later became a very great sportsman indeed, and he represented Australia at polo. He was also a prominent rugby union player. In his early days, he joined the Hunter River Lancers because he was interested in the defence of Australia and he was interested in horsemanship. He played a major role in the Lancers in those days, and I believe that they still exist today.

In 1941, he joined the services and became a major in the 2/16 Infantry Battalion. He served in New Guinea at Shaggy Ridge and Markham Valley. After that, he was transferred to the 7th Division, serving in Borneo for quite a period of time in a major role. It was there that he met his wife, Mary Chandler, a member of the Medical Women's Army Service. After the war they returned to Dungog to follow agriculture.

He is very prominently known as a man who served the community of Dungog, let alone the State and the Commonwealth. After returning from service, he was a founder of the Dungog RSL sub-branch. He always organised the Anzac Day commemorative services. He was a foundation member of Legacy and the President of Legacy. I believe he is the only patron of the Hunter Valley group of the Legacy organisation. At the time of his death late this year, Mr Alison was president of the Dungog Historical Society. I recently attended a function of the society to pay tribute to him. His widow and family were there.

I suppose Mr Alison can be best remembered for his service to agriculture. He was a man who loved stock, he loved the land, he loved the breeding of stock, he loved the production of the product, both of the beast and the soil, and he was interested in the manufacturing and the marketing of the dairy and beef industries.

He was a chairman of the Dungog Agricultural Society and his son, Dougal, was the chairman to follow him. He was always the chief dairy cattle steward at the Dungog Show. He was a keen follower of the Royal Agricultural Society and he was a steward of the beef section there for a 20-year period, which is a very outstanding period indeed. In 1946, he followed his father, who was a pioneer of the Dungog district, as Director of the Dungog Cooperative Dairy Society. In 1959, he was elected the chairman of the board, a situation that he occupied until 1981.

He was also a member of the Dairy Farmers Cooperative Ltd of New South Wales, which was a very large commercial group, representing and dealing with the products of most of the dairy farmers of New South Wales. He was elected a member of the board in 1946. In 1953 he was elected the deputy chairman and from 1962 to 1980 he was chairman of the company and the nine subsidiary companies associated with the Dairy Farmers Cooperative. This was a great responsibility because the cooperative was primarily responsible for the distribution of the liquid milk trade in Sydney and most of the State of New South Wales. He was also a member of the State and the Federal cooperative insurance boards and he occupied a position of chairman of each of those for quite a period of years.

I can recall, as a member of the New South Wales Parliament back in the late 1960s, the problems of the dairy industry. The Minister of the time appointed an advisory board to look at the problems of the marketing of liquid milk and of the sale of the manufactured product. Mr Alison was appointed as a member of the council to investigate the industry. They certainly gave an excellent report in relation to the condition of the industry at that stage and also to the future of the dairy industry in New South Wales. In about 1977 he was recognised by the Queen for the services that he gave, for his contribution to the community and to primary industries.

Besides being survived by his wife, Mary, he is also survived by five boys; there were no daughters in the family. Robert, his son, is the Usher of the Black Rod in the Senate chamber. His son, James, occupied the position of chairman of the Dairy Farmers Cooperative Society after the retirement of the father. In fact, Mr Alison left in his family the legacy of a group of people who were very interested in the welfare of the community of Dungog and the district generally.

I pay a tribute to Mrs Alison and the five sons for the way that they supported the husband and father over such a very long period of time. The late John Alison was not only a man who served Australia in time of need but also a person who served the community of Dungog. He loved the town of Dungog. He loved the community, as he loved his soil and his stock. If you went to Dungog today, which is a small country town, and spoke to citizens in the main street or anywhere, they would all have a good word to say about the late John Alison. He was a modest man; he was a personal man; he was a man who set a fine example to the citizens around him. He encouraged people to actually produce from the soil or from manufacture or from anywhere else. He was that type of a man. I knew him well because he was involved with the old Country Party for over a 50-year period. Naturally, I respect him for that.

I knew John Alison because of the advice that he gave to me on a number of occasions—sensible, practical advice that provided solutions to problems that we saw around the community that were difficult to find an answer to. John Alison was a person who could sum up the problems in a very few words; he could give you the answer and encourage you to go on.

I suppose that I shared with him a similarity so far as our past inheritance was concerned because he was fair of skin and I was fair of skin. I had to leave the farm because of the sun cancers on my skin. He always used to say to me, `Bruce, make sure that you wear a hat.' We always had a talk about a hat and he always asked me where my hat was. I fondly remember him because of that.

We pay a tribute in this chamber not only to those who have served here and who have now departed the scene but also to many others that we recognise within the community. There would not be a better person that we could pay a tribute to than the late Robert John Alison of Dungog.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a good time to pause, remember and recelebrate a great victory for Labor on 2 December 1972 when Gough Whitlam brought Labor in from the cold after 23 years.
—Did you see the program last night?

—It was an excellent program last night and it reminded me to come in here and tell the House some of the lessons from that time. I was a student at Monash University at the time and I remember attending some marvellous performances by Gough at the Springvale Town Hall and Festival Hall in Melbourne. I had joined the Party a little earlier that year, so it is 20 years now that I have been active in the Labor Party. I also recall that on 29 August of that year I turned 20, my birth date was drawn out of a hat and I became eligible to do national service and to be sent to Vietnam. I did not vote Labor simply because one of Gough Whitlam's first acts was to be to stop national service for Vietnam, but I was most grateful that Labor was elected to power in December 1972 and that I could avoid the terrible trauma that other young Australians went through.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy just three years later was that Gough and his team were thrown out in conspiratorial circumstances when for the entire three years the Senate numbers of the coalition were used against Gough's reforming agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —It blocked more Bills.

—More Bills, as Gough reminded us last night, were blocked by the Senate in that period than since 1901. I might say that more Bills were introduced and passed by the House of Representatives by Gough Whitlam's Government than by any other government in a similar period.

PARA.TAB: There are a couple of lessons that I take out of the Whitlam period. One is about the pace and the cost of reform. Reform needs to be introduced at a pace whereby people understand it, and one brings along the people. But that does not mean that one shirks that reform, and we certainly have not. It also means that one has to pay for those reforms. We are the only government since Federation to run surpluses of the Commonwealth Budget. We understand the need to spend at times on reform and at other times to save money. We should remember, of course, that Whitlam brought the Federal government into the mainstream of Australian life. It had been asleep for 23 years, it had not been used as a decent instrument of government, and what Gough did for us was to teach us the lesson of the importance of this chamber, this place, and the powers of the Commonwealth Government to make it a better nation.

A second lesson which I take is the whole concept of the social wage, which Gough told us about. Wealth is not just the income which people derive from work but the things that governments can deliver like Medicare and decent schools and hospitals. The problem that Gough ran into, and he reminded us of it again last night on the program, was that the trade union movement had not learnt the lesson, along with the political arm of the Australian labour movement. They were still pushing for higher wages. The Whitlam Government was unable to stop that wage push and convince people at that time that there were decent substitutions or additions to people's income via Medicare and increased spending on education and hospitals and so on. But that is a lesson that we have learnt. We introduced an accord between the trade union movement and this Government way back in 1982, such that we could marry two things together.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Bill Clinton is going to follow that.

—Yes, Bill Clinton, President-elect of the USA, has learnt that lesson. One can put together a package of government services that one gives to people and they need to understand that in fact that is an important part of their income.

PARA.TAB: The third element is that Gough first taught us the lesson about the importance of the rest of the world. Australia had been very narrow minded in the way that it approached the rest of the world; we had mainly been hiding behind the coat-tails of the United Kingdom. I guess it was Gough's diplomatic efforts which took us into the international arena which we now, in the last 10 years, have improved upon by taking us into the economic arena internationally. But I think we have really carried on a tradition that Gough Whitlam commenced. He opened us up really through the foreign affairs, through his ability as a diplomat and a national leader, and we followed on and improved that because we in the Labor Party have also learnt the very important lesson that we need to produce wealth as well as to learn how to distribute it.
