That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —This could be my last 90-second speech. I know that my rivals opposite would say, `Great', and that even my most attentive critic, Ian Warden, would say, `Thank God for that', but let me say that I have been here for 17 or 18 years and sometimes I do things that I am sorry for.
—Chook, chook!

—That was an anniversary too. I am a very loyal person but today it was said that I said certain things about the GST and about my Leader. No, I did not. I stand behind the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) 100 per cent. He does not have to give me a diplomatic job. I stand behind the GST 100 per cent because if that means getting rid of honourable members opposite I will be very pleased. There are a million unemployed. Poor people in my electorate are going broke left, right and centre. People cannot afford to pay their bills, including me, and a lot of others cannot afford to live. So, if it means getting rid of honourable members opposite, I stand by the Leader of the Opposition and the fellows who are trying to sell the GST as hard as they can. I stand behind the GST 100 per cent if it means, I repeat, getting rid of honourable members opposite. I finish up by saying that I hope I will be back to give more 90-second speeches in the future. (Time expired)

—Yesterday the High Court made two interesting decisions. First of all, it began the process of ethnic cleansing of the Australian political system and, secondly, it showed, as lawyers showed in 1975, that lawyers are quite capable of making politically strange decisions and destroying the political process. I want to put both of those things on the record. Firstly, I think that we now have a process of ethnic cleansing in place in Australia, and that is a shame, and the second thing is that they do show that they are not capable of reading the political system.

PARA.TAB: I also want to talk today about the AFL draft. The draft has two characteristics: it certainly does tend to recruit young boys who ought not be recruited into AFL teams and also it is really based in Victoria. The interesting thing with the accession to power of Jeffrey Kennett is that it will now be much easier to draft players into Western Australia and South Australia to escape Jeffrey Kennett. The West Coast Eagles now are the dominant power of AFL football. It is going to be so much easier to retain our position as players will be seeking to leave Victoria because of the depressed living standards and to come and join us in Western Australia and South Australia.

I do not think that Ross Oakley and the powers of the AFL had allowed for the Kennett factor but this will really disrupt the AFL draft and will now see players seeking to leave Victoria as economic refugees and come to Western Australia where they are very welcome. They can play in a good State, join a good team like the West Coast Eagles and certainly benefit from the economic circumstances in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legal decision on the Wills by-election has exposed an unfair and archaic absurdity regarding the question of office of profit and when the person is `chosen' to enter parliament. This should be resolved by referendum at the next election and I believe it would attract bipartisan support. The High Court judgment, however, has exposed a more far-reaching constitutional problem. It seems that Australian citizenship is not by itself sufficient qualification to stand for parliament. This creates two classes of citizenship in Australia. It affects the rights of millions of Australians born overseas and many of their children born in Australia. It has major overtones for policy on multiculturalism. It creates a situation where the constitution was written to preclude non-British subjects from holding office but now has underlined that being a British subject means disqualification. In effect, the various citizenship Acts redefining `foreign' may be unconstitutional. The ejection of Robert Wood from parliament may also have been unconstitutional. Race Commissioner Irene Moss has also pointed out the incompatibility of permitting one million British subjects to vote under current laws. What has been exposed is a national legal and cultural identity crisis which can only be resolved by a referendum. This case, together with the Mabo and freedom of speech judgments, has redefined the role of the High Court and raises the question of methods of appointment to that Court.

—People seeking public housing accommodation in the Townsville-Thuringowa region would have appalling prospects under the proposed public housing cutbacks that the Liberal and National parties would impose were they to win the next Federal election. The Queensland Treasury has issued an official analysis of the consumption tax package of the Liberal and National parties. That analysis shows that under a coalition government there would be an immediate cut of $25.4m in Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funds for Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The impact on people seeking to obtain public housing in Townsville and Thuringowa would be devastating. For the few still lucky enough to obtain public housing, despite all the odds, the goods and services tax of 15 per cent would then result in an additional slug to their expenses. All goods and services taxes charged on painting, repairs and maintenance to housing would be passed on to tenants through higher rents.

The Building Owners and Managers Association has expressed concern that the building and construction industry would be hard hit as a result of the plans of the Liberal and National parties. In view of the coalition's pledge to renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to redirect funds away from capital investment, this concern is well placed. The tragedy facing tenants in Townsville and Thuringowa cannot be underestimated. An already difficult situation would be made intolerable because of the drastic cutbacks under a Liberal-National government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a copy of a document called `Canberra report' which is published by the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and Senator Cook. It contains the tired old dogma about working conditions in New Zealand. It is notable that in this place no-one raises that any more because they have all read the New Zealand Statistician's report which shows that wages in New Zealand have gone up 1.3 per cent in real terms, while Australian wages have gone down by 0.5 per cent under this tired old system.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of my rising is to draw the attention of the electors of Canning to the fact that, to make their case reasonable, these people have had to readjust into Australian dollars the minimum wage paid to New Zealanders. A comparison of the newspaper advertisements for groceries in the two countries on the same day shows, for instance, that soft drinks in New Zealand are $1.05, while the Australian supermarket price is $1.15. Corned silverside in New Zealand is $NZ6.95, and in Australia it is $A6.97. In other words, New Zealanders buy with their dollar exactly the same amount of food as an Australian buys with his dollar. Why do these people practise a fraud on their constituents and try to suggest that wages in New Zealand are $175 per week when in fact they are $232? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I express my dismay at yesterday's High Court decision which has, in effect, resulted in the properly elected member for Wills being evicted from this chamber. Not only have the people of Wills been robbed of their elected representative, but the High Court decision has also disenfranchised millions of Australians from seeking election to Federal Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The High Court has held that, even though Mr Cleary was on unpaid leave from his job as a high school teacher, he was still technically holding an office of profit under the Crown and was thus ineligible to stand for the seat of Wills. Such a ruling could well lead to a situation as exists in America where only the very wealthy can run for office. People who have money can run, but a poor old school teacher must quit his job, have no security of tenure and, indeed, if he does not get elected then he will be unemployed. This is a most unsatisfactory situation.

The High Court went further and said that the other main candidates in Wills were also ineligible because, even though they were Australian citizens, they had not renounced their Greek and Swiss citizenships respectively. In a multicultural society such as Australia, a society of which we are justly proud, are we to deny such a large proportion of our population the right to seek elected office? Whilst the High Court may have been merely interpreting the Constitution, I believe that such a rigid interpretation could well lead to an elitist, unrepresentative parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some months ago the Port of Melbourne Authority paid out $1.6m to a young man who received permanent spinal injuries when he jumped off the Seaford pier in my electorate. The amount, I understand, was settled out of court and from what I have been told took no account of the young man's personal responsibility in the matter. Regretfully, he has permanent injuries which will be with him for the rest of his life. However, I understand from a man who helped recover the injured person from the water that he had been warned twice about the dangers involved and advised to desist.

PARA.TAB: There are two aspects to the matter. The first is the $1.6m worth of taxpayers' money paid out and the second is that the Port of Melbourne Authority now wants to demolish the pier to prevent further accidents. Where does individual responsibility begin and end? Why should a community be deprived of a facility because of one person's foolishness? Should we stop the trains because almost one suicide a week takes place in front of them? Do we ban multistorey buildings because people jump off those? Do we ban bridges because people jump off those? Do we go to the extreme of removing all the cliffs around Australia because people fall off those? Personal responsibility in these sorts of things has certainly got to come to a head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most interesting contests in the next Federal election will no doubt be in the electorate of Rankin where the former Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Mrs Sallyanne Atkinson, is attempting to restart her political career. She started to relaunch her career by fronting up in the working class suburb of Inala wearing a tracksuit to try to appeal to ordinary working people, and this tack of trying to show that she is an ordinary person has continued. As reported in the Queensland Times, a local newspaper in that electorate, in an address to the Boonah Golf Club, she continued on the same theme. After attacking some industrial relations policies, she went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Have you noticed that when you get on an aeroplane, ordinary folks like us are at the back and the trade union leaders and their followers are up the front?

This was treated with a certain amount of scepticism because the electors of Rankin might recall that when Sallyanne was Lord Mayor of Brisbane she had no fewer than 37 domestic trips and some 17 overseas trips. Interestingly enough, economy class did not feature highly in the Lord Mayor's flying. In fact, all of it was either business class or first class. Of course, it does not quite end there. There is further evidence to suggest that Mrs Atkinson's new found affinity with the working class residents of Inala and Darra is definitely one-sided. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the New South Wales Country Manufacturers Association met at Parliament House, Sydney. One of the actual decisions that it made was to request the political parties in this Parliament to have a ministry for manufacturing. I strongly support the move it has made, for particular reasons. One is that this country is badly in need of more manufacturing. I heard the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) speak of this today and I fully support it. Here is a country with all the natural resources that a nation can have. Our people have the brains, we have the ability, and yet we are not value adding to many of the rural and the mineral resources that we have. When you can go into the supermarkets and buy products from overseas and know that we have them here produced in the raw material stage, it is time that we woke up to this and did something about it.

PARA.TAB: There is a feeling throughout Australia that we really should not be a manufacturing country. When there are a million unemployed people who are walking the streets of the towns and cities of Australia, surely it is time that we gave greater attention, at both the Federal and the State level, to manufacturing in this great country of ours. Why should industries be moving offshore when we can establish them here, value add and sell the product here? I say that our Country Manufacturers Association needs a lot of support in this. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. In the words of the Prime Minister, the abolition of payroll tax would create 200,000 jobs. With one million unemployed, why do you not abolish payroll tax as a Christmas present to those thrown out of work by your recession?
—The Opposition has made much of this question of payroll tax, overlooking the fact that it is a State tax imposed by State governments—
—The States have agreed to let it go.
—Order!
—and overlooking the fact that it is not a tax paid by many small businesses in any event.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—Much of the benefits which the Opposition claims for the abolition of payroll tax must be taken with a grain of salt at least.
—So it is a good tax.
—Order!

—But there is another proposition around; that is, to impose a GST. A GST is a tax on the value added during the process between manufacture and sale. The way in which value is added is, at least in large part, by labour. The Opposition is imposing a $20 billion tax on the business community in respect of the cost of labour; this is what is being taxed. What the Opposition is taxing—
—You know that is not true.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—in a manufacturing enterprise is the value which comes from the application of labour to the raw materials which are then converted into manufactured goods. So this is clearly a tax which is imposed on the labour used within a manufacturing process, or indeed within the process of providing and selling a service to the community.
—You are wrong.
—Order! The honourable member for La Trobe will cease interjecting from out of his place.
—It is even more of a problem in relation to the services sector which at the moment is largely devoid of wholesale sales tax, yet this is a new tax—
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Minister for Immigration will resume his seat.
—on the provision of services and, after all, services are substantially provided by people doing things for other people. So this is unambiguously a tax on value adding. I did notice—
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.
—I am not interjecting!
—If the honourable member for O'Connor interjects again, I will deal with him.
—He was talking to us. He was not talking to you.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting as well.

—This is a matter which is apparently in some dispute on the Opposition side because the Deputy Leader of the National Party put out a press statement which was intended to take issue with my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Mr Lloyd accused the Minister of deliberately misleading Parliament by saying that the GST was a tax on value adding. Of course, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was absolutely right, and his authority, apart from anywhere else, comes from Fightback itself. What does Fightback say? Under the heading, `What is a goods and services tax?', it says that `a goods and services tax is a tax charged on the supply of goods and services in Australia. It is a "value added" tax levied at all stages of production and distribution'.

PARA.TAB: Once again, we have the Opposition engaged in a campaign of deception and deceit, trying to mislead the people of Australia about the real impact of a GST which, unambiguously, is a tax on the provision of labour. This will impact most seriously on those smallest businesses which at the moment—
Opposition members—Wrong! Wrong!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—are not exposed to a tax of that kind but, under the Opposition's plans, of course will be with critical effects on employment in Australia.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister.
—Ask him about Warren Andersen.
—I beg your pardon.
—Order! The honourable member will get to her question quickly.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of proposals to change the health system by abolishing bulkbilling and encouraging private insurance? Does the Government intend to adopt any of these proposals, and can the Prime Minister advise the House of the effect of such changes on health costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that the Opposition plans to abolish bulkbilling for the vast majority of Australians—about 80 per cent—and to introduce subsidies and penalties to coerce people into private health insurance. The Government supports bulkbilling and the free treatment of public patients in public hospitals. We also believe that people should have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals, supported by private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: But the Opposition's proposal would be radically different and would thoroughly dismantle Medicare. It is crucial that these proposals are examined thoroughly. Dr John Deeble, a senior research fellow at the Australian National University, has published a paper. He has done a thorough and objective analysis of the health proposals in Fightback. Dr Deeble has excellent credentials to undertake this research. He has worked for both Labor and coalition governments in the health department over a 25-year period. His conclusions are:

ANSWER.PARA: On quite conservative assumptions, the additional medical and hospital costs of Fightback would be at least $1.42 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—Who would gain from the increase? According to Dr Deeble more than $1 billion of the $1.42 billion would go to doctors. He says that doctors' incomes, on a conservative estimate, would increase on average by 60 per cent.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—These increases would be paid for overwhelmingly by individuals through out-of-pocket payments and higher insurance premiums. This, he says, is according to conservative assumptions. Under some assumptions, he says that doctors' incomes would double. As he points out, Fightback would give the doctors everything they have sought over the past century. There would be no limit on the fees they charged. Under Opposition policy, it will be a case of `while we take your temperature we will take your wallet with it'.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Dr Deeble asked: why would the Opposition propose such a policy? He asked, `What possible grounds could there be for such largess to the doctors?'. His conclusions are:

ANSWER.PARA: It is hard to see that it is other than a blatant rewarding of political support, which sits ill within a policy portrayed as based on rationality, efficiency and elimination of restrictive practice gains.

Basically, $1.42 billion will be paid by the public, $1 billion of which he says conservatively will go to doctors which will increase doctors' incomes, on average, by 60 per cent. Dr Deeble asks: what is the point of the policy? Even if the coalition within their frame of reference is talking about efficiency and eliminating restrictive practice gains, why would they pursue a policy which hands out so much largess to doctors with such an increase which could not be defended on income grounds anywhere in the country?

PARA.TAB: That contrasts with what they are doing to nurses in Victoria. I noticed a report in the Age of one nurse, a single mother, who says that she will lose two-thirds of her wages as a nurse under Mr Kennett's policies—that is, the policies the honourable member for Bennelong says he agrees with on the basis—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on the matter of relevance. The Prime Minister was asked to report on Medicare. —My question follows the question from the Leader of the Opposition on tax. Can the Treasurer explain to the House the technical meaning of the term `tax cascading'? Is Australia's wholesale sales tax more subject or less subject to tax cascading effects than alternative forms of taxes? Finally, can the Treasurer provide details of any expert studies which are currently under way on this issue?
—First of all—

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.
—unlike yesterday, tax cascading has nothing to do with taxing water.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was a serious question which deserves a serious reply.
—Order!

—It refers to the situation where a particular tax is imposed at one stage in the production or distribution of a good or a service and then the same tax is imposed again at a subsequent stage in such a way that the tax is levied on top of the same tax. Tax cascading is a particularly unattractive feature of certain types of business turnover taxes that have been used in some countries in the past.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Just hang on a sec; the laugh will be on the other side of your face in a moment, Peter.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—In principle, there are two avenues for dealing with the tax cascading issue: one is to have a tax which is a single stage tax and to exempt from that tax any goods and services which pass through the taxing point elsewhere; the second is to have a multistage tax with a comprehensive system of rebates for tax already paid at the preceding stage.

PARA.TAB: Our existing wholesale sales tax system takes the first approach. A goods and services tax, of course, attempts to take the second avenue. Opposition members have frequently extolled the virtues of their own proposals as being ones which eliminate the effect of tax cascading.

The problem with the Opposition's proposal is that it is not comprehensive in the way in which it provides for rebates for business inputs. Let me give a couple of examples. Banks and insurance companies would pay GST on the goods and services they use, and this money is not to be rebated.
Opposition members—Boring! Boring!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—So when other business enterprises pay their bank charges and their insurance bills and then charge GST on their sales, you get GST on top of GST; in other words, tax cascading. Similarly, when builders of shops, tourist hotels and factories have to pay GST on the goods and services they use—and this money is not rebated—then the users of those businesses charge GST to their customers, and again you get GST on GST, and again you get tax cascading.

PARA.TAB: Even those people who are punters, those people who go to the TAB, will not be spared. TABs will pay GST on the goods and services they use, and it will not be rebated. When the TABs pass on a share of their profits to racing clubs, the GST will be paid on that money. So, similarly, there is a cascading effect. Of course, it would apply to those businesses small enough to be outside the GST registration system. This is a serious defect in the Opposition's GST proposals—
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—This defect is so serious that the Opposition established the Cole committee in order to investigate these matters. The banking industry has expressed its concern and the commercial building industry has expressed its concern. But they have been told to take their concerns to the Cole committee, which has turned out to be a big black hole into which all these concerns can be dropped and then forgotten. If the Opposition is serious about the Cole committee, it has to tell us when it will report and has to undertake to publish the report prior to the next election. Otherwise we are entitled to think, and those who are concerned about these taxes have every right to think, that it is simply a politically inspired device to put to one side the legitimate concerns relating to these matters.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—It is time the Leader of the Opposition came clean; time he told us what the answers to some of these questions are. The banks are concerned, the insurance companies are concerned and the building industry is concerned—and well they may be, because the effect of this proposal will be to tax these industries in a way which will ensure there is an additional burden imposed upon their clients.
—I call the honourable member for Burke.
—Mr Speaker—
—He was standing right beside you.
—Order! The House will come to order! If the honourable member for Bradfield stood and sought the call, I will give him the call.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister provide evidence to confirm the effectiveness of the Government's labour market programs and the level of support for these programs among community representatives? Is the Government aware of any proposals for alternative labour market programs? In the light of these, does the Government intend to make any changes to its present approach?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, and I am happy to answer the various components of it. The position of the Government's labour market programs is that they fall into four broad groups: training to improve skill levels; wage subsidies to provide incentives to employers; work experience coupled with training; and focus programs to help people with disadvantages. We did a study in my Department in the middle of 1991 and we discovered that people who had been unemployed for a period of some 12 months or more had a statistical chance of getting themselves into an unsubsidised job, from being in that situation in the work force, of about 3 per cent. If they were able to pick up one of these labour market programs, it improved their chances sevenfold.

PARA.TAB: The figures have changed since then. The chances now are eight times greater for people who are long term unemployed who find themselves in this situation. If the long term unemployed pick up the Jobstart job subsidy, their chances improve to something like 16 per cent. Of course, it is very important to remember that all of these programs are operated through the CES. There are alternative programs around in the community, and the Opposition has made suggestions on some, as to what ought to be done about this. The Fightback proposal contains a suggestion that we ought to cut $700m off these programs. There is an extra $1.2 billion in the Budget for these programs, and that is incorporated in the claims of the Leader of the Opposition that $7 billion ought to be cut off the Budget, identifying the new areas of expenditure as the areas from which they ought to go, cutting down support for these places from some 400,000 to 200,000.

What everybody in this Parliament knows is this: whoever is elected to office at the next election—and we believe it will be us—will be dealing with a situation of those in long term unemployment, some 350,000 of them, for several years at least. Nobody has put up a program here in this Parliament—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we have.
—No, you have not. You have not put up a program to deal with the position of the long term unemployed—and you have admitted it—
—Too right we have!
—Order!
—Too right we have!
—and so has your spokesman, the honourable member for Bennelong.
—Absolutely dead wrong!
—Order!

—The problem for the members of the Opposition is that they know that, when they confront this, they confront a reality that they cannot evade, and therefore they try to conceal the true effect of their policies. They know that within 18 months of being elected to office, if they are going to deliver the changes on the income tax side that they want to enable them to skate through with their 15 per cent consumption tax, they must get that $1.9 billion worth of savings out of labour market programs. They know it, and they know that the consequences of that are ruination for people in that position or non-delivery of the tax cuts. It is a simple alternative and they know it. Therefore, we find an interesting situation where spokespeople for the Opposition, when they believe that they are out of the kin of certainly the people upstairs behind me and into the regional press, say other things. The honourable member for McEwen, when asked to comment on exactly which one of these labour market programs that would be cut, said, `Obviously we need programs like this. I support this program because it is giving these people a chance to get back into the work force'.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The proposition of the Opposition is that CES offices will be rolled into Department of Social Security offices and the job brokerage functions farmed out and these other labour market program functions abolished.

PARA.TAB: The problem that you have in dealing with that problem in rural areas is this: CES offices exist in far larger numbers than do Department of Social Security offices. By and large in rural areas with that proposition there would be nowhere for them to go. That is why I identified your comments on the rural areas because, when you say that the CES offices in rural areas will pick it up, you are in fact under your own policy proposals talking nonsense. There are no DSS offices there to deal with the problem.

Those were comments from two Opposition frontbenchers. Then we had the position recently of Senator O'Chee from the Senate, who is not a frontbencher but who likes to imagine himself as one. Responding to the honourable member for Richmond, who recently talked about the Opposition's proposals for phasing out funding for Skillshare, Senator O'Chee said that that was not the Opposition's proposal. He quoted from a section of Fightback which states, `The coalition will build on the Skillshare program'. He said that to identify his position. What he forgot, unfortunately, was page 39 of Fightback where it states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . there will be an increasing requirement over the decade for Skillshare groups to become self-sufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Kim. Hurry up!
—Order!
—Order! There is far too much noise.
—The point of the three quotes is that—
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson!

—when the Opposition comes to confront reality, it does in many ways understand it. It does in many ways understand that, if you are going to get a chance to get your long term unemployed into the work force, you need a labour market to assist you; it does know that, if you are unemployed and you are going to protect yourself, you need the CES to assist you; it does know that Skillshare is a remarkably successful program. It knows all these things and, when it appears at all these bodies, it says that it knows those things and that it comprehends them.

PARA.TAB: What it does not know is how you deal with the problem when, within 18 months of assuming office, all these things have to be cut by at least $1.9 billion if you are going to deliver your tax cuts. If you do do that, that is fine. But we ought to know about it because it means that the tax cuts will not be delivered and, if they are not delivered, the promise to reduce what you regard as the massive overspend in outlays cannot be delivered. The problem is that you are now locked into an undeliverable straitjacket, the only element of which that is in any way reliable, the only element of which you have never actually retracted in your public statements when individual items like water come up for discussion, is a 15 per cent goods and services tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the comments of Ross Garnaut recently who said, when asked about the relevance of short term stimulatory policy:

QUESTION.PARA: I think if you pump up domestic demand, a bit more Government expenditure—that's an illusion. That slows down the fundamental structural changes that'll end up delivering more good jobs at high prices.
I ask the Treasurer: why is he deliberately slowing down the structural change which will deliver more good jobs at high incomes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to have the Opposition quoting from Dr Garnaut. Dr Garnaut said, of course, that it was the nature of the stimulus that was important, and that is something with which the Government totally agrees. That is why the stimulus that we are providing has two crucial attributes: one is that it is not consumption expenditure; overwhelmingly it is expenditure designed to improve the efficiency of the economy. That is why the expenditure is going into the rail system—
—Why are you taking money away from the railways?
—Order! There is far too much noise.

—and that is why it is going into the road system, the ports and so on. The funds are being provided to ensure that the transportation system generally will be improved, with very considerable flow-on benefits to all of those industries which use the transport system.

PARA.TAB: The other crucial attribute of our stimulus is that it is temporary in nature. We are providing a stimulus now which will wind out of the Budget, thus returning the Budget to balance and to surplus in later years. This is an entirely responsible use of a stimulus. It is something—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what a joke!
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—which any country which had the capacity to do so would use. We recently had the major committee of the OECD reflecting on what should be the appropriate fiscal policy stance of the developed countries. Essentially it said two things: first of all, you should not try to artificially reduce government expenditure at a time of lower activity in the economy; and, secondly, those countries which had the capacity to provide a fiscal stimulus should do so.

PARA.TAB: Australia happens to be one of the few countries in the happy position of being able, responsibly, to provide a fiscal stimulus, simply because of the way in which we repaired our Budget during the late eighties in a way in which many other countries failed to. If you were to graft the US fiscal deficit onto Australia, the deficit here would be over $20 billion. Similarly, if you were to graft the UK deficit onto Australia, it would be over $20 billion, and that is without providing the kind of temporary stimulus which we have been able to provide to our economy.

The Opposition can draw no comfort from any respectable commentator around Australia because no-one would be so irresponsible or so absurd to suggest that the Australian economy in its current state could stand a reduction of $6 billion or $7 billion in the size of Budget expenditure, which is what the Opposition is proposing. Everyone knows that that kind of policy would simply stop the economy in its tracks and send it backwards, escalating enormously the number of people out of work. Mr Speaker, you do not have to look very far to find critical commentary about the proposals of the Opposition. I refer—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are having trouble. Keep looking!
—Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members on my left!

—I refer to what the Leader of the Opposition said just a year ago. When asked about the unemployment question he said, `I am not making any promises about the level of unemployment. There will be transition effects'. That is code for: he is not making any promises about unemployment because it will go up, not down, as a result of the Opposition's policies.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what Mr Gittins had to say recently. He made this observation about the Leader of the Opposition. In talking about micro-economic reform, which was the subject matter of the honourable member's question, he said:

Dr Hewson is trying to conceal from voters that most micro reform is like an investment: short-term costs in return for long-term benefits. That's particularly true of tariff cuts and the reform of government business (particularly if the reform is made at a time when demand is weak).

It's about releasing resources from inefficient uses in the belief that they will shift to their most efficient use. Which is an economist's way of saying that the initial effect of much micro reform is to increase unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: He goes on to say, `This is the measure of Dr Hewson's dishonesty'. In other words, the dishonesty of the Leader of the Opposition is in a claim of increased employment when he is really talking about the opposite. Of course, this is doubly true of the taxation measures which the Opposition has in mind.

PARA.TAB: Micro-economic reform continues to be a serious primary objective of the Government. But there is a way to do it and a way not to do it. There is the way of ensuring that micro reform is embraced by those people who have to adjust to it, and there is the other way of pointing guns at people's heads. We have chosen the former way. We have sought the optimal pace of micro reform so that we have seen dramatic improvements across a range of industries which have actually been embraced by those industries and those people who work in them.

There is another way; it is the Kennett way and the Liberal way. That is the way of simply ensuring that everyone is offside. No-one embraces the idea of micro-reform; in fact, they try to resist it. That is reform Liberal style. That is the type of reform which is destined to fail. That is why we have pursued micro-economic reform at a pace which is breathtaking in terms of anything we have seen in Australia in the past.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—But, nevertheless, it is manageable in terms of the ability of the economy to digest it and in terms of the workers who are affected directly embracing the ideas as being in their interests as well as in the interests of the nation as a whole.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. As the Government has now announced round 3 approval for the local capital works program, can the Minister provide details of local governments' response to the program? Will the Government continue to work in partnership with local government?

—I thank the honourable member for Oxley for his question. I am delighted to be able to tell the House that local government Australia-wide has responded absolutely magnificently to this program, as this Government knew it would.
—Yes, why wouldn't they?
—Order! The honourable member for Bass! The House will come to order.

—The program was a response by the Government to local governments' offer to assist in getting economic activity moving at the local level. In fact, during this program some 410 councils Australia-wide have participated in a $345m infrastructure program. Unfortunately, most of those communities have been affected by high levels of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—One of the major consequences of this particular program is to lift the community's confidence in those local areas. We will see this coming through over the next few months as more than 2,000 projects come on stream with this program. Last Thursday in Brisbane, in conjunction with the new President of the Australian Local Government Association, Alderman Peter Woods, the Queensland President of the Local Government Association, Councillor Jim Pennel, and a number of my parliamentary colleagues, I announced that we had approved the third round. I am pleased to say that within three months of the Budget being brought down 99 per cent of the $345m worth of program funds had been approved.

INTERJECT.PARA: Re: Petition to the Court of Disputed Returns in respect of the by-election for the Electoral Division of Wills

I wish to advise that pursuant to the provisions of s 369 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, I am enclosing herewith a copy of the order of the Court of Disputed Returns made this day in Melbourne, declaring that the by-election held on 11 April 1992 to elect the member of the Commonwealth House of Representatives for the Electoral Division of Wills was absolutely void.
I am also enclosing a copy of the reasons for judgment of the Full Court for your information.
IN THE HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA
SITTING AS THE COURT OF DISPUTED RETURNSNo. M25 of 1992
IN THE MATTER of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918
IN THE MATTER of the Election of one member of the House of Representatives for the DIVISION OF WILLS in the Commonwealth of Australia

THIS PETITION addressed to the Court of Disputed Returns having been filed on 28th May 1992 and a case having been stated and questions having been reserved pursuant to S.18 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth.) for the consideration of a Full Court AND the Case Stated having come on for hearing before a Full Court comprising Chief Justice Mason, Justice Brennan, Justice Deane, Justice Dawson, Justice Toohey, Justice Gaudron and Justice McHugh on 26th and 27th August 1992 AND THAT COURT UPON READING the Case Stated filed herein AND UPON HEARING Mr J.I. Fajgenbaum one of Her Majesty's Counsel for the petitioner, Mr S.P. Charles one of Her Majesty's Counsel for the first respondent, Mr K.H. Bell of Counsel for the third respondent, Mr D.J. Rose one of Her Majesty's Counsel for the fifth respondent and Mr G. Griffith one of Her Majesty's Counsel, Solicitor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia for the Attorney-General for the Commonwealth of Australia intervening DID ORDER on the 27th August 1992 that the said Case Stated should stand for judgment and the same standing for judgment on 25th November 1992 at Canberra THAT COURT DID ORDER that the questions reserved in the Case Stated be answered as follows:

PARA.TAB: Was the first respondent duly elected at the Election?
If no to (a), was the Election absolutely void?
If no to (b), was any and which candidate duly elected who was not returned as elected?

INTERJECT.PARA: Answer: By consent there should be no order for costs.

AND THIS PETITION coming before this Court this day at Melbourne for the making of orders in accordance with the answers of the Full Court IT IS DECLARED that the by-election held on 11th April 1992 to elect the member of the Commonwealth House of Representatives for the Electoral Division of Wills was absolutely void AND IT IS ORDERED that the security for costs paid by the petitioner in accordance with S.356 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Cth.) be refunded to the petitioner Ian Grant Sykes AND IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that liberty be reserved to each party to apply within seven day upon forty-eight hours notice to the other parties AND IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that there be no order as to costs.
IN THE HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operation of Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act

TALKER.NAME: Mr GRIFFITHS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, pursuant to part 7 of the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991, I present the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. I seek leave to make a statement on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax and the enhancements to the PRRT introduced in the August 1990 Budget were integral components of what has become a decade of micro-economic reform undertaken by the Government in the petroleum industry.

PARA.TAB: On taking office in 1983, Labor found a petroleum industry subject to heavy government control, and where uncertainty was undermining an industry already possessing a high degree of natural risk. Moreover, in 1983 the outlook for Australia's continuing to supply a high proportion of its oil needs from its own production ranged from uncertain to poor.

In the early 1980s the then Bureau of Mineral Resources indicated that the domestic production of crude oil, condensate and naturally occurring LPG from existing and planned new developments would increase to 1985, but then decline. In the absence of substantial new discoveries, the reports indicated that Australia's level of self-sufficiency would fall to somewhere about 30 per cent by the mid-1990s. These reports emphasised that new discoveries and developments would be essential in the forecast period if Australia's level of self-sufficiency was to be maintained at the level then prevailing, some 66 per cent.

The Government addressed this challenge through a comprehensive program of fundamental reforms designed to encourage a vigorous, dynamic and competitive petroleum industry. The Government's program of reform to date has included deregulation of the oil and liquefied petroleum gas markets, implementation of an offshore exploration strategy to facilitate the development of Australia's petroleum resources, fundamental change to secondary taxation regimes, and the development of a national gas strategy.

As a consequence of the Government's policy reform agenda, the gloomy picture foreseen by earlier forecasters has not emerged. The policy environment in which the industry operates has been changed beyond recognition; the industry has, simply put, been revitalised.

Real oil prices today are lower than they were following the first oil shock in 1974. Despite this, Australia has fared well in terms of investment in exploration and development in our offshore waters. Self-sufficiency currently stands at around 85 per cent. Furthermore, we can be optimistic about future prospects. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in its latest forecasts, noted that there was an excellent chance that oil production could be maintained at current levels or even increased, up to and beyond the year 2000.
The Government has overhauled the industry, and the results are there to be seen. The PRRT is an integral part of that reform program.

The requirement to report on the operation of the PRRT Act arose out of the legislation that implemented the 1990 Budget reforms to the PRRT. These reforms extended the PRRT to Bass Strait. They also introduced company-wide deductibility for exploration expenditure in all PRRT areas.
The PRRT is an efficient tax. Unlike other secondary taxes, it is levied only on the net income of a profitable project. It does not adversely affect production in times of changing prices and costs.

Moreover, the PRRT provides a reasonable balance between providing the private sector with adequate returns for the risks it takes in investing in petroleum exploration and development, and providing the community with a fair return on the use of its non-renewable resources.

The decision in 1990 to extend the PRRT to the Bass Strait project was the outcome of an intensive review brought forward by the Government in the light of industry concerns evident at the time. The excise and royalty regime, which the PRRT replaced, had become too inflexible to adapt to changing market conditions. Frequent variations had become necessary, with the result that the regime was complicated and distorted investment and production decisions. The Bass Strait producers argued that they could invest a further $1 billion to $1.5 billion to extract an additional 200 to 300 million barrels of oil if the petroleum taxation arrangements were reformed. The impact of the tax changes is clear—the Bass Strait project has been rejuvenated.

New developments currently under consideration include the construction of two new platforms at a combined cost of $650m to extract a further 85 million barrels of oil. Two other fields, containing a combined total of 16 million barrels, are also expected to become viable under the PRRT. Major infill drilling and workover programs on existing platforms are currently estimated to add 150 million barrels of economically recoverable oil. Exploration activity has also surged, with big increases in both seismic surveying and exploration wells.

It is clear that the fundamental impediments to further development identified by the Bass Strait producers have been removed. Furthermore, it is clear that the move to PRRT has avoided the situation where some production was stopped at low oil prices, because of the distorting tax regime then obtaining.

The wider impact of the PRRT reforms also needs to be considered. Australia's offshore areas are only lightly explored. To ensure that the full potential of our resources is realised, we must create an environment that facilitates efficient exploration. The introduction in 1990 of company-wide deductibility for exploration expenditures against the PRRT removed a significant impediment to efficient offshore petroleum exploration. The reforms mean that new exploration decisions are driven by prospectivity and technical factors rather than by distortions in the taxation arrangements. While it is too soon to fully assess the impact of this amendment to the PRRT, the signs are all positive.

The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association has reported that wider deductibility appears to be diversifying exploration activity among its members. Increased holdings of offshore acreage by local and international companies indicate that funds that may once have gone to areas abroad have been redirected to Australia and activity in offshore frontier areas has remained very encouraging.

Some industry submissions to the report raised concerns about the effect of the 1990 reforms on natural gas developments. I should say that copies of those papers are available from my office. One concern was the reduction in the premium on the carry forward rate for general project expenditure from 15 to 5 percentage points above the Commonwealth long term bond rate. It was argued that the reduced premium would impede the development of commercial gas projects.

The reduction in the premium reflected the significant benefits to industry that derived from the introduction of company-wide deductibility for exploration, and the relative risks of the different stages of a petroleum project. The carry forward rates and the tax rate for the PRRT are part of a balanced and integrated package that includes wider deductibility for exploration expenditures. To preserve the community return, any adjustment in the carry forward rate for general expenditure would require a corresponding adjustment elsewhere. The issue raised has been carefully examined, and there is no evidence that the current provisions are impacting adversely on developments. Therefore, changes will not be made to the carry forward provisions.

I will now turn to the concerns raised in connection with the impact of the PRRT on gas prices. Some submissions argued that the PRRT will directly impact on Victorian gas and ethane users with a consequential adverse impact on industry and employment. Requests for change were made in submissions by both the producers and their gas and ethane customers. The Bass Strait producers asked that gas and ethane revenues from the Bass Strait project be singled out for a specially reduced rate of taxation. The Government is not prepared to accept this suggestion. The PRRT is a project tax, not a product tax. A change of this kind would reintroduce the type of taxation distortions on investment that characterised the former excise and royalty regime. The producers' request also ignores the windfall reduction in secondary tax that they received in the early years of the PRRT. It would undermine the legitimate community return from the project.

Users of natural gas and ethane asked the Government to regulate in some way the price of gas products from Bass Strait to ensure that the producers were not including a PRRT component. In this regard, it is worth highlighting that a number of factors intervene to determine gas prices to the consumer.

First, I want to reiterate that the PRRT is a project tax, not a product tax, and again note the windfall gain in reduced secondary taxation in the early years of the PRRT received by the Bass Strait producers. Second, prices for gas and ethane are negotiated by the parties involved consistent with normal commercial practice. Whether PRRT falls under the definition of costs that can be passed on is currently being decided by legal interpretation of the existing contracts and by arbitration.

Consistent with normal commercial practice, the Government would expect that once the legal standing of the contracts has been decided negotiations will commence in regard to what amount, if any, of the PRRT will be passed on. These matters are best determined by the parties concerned and are currently being resolved by contractual arbitration and negotiation.

A further factor relevant to natural gas prices in Victoria is the Victorian Government's public authority contribution charge on the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria. In the 1990-91 financial year the contribution amounted to $242m. In 1991-92 it was $265m. The Victorian Government has the option of varying this charge, which is three to four times the figures being discussed in relation to the PRRT.

One can observe that, in the absence of these charges, Victoria would have by far the cheapest gas in Australia, with an indicative city gate price for 1990-91 at Melbourne of 87c per gigajoule, compared with $2.40 per gigajoule in Adelaide and $2.85 in Sydney, based on figures from the Australian Gas Association. One can also observe that the Kennett Government has shown no compunction in raising Victoria's domestic gas prices by some 10 per cent since assuming office some weeks ago.

In the light of these factors, the argument that the application of PRRT will be disruptive to end users of natural gas and ethane cannot, in the Government's view, be sustained. It is clear that there is no direct link between the PRRT and the price of natural gas and ethane to the consumer. Nevertheless, the Government recognised that there were special circumstances affecting the prices for natural gas in Victoria. When the Government implemented the 1990 reforms to the PRRT it sought to minimise any potential transitional impacts on the Victorian natural gas market.

The Commonwealth therefore provided the Victorian Government with a special grant of $60m for the first two years of the application of the PRRT in Bass Strait. Following the grant, the then Victorian Government stated in the Victorian Parliament in May 1991 that it would become its responsibility to ensure that the application of the PRRT was not passed on. I am not aware of any change in this position following the change of government in Victoria.

It is clear that the PRRT provides the certainty and stability needed to attract long term investment in our petroleum exploration and production industry. The Government indicated at the time of the 1990 reforms that it would not be considering any further concessional changes to the arrangements for petroleum production taxation. Nevertheless, in preparing this report I have given careful consideration to industry arguments.

I can advise that the Government will further examine the restrictions on the transferability of expenditures on disposal of a partial interest in a project. We will consider issues such as whether a transfer of expenditures should be proportional to the interest in the project, whether each project category of expenditure should be transferred proportionally or whether it should be optional.

We will also examine further the legislative provisions affecting the end of year transfer of exploration expenditures under farm-in arrangements that are commenced part way through the financial year. In this context, we need to ensure that the policy objectives of company-wide deductibility are in fact being met, while ensuring that the PRRT does not inhibit risk sharing and management that are normal aspects of oil industry activity. I expect that an announcement on these matters will be made in the first quarter of 1993.

The Government gave an undertaking to the Senate in June 1991 to include in this report details of the time taken to administer applications for project production licences. Since 1985, the Commonwealth has received 14 applications for a production licence of which 13 have been awarded. In considering applications the Government needs to examine a number of resource management issues. Details of the processing of applications are included in the report.

In conclusion, Australia has a regulatory and taxation regime for petroleum exploration and development that makes us internationally competitive. This has been recognised internationally by respected, authoritative sources. The report I table today shows that the Government's package of reforms for the industry is working. New investments are going ahead in Bass Strait under the PRRT. The report also indicates that exploration activities in our offshore areas are no longer being affected by taxation that distinguishes between project and frontier areas.

When the Government assumed office in 1983, it found a hopelessly over-regulated petroleum industry, contemplating a declining role in meeting Australia's vital crude oil needs. The Government set about systematically freeing up the energies of the industry, with bold reform policies. Petroleum resource rent tax is a key element of those reforms, providing a strong stimulus to the industry, while safeguarding the community's return for the use of its non-renewable resources.

The PRRT is an excellent example of micro-economic reform introduced by this Government in the area of energy, and indeed the economy as a whole. It demonstrates the Government commitment to policies that will ensure a strong, competitive petroleum industry into the twenty-first century.I commend the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987 to the House and present the following paper:
Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act—Report on the operation of the Act—Ministerial statement, 26 November 1992.
Motion (by Mr Staples) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report deals with the complex subject of the operation of the petroleum resource rent tax. It is a report which was mandated by the Parliament and which has forced the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) to come back and present the same to the Parliament on this occasion. Perhaps the two most critical aspects arising from the report—quite apart from an error in it—are that, firstly:

SPEECH.PARA: Insufficient time has elapsed to be completely definitive about the impact of the PRRT on the petroleum exploration and production industry.

PARA.TAB: It is not possible to draw firm conclusions about the impact of the company-wide deductibility provisions for exploration expenditures under the PRRT.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, this is a report giving a holding judgment—an interim or transitional judgment—in respect of the operation of the PRRT. I do not necessarily criticise that, because it has come about, in part, because of the time factors and constraints and the relatively short period of overall time which has elapsed since the commencement of the operation of the PRRT, especially in respect of the Bass Strait project. The second and more sweeping statement is as follows:

A number of submissions argued that the PRRT will directly impact on prices for Victorian natural gas and ethane. The arguments are not sustainable. There is no direct correlation between the community return derived by levying the PRRT on net revenues from the Bass Strait project and the prices for natural gas and ethane to consumers in Victoria. A number of agents and factors occur in the production and marketing chain to determine prices.
That is a very sweeping statement which will be subject to detailed examination. It prompted the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) to give me a note which says:

The intent of the PRRT legislation was to shift tax from excise base to profit base. There was no intent to create a new consumption tax. Esso is currently taxing Chemplex for ethane as a feed stock to make polythene foam, and a bill in respect of this has now been affirmed at around $15m, but that is a matter of disputation, litigation and arbitration at this time. The Gas and Fuel Corporation expects to have price increases demanded by producers and will pass on those price increases to consumers, whether they be industrial or private.
The honourable member for La Trobe has studied this issue in considerable detail.

PARA.TAB: I will make some general comments on the operation of the PRRT since its introduction to the Bass Strait—the main dimension associated with this report. It was always obvious that the PRRT would have a particular impact on Victoria, but not exclusively Victoria. It created a degree of uncertainty at a very difficult time for the Victorian economy. This report does not really offer much definitively in terms of clearing up that measure of uncertainty; which is the subject of some continuing negotiation, liaison, conciliation, arbitration and, ultimately, litigation, particularly with regard to the standing and legality of a number of contractual obligations.

There is a long way to go before this matter will be resolved. The Minister's statement—in a sense, conjuring up the belief that all is okay with regard to this matter—is not really stating the truth, because all is not yet okay. On page 8 of the Minister's statement on the report, he indicated that this matter is not yet resolved. There are different tax and royalty rates for oil and gas projects across Australia and Australian waters. Of course, these differences lend to distortions of the market and they cause economically inefficient decision making. That is very much the case and it will always flow from a situation where there is compartmentalisation in respect of tax regimes on gas. However, I accept that there is a need for that compartmentalisation in special circumstances—for example, in relation to the North West Shelf.

It is true that the Federal Government gave $60m to the then Victorian State Government—the Cain and Kirner governments—as a one-off adjustment to ease the burden of the transition flowing from the application of the PRRT to the Bass Strait. It is not clear where that $60m ended up. I assume that it went to the Victorian State Treasury and that it has, in fact, been paid. The Minister has confirmed that, and I thank him. So great is the morass of Victorian public finances that there is no real certainty at the end of the day that the $60m, in practical terms, went to the problem earmarked and allocated for by the Commonwealth Government.

It is necessary to examine this aspect very carefully. I want to provide a degree of certainty on this matter from the Opposition side by stating that there should be no expectation that a coalition government would add to that $60m payment. As the Minister has indicated, that was a one-off payment in circumstances which were detailed at the time by the then Treasurer when introducing the PRRT Bass Strait dimensions some time ago.
However, I want to highlight further a couple of other aspects of the report. Chapter 3 on page 8 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The notion that the PRRT will adversely impact on the competitiveness of Bass Strait gas is rejected. No evidence is available that the difference between attributable PRRT and State royalty for onshore projects is likely to be a major consideration in the cost of natural gas to consumers. Other factors including market value are far more important in the final price of gas.

I highlight that statement because I know it will be of considerable interest to many organisations and many commercial operators in the State of Victoria as they go about their planning. This is the comment flowing from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in its report tabled by the Minister this day.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to page 9 of the report. Under a section headed `Comment', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Prices for natural gas and ethane are determined under negotiated contractual arrangements. Currently the only PRRT-liable revenues from natural gas and ethane are derived from the Bass Strait project and the two products are sold exclusively to Victorian consumers.

That statement is not correct. What the Department has overlooked, what the Minister has overlooked and what the Government has overlooked is that the Gas and Fuel Corporation is a supplier for this provincial City of Albury. It is their bad luck that Albury happens to be in my electorate of Farrer which is within the State of New South Wales. In fact, it goes further. It goes beyond Albury and the municipality of Albury: it goes to the brickworks at Jindera, which is beyond sight of the Murray River and beyond sight of the State border between New South Wales and Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has all these public servants sitting down there in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy applying themselves to producing a very important report. I accept that it is a very important report and that he is an active Minister. He recently led a delegation to Taiwan—he was following in the footsteps of myself, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and others—and showed a degree of activity for which he is noted, including bungy jumping. Quite seriously, I make the point that, as Minister, he would require of his Department that these things were set right.

There is another ramification to this. Elsewhere in the statement the Minister alluded to the PAC dividend and the fact that the Kennett Government has raised domestic gas prices by some 10 per cent in that particular mini-Budget, which I acknowledge. But it does not stop at the border either; that 10 per cent increase flows into Albury, into the Jindera brickworks, which is north of Albury, and further into the State of New South Wales and to other consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to get stuck into Mr Kennett.
—My constituents are very Christian-minded. They have no choice in the matter but they are happy to help their colleagues. They like ensuring the viability of the State of Victoria.
—What are you complaining about then?

—I am complaining about accuracy. There is a very clear-cut statement that the gas is sold exclusively to Victorian consumers. That is not the case. It does in fact flow across the border. As we develop the Australian gas industry, it is logical that it is going to flow across a lot more borders variously around Australia. We need to be very conscious of that aspect as we deal with this report before the House. The coalition will give further careful consideration to the implications of the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987.

PARA.TAB: I reject one aspect of the Minister's comments that we are now internationally competitive so far as oil, gas resources and energy generally relate to their prospects in competing on the international stage. I am afraid to say that that is not fully true because there are other taxes which impact on oil research, oil exploration, oilfield development and oilfield production as well on gas exploration and gas production. I refer to taxes such as payroll tax, direct and indirect elements of sales tax, as well as fuel excise tax itself, which is not a small amount in terms of the operation in remote areas and in Bass Strait on the costs of these companies.

I say to the House in very clear-cut terms that we will add to the international competitiveness of the energy and resources sector by our clear-cut commitment in the coalition's Fightback package to abolish all payroll tax, to abolish all sales tax, to abolish all fuel excise tax and to lower income tax in relation to the key elements of the Fightback package. The Minister even has that wrong because the Leader of the Opposition has made a very clear-cut statement that there will be no road user charges until 1 July 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mark my words. Dr Hewson will dishonour it.

—I guarantee that there will be no GST until all sales tax is abolished, until all fuel excise tax is abolished. That is absolute in terms of helping this key energy and resources sector and the contribution that it must make to the economic recovery of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I note and acknowledge the action of the Minister in tabling the report on the operation of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. I express those concerns partly on behalf of the honourable member for La Trobe, who has taken a deep interest in this area, and the coalition more generally. There are further steps that the Government could take to make this sector even more internationally competitive.

It is interesting to record that this formal report to the Parliament of Australia tendered by statement of the Minister today does carry one particular error, which has been confirmed. I know it is the interests of the proceedings of the Parliament and the governments of Australia that those errors are not allowed to creep into important reports of this nature.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Darling) adjourned.
