PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The failure of the Government to reform the tax system as an essential part of a package to stimulate Australian businesses and create jobs.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have put considerable evidence before the people of Australia during this week in a succession of three matters of public importance about the magnitude of our economic and social problems in Australia. It goes without any exaggeration to say that the people of Australia are hurting and they are now getting quite desperate for solutions to our deep-seated economic and social problems. I believe the people of Australia want to know what both major parties in the political debate are prepared to do about those problems. In particular, they want this Parliament to do what it should do; that is, provide a forum for debates about those major issues so that both sides can put their views and the people of Australia can be given a clear-cut choice at the next election.

PARA.TAB: In that vein, last Sunday I proposed, by way of press release and an announcement, that this week we would have three major debates on the state of our economic and social problems: first, a debate on the state of the economy and forecasts for the Australian economy, the likely direction we are drifting as a result of recent policies and in current circumstances; secondly, a debate about unemployment and, thirdly, because we are constantly challenged by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), a debate about tax reform and the essential role of tax reform in the resolution of those economic problems. Three days in a row there have been three matters of public importance and on all three occasions the Prime Minister has not bothered to turn up. Indeed, those on the other side have taken it on themselves for nobody to turn up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Copped out.

—Absolutely, a cop-out. They have taken it on themselves not to turn up at all and to ignore three fundamentally important matters to the people of Australia. Are we to conclude that the Government does not think these matters are important? Should we conclude that those opposite do not think unemployment is important? Should we conclude that they do not think tax reform is important? Should we conclude that they do not think that the likely future direction of the Australian economy over the rest of this decade is important?

PARA.TAB: The only thing those opposite seem to think is important is their own political survival. They will do or say anything to try to ensure that. No matter how many times Government members try to distract attention by running one diversion after another—I do not care whether it is the flag, the monarchy or any other diversion the Prime Minister chooses to run—and no matter how many times they abuse Question Time in this House, because they use it as a cowards' castle where the Prime Minister gets up, drops his bucket and leaves but is never prepared to debate the basic issues of Australia, the people of Australia will never be fooled.

If they listened to the debate in Question Time, they would think that we had been in government. We must be the most powerful Opposition in the history of the Western world. We are being blamed for this recession. We are blamed for everything that happens in this country. Of course, at Question Time there is a constant barrage of attack and abuse from the other side. We must, without qualification, be the most powerful Opposition that has ever existed in any Parliament in the Western world.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it does not matter what the Government does in this Parliament. It will not make any difference to the outcome of the next election. It does not matter how many clever lines the Prime Minister gets from Dr Watson. It does not matter how many clever lines he uses. It does not matter how much abuse he throws or how many diversions he runs. The people of Australia will never forgive him for what he has done. He is responsible for this recession and the people know it. He caused it and the people are seeing day by day that he has no solutions. He cannot fix it. He will be held totally accountable for the pain and misery that he has inflicted on average Australians.

I might just pick up one person whom honourable members on the Government side have quoted incessantly this week in the course of the debates and that is Ross Gittins. They have incessantly quoted Ross Gittins about us. Just to summarise how the image of this Government is emerging and how the people of the electorate are going to see this Government at the next election, even Ross Gittins has put down a description of this Government that is really worth noting, and noting very carefully.

He describes it as the `clapped out, idea bereft complacent Government of Paul Keating'. He refers to its having `a blank mind'. His mind is blank. `Dr Hewson has a plan', he says, and then he finally comments on the prospect of Labor being given a fifth term as `appalling'. That is a summary. Even one of the people they quote incessantly can see the extent to which they have let the problems of Australia drift and failed to provide any effective solution.

The point of the discussion today is to focus on the issue of tax reforms which anybody who looks at the issue of tax reform in Australia knows is fundamentally important to solving our economic and social problems. Any objective observer of our tax system at the present time must draw several simple conclusions. One, it is totally inefficient from the point of view that the tax system ought to be able to efficiently raise a set amount of money to finance the operations of government. It is an inefficient system. It is an inequitable and unfair system and, quite frankly, it compounds many of our basic economic difficulties.

Most objective commentators would conclude from that that tax reform is absolutely and fundamentally important to solving our economic and social problems in Australia. It is fundamentally important to developing the sorts of attitudes and the sort of culture we need in Australia to become internationally competitive, to be able to match and to beat the best in the world, and it is fundamentally important, I believe, to building a fair and equitable Australia, which is what we are all very keen to see develop in the course of the next few years.

I think perhaps most disturbingly, though, when we look at our major economic problems today—and I think that most people would list those as jobs, the balance of payments and debt, and the lack of savings as the three major problems—our tax system makes each of those problems worse. It is an anti-job system. It accentuates our balance of payments problems and it discourages savings. As I say, it is unfair and inequitable.

The average taxpayers, the PAYE taxpayers, are disadvantaged under the present system. They are left with money being taken out of their pay packets every week, and yet tax cheats are allowed to run rife in this country. The cash economy is allowed to go on unchecked in this country. It is a basic inherent feature of the existing system that it is fundamentally inequitable and unfair in terms of its impact on PAYE taxpayers. Of course, there are many substantial arguments that others who use our system and use our infrastructure, for example, tourists, do not pay a fair share of their tax when they come to this country.

I think if we just focus briefly on the major economic problems, those of jobs, balance of payments, debt and savings, we see how clear-cut it is that this tax system that we have today accentuates or compounds each of those three problems. In fact, the solution to those problems has a fundamental role for tax reform. Fightback overall is an integrated package to deal with those and other problems in Australia. It is more broadly based than just these three economic problems and it goes to the very heart of a whole range of our social problems. But one of the key elements of Fightback is tax reform, principally because it is fundamental to solving those three economic problems.

Let us just look, for example, at the issue of jobs. The main reason we do not have jobs in Australia is that the business sector in Australia has been subjected to a phenomenal increase in cost, government charges and other inefficiencies in the system which have increasingly made it internationally uncompetitive. We cannot in a large part of our business community compete effectively with comparable businesses in comparable industries in other parts of the world.

A fundamental reason for that is the nature of the tax system. If we can develop an alternative tax system which cuts business costs, which abolishes certain key taxes and charges on the business community, which, in the context of a bigger package, lowers a lot of the infrastructure costs and other disadvantages on our business community in Australia, we can boost that business community, we can make it internationally competitive, and it can get on and create wealth and jobs. Quite frankly, the rebuilding of the business community is the only way in which we are going to rebuild or create sustainable and real jobs in Australia.

One of the essences of tax reform is to go into the tax system, identify where it is an impediment to the development of business in Australia, and seek to eliminate that impediment or, at the very least, reduce those impediments. That is why our package moves towards a broad-based goods and services tax. It is a fundamental element of becoming internationally competitive as a business community. It is fundamental that the disadvantages our businesses face in terms of the indirect taxes they pay, taxes which are passed through to exports, which make us internationally uncompetitive, have to be eliminated.

That is why we will not only introduce a broad-based goods and services tax, as something like 70 other countries have done—we do not want our business to be at a competitive disadvantage—but also go ahead and abolish other major cost imposts on business, like payroll tax, petrol excise, sales tax, freezing the superannuation guarantee levy, abolishing the training guarantee levy and, of course, seeking, by genuine micro reform, something they do not understand, to eliminate a lot of the cost disadvantages that exist in power and transport, in water, in telecommunications, on the waterfront, and right throughout our basic infrastructure in Australia. It is a package that is designed to lower business costs, and fundamental to that is the GST and the role that tax reform more broadly plays in relation to business.

The second problem is balance of payments and debt. We have a tax system right now which discourages exports and encourages imports. We are running at a huge current account deficit. I think people, quite frankly, are surprised at how big our current account deficit is today relative to GDP, even in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years. Most economists figured that we would see a much more significant improvement in our external accounts than has been the case. But we have not. In fact, we have already seen signs in this budgetary year that that situation is getting worse. An essential element in why it is getting worse is because the tax system discourages exports and encourages imports.

One of the most powerful arguments for a goods and services tax is simply that it takes tax off exports. It encourages exports and it puts tax on imports. It discourages imports. If you want a powerful argument in a debt-ridden country for GST then that is it. It works consistently with the direction we have to go in improving our balance of payments, in boosting exports, in constraining imports, or replacing imports by effective import competition. Of course, it is fundamental to our business community becoming internationally competitive.

I think it is worth noting that that is the principal reason why most other countries, the 70 I have mentioned, have gone in the direction of a goods and services tax. Under the GATT arrangements, a goods and services or value added tax is the only effective way to subsidise exports—eliminate the cost disadvantages of those exports, while discouraging imports. Until we do that, we are at a massive disadvantage relative to the businesses in any other country that have a broad based goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Tony Cole said.

—That is exactly what the Secretary to the Treasury said last week in Brisbane at a private function. I think that it is interesting that the Government has never denied that he said it. It knows that he believes in it. It knows that he is probably working on it right now, because he knows that somewhere down the track, we as a nation are going to have to deal with the problem of our balance of payments.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, of course, there is the issue of savings. Savings need desperately to be encouraged in Australia. We have a deficiency of savings, so we borrow everyone else's savings and we put our country up for sale. In fact, the bottom line of this Government has been two things, apart from the million unemployed—three things, let us say. It has been a debt level of $180 billion. We have borrowed ourselves almost beyond the limits of tolerance of the international financial community and they have put this country up for sale.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've sent David Jull to sleep.

—You ought to be worried about them putting this country up for sale. You ought to be worried about your policies putting this country up for sale because that is exactly what you have done in terms of the policies you have run.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Barton should not interject.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is another powerful example for tax reform built around the goods and services tax. The goods and services tax taxes expenditure, not income. It encourages you to save. It makes you pro-save; it is a pro-savings policy, the second argument that the Secretary to the Treasury put last week apparently to this private meeting in Brisbane. It is pro-savings in a country that has a massive savings shortage.

PARA.TAB: In relation to those three economic problems, it is pro-jobs. In relation to unemployment, it is pro-jobs; in relation to tax reform, it is pro-jobs; and in relation to GST, it is pro-jobs. In relation to the balance of payments and debt, it is pro-improvement in the balance of payments; it is pro-reduction in debt; and, in relation to savings, it is pro-savings. Three powerful reasons that are essential elements of why the broad based goods and services tax, as part of genuine tax reform, is absolutely fundamental to solving our economic problems in Australia. It opens up the key to deal with the other problems; it gives you a fairer system, where the tax cheats actually start to pay, and where tourists actually start to pay a fair share for their use of the infrastructure in Australia; and it provides the wherewithal for the largest personal tax cut in our history—a 30 per cent personal tax cut! It gives us a Hong Kong style tax system in terms of average tax rates in Australia. A person on an average income of around $25,000 would pay only 14c in the dollar tax; on twice average income he would pay only 22c in the dollar tax. It encourages people to work, it encourages people to save and, with the capital gains tax changes to back it up, it encourages people to go into business and to expand business.

If you want a fight on the GST and tax reform, we will have it. As far as we are concerned, the GST means more jobs for us and it means more jobs for our children; it means a decent education because it opens the door to a better education and a better health system; it means cheaper petrol; it means the abolition of your iniquitous and unfair wholesale sales tax system; it means no payroll tax on jobs, which the Prime Minister himself has said would create 200,000 jobs—it means, in effect, all up, about two million jobs by the end of this decade, a halving of the unemployment rate, a better balance of payments, a control over our debt levels and, ultimately, significant reductions in debt and an environment in which this country saves and pays its own way in the international community. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) announced before the beginning of this sitting week that he was going to bring to the Parliament debates about primary economic issues. He is now leaving the chamber, having initiated his third feeble attempt to engender some interest in the debate about his policies.

PARA.TAB: The point about all this is that it was not an exercise designed to talk to the people of Australia; it was an exercise designed to talk to his own nervous and irascible back bench, a back bench which was never consulted about these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were.

—No, you were not. His backbenchers were never consulted about these matters. These were policies which were dreamt up by a small clique in the leadership and then foist upon the unsuspecting and, unfortunately, unwitting and uninformed members of the Opposition parties. They were encouraged to believe, from the first flush of approval which these policies received in some quarters, that they were on a winner, that somehow their brilliant leaders had come up with a formula which was the answer to Australia's problems and at the same time electorally saleable.

PARA.TAB: As the year has passed by, and as they had that morose looking party where they brought out the birthday cake a couple of nights ago, in an attempt not to celebrate anything but just to try to cheer themselves up about the appalling state to which their fortunes had descended during the 12 months since the release of Fightback, they have realised that it has been a real lemon. More and more people have realised that it is not an answer to Australia's problems and, therefore, not surprisingly, it has received very little support in the community as a whole. The community is much smarter than the Opposition gives it credit for. It was not just a matter of pretending to have a plan; it was a matter of what was in the plan which was important to the Australian electorate and, most particularly, to the business community.

The fact is that we are hard-pressed to find anyone out there who is prepared to unambiguously and enthusiastically support the Opposition's proposals. Very few people are prepared to unambiguously support the Opposition's approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —NFF? CAI?

—I have heard Mr Spicer try to work himself into a frenzy of support, but the trouble with Mr Spicer is that his remarks are so political and so biased that nobody takes any notice of him. He knows, I suspect, that close to, if not more than, a majority of his own membership has given up on this particular policy approach, more particularly because they have begun to see some of the consequences of the practical implementation of some of these policies in the context of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: But again we heard the Leader of the Opposition come in here, trying desperately to convince his back bench and, I might say, even trying to reconvince himself about these particular matters. That is what—
Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know all about silvertails, and I know what is wrong with them. That is what you do not like.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Mayo should not interject.
Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know what is wrong with them and I know what is wrong with a country which was governed for too long—

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo for interjecting. The Treasurer should not respond to interjections across the table.

—All right, I resist the temptation. The Leader of the Opposition decided to make today's debate one about tax reform. He is persisting with this piece of idiocy that somehow a $40 billion tax shift is going to make a difference to the fundamental problems confronting Australia. He has identified the fundamental problems as being jobs, balance of payments, and I think his third one was the question of savings. He knows that the introduction of the GST would create not one new job, save possibly amongst the accounting profession whose members will have to go through the bewildering administration of trying to operate a GST at the level of each business, and save for the number of additional tax collectors who would have to be employed by the Australian Taxation Office in order to collect this new tax. But in terms of real jobs, jobs which are about adding to the nation's GDP, the GST will not add one job. Worse than that, the package as a whole will actually cost Australia jobs, as has been pointed out repeatedly by so many people who are respectable commentators around the place.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition refers to Mr Gittins. What more damning indictment could there be than that from Mr Gittins where he says that the Leader of the Opposition is dishonest when he says that Fightback will actually lead to an increase in jobs. Mr Gittins has said, and the Leader of the Opposition knows, that the implementation of Fightback will in fact cost jobs, not increase jobs. Yet we have the Leader of the Opposition coming in here, in the face of that criticism of dishonesty from Mr Gittins, saying that the GST is all about jobs. It is not about jobs, except in the sense that it will be about a diminution of jobs in Australia. Yet what can the Leader of the Opposition say, because little by little his whole approach is beginning to fall to bits.

He tries to pretend—and this is really the heart of the argument, the heart of the deception in this policy—that this is a policy about taking taxes off business. This is the essential message of what the Opposition is saying. We know that at the time when those opposite are taking taxes off, they are putting them back. Where? Right on business. Who collects the GST? It is business which collects the $20 billion worth of GST, and it is business which will have to collect it and remit it to the Australian Taxation Office. So this point about relieving taxation from business is just another of the deceptions.

The Opposition does not seem to understand that, far from removing taxes, there are seven new Hewson taxes proposed in the Fightback package. I will go through these seven new taxes. First of all there is the GST, which the Opposition is sometimes prepared to own up to—only sometimes. If we look at the Opposition's pamphlets, we will often see all the taxes which it says it is eliminating, and sometimes—and only sometimes—it refers to the GST it is putting on.

The second new Hewson tax is the tax on lump sum superannuation payouts taken by people between the ages of 55 and 60. Today, the first $76,000 is tax-free, with a rate of 16.25 per cent applied to the amount above that figure. Fightback proposes a new tax of 20 per cent with no tax-free threshold on those lump sums. The third new Hewson tax is the additional tax on super fund earnings, which will be up from today's rate of 15 per cent to 20 per cent. There will be a new tax of 20 per cent on superannuation fund earnings, compared with the 15 per cent that exists today. Fourthly, there will be new taxes on the contributions to superannuation funds if a person is contributing more than $6,000 a year to super.

Fifthly, the company tax rate will go up from today's rate of 39 per cent to 42 per cent under the Hewson package. Sixthly, tobacco excise will go up by 25 per cent. The seventh new and, to this point, secret tax relates to new road user charges. The Opposition has said it is committed to a user pays principle as far as paying for roads is concerned, which can only mean a road user charge. It cannot work out how to do it, so it has put it off—at least, it knows what it is going to do; it is just that it will not tell us what it is going to do. We have seven new Hewson taxes, one of which is a secret tax which it will not reveal until later, when it thinks it will be in office.

The Opposition Leader, in the dying minutes of his struggling speech—and in the dying days of his leadership, because after the election those opposite will not want him as Leader of the Opposition—said that this was going to boost exports. Let us examine that for a moment. Which industry has become the largest single export earner for Australia? Which is our largest single export industry in Australia? The answer is tourism. What does Fightback do to tourism?
Opposition members—Boosts it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It boosts it, for sure. It boosts it in the sense that Australians will be encouraged to take their holidays overseas, which is a negative as far as our balance of payments is concerned. Why? Because the cost of holidaying in Australia will go up. The cost of air fares will go up 15 per cent. The cost of accommodation will go up. The cost of bus fares will go up. The cost of eating out will go up. All of these things which one does on holidays will go up; therefore, people will have an added incentive to take their holidays overseas. On the other hand, it will discourage overseas visitors from coming here, because the cost of holidaying in Australia for an overseas visitor will go up as a result of the imposition of a GST on the tourism industry. We have the Opposition Leader telling us that it is good for exports and bad for imports, when in fact on our leading export industry it has the opposite effect. It is bad for this industry. It encourages Australians to go overseas and it discourages overseas visitors from coming to Australia.

PARA.TAB: The other point which the Leader of the Opposition made about halfway through his speech was that this is an efficient tax. It is efficient only in the sense that it loads the cost of compliance onto Australian businesses. To see this, we have only to look at the analysis of what has happened in New Zealand. A report on that in today's Melbourne Age reveals that a GST is a much more expensive tax to collect than PAYE and that it is particularly expensive as far as business compliance costs and, more particularly, small business are concerned.

What we need to do in Australia is provide encouragement to small business and encourage it to employ people. What a GST does is impose a new tax on small business. It increases the cost of employing labour in small business. Now it does not pay payroll tax, but it will pay a GST, which is a tax on labour. Worse than that, a GST imposes a bewildering compliance cost on small business, which means that it will have to bear the cost of a tax which actually punishes it in terms of its ability to employ people. It will cost small business more to comply than it will big business; therefore, it disadvantages small business as opposed to big business. The GST will not create one job; it will eliminate hundreds of thousands of jobs from the Australian work force. The Opposition ought to have the honesty to face up to that nasty reality. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —After that shabby effort by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), it is time to put down the nuts and bolts of the Fightback alternative because, clearly, the Government has no alternative to the status quo, to the one million unemployment level, and to all the aspects of the horrific recession we did not have to have.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer referred to so-called nervous members on the coalition side. I can quantify for him six nervous members on the Government side. I refer to six members of the House of Representatives who have decided to jump ship from the Labor Party Titanic and have announced that they are getting out, voluntarily and not as a matter of preselection. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) is gone; he is jumping. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) is jumping out of the team and out of the Government; he is not seeking to recontest his seat. The honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) has had enough; he is off to greener pastures. The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) got bumped sideways by a staffer of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and he has had enough as well. He has put the white flag up the mast and is getting off the Titanic. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has had enough. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), a distinguished former Speaker of the House of yesteryear, has had enough. A total of six members of the Government have had enough.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I think the honourable member is imputing improper motives to me. I have been here 25 years and I think that is long enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the one million unemployed, there is now a clear-cut choice. It is: do you want more of the same or do you want fair dinkum and fair change? It is in respect of that that I now lay before the House the nuts and bolts of the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: In summarising the Fightback package, I ask this Government: why does it not raise the tax-free threshold; institute a tax-free savings scheme; double the family allowance; abolish payroll tax; increase the dependent spouse rebate; abolish petrol and diesel fuel excise tax, at a saving of $11.40 each time a motorist fills the average fuel tank; institute a uniform goods and services tax, just like the one the Prime Minister advocated in 1985; extend pharmaceutical benefits to non-pensioner retirees; abolish wholesale sales tax—the 10 per cent, the 15 per cent, the 20 per cent and the 30 per cent sales tax; reduce capital gains tax; reduce fringe benefits tax; and improve the first home owners scheme? That is only a small window of the opportunity and the detail contained in the Fightback package, launched successfully by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) some 12 months ago and successfully sold by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) at meeting after meeting right around Australia.

I think it also needs to be expressed in another terminology. There are in fact seven steps associated with the Fightback tax reform package. In the interests of fair and intelligent debate, it is time that these were put down on the record of the House.

The first step is the total abolition of seven taxes. Out goes all payroll tax, all sales tax, all fuel excise tax, Labor's lump sum superannuation tax, customs duty by the year 2000, and also the 1 1/2 per cent training levy and the coal export duty. Such an impressive proposal is the latter that indeed the Government has picked up on it. The second step is a massive reduction in income tax; an increase in the threshold level from $5,400 to $7,000; and about a one-third reduction in actual income tax paid by the PAYE worker—along with a reduction in the fringe benefits tax and a review of its impact on regional and remote Australia, a reduction in the rate of capital gains tax and a review of its impact, and particular provisions to assist small business, retirees and others.

The third step is the introduction of a GST at 15 per cent, a much fairer form of taxation. Fifty-nine other countries around the world have already gone down this path. But there will be no GST on health, education, churches, charities, the sale of a property as a going concern and core council rates. It will not increase the CPI by 15 per cent. It does not mean $15 on top of a $100 supermarket bill. It is in fact a 4.4 per cent consumer price index increase, and that has been validated by the Treasurer. Related to that are two other caveats. Let me make it absolutely clear that all GST on all business inputs will be fully refunded. We need to understand that to work out very clearly why it is tilting the tax system back towards the productive sector to generate fair dinkum jobs.

The fourth step is the treatment of excises. I mentioned petrol and diesel fuel excise tax. It will be 26c less for business usage and, when the GST comes back on at about 7c, the individual motorist will still save around 20c a litre—$11.40 every time we fill the fuel tank. On the question of alcohol excise, there is no change. On the question of tobacco excise, we recognise that there are other considerations which must be taken into account, and there will be an increase.

The fifth step is very clear-cut and relates to the fact that there is no such thing as an international level playing field. We are prepared to do something about that. Our view on this was validated by Dr Tony Cole when he spoke last week in Brisbane. He thought he was a safe distance from Canberra, from headquarters, and from the failed Treasurer who just addressed this House, but in fact it was on the front page of Saturday's Courier-Mail when he said that the GST reform of tax is the only correct way we can go forward to rinse out the impact of indirect taxes on our exports and make us truly competitive with so many of the other OECD nations and other key nations around the world.

We will in fact zero rate all exports under the GST and remove that sales tax slug from exports, which constitutes a 5 per cent disadvantage on all exporters. That is not my figure; that is a figure from Senator Button's Deputy Secretary—that all exporters in Australia, against this very unlevel international playing field, are hit with a 5 per cent disadvantage created by the existing sales tax slug. We will abolish all payroll tax, sales tax and fuel excise tax and zero rate all exports.

The sixth step, of course, relates to compensation. This is not a scorched earth policy; it is a sincere, warm, friendly policy with empathy, particularly for those in need. For aged pensioners there will be an 8 per cent increase in their pension, and a continuing increase from the commencement of a GST. There will be an 8 per cent increase in the service pension, the war widows pension, the civil widows pension and other Commonwealth pensions. There will be a 6 per cent increase in Austudy payments and a range of other benefits. Both the 8 per cent and 6 per cent figures greatly exceed the cost of living increase brought on by the 15 per cent GST. Of course, for retirees there is a special and exciting package, and one which will involve a special payment of $2,500 in certain circumstances. This is a benefit that flows from the increase in the tax threshold level, the $1,000 new savings scheme and the like.

Finally, we come to the seventh step: how it all adds up. It adds up because it adheres to that clear-cut objective: less government, less taxation, more incentive, more productivity and more jobs. We will deliver that by bringing in the GST, a fair form of taxation, but at the same time abolishing seven other taxes and greatly reducing income tax. It is what the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) might describe as a lower tax policy, an LTP. It will give Australians hope; it will give hard-pressed farmers hope; it will give hard-pressed PAYE workers, whether they are in Broken Hill, Braidwood or beyond, some hope. It will give workers right around Australia a fair dinkum return on their efforts, whether they are blue-collar or white-collar workers.

This package adds up. It will raise some $27 billion through the GST and, at the same time, will review some of those programs crying out for review under other government departmental expenditure. It will collect more money from the cash economy and provide a basis for fair dinkum and believable income tax cuts to give real incentive to the Australian community and get this economy back on the rails.

The Treasurer and this tired old Government have failed this country. The Treasurer's first anniversary as Treasurer is shortly coming up. It is that time of the year when this Government has been shuffling its Treasurers. It is time again that it shuffles its Treasurer for the few short weeks that it remains in office in this country. The sooner the election comes on, so that the people can have the real choice, the better, for the sake of all Australians, both today and in the future. The choice is simple: do people want more of the same under Labor, or fair dinkum and fair change under the coalition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I follow the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), in this debate. I first of all take the opportunity to congratulate him and his good lady on their recent marriage. But I congratulate him more so on having the good sense to get married before the election on the off chance that he might become the Deputy Prime Minister after the election, when to get married would cost him a good 15 per cent more. He has obviously had a good deal of commonsense.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party listed six members on the Government benches who are retiring at the next election and likened them to rats leaving a sinking ship. I point out for his edification that my good friend the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards), the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) and the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney)—six members on the Opposition side—are also retiring at the next election. The Leader of the National Party should think before he leads with his chin.

This debate is supposed to be about tax reform. We are told here, and we have been told yet again today, that the GST is tax reform. The GST is not tax reform; it is tax deform. It is a disfigurement of the taxation system, driven by a rigid and uncaring ideology, sold by a rigid and uncaring Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and his Deputy, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), one of my prime electoral assets. Driven by ideology, it is a tax deform, not a tax reform.

If we should have the misfortune after the next election to have those opposite occupy the Treasury bench in this House, there will be the largest single redistribution of income in the history of this country, but it will be a redistribution of income from lower and middle income earners and taxpayers to the wealthy. Only today we heard that doctors would get a 60 per cent increase in their incomes under those opposite should they attain government. That is at the very same time when the would-be social security Minister on the other side of this House was caught out labelling the unemployed as riffraff.

Do those opposite really believe that this is some sort of reform to be proud of? Is it some sort of reform that, accompanying this revamping of the tax structure, this redistribution of tax impost, would slash some $7 billion from the social services and social wage of this country? On this point, those opposite are condemned out of their own mouths. In a press release of 19 August this year, the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: Only a portion of the GST goes to finance the Coalition's historic reductions in income tax—the main portion is financed by expenditure cuts.

The truth is that, whether it be in the area of taxation, health, education, social services, sport or the arts, the GST package offered by those opposite will go through the average Australian family quicker than an XPT—that is, an extra personal tax.

PARA.TAB: The whole framework of this debate by those opposite is essentially, by implication, that this Government has not reformed the taxation system. I think it is amazing that that came from the Leader of the Opposition, given his position as a senior adviser in the previous Liberal Government. I remind the Leader of the Opposition, members of the House and those listening that this Government has lowered the bottom rate of taxation from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. We have lowered the top rate of taxation from 60 to 47 per cent. We have lowered company taxation from 46 to 39 per cent, and we improved the taxation system in this country to make it fairer.

I remind those who occupy the Liberal Party branches on the North Shore of Sydney and in Toorak in Melbourne, who so strenuously and passionately opposed this Government's tax reform efforts in the mid-1980s, particularly on the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, that those things made the taxation system in this country a damned sight fairer than it was in 1983. We found it in disrepair and disarray when we inherited it from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and his adviser, the present honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). I remember full well how they marched up and down this country, promising to get rid of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the assets test. Where are those things now? They are in the Opposition's own policy document. It has been done for short term political gain.

If we are really about creating jobs, we have to have a pro-active approach to taxation policy in this country. I invite those opposite, who are supposedly passionate believers in the efforts of small business, to do that. I invite the Opposition spokesman on small business, housing and customs, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), who is sitting at the table, to look at a recent pamphlet which was put out by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) just to see that 58 of the 66 recommendations of the Beddall report on small business have been implemented. So many of those recommendations concentrate on tax reform. I ask the empty vessel who is sitting on the Opposition side of the table to have a good look at that pamphlet. It will be the most concrete look at small business policy that he has had yet. I remind him that in the OECD, by international measure, we are the second or third lowest taxed country, depending on how one wants to argue the issue. That is something that those opposite could never live up to in their day in government.

I also remind those opposite that their new consumption tax will reduce the value of every dollar which every Australian now has. I remind them of the transitional aspects of their package on the unemployed; the transitional aspects that the Leader of the Opposition has been forced to admit. I remind those opposite, particularly the Opposition spokesman at the table, about the costs of complying with this new consumption tax, which will be far heavier for small businesses than for large businesses.

I also remind those opposite about this proposed new consumption tax that would provide holiday makers with an incentive to have holidays overseas rather than in Australian resorts which would create jobs for Australian kids. It is a tourism policy that the Opposition spokesman on tourism, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), has been belittled and betrayed by. It is no wonder that he fell asleep on his elbow today as the Leader of the Opposition was putting a matter of public importance before the House. Fall asleep he may well do; he is much safer asleep than listening to what the Leader of the Opposition might have to say in his policy area.

Do those opposite honestly not believe that it does not run the risk of reigniting an inflationary spiral in this country? I also ask them about the confusion in their own ranks. I again refer to the honourable member for Fadden, who said on radio 4QR on 5 April this year that there was no GST on second-hand goods. One of the Opposition's own frontbenchers, on a public radio program, did not even understand a basic aspect of its supposed tax reform. Those opposite wonder why they cannot sell their package to the people of Australia. It is so bereft of any logic that they do not understand it themselves. The honourable member for Fadden, an increasingly slower moving target, fell in it again.

Do those opposite really believe that their new consumption tax will not mean extra costs, paperwork and headaches for Australia's religious and charitable organisations? In Question Time day after day they shed crocodile tears, supposedly trying to paint themselves as being on the same side as these institutions. How does the Leader of the Opposition expect to collect his new consumption tax on the services that are provided for cash to people in their own homes—such as plumbers unblocking the drains, gardeners, painters, decorators, tilers and people who mow the lawns? The truth is that the complicated system of those opposite will be a fillip to the cash economy, and they know it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) give an insight into the Budget making process under this Government and under the oversight of this incarnation of the artful dodger we have as Treasurer of the country. The Budget process is something to marvel at. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) seems to operate like a mad scientist. He throws every bit of economic nonsense into the test tube, puts a match to the Bunsen burner and waits for the thing to blow up. That is exactly what he does. Then he has the cheek to come in here when he delivers his Budget yelling, `Eureka, I've found it; this is it; this is the answer to all our problems'. Thereafter, he has to go into damage control. That is what these Bills are all about.

PARA.TAB: Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No.4) reflect the blind panic of a government confronted with a national unemployment rate of 11.3 per cent, the worst level of unemployment on record since the Great Depression, and an economic outlook that is, at best, flat over the next 12 months. Within a day of the appalling unemployment statistics being revealed recently, the sad catalogue of events that led up to this situation started to exercise people's minds. Subsequently, the Government produced a mealy-mouthed statement entitled Expenditure program re-allocation, which represents the full extent of Labor's response to the unemployment crisis—the nearly one million unemployed in this country, and the equal number under-employed—that it has foisted on the Australian population.

The so-called expenditure program reallocation sets out to justify reassigning some of the Government's `One Nation, One Job' economic statement spending into the areas that will bring about more rapid job creation. The Treasurer's statement is quite explicit about this. In his press release of 13 November, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government examined all areas of Commonwealth expenditure in order to identify those worthwhile projects and programs that could quickly spend additional funds and deliver rapid job growth.

The basic thrust of his statement is then to throw money at problems at an even faster rate than provided for in the `One Nation, One Job' economic statement and in the 1992 Budget of only a few months ago. The Treasurer's statement of 13 November, and these Bills, which give effect to that statement, represent the entirely predictable failure of the `One Nation, One Job' economic strategy put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and I use the word `strategy' jokingly.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation statement was always going to be a failure because it failed to provide for greater business investment and thus for economic growth and the creation of real jobs. Instead, it sought to artificially stimulate employment ahead of the next election, of course, with absolutely no regard for the consequences that would flow for the economy once the election had passed and the unfunded spending of the `One Nation, One Job' statement comes back to plague the Commonwealth Budget. It now turns out that the `One Nation, One Job' statement has failed to deliver even on the miserable goal of artificially stimulating employment prior to the next election. The `One Nation, One Job' statement has failed to provide the jobs Labor promised at the time of its delivery of that statement, so Labor will now rip funds off many of its One Nation spending promises and reallocate them to areas that will serve to fast track artificial job growth ahead of the next election.

The Government will take $150m from its promised One Nation rail expenditure and another $24m off its electricity grid expenditure for this very purpose. These reductions will be offset by increases in spending on labour market programs and a variety of community, sport and heritage pork-barrelling, giving the impression that the Government somehow believes in a community, sport and heritage led recovery rather than one driven by business investment and economic growth. In addition, the Government will bring forward some of the local capital works spending that was to have been set aside for future years as well as some of the spending on the `black spots' road program. This reallocation of expenditure reveals how totally thoughtless and irresponsible Labor was in its initial allocation of the One Nation spending. The Government simply gave no consideration to the effectiveness of the proposed expenditure then, and it is seeking to rectify that in the most artificial way.

The Treasurer's statement says that it would be extremely difficult for the National Rail Corporation to spend prudently by 30 June 1993 the entire $283m allocated in 1992-93 for the national rail system in the One Nation statement. So what is new? Everyone else in the country knew that at the time the `One Job' statement was made in February. Similarly the statement goes on to say that the review `also indicated that funding is not required in 1992 for the upgrading of existing electricity transmission links between the south-eastern States'. What is new? It was apparent to blind Freddy that the Government could not have spent that sort of money in the time span proposed. In other words, Labor was promising to throw money around willy-nilly in its February statement and in the 1992 Budget with no regard to whether these funds were actually required or could be usefully spent in the timeframe that was originally proposed.

The Government's desire to spend its way out of trouble has, amazingly, in the eyes of the Treasurer, if we can believe him, exceeded the capacity of the nation's run-down national infrastructure to absorb that very spending—at least in the case of the railways and the national electricity grid. The Government's incompetence is of such a magnitude that it cannot even create short term artificial jobs with additional government spending, much less real jobs, that might flow from a genuine and comprehensive attempt at economic reform in this country, such as that proposed by the coalition in Fightback. The Labor Party's attempt to increase spending on so-called labour market programs is indicative of how desperate the Government is to save jobs—the principal one being, of course, the job of the Prime Minister—ahead of the next Federal election.

The Treasurer claims in his statement of 13 November, `we expect a total of 20,000 new positions to be created or brought forward as a result of these initiatives'. It is noteworthy that the Government describes these as positions rather than jobs, because that is exactly what they will be. The Government will not be creating real jobs or new jobs that will last beyond the government spending that creates those very jobs; it will be creating positions, and short term positions at that. It is simply creating holding bays for the unemployed until after the next election. It is not interested in, nor is it capable of, creating genuine jobs for the unemployed.

The Government's attempt to subsidise new job creation is simply laughable. Everyone knows that new jobs are not created by the Government subsidising employment in and by private business. While it is possible that subsidised jobs will result in the young unemployed gaining some additional skills, that is the very most we would expect from these programs. What these programs will not provide, and cannot provide, is real and lasting jobs for people to go into and make use of what skills they have. Real and lasting jobs are not created by government subsidies; they never have been and they never will be. Real jobs are created by business investing for growth, and businesses will only start investing again when we have the right investment climate, the right tax policies, the right industrial relations policies, and progress across the board on micro-economic reform and all the other things that need to be done to get this country moving again.

Needless to say, the Labor Party has been a monumental failure in providing for all of these things, which is why we have the unemployment crisis facing us today, and which is why we have the nearly one million unemployed and a similar number of under-employed. What these Bills show is that Labor has learned nothing in its nearly 10 years in office. It is going on to repeat the same mistakes it has made since 1983 and which have given this country the worst recession and the worst unemployment rate since the Great Depression. An indication of the Government's desperation to create some jobs—any jobs—is its 008 telephone number that Labor will establish, which will enable employers to get immediate access to the employment subsidies facilitated by these Bills.

The bureaucracy will be bending over backwards to help spend this money before the next election, with what could be called the Labor Party's re-election hot line. People can ring up and ask for money and it will be theirs if that will get some people off the unemployment queues and out of the unemployment statistics. That is Labor's version of economic reform for the 1990s—dial a subsidy and to hell with the long term consequences for the Budget and the economy. Due to massive amounts of unfunded spending, I can assure honourable members that that problem will arise in the future for ensuing Commonwealth governments. It is significant that this ridiculous program will cease on 31 May 1993 which, as honourable members will be aware, is the likely election date, or after it, next year.

If ever we needed further evidence that Labor cannot deliver the hopes and aspirations of Australian people, it is encapsulated in these Bills. These Bills are proof that it cannot deliver its One Nation promises and cannot deliver the hopes and aspirations of Australians. These Bills epitomise Labor's addiction to compromise and capitulation. They are evidence of how it goes about substituting compromise and capitulation for sound policy formulation and for energetic, far sighted and innovative government. In all this, of course, the casualties are principles and morality.

Apart from these totally ineffectual labour market programs, the Government proposes to bring forward the local capital works spending that was provided for in the 1992 Budget. The expenditure is nothing more than blatant pork-barrelling of the worst order. Funds for local capital works are being concentrated in electorates where the Labor Party is in most trouble. Honourable members will be aware that the fact that these areas are often the hardest hit by the recession is not entirely coincidental.

In respect of capital works, the Labor Party will also be spending $20m on a variety of community, heritage and sporting facilities. The only rationale provided by the Treasurer for funding these projects is that they will create some artificial jobs quickly in areas where Labor's electoral prospects are bleakest. The notion that this spending will in any way underpin lasting employment growth is simply a bad, sick joke.

The two Bills before us today are designed to give effect to measures announced in the Treasurer's statement of 13 November. It is testimony to Labor's incompetence and desperation that these Bills have been introduced at this time. These two Appropriation Bills are quite unprecedented in that they reappropriate funds from Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2—the two key Budget Bills. Those Budget Bills had not even been passed by the Senate before the Treasurer made his 13 November statement which will now result in those Bills being altered to reflect the failure of the Government's One Nation and Budget initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are panicking.

—They are panicking; they are in great panic, and they are heading for the hills. Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2 are barely three months old, and already the Government has been forced into the recognition that $174m of its proposed spending in 1992-93 cannot now be achieved. These Bills represent the total shambles into which Labor's budgetary strategy has once again fallen. This Government chops and changes Budget Bills within weeks of their being debated in the Parliament, and sometimes when they are still before the Parliament—always to reflect its politically expedient ends.

PARA.TAB: The Government will resort to any legislative contortion or distortion the law will allow in order to get its latest spending stupidity through this place. It should have been possible to utilise the Advance to the Minister for Finance to accommodate the necessary changes to the Government's spending priorities contained in these Bills, but the Government has not used any of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Obviously the Government wants to keep these funds already allocated in reserve as a contingency fund to buy votes in the lead-up to the next election.

Nothing could be more indicative of Labor's economic mismanagement and of its complacency about the need for fundamental economic reform to take place in this country than the two Bills before us this evening. The political expediency of Labor in these matters knows no bounds. It will do anything and it will say anything to get itself re-elected. This includes making up what it passes off as economic strategy as it fumbles along, with every chop and change being rendered by the Labor Party's rhetoric as some new economic policy victory.

In the meantime, the unemployment queues grow longer and Labor becomes more and more brazen in the way it re-invents its so-called economic strategy to suit the needs of the moment. One day the Government will describe an anti-inflation policy as advocated by the coalition as a scorched earth policy; we have heard Government members do that. The next day, when the Government stumbles into a low inflation environment—courtesy of the recession we had to have—low inflation becomes the crowning achievement of the Government's record of economic management. Only this Government could come out and describe as a macro-economic policy achievement a totally unintended and totally unplanned reduction in the rate of inflation as the result of the recession. Only this Government and its leaders have the gall to do that. Even the backbench blanch when they are called upon to do that.

We see the same barefaced lies in relation to the Commonwealth Budget balance. It was not so long ago that the Budget surplus was sacrosanct to Labor, or so it said; it was another supposed achievement of this failed Labor regime. Of course, the surplus has long since been shown to have been an entirely cyclical phenomenon that has been swept away by the emergence of a structural Budget deficit of alarming proportions. Now the Prime Minister says that the Budget balance is essentially irrelevant and dismisses its importance, now that it is no longer politically convenient for him to talk about it and now that it reflects badly on his administration. This is how the Government justifies its almost $50 billion in totally unfunded new spending over the next few years, adding to the public sector debt and interest rates and putting the long term future of the Commonwealth's finances in dire jeopardy.

But far more outrageous than the Prime Minister's claim that the surplus no longer matters is his statement that the process of micro-economic reform is now complete. Can honourable members believe that! Everyone knows in reality that the process of micro-economic reform in this country has barely started. It is a sick joke to try to kid the Australian people otherwise in the manner of this failed Prime Minister. It is typical of the weak leadership of this man that he would abandon any pretence at giving the nation some form of economic leadership when he thinks there is political mileage to be had by sitting tight and letting the country basically go to rack and ruin.

In view of the horrendous levels of unemployment currently facing this country, the Prime Minister and his Labor cohorts should be doubling or even tripling their efforts on the micro-economic reform front. Indeed, they should have done so long ago, starting with their first term in office. Never before has micro-economic reform been more important to this country's future well-being and yet this Prime Minister has the arrogance and the insensitive complacency to claim that the job has already been done. Of course, if the major micro-economic reform tasks had been completed, we would not now be facing this tragic unemployment situation and the economic downturn that Labor has mindlessly inflicted on this country. The Government's complacent rhetoric is betrayed by the staggering magnitude of this country's economic problems. So Labor has failed us in two ways in this context: first, by failing to deliver on micro-economic reform and, second, by failing to recognise the dire consequences of this failure and of providing the necessary leadership to address those consequences.

The failure of this Government was epitomised by the Prime Minister's now infamous performance on the Lateline program when he was confronted with the total failure of his policies, and the failure of the One Nation economic statement in particular. For once in his life the Prime Minister was left totally dumbstruck when confronted with the enormity of his economic failures—and so he should have been.

The `One Nation, One Job' projections on economic growth have been revealed as a sham, and were scaled down in the August Budget, just a few months later, to levels that are now also regarded as optimistic. The only way is down with this Government. The same is true of the Government's projections for unemployment and for the Budget deficit. These have also been blown out of the water by the depth and the protracted nature of the recession this Government knowingly and deliberately inflicted upon the Australian people.

The extravagant commitments made in the One Nation economic statement, promising personal income tax cuts as well as a Budget surplus by 1995-96, are now recognised as wildly optimistic and, most likely, quite unattainable. I would put it even more strongly than that: they are simply unattainable. Even the forecasts made in the 1992 Budget, now barely three months old, are looking decidedly shaky.

The Budget forecasts for unemployment have already been proved to be spectacularly and tragically wrong. The Government has destroyed nine real jobs for every job it has created since handing down the `One Nation, One Job' economic statement, yet it has the barefaced cheek to boast about its so-called expansionary policies for the Australian economy. Whatever the intent of the Government's policies, one thing is clear: they are not expansionary. On the contrary; they are compounding and extending the effects of the recession the Government has knowingly and deliberately forced upon us.

The Government is having itself on if it thinks that its fiscal stimulus will do anything other than increase interest rates and crowd out private sector investment, thereby putting the economic recovery in real jeopardy. It is the coalition's Fightback package and its reforms which will stimulate private investment and economic growth by lowering business costs and lowering the overall tax burden on the Australian community. That was more than adequately dealt with by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in debate just an hour or so ago in this chamber.

Reductions in Government spending will free up resources for use by the private sector in getting the economy moving once again. The Government continues to believe that it can address fundamental economic problems by throwing around money that it does not have, money that it has borrowed against this country's economic future. This is despite the overwhelming evidence that such an approach is doomed to failure, along with the rest of this Government's economic policies. The Government has tried this approach time and time again, and it has failed time and time again. The results are there for everyone to see. There is not one economic indicator giving us hope and, as I have said already, there are tragic levels of unemployment.

In November last year there was the employment statement handed down, if anyone remembers, by the former Prime Minister, which sought to have us spend our way out of trouble. It followed the stimulatory 1991 Budget. Then there was the current Prime Minister's One Nation statement, which was followed by the 1992 Budget. Now we have this reallocation of expenditure which somehow is expected to do what its predecessors failed to do—that is, increase employment and economic growth by throwing money at problems that cannot be solved in that way. Everyone in this country, including the current Prime Minister and those in the Labor Party, knows what needs to be done to get Australia going again.

What amazes people around this country is the failure of Labor to get on and do the things that need to be done, and which it has failed to do over nearly 10 years in office. Even more amazing is the fact that the Government has not put forward any policies or any plan for the future of this country after the next election, or even in the run-up to the next election.

Where are its policies? We do not see them. They are not in written form. They have not been articulated, either briefly or at length. There is no evidence that this Labor Party has any idea of what it proposes to offer to the Australian people in the lead-up to and after the next election should there be a tragedy and it is re-elected. Nothing is offered to the Australian people. All Labor is offering is more of the same. God help us. God help this country. Labor simply has no idea what it wants to do after the next election, and we can only conclude that, if it is re-elected, it will basically do nothing because that is the sum total of its policies articulated to date.

Clearly the Labor Party will resort to scare campaigns and the big lie as its platform for the next election since it has no positive policies of its own to speak of. Even in terms of short term political expediency the Labor Party would surely be better off adopting some of the economic reforms proposed by the coalition, instead of sitting on its hands and doing nothing except throw money it does not have at problems it cannot fix. At least the Government would then be holding out some hope for the future, regardless of who won the next election and regardless of whether it can be believed.

Unfortunately, this Government is too short-sighted, too blinded by its own perceived political interests, to do anything in the long term interest of this country. It hopes that by throwing enough money around it might just squeak past the post at the next election, thereby achieving the full extent of its vision, whatever that might be, for the future of Australia. It must be Labor in power, I suppose, whatever the price. Labor in power whatever the price—that can be the only objective that is apparent to thinking people in this country.

Over the weekend the Leader of the Opposition signalled his intention to come into this Parliament and debate the real issues confronting this country; not the diversions, not the stunts. The Treasurer is the Minister for stunts, the Evel Knievel of this Parliament, who promises a soft landing and, like Evel Knievel, does not actually manage to achieve it.

That intention of the Leader of the Opposition was clearly signalled. The Prime Minister was aware of it. But what does he do? He still relies on the fact that half the community, unfortunately, thinks that Question Time is a substitute for debate. We have Ministers saying in their answers, `What this debate is all about'. There is no debate. The coalition parties do not have an opportunity to state an opinion on the views being pressed upon us and the rest of the country at Question Time.

But when there was a chance given for that debate, provided over the weekend, as I have said, by the Leader of the Opposition—he was not trying to ambush the Prime Minister; it was all out there in the open that he was going to come in and debate the issue—where was our Prime Minister? Our famous Prime Minister dingoed out. He refuses to debate the real matters of substance in this country today. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) said, he will go for any diversion, any distortion, be it republicanism or the monarchy or the flag, to get away from the real issues because he cannot cope. I know he is up there now having his afternoon nap, and good luck to him. I would like to be having a nap myself. For all the relevance and the importance he attaches to this chamber, he is in the very place he should be. I wonder why he even bothers to come down to Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we would all have been grateful had the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) gone and had his nap rather than contribute for 30 minutes, to be perfectly honest. I notice that the public gallery all but cleared during that time, and that is understandable.
—They're not flocking back in now, are they?

—No. They probably realised, after 30 minutes of the honourable member, that there are other places in Canberra worth seeing. In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), it is probably worthwhile spending a bit of time looking at some of the attitudes of the Opposition over recent times in respect of the economy and encouraging economic growth.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting when we look at areas such as fiscal policy that the honourable member for Curtin referred to the fact that Budget surpluses were a cyclical phenomenon. That was the claim he made, and that was the reason he gave for the three Budget surpluses in the late eighties. The Opposition has occupied the Treasury bench for something like 30 of the last 40 years and we know that, prior to the late eighties, there had not been a surplus presented to the Parliament by a Government since the beginning of the 1950s. One wonders how long the cycle must have been if the surpluses of the late 1980s were purely a cyclical phenomenon, as the honourable member for Curtin claimed.

We then turn to the discussion about interest rates. Ever since the first in the current round of interest rates cuts in February 1990, the gloom and doom that we heard today from the honourable member for Curtin have been expressed by various Opposition spokesmen. They have claimed that we would create a run on the dollar, that we were pushing the pace too quickly, that we would be out of step with the needs of the rest of the world, that we would reignite inflation and so on. But all of those claims have been proved wrong.

It is only this Government which has broken the back of inflation—a disease which was endemic throughout the Liberal period in government. The Liberals could never overcome inflation. It did not matter whether the economic tide was turning or whether it was during the 1982-83 recession, at no stage could they get control of inflation. Because they did not have an adequate wages policy, inflation was allowed to run amuck. Inflation was built into the psyche of everyone in the nation during that time. Businesses had to learn to grapple with that inflationary cycle. Indeed, broader problems occurred later because Australia did not develop a proper anti-inflationary strategy in those years.

We now come to dealing with the problems which Australia has today. They are acute indeed. In these Appropriation Bills and in the measures which are contained in the Budget and the One Nation statement, it is a case of trying to create the stimulus which is vital in order to get the economy going. We are not approaching this problem with a notion of spending for the sake of spending. We are looking at ways in which we can achieve greater efficiency through training the work force more effectively, providing the training mechanisms to deal with the structural adjustment which has gone on—and is going on—in many industries, and through looking at the micro-economic reform measures which are vital to the economy.

The honourable member for Curtin said that nothing had been done with regard to micro-economic reform. I wonder what happened in aviation. Substantial reform in that area has contributed to the broader efficiency of the Australian economy. This has been achieved only by a Labor government; it was never touched by the conservatives in their period in office. Indeed, they tightened up the aviation industry in 1983 on the eve of an election which they would inevitably lose. Yet we are told that those opposite have the blueprint for micro-economic reform. Their record does not suggest they have anything of the sort.

In the area of telecommunications, again it is this Government which has introduced competition. One has only to pick up a newspaper every day to see the benefits which will flow to the whole of Australia, but particularly business throughout Australia, as a result of the reforms in telecommunications. We then turn to the area of financial deregulation. The honourable member for Curtin says that this Government has failed to tackle micro-economic reform, but financial deregulation certainly fits into that category. We can also look at areas such as the waterfront where there has been a 50 per cent reduction in manning levels as far as coastal shipping is concerned. But we are told that is not a significant reform. Of course, that is a nonsense.

In the One Nation statement we have sought to recognise that, by rebuilding national infrastructure—national rail and road networks and so forth—we can build efficiency into other areas at the same time. Much of this infrastructure was allowed to fall into decay for decades, and it is an indictment on those opposite that we have not been able to move those projects through as quickly as anyone would wish.

But the point of these Appropriations is not to say that we will not continue with the effort to build a national rail network and the efficiency which goes with it in relation to freight movements around the country. We have acknowledged that we cannot do as much in this financial year as was envisaged originally. But we will not lose the benefits of those improvements; they will be carried out over this financial year and the next. At the same time, the stimulus which the economy needs will be applied to other areas this year.

If we look at the Opposition's Fightback document, we can see that the Opposition has always underestimated the worth of local government in terms of the national economy. Those opposite have never appreciated the value of working in partnership with local government. The local capital works program is one of the provisions contained in these measures. Additional funding has been brought forward from the 1993-94 financial year to this financial year. It has been clearly shown that this scheme has worked effectively. Local government has picked it up and supported it strongly. It has acknowledged its capacity to help to rebuild parts of the local infrastructure. Local government has acknowledged the part it can play. It is a body which has the capacity to gear up quickly and start the civil works projects which it has on its books and which were in need of funding.

I can nominate all sorts of projects. I have received an update from the Parramatta City Council of the projects it has up and running already. It has not needed to wait, it has them up and running now. These projects are important in terms of the local infrastructure needs in my electorate and they have ramifications for other electorates. Many of the projects that have been approved throughout Australia relate to the tourism industry—a growth industry which promotes growth in employment. In my electorate alone, something in excess of 1,000 people are employed in the tourism industry. That is an increase from zero in 1983, with the capacity for that number to be increased even further. It will be increased and enhanced by providing a stimulus through infrastructure to encourage more interest in the tourism industry in regions like mine. Many other regions have even greater tourism infrastructure which can be enhanced through local government working with the community.

The welcoming of such initiatives has not come from just local government; it has come from business organisations, community organisations and environmental groups in the area. A very wide cross-section of people acknowledge that there are opportunities here. These people acknowledge that initiatives can be taken to encourage long term employment growth and to encourage the immediate stimulus that is needed as part of the building blocks which will enable that very strong industry to develop and prosper in the years to come.

All of those things are being achieved because the decision was taken in the Budget—and the additions that are provided in these Appropriation Bills reflect this decision—to use local government as a strong lever to get stimulus going. We are told, `No, that is all just pork-barrelling'. That was the concept put to us this afternoon—that none of this is worth while.

The people whose homes are flooded frequently—and this occurs in parts of my electorate—and who are not able to get adequate attention from all levels of government to have those problems solved welcome the fact that the Federal Government has at last taken the lead in doing something to solve those problems. The benefit cost of doing those things—that is, in terms of not having to call on national disaster funds as we have had to do in the past—will be considerable. We are making an investment by embarking on those projects. They are anything but some sort of pork-barrelling exercise, which was the nonsense that we heard earlier in the debate.

Let us move to the area of training. Again, we are told that labour market initiatives are a waste of money and that they are just positions; they are not real. Could we then say that the formation of the National Training Authority—the initiative taken in July this year—falls into the same category? What an absolute nonsense. At long last we will have training in the vocational area of education treated on a proper level.
