The moneys that are provided in these Appropriation Bills will help to build on those initiatives and help to ensure that there is the financial support to pick up the labour market initiatives.

If we were to go to a Jobskill centre or a Skillshare operation and see the successes and the value that have been achieved in terms of people developing technology skills to enable them to gain employment in new areas of the work force, would we say, `That is not a valuable investment by the people of Australia in the futures of young people in this country.'? Of course, we would not say that.

The Jobskill project, the Skillshare project and the various labour market programs are providing people with real opportunities. The take-up rate of permanent employment as a result of those programs speaks for itself. That is why the initiatives being taken in these Appropriation Bills to provide that additional $17.54m for entry level training and the $59.1m for labour market assistance to job seekers are very welcome. Packages are being provided to enable employers to take on new employees as part of that process.

Those opposite could say that the process that Bill Kelty and Lindsay Fox have been going around the country espousing does not have value. That is presumably the net result of the contribution by the honourable member for Curtin. Clearly, employers throughout regions such as western Sydney have recognised that they can play a part. Often the employers are looking to the Government to show its commitment and enthusiasm and to find ways of accessing those programs. There has been strong support for the initiatives that involve additional assistance, where employers are prepared to take on at least 100 people who have been unemployed for six months. The reaction to that announcement a fortnight ago, certainly in my electorate, has been significant. Undoubtedly, there is more scope to improve on those programs as time goes on.

Turning to the upgrading of our road system, it is interesting that Fightback does not give too much clarity as to what the Opposition plans, other to say that it will basically be looking at funding levels equivalent to the 1991-92 year allocation, which is nothing like the investment being made in our road system today—again, part of building the national efficiency and the competitive opportunities for Australia.

Those opposite say that the money which is provided by this Appropriation Bill, the additional $30m for black spot road funding, is not a sound investment. I think it is irresponsible of them to make that sort of claim. We are dealing with various segments of road such as those that exist in my electorate, one of which was funded quite recently, where we have had fatalities this year. Those opposite say that spending money to fix those problems is not a priority. That is an outrage in anyone's language.

It is important for us to fix up our national road system, partly because of road safety and, secondly, because it helps to improve the efficiency of movement of goods around the country and our trading position. If we want to be internationally competitive in our export industries and so forth, we need to improve our road system and we need to improve the access arrangements of the linkages between the roads and ports, the railheads and ports and so forth. All of those things take time, but what matters is that they are given priority by every government in the country. Every government in the country should be committed to those things.

It does get somewhat difficult when one sees State governments not attaching much priority to the speed with which some of those things are done. Surely, with many of these projects, the plans should be on the drawing board ready to go. There should not be any need for a long gearing up process to occur. We have recognised that in some cases the projects are not moving as quickly as they should. We have said that local government, black spot road funding and labour market programs are areas where real performance is being achieved. We are enhancing those areas to provide long term opportunities from which people will gain as a result.

We have been told by the Opposition that funding on sport and community facilities is not a matter of priority. For many people, the provision of infrastructure for those things has important benefits in terms of health, in terms of providing opportunities for children, in terms of providing training facilities for children and in terms of providing the capacity for their interests to be pursued not only in educational hours but also outside school hours and on weekends when many people put in voluntary work. The Opposition says that those things are not really a priority.

The virtue of those projects is that they will ensure employment as they are developed. Last week I visited a project in my electorate of Parramatta that is being funded under the community sporting facilities program. I noted the progress being made in the development of this athletics and hockey complex. I noted the number of children who are taking a keen interest in sports, particularly as a result of Australia's success at the Olympic Games. I also recognised that, for the first time, children from the Parramatta area will have access to proper class facilities in order to develop their instincts and skills. Hopefully, as a result of that, we will have more people who are very enthusiastic about their sport and achieve excellence in sporting activity.

The benefits in terms of people participating in community and sporting organisations in the youth category should be self-evident. The benefits in terms of the health system by encouraging people to have a healthy lifestyle through participation in sport and associated facilities have been well documented over a long period. Again, it is wrong to claim that those sorts of allocations are purely short term-type initiatives. Nothing could be further from the truth.

I come back to the fundamental point of these projects. Many of these schemes are important civil works that local government in particular has not had the resources to undertake. As part of the preparation for the Budget, the Government took up the initiatives and the suggestions of local government throughout Australia because it felt that local government was in a position to play a very important part in Australia's economic and employment recovery. The Government, having obtained the details of many of those projects that local government organisations around Australia said they could develop, took those issues on board. The overwhelming reaction from the community at large has been extremely positive.

What is quite difficult with these debates is that the Opposition comes in here and says that all of these things are a waste of money. Yet, some members of the Opposition who are associated with these areas are the first to get in and try to establish that they deserve the credit for these particular initiatives. That just shows the duplicity that is attached to the Opposition's approach—that is, to say one thing here, but to try to demonstrate out in the community that they want to be supportive of these initiatives that take place.

What matters is that the people get the benefit of the facilities that are developed and that the employment which goes with the creation of those facilities is targeted to provide help to those who really need it. In the long term, the whole nation benefits by having projects developed that ensure both a better lifestyle and more opportunities for the people of the regions concerned. Industries such as the tourism industry are also developed as a result of these programs. Tourism is obviously a key one in many areas but there are numerous industries that are helped by these types of programs.

We can say that education does not really matter and that training does not really matter. We could go back to the days of 1983 when it was not considered appropriate for the majority of people to get access to higher education. In 1983, when this Government came to office, in western Sydney only one person in three was able to complete secondary school because no stimulus was given to encourage that to occur. Today over 70 per cent of people are completing secondary school. There are other initiatives, such as vocational training, the development of universities and the broader interest in labour market programs, which are helping enormously in that regard.

We are committed to ensuring that we provide the maximum help to all Australians as far as economic recovery is concerned. We are determined to deliver that. We are not going to get the projects bogged down by the lethargy of State governments that have not been able to gear up projects quickly enough to get them going; we are not going to let them be bogged down by the attitude of the Opposition that we should delay and not introduce these measures.

We have decided, quite properly, that local government and the various schemes that are contained in these Appropriation Bills can deliver important initiatives this financial year. We can pick up the other longer term infrastructure projects next financial year. It is entirely appropriate to finetune the measures in that way. I have much pleasure in supporting these Appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), I was rather taken by the fact that he seemed very quick to listen to the tired old rhetoric of his Leader but he did not actually do much careful calculation. I heard him say early in his speech that the Labor Party has been in power for only 10 of the last 30 years. By my calculations, as I was sitting here listening, I think it would be somewhat more accurate to say `13 out of the last 20 years'. Maybe that would put a slightly more effective and realistic measure on who is responsible for what has occurred in this country over the last 20 years. For the honourable member for Parramatta to try to give us a history lesson that goes back over the last 30 or 40 years is missing the point and totally misleading.
—They are trying to blame someone else.

—Of course they are trying to blame someone else. As usual, the honourable member completely overlooks the main problem that is facing this country right now—a very serious problem—and that, of course, is unemployment. Not only has he overlooked the problem and the size of the problem but also he was very quick to ignore who has really caused it. There is no doubt—one cannot go back into history—that it is the current Government, which has been in office for 10 years. It is in those 10 years that the seeds of the problems we have today have well and truly been sown.

PARA.TAB: He talked about some of the reforms that supposedly have occurred. He mentioned the waterfront. Can I say to the honourable member that, while there may have been some progress, it has been at considerable expense, not only to the users of the waterfront, but also to all taxpayers. At the same time, we still have a situation where the charges on our waterfront are anything up to six times as high as the charges in New Zealand. So I am not quite sure where that reform has led in terms of getting the costs down which, presumably, was what waterfront reform was meant to be all about.

He also wanted to talk about road funding. I understand that the honourable member has not been in this chamber all that long, but can I tell him that the run-down in road funding under this Government is nothing short of scandalous. When the current Government came into power, we had a thing called the Bicentennial Road Development Fund. That road development fund led to a significant increase in road funding. It was an initiative of the Fraser Government, not the present Government.

Since 1983-84 that program has been steadily run down. In fact, until this year, there has been a cut of something like 20 per cent in real terms in the amount of money going into roads—so much for his talk about what they are really doing for the country—and there has been a belated recognition in this year that maybe we had better spend a bit more because there is an election coming up.

At the same time, the long suffering road user, the motorist, has seen the fuel excise increase by well over 100 per cent. We have seen the situation where we now have over $7 billion being taken off motorists just in fuel excise. At the same time, the Federal Government is going to spend this year maybe $2 billion, but next year it is planning to run it all down again. In the Forward Estimates, I think, for the year after, it is down to about $1.4 billion, yet the tax will continue, quite contrary to what the coalition is on about.

I also notice that the honourable member spent some time attacking the States. He made the comment, `This Government is not going to allow itself to be bogged down by the lethargy of State government'. For the benefit of all honourable members, I draw attention to a very interesting article that talks about the activities of the Trades Hall Council in Victoria. I think it is very illustrative of the problems that have occurred, not under the current Government but, in fact, under the previous Government, the Cain-Kirner Government. When this Government wants to talk about micro-economic reform, it ought to look at the activity not only of the Government in Victoria—a Labor government—but at the way one of its senior Cabinet Ministers actually interfered in efforts by that Government to try to bring in some micro-economic reform. When honourable members read that article and see just what happened, maybe they might realise that the Government does not come to this debate with clean hands. Far from it. I will quote a little bit from this article written on 16 October this year by the former Premier, Mr Cain. He pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: At a Transport Ministers' meeting in Canberra 1989, Jim Kennan—
the then Minister for Transport—
had said the Federal Government was allowing Gerry Hand—
that is, the current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs—
to undermine micro-economic reform in Victorian transport.

Those are the words that were printed by Cain earlier last month. They show that back in 1989, in fact when the Cain Government did make an attempt at micro-economic reform, it was none other than a senior Minister in the current Federal Government who was trying to interfere. Mr Cain went on in his article in the Age to talk about when he spoke to Brian Howe. He said:

I told him that I had spoken to Bob Hawke several times about Gerry Hand and the way he was behaving. I said I believed the Prime Minister should exercise his authority over Gerry and ensure that he stopped undermining the Government's reform program.

May I just read that again? Mr Cain said that he asked the Prime Minister to exercise his authority over Gerry and ensure that he stopped undermining the Government's reform program. This is the transport reform program, the one that honourable members are talking about with such vigour today and yet, back in 1989, it was pretty clear, for some anyway, that their heart was not in it. The article goes on to say:
From what he said, the Prime Minister had not made any attempt to speak with Gerry Hand or to exercise any control over him as he had told me that he would endeavour to do.

So it was not just the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; it was the then Prime Minister who was sitting on his hands as well when a State government, a Labor State government, a State government of the State that both the Minister and the Prime Minister came from, was, in fact, trying to do some micro-economic reform and neither the Prime Minister nor this Minister was prepared to do anything to assist. In fact, the Minister has been accused by the then Premier of being worse than that, in trying to stop the reform.

PARA.TAB: The article goes on to talk about the way that the then State Government tried to get around it. It is really quite farcical when one sees what happened. The article talks about trying to get the new tram tickets and the stoppages that were going on throughout Victoria, masterminded by the Trades Hall Council, obviously assisted by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and obviously condoned by the Prime Minister, none other than the Labor Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

What happened? The Government of Victoria did try. It even went to the trouble, when it found that the printing of the new tickets for the trams was banned in Victoria, to get the work done in South Australia. Likewise, the transport of these tickets was banned. It had to find a way around that. So it actually took the tickets to the retail outlets in the boots of the executive cars. It sounds like high farce. But this was a State government that, at that stage anyway, tried to do something. Is it any wonder, after being let down by its own colleagues in Canberra, that the State Government under Mr Cain started to give it away? Is it any wonder, maybe, that Mr Cain gave it away? Mr Cain has a bit more to say about this which I think is worth bringing to the attention of honourable members. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think on reflection what the MetTicket dispute showed up until the end of January was how far behind national requirements for micro-economic reform the THC was at the time. The mindless number-only approach of transport unions might have been understandable in the climate that those unions had created over a long period of time. For the Trades Hall Council however there is no excuse for such an approach.

Yet we see today the same people, the same Trades Hall Council, trying to undermine a new State Government in its efforts to bring in micro-economic reform. What does this present Government do when it talks about its big progress on micro-economic reform? What does it do when a State government tries to do it? Having undermined its own colleagues, of course it has not hesitated to encourage its mates in the ACTU to go in to bat with the Trades Hall Council to try to help to undermine yet another attempt by the current State Government to bring in proper micro-economic reform in the area of public transport.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that the former Government had so much trouble? Is it any wonder that the people of Victoria are currently suffering unnecessarily through all the stoppages that are going on when one finds that there is a direct conduit to the present Federal Government here in Canberra in trying to undermine this micro-economic reform. So much for the efforts of this Government when it talks and brags about micro-economic reform, because when one sees what its actions are, one finds that they are very different. I will just quote one more section from Mr Cain's article. He put it very bluntly. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government comes out of this badly. These reforms were the very kinds of reforms that they had been telling us for some time we should be introducing. We agreed. We should have enjoyed the strongest possible support from our federal colleagues. The reverse was the case.

I say to the Government: shame on you. It is a disgrace. It is an absolute disgrace. Government members come into this chamber and try to tell the nation that they are all for micro-economic reform, when their actions, as pointed out by a former colleague in leading a State government, were quite to the contrary. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) earlier today in this place, when we were talking about micro-economic reform, said, `We are undertaking them at a breathtaking pace'. All that I can say is that if it is a breathtaking pace, he must be talking to a snail, because that is the only way a person would have noticed it.

PARA.TAB: I would like to talk specifically about a couple of things in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). I think that what I have said is very relevant because it highlights the problems that this Government has created through unemployment and so on, and it also brings to mind just how much the Government is panicking when one looks at some of the facts behind it.

This legislation reappropriates funds from Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) which had not even been passed into law at the time the new statement was made. That is how much the panic has set in; that is why the mismanagement is becoming so clear. It is really quite pathetic. The Budget was only two months old and the Government had to admit that it had miscalculated by at least $174m in the spending program for 1992-93.

The One Nation statement, the February economic statement, was the sixth economic statement of this Parliament. The Budget is the seventh since February 1990. It shows that the Government is having a statement-led return to this Parliament, a statement-led mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —Total.

—It is in total disarray. By its need to make statement after statement, we can see just how ill thought out the whole approach to the economy is. I might add, for the benefit of all honourable members, that the coalition has made this very clear on many occasions. Yet, because the Government has refused to heed the warnings, we now have nearly one million people out of work, 11.3 per cent of the work force is out of a job, and many of those jobs have been lost through the sheer incompetence of the Government. People must keep asking themselves: how can the Government keep making those mistakes?

PARA.TAB: What did the February economic statement do in relation to land transport? It was supposed to create 21,000 jobs in two years, and 15,000 of those were to come from road and 6,000 from rail. Yet we see unemployment keep rising. The Budget has also increased the funding for roads, admittedly from a low base, as I explained earlier. But all of this has failed when it comes to getting the country going again. It is clear that the Government is bereft of ideas. Let us look at some of the primary objectives of this Government and go back to April 1990, when the then Prime Minister wrote a letter to the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . our fourth term offers opportunities to quicken the pace of reform . . .
He went on to say:
. . . explore all options to create and fund a competitive land transport system, and must ensure the best possible return from the huge annual investment in this area.
That was in April 1990. Some 2 1/2 years later those plans are in total disarray. As Tom Burton said in the Sydney Morning Herald on the 14th of this month:
Adhockery wins again.
The pace of reform has not quickened. Indeed, One Nation slowed the pace considerably because it was politically motivated, not based on sound planning of the infrastructure needs of Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have seen many commentators point out time and again the problems with transport reform and the fact that it has not been moving fast enough. Back in April 1991, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is prepared to move quickly and decisively . . .
Do honourable members not like those words? He continued:
in cooperation with the states and territories to implement micro-economic reforms in Australia's road and rail sectors . . .

He went on to talk about the benefits which the Industry Commission estimated would come out of it, such as improvements to land transport or the reform of land transport, which would add $6 billion annually to Australia's GDP. The Minister went on:
Such substantial gains cannot and will not be ignored by this Government. It makes absolutely no sense to continue to forgo these benefits.

Where are the gains? Where are the benefits? We have not seen too much occur, have we? After all, the Minister talks about the rail reform, and now we have seen the desperate attempt to reallocate this money. We have seen the National Rail Corporation get started. What has it got? It is quite interesting. It has not one but three headquarters. That is quite an achievement: the new Corporation has three headquarters. But guess what: it does not have a train. It has three headquarters and no trains. That is real micro-economic reform!

TALK.START.PARA: —No trains? How can you run a railroad without trains?

—Well may the honourable member ask. But it has three headquarters, and one of them is on the forty-fourth floor of the Rialto building in Melbourne, right up the top; some of the most expensive real estate in Melbourne. That is an interesting set of priorities.
—Who caused this? The Minister?

—Who caused it indeed? Clearly the Government has to accept the responsibility. We could go on and look at some of the other so-called reforms that are just not occurring. When we look at the problems in Victoria today, it is significant to go back to the article written by the former Premier, Mr Cain. In 1989 he made an attempt to do some micro-economic reform. What did he find? Not only the unions were not going to cooperate, but in fact a senior Minister in this Government was aiding and abetting them and, even further, the then Prime Minister was condoning it by sitting on his hands when he was approached by the Premier asking for assistance. And what did he get? Nothing.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the current State Government in Victoria will be at the forefront of these reforms. We have in Jeff Kennett and Alan Brown, the Minister for Public Transport, two people who are determined to make it work, no matter what this present Government does. When we see the current support that it is giving through the ACTU to the union movement in its efforts to thwart the attempts by the new State Government in Victoria to bring in real economic reform, we have to question its bona fides when it keeps talking about micro-economic reform in relation to transport. We have already seen how it undermined its own colleagues back in 1989. We are now seeing it, through its efforts with the ACTU, trying to undermine the Victorian Government. I merely raise a very serious question: when the Government talks about micro-economic reform, we have to ask it whether it is really serious, or whether it is just rhetoric, like so much of the talk in this place every day.

The people of Australia are getting tired of that rhetoric. They are getting tired of a Government that ignores the problems. It is clear that the Government has failed. It has no new ideas, no new plans, no new policies; it is just lurching from disaster to disaster. As my colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) pointed out, the Government is now trying to think up a new stunt every week to distract people's attention from the problems that it has created, to try to make people think that the one million unemployed will somehow go away, although of course it will not. It has all the hallmarks of a government that is seriously in decay.

Like it or not, I say to the members of the Government: they have one million people unemployed in this country and the question is: when are they going to start doing something about it instead of just talking about it? It is clear that they have failed to deliver in reform; their economic management is appalling; the One Nation statement has failed; the Budget has failed; and these Appropriation Bills are just further symptoms of their incompetence.

Meanwhile, the recession continues, the debt climbs, and all we see is panic setting in. As I said earlier this month in my speech on a matter of public importance, while the Government may think what it is doing is good politics, it sure as hell is not good government. I do not think these Bills even reflect good politics, and they reflect even worse government. Labor members should hang their heads in shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has just delivered a speech which has next to nothing to do with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), but I will spend a moment replying to one or two of the things he said because they are worth responding to. One of the central points he was trying to make was his claim that the Government was opposed to micro-economic reform because it was opposing the industrial relations package in Victoria. This is the first time that I have heard micro-economic reform equated to exploitation. I would have thought that the industrial relations package in Victoria ought to be evaluated as to what it purports to be: a way of managing industrial relations. It involves removing most of the protection that employees in Australia have had during most of the last century, and shifting the power in the employment situation to employers so that they can then impose any kinds of conditions on their employees. That amounts to exploitation. That is not micro-economic reform; it is just a way of ensuring that injustice predominates.

PARA.TAB: It is entirely responsible, economically and in terms of social justice, for the Victorian union movement to reject that completely, and for everyone else in Australia who has any sense of commitment to good government, to consensual politics and to the resolution of disputes to oppose it so that it is eventually abandoned. If we are to have a just society in Australia, it is essential that the Victorian industrial relations package be defeated. To equate it with micro-economic reform is simply nonsense. The Federal Government's record of micro-economic reform is very impressive. I will not be dragged into a detailed recitation of it, except to say that there have been figures released again this week on the 20 per cent improvement in productivity on the waterfront during the last year. The honourable member for Wannon completely neglects that sort of achievement.

I will return to the Bills, because it is the Bills that we ought to be talking about. These Bills are about the continuing strategy of the Government to increase employment. The One Nation statement, the Budget and now these Bills have all been aimed centrally at maximising the rate of growth of employment. I was glad to hear the honourable member for Wannon say that he was concerned about employment. I wish he would demonstrate that in what he says, and I wish he would urge his own Party to adopt that as its central goal, because the effect of what it is proposing would be to increase unemployment further.

We have heard the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in the last few days rejecting the idea of expansionary fiscal and monetary policy at a time when, it is true, the economy is recessed. It is absurd for the Opposition to imagine that it can assist the economy to recover by further reducing government expenditure. Every Western country which is aiming for growth in employment and economic growth is introducing stimulatory policies. The President-elect of the United States, Mr Clinton, is committed to the expansion of government outlays in well-targeted ways which will build up the rate of economic activity and productivity in America. He is planning to increase outlays on infrastructure, on education, and on research—on the programs which will assist the improvement of productivity at the same time as they assist economic recovery. Mr Clinton is leading the way.

Japan introduced a major expansionary package a few months ago. The British Conservative Government, to whom the Opposition commonly looks for its guidance and for precedents, has just brought in another expansionary package. It has increased the proportion of national income passing through the public sector, through public outlays, by 4 per cent. It has increased public outlays from 42 per cent of its national income to 46 per cent in the last 18 months as a way of stimulating economic activity. Yet we have the Opposition feeling that it is cleverer than all the rest of the world, that it can act in a way which every other country would regard as perverse, and that in some way that will magically assist recovery.

We cannot take its set of proposals seriously. They did not work during the Great Depression. Those were the kinds of policies that were adopted in Australia, the United States and Britain in the early part of the Great Depression, and what did they do? They drove those countries deeper into depression. Adopting the same policies here—cutting government outlays and cutting wages, as the Opposition proposes to do—would drive the Australian economy, in the same way they did in the early 1930s, deeper into depression. We have to reject those policies conclusively and wholeheartedly and adopt, encourage and reinforce the well-targeted policies of the Government.

The Government, impressively, has responded effectively and in responsible, well-modulated ways to the recession. Of course we regret the recession. Of course unemployment is disastrously high. Of course that is a great tragedy. Of course, though, it is partly due to what has happened in the rest of the world. I will refer to some figures in a minute that show that much of the rest of the Western world is even more deeply recessed than Australia. But the Government has responded in responsible, well-targeted ways to that situation.

Since 1989-90, the Government has switched from a Budget surplus to a Budget deficit. The Budget surplus in 1989-90 was $8 billion; this year the deficit will be in the region of $15 billion. That is a switch equivalent to about 5 per cent of GDP. Some of us might have liked that deficit to be a bit larger still, but one has to accept entirely that a switch of 5 per cent is a major and quite dramatic change. It will steadily have an impact on the level of economic activity—it is already doing so, in ways which I will refer to in a moment—and it will steadily reduce unemployment. There is no doubt that more than simply changes of macro policy are involved in moving towards full employment again, but getting macro policy right is a necessary and perhaps the principal condition that is required.

This legislation is one step towards further implementing the expansionary strategy which was adopted in the One Nation statement and reinforced in the Budget in August. I do not find any difficulty in entirely defending the Government for trying to switch expenditure to the areas in which it will be most effective. The honourable member for Wannon tried to say that it was because of inadequacy that such a switch had to occur. I would have thought that any reasonable person would recognise that sometimes programs cannot be implemented as quickly as one would like. There are major planning processes, negotiations, and ordering and tendering procedures that have to be gone through before large projects can be brought into operation.

This legislation embodies some shifting of funds from areas in which there will be some delays into areas in which the funds can be effectively spent quickly, particularly areas of direct employment creation such as local government programs, programs through regional authorities, large enterprises that can take on more of the long term unemployed, and road funding. The honourable member criticised the Government for its expenditure on road funding. I was astonished by that. The major element of the infrastructure spending in the One Nation package was an additional $600m for roads. How much would the Opposition spend if ever it had the opportunity? All it talks about is cutting government outlays. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot criticise the Government for not spending enough and announce it will spend even less. So this is entirely appropriate legislation.

I want to describe the Government's strategy using some figures on economic policy that have just been published and which I do not think have been used in debate in this House. They are the figures that are produced annually by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on government financial estimates. They draw together the Budgets of the Commonwealth and the States and show how they will affect the economy on a standardised basis. These figures show, I am glad to say, that the Commonwealth is giving the Australian economy a major stimulus. The ABS estimates that the deficit in 1992-93 will be $15 billion. That is a very substantial stimulus. Last year the deficit was just over $10 billion. It is a bigger stimulus; it will, therefore, have a bigger effect.

At a time when inflation and our government debt is the lowest in the Western world—two facts that the Opposition seems to neglect but which, I am very glad to say, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been quite rightly emphasising—at a time when the two most important conditions which have to be met in order to justify a major expansionary fiscal policy are in place, the Government has seized the opportunity and is adopting a stimulatory stance.

I will dwell on debt for a moment, as it is under-recognised in the wider community. The wider community tends to be oppressed by the size of our overseas debt, which is a significant problem. It is very important to turn the current account deficit around. At present in public debate we normally fail to recognise that Australian government debt is the lowest in the Western world as a proportion of our gross domestic product. Our government debt as a proportion of gross domestic product in the last year, for which figures were published by the OECD, was 16 per cent. No country had a lower percentage of government debt than that. That figure includes not only the debts of the Commonwealth but also the debts of the States and local governments.

It is another way of pointing out that there is no crisis in Victoria. The Victorian Government debt as a proportion of state product is the second lowest in the Western world. It is only 26 per cent of state product, which is amazingly low. It is true that it is higher than some of the other States, but it is lower than in most other countries. Japan, for example, has a government debt to GDP ratio of over 100 per cent; Britain has one of just under 50 per cent; and Germany has one of about 60 per cent. I do not have the figures in front of me, but those are the orders of magnitude. All of them are much higher than the Australian or Victorian Government figures.

Let us get this into perspective. There is no crisis anywhere in Australia about government debt. It is true that it is always better to have lower debts because we have less to repay and less to service, but at a time when the Government debt is so low, getting it down further is not a priority. The priority at present is to stimulate employment and economic activity, and that is exactly what the Government is doing.

The figures published by the ABS show that current outlays by the Commonwealth this year are expected to rise by 6.7 per cent. Outlays by the States and local government sector are expected to rise by 4.3 per cent. That is a good complementary activity by them. Capital outlays by the Commonwealth are expected to rise by 16 per cent. That is a direct result of the One Nation statement, exactly what we want because it targets the need to build up activity in ways which will also contribute to building up productivity. Capital outlays by the States and local governments are expected to rise by 15 per cent. So again we have a complementary stimulus from the States, which is very welcome.

The growth in Commonwealth outlays is partly concentrated in social security and welfare, which is what one would expect at a time of high unemployment because high unemployment requires a high level of income support for the unemployed. There are small increases for health and education, which are very welcome in themselves. The growth in education spending is one of the features of the Budget which will contribute directly to the improvement of the skills of the work force, and that is very valuable. I could continue going through the figures, but there are a couple of other things I want to talk about before my time runs out.

I will draw the attention of members of the Opposition to some forecasts which the Prime Minister mentioned earlier in the week, which were published in the Economist last week. According to a group of authoritative and influential forecasters, Australia is expected to have a faster rate of economic growth this year and in 1993 than any other Western country. Those opposite talk about collapse, decay and so on. That is absolute nonsense. The facts simply do not support their case. The effect of good government policies, a stimulatory Budget, low inflation and a responsibly accommodating monetary policy

SPEECH.PARA: is that economic growth in Australia is recoering.

PARA.TAB: In 1992 these forecasters, who come from the United States, Japan, Britain and other places in Western Europe—they are averaged so that they draw together forecasts from a whole series of different sources—on average estimate a real growth of GDP in Australia to be 2.1 per cent in 1992, which is faster, as I have said, than any other country. In Britain, the economy is in decline. It is expected to go down by 0.9 per cent. In a number of other countries that is true. In those countries where there is growth, growth is slower than it is in Australia. In Germany it is expected to be 1.1 per cent and in the United States it is expected to be 1.7 per cent. All those figures are lower than that of Australia.

Next year there is mostly expected to be somewhat faster growth, but only moderately so, I regret to say. Again, the growth rate in Australia is expected to be faster than anywhere else—3.4 per cent compared with 2.3 per cent in the United States, 1.2 per cent in the United Kingdom, 0.6 per cent in Germany, and so on. Growth in Australia will lead to growth in employment and a reduction in unemployment, which is what we are already starting to see.

I want to conclude by drawing attention to the latest job report which has come out from the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training and which goes through its assessment of the labour market situation. It found in the September quarter of 1992 that CES job vacancies and job placements were the highest recorded for any quarter for the last two years. So stimulatory policies are starting to lead to growth in the number of vacancies and growth in the number of job placements. That is exactly the kind of hopeful sign we have been looking for. As well as that, the job report concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: Compared with the same period in 1991, vacancies increased in all industry categories in all States, with the strongest increases in SA, Victoria and WA and the weakest in NSW, Tasmania and Queensland.

That is very encouraging. It is exactly the kind of positive news we would expect to receive at a time when stimulatory policies are being adopted. That is now starting to happen. As well as that, the job report shows that the number of placements in labour market programs organised by the Department are very positive as well.

PARA.TAB: For these very constructive reasons, it is a delight to be able to support this very positive and responsible Bill which puts more funds into those areas where employment growth can be stimulated most quickly and most directly. Therefore, I wholeheartedly support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise tonight to talk about Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). Before I begin my speech, I refer to the speech made before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) made a couple of extraordinary points. I was staggered to hear him say—and this is quite unbelievable—that there is no problem with debt in Australia. He then went on to say that there is no problem with debt in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: As a Victorian, I have to say that the new Victorian Government has a somewhat different attitude and the Victorian voters have a somewhat different attitude. It seems to me that the honourable member for Fraser does not understand the basics. Victoria has got itself into an extraordinary situation. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was so ashamed of its financial efforts that he failed to show the $1.2 billion in the last Budget Papers. It was pushed conveniently to one side; it did not exist. When a State government borrows money and then uses the borrowings to pay interest on loans, how can the honourable member for Fraser say that it has no problems with debt? One wonders what financial school he went to: it was obviously the school that pays American Express with Bankcard and Bankcard with Visa.

I have never heard so much nonsense from a member of this place. For him to say that there is no problem with debt shows that he does not understand the fundamentals. Debt has to be paid back sooner or later by somebody. The tragedy in Australia today is that the $180 billion deficit that we owe as a nation will be paid back largely by our children and our grandchildren. Anyone who has been part of this Government for the last decade, who has seen that debt run from $30 billion to $180 billion, ought to hang his or her head in shame at that particular record.

This Bill will reallocate $150m of railway expenditure and $24m of electricity expenditure to other areas of the Budget. It is fairly obvious that, even though the Budget was brought down only a couple of months ago, we have a government in shambles. Why in such an extremely short time is the only two-months-old Budget already out of date? The Government already has to reallocate moneys—duck and shove. Maybe we have an election coming on! Who knows? Maybe the Government will try to get unemployment down by taking money from infrastructure and putting it into artificial job creation schemes. It is a worry when a government takes huge amounts of money, pokes them around and plays ducks and drakes instead of governing this country as it is charged to do.
A press release from the Treasurer dated 13 November, in which he announced this relocation program, states:

SPEECH.PARA: We expect a total of 20,000 new positions to be created or brought forward as a result of these initiatives.
It sounds reasonable until one looks at the record. It continues:

In particular, the Government is offering an enhanced package of assistance to every major employer in this country willing to employ full-time at least an additional 100 persons who have been unemployed for at least six months or who qualify as young trainees. The same offer will apply to incorporated regional authorities proposing to employ full-time at least an additional 200 persons.

On reading this, the flavour of this Government comes out again: big government, big business, big unions. That is the thrust of it. Government members do not care about the little man; they do not care about small business, which is the backbone of this country. They just go down that line of looking after their mates.

PARA.TAB: I found one bright spot in this reallocation of money, and it is in relation to road funding. This press release talks about the black spot program. An extra $30m is being added to the road funding program to improve black spot areas. I am pleased that the Princess Highway running from Pakenham in the west of my electorate through to Traralgon is being duplicated. Those sections that have not been duplicated in the last two years have the tragic record of 10 deaths. I find that a tragedy, which I hope we can overcome by duplicating that freeway and other parts of Australia as quickly as possible. We must all pull together to reduce the carnage on our roads.

One Nation is supposed to be a package to create jobs. But what did the Government do? It picked the place that has the highest level of employment in Australia—Canberra—to allocate $1.25m for the refurbishment of old Parliament House. For the Government to allocate $1.25m for the refurbishment of old Parliament House in an area that has high employment in the middle of the worst recession in 60 years is quite frankly a disgrace. What standards has the Government set by allocating $1.25m to this project? It seems crazy on any criteria for the Government to allocate this money to an area of high employment compared with the rest of Australia.

I thought it beholden upon me to look back at the One Nation speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 26 February to see the record and what was proposed. It was an interesting speech, made on 26 February, a little under 12 months ago. It starts as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: When I became Prime Minister a little over two months ago I pledged to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy I could muster.
It goes on to say:
Tonight we turn those words into action. Tonight the Government presents a Statement to get Australia moving—a four year strategy for growth in the nineties.
Those were big words. The next page of the One Nation document reads:
A four-year plan
Labor's plan for the next four years will create over 800 000 jobs, without increasing the current account deficit and at the same time returning the budget to surplus and Australia to growth.
It is sick when one thinks about the reality of what has actually happened. It goes on further:
We have a $2.3 billion dollar plan for Australia.
Mr Speaker, tonight's Statement contains great initiatives. I believe, historic initiatives.
Measures big enough to kickstart the economy and get things going. Big enough to get people back to work.
This was in February this year. It is extraordinary.
And big enough to stir the imagination.
But our program will do more than speed our recovery from recession—it will build the Australia of the future.
It will help our young people now; and it will still be helping them when they raise their own children.
Building on our advantages and the great gains we made in the `80s, it will make us much stronger.

People cannot believe that this statement was made by the Prime Minister on 26 February this year when they look at the Government's miserable record—where unemployment has gone to 11.3 per cent. Underemployment adds dramatically to that figure. Yet the Prime Minister still has the audacity to come into this place and say, time after time, how proud he is of the record. He should be ashamed of himself. Under the heading `The Big Projects' he states:
Mr Speaker, for much of our history Australia has been disadvantaged by the great distances which separate us. . .
Our major population centres were—and remain—hundreds of kilometres apart.
Our lines of supply were long: the costs of transport high.
Why does the Prime Minister not take out the fuel excise? One simple move, as per Fightback, and the tyranny of distance would come down. He then talks about the workplace, and says:
Mr Speaker, a nation cannot be strong if at the very point where wealth is made—the workplace—people are locked in conflict.

But in the last fortnight we find him standing up in the House being proud of the recycled communist in Victoria—Halfpenny—leading strikes against a duly elected government with a mandate to reform the workplace. This Prime Minister goes down the track of supporting such a man. He went on to say something about industrial relations which I agree with:
But basic standards must be met. We will not support slashing minimum wages and conditions.

It is strange that he says that because the average income in real terms in Australia has dropped by 1 1/2 per cent over the last 12 months, the period since this document came out. Unlike the Prime Minister's document, with Fightback we believe in a genuine high wage policy that will give average workers the freedom to do something about looking after their own destiny.

PARA.TAB: Towards that end, I thought it would be interesting to briefly run through a speech given by Terence Ward, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of Heinz Australia in Dandenong. It is interesting to note that the Heinz company has just bought out Watties New Zealand. Heinz Australia is a manufacturing food company which has a $230m turnover. Watties has a $540m turnover, so they are roughly comparable. In a speech to the primary industry committee of the Opposition, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: For some time Australian food processing companies have been conscious of the lower cost structures which apply in New Zealand. Average weekly ordinary time earnings in the fruit and vegetable industry are about 73% of comparable Australian rates. Labour on-costs in Australia which include payroll tax, workcare premiums, rostered days off, sick leave, long service leave, annual leave provisions, annual leave loadings, and shift premiums add 33% to wage costs; whereas in New Zealand the figure is closer to 16%. In total the cost of employing people in New Zealand is only 64% of what it is here.
He went on further to say:

Business is also attracted by the opportunities afforded by the New Zealand's deregulated labour market. The ability to negotiate on shift loadings and weekend penalty rates can make it feasible to operate a factory twice the number of hours that is economically viable in Australia.
Deregulation of energy, shipping, ports and transport is progressively reducing the costs of these services in New Zealand.
. . . it is considered that New Zealand is a significantly lower cost base than Australia for exports to Asian and South Pacific countries.

. . . if we wish to grow our Australian business and expand our exports into Asia we have to improve our competitiveness compared with our new New Zealand affiliate, and this is a significant challenge for us.
We cannot succeed unless the environment in which we are operating in Australia becomes less unfavourable compared with New Zealand.
He is talking about government policies. He goes on to recommend the following:
Government charges—particularly payroll tax must be reduced or eliminated and probably, as in New Zealand, the only way this can be accomplished is through the imposition of a Goods and Services Tax.

This is said by the Managing Director of a company which has a company in Australia, Heinz Australia, and Watties New Zealand. He is comparing like with like and is saying quite clearly that if we keep going down this track with the nation that we used to think of as a basket case and a bit of a joke 10 years ago, we will export Australian jobs to New Zealand as well as to other parts of Asia. As part of his speech he makes the comment:
Labour contracts must be deregulated—as is happening here but too slowly. . .

Despite the rhetoric of the Prime Minister, who tells us that voluntary employment agreements are wonderful, Mr Ward says they are happening much too slowly. One of the final indictments he has of the Government's policy is when he says that transport is a big cost in the tomato industry. Heinz is a great producer of tomato paste. He goes on to say:

Tomatoes have to be carried from farm to factory and finished products shipped to markets in the cities, usually some distance from the rural based factories. The per kilometre cost of carting tomatoes is twice as high in Victoria as—
wait for it—
in California as a consequence of Government imposts on fuel prices and we welcome the Coalitions' intentions to address this issue.
This man, a great Australian, who is at the coalface of creating jobs, is saying very clearly that, under current Government policies, he has no other option but to export jobs from this nation.

PARA.TAB: I spoke to him about the Dandenong plant. I asked about its future, given the bad industrial relations record of a couple of years ago when it had hundreds of tonnes of tomatoes rotting in its store. I said, `Will you relocate somewhere else in Australia to a greenfield site?'. The answer was `No'. Quite clearly it meant that if Heinz Dandenong is to shift, it will shift offshore. This is a tragedy when we look at the One Nation policy that this Government has brought out, which says that it is a wonderful policy and that it is on track. The trouble is the track is a disastrous one and is leading this great nation to rack and ruin. We have a Prime Minister who will say anything or do anything to maintain his own job at the expense of so many young Australians: it is something he should be ashamed of. It was interesting to pick up today's West Australian and find, under the headline `Australia 10 years behind NZ—Myers', that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Leading New Zealand businessman Douglas Myers says Australia's economic and industrial reforms are moving far too slowly—so slowly they are a decade behind. . .
The article finishes by saying:
Studies showed New Zealand's productivity was now around 30 per cent better than Australia's and wages had risen marginally.

PARA.TAB: Mr Myers said the goods and service tax was a non-issue in New Zealand.
"The Labour Government (which introduced the tax)—

SPEECH.PARA: in New Zealand—
won the argument by getting out and showing people that, compared with alternatives, a tax mix including GST was a better and fair system." he said.

PARA.TAB: "It seems odd that a tax adopted by most OECD countries, including the Catholic countries of Europe, should arouse such passion among church and welfare lobbies in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So there we have it. The evidence is in black and white from those at the coalface that what the Prime Minister is doing with jobs in Australia, and with Australia's future, is just more of the disastrous same of the last 10 years and he should be thoroughly condemned, as I have no doubt he will be at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reasons for Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) have been well canvassed, not only in the second reading speech by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) but also in the speeches that have preceded my contribution in this debate. It is perhaps in the best interests of the House if we reflect on the issues that are involved in why we find ourselves in this position. Partisan politics aside, what we should consider is that a genuine effort was made in the One Nation statement to allocate funds to worthwhile infrastructure projects. These projects involve the Commonwealth's sitting down with the State governments and coming to an agreement about process and about implementation. If we consider that the process has been slow leading to the reallocation of these moneys, it is a slight indictment of the way that our federal system operates.

PARA.TAB: It is further emphasised that in the reallocation of these funds the measures announced in the Budget, involving further infrastructure projects, this time aimed through local government, have proved so successful that we can consider changes that would involve that sphere of government even more. It is really a challenge for Australia to come to grips with the way in which the three spheres of government relate to each other.

Later in my contribution—I do not think the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) will be surprised at this—I will mention what is happening in Victoria. But, even giving that case as an extreme example, Australia's future demands that we improve upon the system left to us by those who framed the Constitution, some 100 years ago, to bind together six colonies of the British Commonwealth.

The High Court decision of yesterday about other matters within the Constitution has evoked a great deal of comment; some, I might say, has not been complimentary of the High Court itself. But I do not totally agree with those who make those comments because I think that what is at fault is the Constitution on which the High Court had to make its judgments. The sooner the Australian people understand that and can look at the Constitution and constitutional change with maturity, the better. What we need to do is to look at a constitutional framework for this nation that best suits it not only in the 1990s but into the twenty-first century.

As honourable members have acknowledged in their speeches in this cognate debate, the reallocation of moneys in these Bills involves not only the bringing forward of local capital works program money allocated for the next year but also allocating moneys for black spot eradication projects and other very worthwhile infrastructure projects of that kind. I was disappointed with the statement by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall) about the allocation of funds for the refurbishment of the old Parliament House. On previous occasions in this place, I have urged the Government to take action to find a use for the old Parliament House, the provisional Parliament House. On those occasions I have suggested that it could, in some form, be used as a place of historical education about a whole host of things associated with the constitutional development of this nation and parliamentary democracy.So I am pleased that the Government has seen fit to take the step to allocate this money. Millions of people have visited this building since its opening. If visitors were able to go down and have a look at the provisional Parliament House, that would be an additional experience, and an educational experience, while visiting Canberra. I do not think we should look at things in a parochial way. There are regional imbalances in the way in which unemployment has hit different parts of Australia. We must realise that there are reasons for funding worthwhile projects that, in addition, will lead to worthwhile employment.

The election that will occur next year will be an election of contrasts. It will be an election that shows the different approaches of the Government and the Opposition. It will be a contest between the Government, which sees it as quite correct to be, in part, expansionary and to provide stimulus to the economy, and a government that would contract government outlays and be very contractionary in the way it looked at its Budget. It will be a contrast between the Government, which sees that there is a need to move, in not only the long term but also the short to medium term, on the aspect of unemployment, and the Opposition, which would offer the Australian public measures, the benefits of which, if any, on the unemployment and employment situation would be very much long term.

The type of new tax being offered by the Opposition needs further explanation, and not only in the sense of marketing and selling a product, for the Australian public to be convinced that it will in any way create employment because, really, it is just a rejigging of the tax regime. As has been repeated often, and was repeated today in Question Time by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), the GST, by being a value added tax, can be seen as a tax on the labour input of goods and services provided. In that regard it provides no encouragement at all on the labour input side of goods and services. That is something that the Australian public is acutely aware of and will give good consideration to before deciding who they will be supporting at the next election.

But the contrasts go even further. The behaviour of the Kennett Liberal Government in Victoria gives Australians an opportunity to have a glimpse at what life might be like in the unlikely and unfortunate event of the election of a Hewson coalition government. It is a very sobering experience to consider what those changes could be. After only a few weeks since the change of government in Victoria, Australians can see that putting a Kennett clone in Canberra—or is it the Hewson clone in Spring Street?—would have a distinct effect on their lives.

Firstly, let us look at the way local government has been treated. As the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) said in Question Time today, there has been a blatant disregard by the Kennett Government for consultation with local government and involving it in the collection of the new tax that that Government has put in place—a blatant disregard and lack of consideration of the democratic rights and freedoms of institutions such as local government.

The tax itself is another example of a pernicious and inequitable tax. It is a flat tax, a regressive tax. Already there have been savage and unnecessary cuts in government services, again characterised by the haste with which they have been announced—haste which has led to very little, if any, consultation with the people involved.

The Australian public can now have a glimpse of the future by observing Victoria with its industrial mayhem which has followed the hasty actions of the Kennett Government. But why, we must ask, is it deemed necessary to institute the type of ideologically driven measures that we have seen, the narrow-mindedness that has never been seen before? It reminds us that the Liberal Party always governs in the interests of only part of the community. Honourable members from Victoria know that the community is gripped with fear—the fear of what cuts will come next.

Already we have seen the announcement of school closures, which will mean thousands upon thousands of jobs disappearing and people's democratic rights of protection under awards and their hard-won conditions of employment ripped away. We have seen the introduction of the so-called deficit levy, a pernicious community charge likened to a poll tax. In several ways it is akin to a GST: a flat tax that pays no regard to people's ability to pay.

I was reminded by the release of Paul Kelly's book about politics in the eighties of John Elliott's unsuccessful efforts when he was President of the Liberal Party. This led me to recall a speech I made in 1988 at a time when John Elliott used his position as Federal President of the Liberal Party to enter into policy debate. The John Elliott of that period was very much a Thatcher acolyte. He talked of billion dollar cuts to government outlays and of a consumption tax. It is interesting that at that time we contemplated that the Liberal Party was talking about a consumption tax of 5 to 7 per cent.

With the assistance of some well-guided research, at that time I asked this House what was next, what next the likes of John Elliott would consider from Thatcher's Britain. I put it to the House that perhaps a poll tax would be considered. When the Kennett Government announced its poll tax, those words came back to me. It is a prescription straight from the now discredited Thatcher handbook.

Why is the poll tax so objectionable? Firstly, as I have said, it is the result of a State sphere of government treating another sphere of government with utter contempt and disdain. As the Minister for Local Government said earlier today in Question Time, it shows a complete disregard for any pretence of partnership. There was no consultation; councils were just told that the notices would be sent out and that they then had a debt to the State of $100 times the number of rateable properties. Local governments were told that, even if they did not collect all the amount they were told to collect by a certain date, they would have to pay it, and pay it not only from the collection of this objectionable tax but out of their rate revenue.

The second element that makes this entirely objectionable is the fact that there is a complete lack of equity in the way it is applied. The people of my electorate clearly understand that this poll tax is inequitable. They know that a family of six on minimum wages, living in a weatherboard home in Thomastown, will pay the same as the owner of a multimillion dollar mansion in Toorak. I am sure that not only most Victorians but most Australians would instinctively understand that this is not fair.

Who thinks it is a good idea that the rich pay the same as the poor—or some of them at least, particularly those responsible for developing Liberal Party policy? Here again all Australians can learn a valuable lesson from the punishment inflicted on Victorians by Jeff Kennett. The ideology which led to this pernicious poll tax on Victorians is the same as the concoction of academic waffle known as Fightback. As my research into what John Elliot was considering shows, perhaps it is not even original waffle, but waffle that has been around for quite some time. It has been tried under Thatcher in Britain, tried under Reagan in the United States, and in both cases there is no evidence to suggest that it was tried with success.

Fightback has as its centrepiece another flat tax, another consumption tax—a goods and services tax—and, like Mr Kennett's poll tax, it can be seen to be unfair and to strike the disadvantaged with much more severity. Look at some of the cuts that the Kennett Liberal Government has already announced. Last Friday we had the announcement of school closures. It was announced that over 50 schools will close at the commencement of next year. I know many of these schools well; many are in disadvantaged areas. Not one word has been said about the impact on the resources of nearby schools of the displaced school populations.

No consideration has been given to the special education facilities that will be lost by the closure of secondary colleges such as the Northland Secondary College, which has been acknowledged as having great regard for the disadvantaged people of the area it serves. No regard has been given to where the 318 students of schools such as Keon Park Secondary College will have an educational opportunity when school commences next year. Those 318 pupils will have to be absorbed into nearby schools.

At Northland Secondary College, 475 students, within a month, will have to decide where they might take up their educational opportunity. Both these schools are surrounded by secondary colleges which are already finding it very difficult to find appropriate resources to look after the student loads that they have. Greensborough Secondary College is another school in the local area to suffer. There the senior campus has been closed. The school council has already had to contemplate how it will find places for the students of that senior campus. Places will have to be found and new school buildings put in place.

Other areas are lined up for cuts—whether it be third groups in kindergartens or whether it be the unknown as to what the Kennett Government will do under the national child care policy that had been worked out previously. What will happen to railway lines such as the Hurstbridge line where there have been rumours of a closure? That is not the way the Government should go.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest about debt? You were in power 10 years.
—It should sit down and consult with the community in the tough times ahead. (Time expired)
