DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES (SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill reintroduces part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992—the provisions to licence subscription television broadcasting services, or pay TV. As we are all aware this section was removed from the original Bill by the Opposition parties in the Senate chamber four months ago. Dismay was expressed at the time that pay TV may never again emerge from the `black hole' of the Senate committee system to which it was referred. However, the Committee acted expeditiously to complete its hearings and bring down its report which was tabled in this chamber on September 16.The Committee sought to resolve two major issues: how and when pay TV service licences would be issued; and how best the ABC could participate in the industry.

PARA.TAB: Despite its best endeavours the Committee did not provide the Government with a ready solution to the impasse on pay TV. The debate has moved on even since the Committee tabled its report. Optus recently advised the Government it now intends to move to digital transmission as soon as the technology is available. It proposes to sell channels not transponders. Most potential bidders for a licence have also informed the Government they will wait for digital technology on satellites before starting services.

The Government therefore proposes to mandate the use of digital technology for pay TV using Optus satellites. Opting for digital satellite systems will place Australia at the forefront of world developments in direct-to-home satellite broadcasting technology. Current licence conditions on Optus only require it to make available six channels for pay TV until mid-1994. Optus has agreed to provide satellite capacity for up to 10 pay TV program services until 1 July 1997.

To allocate this capacity equitably, and recognising the commercial requirements of this new industry, the Government intends to issue two commercial licences A and B to provide up to four pay TV program channels on the Optus satellite. These will be issued simultaneously using a price based allocation system under the provisions at section 93.

The choice of the digital system will be a joint decision by licensees A and B in consultation with Optus. It is important that this decision is left to the commercial judgement of the operators because of the significant cost involved in the reception technology and the extent to which it can be adapted to meet licensee needs—for example, pay-per-view, interactivity.

The system chosen will be used by, and accessible to, all satellite pay TV service providers. The chosen system will then be set as a standard by the Minister for Transport and Communications under section 94(1). Any disagreement will be arbitrated by the Minister. No further satellite pay TV licences, other than that for the ABC which I will outline in a moment, will be sold before 1 July 1997.

Hence section 96(3) states that the Australian Broadcasting Authority must not, before that date, allocate a satellite licence. Satellite pay TV licences issued after that date will be allocated under the provisions of section 96 for single program services, with the Trade Practices Act operating to govern ownership limits. It is important to note there will be no restriction on the use of other technologies to deliver pay TV such as cable or microwave—MDS. They will be licensed under section 96. These will be vetted by the Trade Practices Commission under section 97 before licences are issued to ensure competition policy objectives are met.

I now wish to turn to the role of the ABC in the proposed pay TV industry. The Government has always sought to have the ABC participate in a sensible, commercial manner with three vitally important caveats:

SPEECH.PARA: .the ABC's core free to air TV services suffer no detriment.
.the taxpayer not be exposed to any financial risk from ABC involvement.
.the ABC board accept responsibility for the extent of the national broadcaster's involvement, given its fiduciary duties.

PARA.TAB: This Bill provides at section 93(2) that a third licence—licence C—to provide up to two pay TV services be allocated to a subsidiary of the ABC. The Government will maintain its earlier commitment to give the ABC $12.5m in seed finance. The extent to which the ABC participates in pay TV, forms commercial relationships with licensee A and/or B and other subscription service providers, and the nature and extent of programming will be left to the discretion of the ABC board.
To minimise the risk to the Commonwealth from the ABC's involvement the Government will use ministerial powers to set licence conditions under section 93(3) to require it:

SPEECH.PARA: .to operate its pay TV services through a subsidiary company with a separate board;
.to require that borrowings of its subsidiary over $2m are guaranteed only with ministerial approval;
.to require that an approved charging regime be developed for use of ABC assets and for goods and services provided to its subsidiary; and
.to require that an accounting regime on a fully attributed cost basis be developed that fully brings to account profits and losses.

PARA.TAB: Cross-media ownership limits will apply to licence A at sections 106 to 108 of the Bill. These will prevent control and allow a maximum of 2 per cent equity for commercial television broadcasters, large circulation newspapers and the telecommunications carriers. These provisions facilitate diversity in media ownership by allowing at least one new player in Australia's media.

The Government is confident there will be a number of bidders for this licence. No ownership and control restrictions will be applied to newspapers, incumbent commercial television licensees and telecommunications carriers participating in licence B. This is to offset the special treatment given to the ABC and to allow the structural adjustment of the incumbent commercial television licensees to the new medium.

The Government does not intend to place a legislative straitjacket on the ABC. Either or both licensee A and B can participate with the ABC in licence C subject to any conditions specified by the Minister for Transport and Communications and the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. However, it is intended that a condition be set by the Minister, at section 93(3), that the ABC must retain a majority equity holding in its licence at all times.

Section 110 provides that neither licensee A nor licensee B can control or hold more than 2 per cent equity in each other. The 2 per cent limit minimises the opportunity to manipulate the ownership limits as a defence against hostile takeovers. It does not penalise business where a small parcel of shares is acquired inadvertently.

Foreign ownership limits at section 109 are to be the same as those proposed earlier—that is, no more than 20 per cent individual and 35 per cent aggregate foreign holdings in any subscription television broadcasting licence, not just the satellite licences. The Government considers that the Senate Committee's recommendation to increase program expenditure on Australian drama content on all predominantly drama channels to 15 per cent is unrealistic.

Section 102 confirms our earlier decision by placing a 10 per cent program expenditure requirement on satellite drama services, but has expanded it to all drama services irrespective of the delivery technology. This Bill places several imposts on the new industry that will add to the cost of pay TV. It will take some years before pay TV services reach break-even. To impose further expenditure requirements on them could threaten their commercial viability.

Opportunities for Australian production are enhanced under this model. There are more channels available and three licences in the market from day one. Australian content requirements will also be reviewed in line with provisions at section 215(b) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

The Special Broadcasting Service can choose to participate in pay TV. It could do this by being a provider of programs to pay TV operators or by participating in commercial arrangements for the provision of satellite and other subscription services. As with the ABC, any participation by the SBS in commercial pay TV will be subject to conditions to protect SBS free to air services.

The introduction of pay TV and the mandating of digital technology presents exciting opportunities for Australian industry. This legislation allows licence conditions to be imposed to ensure that licensees A and B put in place adequate Australian industry development arrangements. The details are to be worked out by the Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). As we settle these details an important focus will be on the employment opportunities provided by this new industry.

We recognise that industry development requirements should not be imposed in a heavy-handed way. However, minimum requirements will be that licensees A and B will need to select consumer reception equipment that is available for manufacture under licence in Australia. A specific licence condition banning advertisements until 1997 is at section 101 of the Bill. The ban on X-rated programs and restrictions on R material already incorporated in schedule 2 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 have been retained for all subscription television broadcasting services.

Pay TV needs costly and sophisticated central subscriber databases, control systems and technology to turn describe subscribers `on' and `off' and to bill them. All licensees are free to operate their own subscriber management systems but will be required by a licence condition set under the powers at section 100(3)(b) to provide access for other operators to their systems at a fair price.

Section 116A allows use of additional satellite capacity so that pay TV coverage can reach areas where direct reception of the Optus high performance beams is impractical. This provision will allow satellite pay TV licensees to make use of other beams or technologies without requiring separate licences. The Bill recognises that satellite is the only technology that is readily accessible now to most Australians to receive pay TV services.

As set out in section 132 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, the sole means of delivering pay TV by satellite is through use of Optus satellites until 1 July 1997. After that date, other suitable satellite capacity could be used by pay TV operators. Providing this degree of protection during a time when further satellite capacity is likely to become available in our region and mandating the use of digital compression technology for the delivery of satellite pay TV offers significant commercial advantages to Optus.

The Optus `monopoly' extends only to the provision of its satellite based facility. The Government requires assurance from Optus that the use of compressed digital technology for pay TV will not require that the remote services using Optus satellites be converted to digital transmission, nor that there will be flow-on pricing increases for those remote service providers use of satellites. Section 115 and a licence condition at part 6 of schedule 2 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 prevent the siphoning from free to air television of events listed by the Minister.

I would like to make a few points in conclusion. A regulatory regime for pay TV in Australia has been 15 years in the making. The Government has responded in a responsible way to what the Senate has asked for in its Committee report. The Government was asked to mandate one channel for the ABC—this legislation gives it two. We have given it funding and allowed it maximum flexibility within the system.

I would remind honourable members that the original ABC Galaxy model involved the national broadcaster entering a consortium as a minority partner with no money, trading its programming for equity, and competing for a licence in the price based allocation process. It now has its programming, $12.5m of public money and two assured channels on the satellite. This is a rational and responsible proposal for the introduction of pay television into Australia. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the pay television Bill—the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill—and, for some of us, it is `here we go again'. I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who is at the table, for the explanation contained in the second reading speech—yet another attempt to try to establish pay TV in this country. I think people ought to be aware of what is happening here tonight with pay TV.

PARA.TAB: This legislation commenced in the Senate earlier in the week. It has to come here, as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) is in the other place, go through this House rapidly tonight, and then go back to the Senate. Hopefully it will be concluded tonight. Unfortunately this will be a truncated debate about the commencement of a new industry. That is what pay TV is. In part, that is why there has been so much debate over such a long period about the proposed structure of pay TV.

As I have watched this debate over the last 20-odd months—almost the same period as the gestation period for an elephant—I wonder whether we are finally going to see something emerge. Personally, I hope that we do because pay television has been denied to this country for too long.

This debate has occasioned a lot of self-denial from many people. Members on both sides of the chamber have worked long and hard so that we might finally see the pay television Bill passed tonight. I apologise to members of the Screen Producers Association for not attending their dinner tonight but, as this matter was coming on, I felt it was worth spending a little time preparing. This is one group that will benefit from pay TV, because it will provide yet another avenue for programs, particularly programs that are made in Australia, which is dear to members of that organisation, and which they have been discussing in Canberra tonight.

I think that it is probably worth while having a few moments to reflect on the procedures and policy decisions that have been followed in this debate. I will be moving a second reading amendment later in the debate. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, a second reading amendment requires the support of a seconder and of course I am waiting and hoping that a body will appear—any body will do. I do not mind what shape it is. I am pleased that Santa Claus is here. I am pleased to say that the Opposition Whip, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), is here to second the amendment. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House—

SPEECH.PARA: (1)records the fatally flawed nature of the Bill and notes that, in Government, the Liberal and National Parties will move so as to ensure that a much more competitive model is established in accordance with the principles and concerns set out below;
(2)condemns the government for:
(a)what has been a chaotic policy process in relation to this Bill;
(b)its regulatory policy for pay TV services which:
(i)contradicts the stated aim of the principal Act to readily accommodate technological change;
(ii)treats the delivery of pay TV by satellite as a special case;
(iii)creates barriers to entry by placing severe restrictions on licence A and few on licence B and by prescriptively limiting foreign investment; and
(iv)prescribes advertising on the satellite pay TV services;
(3)notes that the Bill:
(a)does not provide an `open architecture technology';
(b)provides for the use of only 10 satellite channels until 1997, with limits on the A and B licensees to 4 channels each and on the C licensee to 2 channels;
(c)makes artificial distinctions between broadcast and narrowcast services; and
(4)expresses its concern:
(a)about the possible vertical integration of satellite pay television licences and possible monopoly control of the subscriber management system;

(b)about the process of setting transmission system standards specific only to satellite pay television which may result in standards different from all future television services and standards dissimilar to the rest of the world;

(c)that the common reception equipment is specified only for satellite digital pay television services when this same equipment may be capable of providing access to all future digital television services; and
(d)that the resulting standards may result in a high cost to the consumer".

Unfortunately, I have to say that the very first matter that I wanted to raise in my second reading amendment, which has been circulated, condemns the Government for what had been a chaotic policy proposal. There was nothing chaotic about the entrance of my colleague, the Whip, to second this amendment. I thank him for doing so.

PARA.TAB: I think that it has to be said that this debate has gone on and on and on. There was a four-year Government imposed moratorium on pay TV that ended in September 1990. No decision was reached and the moratorium was extended for another year. That is despite clamouring for a long period of time that pay television ought to be available in this country. We saw a March 1991 rejection by Cabinet of a proposal by Minister Beazley motivated by the impending sale of Aussat and how to make it more attractive. Then, in October 1991, the Government announced that the moratorium would end on 1 October 1992. There was a great flurry of activity at that particular time.

In November 1991, an exposure draft of the Broadcasting Services Bill was released which included the first of many models for pay TV. Its essential feature was one national licence protected by an exclusivity period until 1997. Indeed, that exclusivity period is a centrepiece of the proposal that is put forward here. There are cross-media limits of 25 per cent for individual commercial television companies, an aggregate limit set by the Minister, and foreign ownership limits, also set by the Minister. By March 1992 the whole matter was thrown into confusion by yet another communications Minister. I have to say that the Government has had a procession of them over there.
Mr Martin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously nobody wants my job. Senator Collins, I think, was about our fourth or fifth communications Minister. Senator Richardson came forward yet again with a new model which had individual cross-ownership limits and an aggregate limit on foreign investment. Yet another Minister was appointed in May 1992 and he again had to go into the learning curve about pay TV, although I have to say that the people involved in the Department have been there all the time and I continue to be amazed at their capacity to live through all these dramatic jumps and hurdles.

PARA.TAB: I was sitting in Perth watching the Channel 9 program one Sunday and I saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) appear and announce yet another pay TV model. I think that that particular announcement surprised about 98 per cent, maybe even 99 per cent of the Labor Party. So we started yet again. That was on 31 May, when we saw yet another model come forward. Then, by June, we saw another about-face, with the Prime Minister announcing mark II with a full transponder licence to be operated by new players. I am not going to go into a great deal of detail.

But then, by 24 June, the Broadcasting Services Bill was introduced. It was during that period and that debate at some early hour of the morning in the Senate—and all the action in this debate seems to take place in the Senate—that we saw the Broadcasting Services Bill, which had included the satellite pay television proposals, excised and sent to a committee. It was interesting that one of the centrepieces of that debate on that occasion was whether or not the ABC ought to be involved in pay television.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who set it up? Who was responsible?
—I cannot remember who was responsible! The honourable member knows well that I can remember who was responsible.
—You were responsible.

—It was responsible to do that. If one took the in principle decision to allow free to air television to migrate into a new industry and there was going to be, over time, a movement of audience from free to air to pay television, as there has been in other countries, it seemed to me to be the logical argument that that opportunity should be extended to public broadcasting. The trick always was: how actually would that be done? Indeed, I am pleased to say that the Government has come up with a decision, which I think has merit. Whether it will work or not remains to be seen.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to the ABC, which wrote to me the other day and provided me with some concerns that it expressed, that it was too late again to get this information to me. I am not sure when it got to the Government but, in any event, some of the concerns it raised I think lack foundation. It was concerned about the Trade Practices Act but, in any event, I think its concerns lack foundation. It has been given an opportunity and I note that in the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade the ABC is lauding the proposals that have been put forward by the Government for pay TV. All I say is that I welcome it. We are all going to be interested to see whether it will work. I do not believe—and I will have some remarks about Trade Practices a little later—that the ABC ought to fear the involvement of the Trade Practices Commission in this proposal.

Finally, we come to tonight, when we are now debating yet another and, I hope, the final proposal. I think that the Government stands condemned for the way that it has handled the policy processes. I think that any objective observer who has watched this debate—it is technical in its terms, but it also excites a great deal of interest from a lot of vested interests—has been confused from time to time about where the Government is actually going as it tries to grapple with this proposal.

The Government's rhetoric is all about competition and allowing technology to flourish, yet the essence of this structure is that it has tried to curtail and limit technology. I have to say—and I have been saying this for a long time, and it probably bores people—that because I have been saying it for a long time and my Party has been saying it for a long time, some of the message has got through. This model includes some changes on the last model. The first and most significant change is that there has been the embracing of digital compressed video, in preference to analog technology. That is a bipartisan position now. That requires and gives the capacity to a whole new range of opportunities.

The last time we were debating analog technology, which was limiting, we got ourselves into great excitement about how to access transponders and who gets what, and so on. There is a much better approach taken on this occasion. But that is the first and most important thing. The other issue that has now picked up, of course, is the role for the ABC and possibly the SBS in being involved in providing some of their program expertise—Australian in flavour that it is—into a pay TV regime that will emerge over time.

The TPC is to be embedded in the Act for the delivery of whatever method, although there is a limitation that it is not applicable to the involvement and the issuing of the A, B and C licences. The Opposition moved an amendment, which enjoyed some support in the other place, that picked up an involvement of the TPC. In my view, that is important. It is consistent with the second reading amendment which I have moved, the genus of which is that we believe that a much more competitive model is established in accordance with the principles and concerns set out in the amendment. I commend the amendment to anyone who might be contemplating entering into the pay TV regime, so that he is fully aware of what the coalition's view is about how the future should unfold.

But to come back to the TPC and the amendment that I have moved—it was agreed to in the Senate—the basis of the amendment is to give the TPC a total coverage across the Act. There is only that small area that is exempted within the Bill, which is hopefully soon to become an Act. I notice that the Minister for Transport and Communications in the other place was not overly excited about this proposal and I welcome his grudging acceptance of it, even though he felt that he had to speak against it.

We want there to be recognition by the TPC of the realities of the marketplace. We want investment and expertise to be involved in pay TV to make it work. The key issue is the definition of `market' in the assessment of any pay TV arrangements and consortia. Our desire in moving that amendment relating to the first licences is to maximise the benefits to consumers and also to ensure that the industry does have an opportunity to proceed.

I know the TPC is cognisant of and sensitive to the sentiments that are expressed in the amendment that we have moved. We would not, of course, expect that the TPC's involvement would in any way curtail the emergence of a pay TV regime. We just believe that the competitive emergence of a pay TV regime is a central issue. It is an issue of principle and it ought to be one that is consistent throughout the Bill.

There are some other matters that are worth mentioning. This time there is no exclusivity in technology of delivery; there is no exclusivity for a single licensee in the provision of satellite delivery; there is common customer reception equipment for satellite pay TV, which is an issue that I think is extremely important; there are codes of practice relating to billing and fault repair, privacy and credit management for satellite pay TV; there is a contents standard amendment relating to R-rated material on satellite pay TV—and I will have a little to say about violence shortly; and also there is an attempt in proposed section 116 to ensure that as much of Australia as possible is covered by satellite pay TV, even though that amendment only extends to not requiring additional licence issues. But that is a matter that is probably going to cause some difficulties and some future concern, and it may be an area that we will have to focus on as the industry develops. Senator Harradine moved in the Senate an amendment to introduce a clause on standards for satellite pay TV relating to the protection of children, and those issues are picked up.

All of those issues have come forward into the regime that we are now debating. They were a product of the arguments put forward from this side of the House, and they have been broadly accepted by the Government. So even though this has been a long, chaotic experience, it has certainly been an experience that has enjoyed broad industry support. It is a structure that, although fundamentally flawed, is a little closer to what we believe ought to be the final outcome. It is for that reason that the coalition will allow this legislation to pass. I know that is cause for a great sigh of relief from the Labor Party Caucus—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very generous gesture.

—It is a very generous gesture, given that the structure is fatally flawed. But it is also important, after so many years, that at least there is a piece of legislation upon which the industry can fixate and from which we can have some stepping forward to the possibility of the emergence of a pay TV industry.

PARA.TAB: I wanted also to make some more points and I was going to talk at length about DCV, but I will not. Digital compression video also means that channels are redundant. It now has the capacity to provide program services that we are talking about. But the flaw in the Government's proposal is that the model artificially limits this capacity to 10 channels. DCV technology dramatically expands the capacity way beyond the 10 channels which have been split between licences A, B and C. There are reasons for that, which I can understand, but in principle it is fundamentally wrong. In combination with that, we have a limit to 1997. I have my own private theories as to why 1997 is the date, which probably do not bear to be expanded here. I do not think it is a rational reason; but it seems to be a date that keeps appearing in the broadcasting legislation. As I have signalled before, it is a date that we do not agree with and it is a date that we will visit, in terms of review and otherwise, at an early time. We will also be looking at the issues to which it relates.

There are alternative delivery mechanisms available. There are MDS—microwave—cable and offshore satellites. The exclusivity of the Optus satellite is challenged by these alternative deliveries. The immediate services are microwave, and they are ready to go now. I expect that there will be some movement in that area straight away. There are no foreign restrictions, and neither there should be, on holding an MDS licence. I hope that they will commence straight away. They will be more localised and regionalised pay TV services. AOTC-Telecom is also examining alternatives for the delivery of pay TV in the period before optical fibre becomes universal. According to AOTC, these technologies are in much the same time scale as DCV by satellite. DCV, or the satellite services that we are talking about, will not start for 12 to 18 months anyway, and if we have these alternative technologies available, they may well be coming on stream at the same time as the satellite systems—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—I will not hold my breath, but my fundamental point is that as there are emerging alternative technologies, it lends credence to my point: why restrict our preferences to the use of one technology? That is the issue that I have raised in the in-principle amendment. The hybrid optical fibre co-ax proposal is a mature technology which can be commenced in the short term but requires significant investment. It is probably that, more than the technology, that might delay it; but in combination with MDS, perhaps, other opportunities might emerge. There is digitally compressed video to flow over copper, which is a new but proven technology, and that also might be a possibility. Again the main question will be cost. Indeed, trials are about to commence in Centennial Park and Wollongong to try out these alternatives.
—Absolutely.

—Sorry, I should not have mentioned Wollongong with the Parliamentary Secretary here. There are other issues and alternatives, too, and they include the offshore satellite services. AsiaSat 2, Pan Am Sat and Intelsat will come into Australia in 1993. Satellite services emanating outside Australia are not limited by the Bill. This is a major victory and concession to us, as we have strongly pushed for no limitations.

PARA.TAB: So, in other words, services which are competitive with the exclusive until 1997 Optus DCV satellite will be a reality prior to or at the time of the commencement of what is provided for in this Bill. The Government's model is, in a sense, an unlevel playing field, and some are concerned that licence A might be a virtual dead duck. It is the licence for new media players with a 35 per cent foreign aggregate restriction. As I point out, we are not prescriptive about the level of foreign investment in this industry or, indeed, others.

I have already mentioned the Trade Practices Commission. The Bill breaks new ground in the coalition's agenda by requiring in proposed sections 96 and 97 that the TPC overview licence allocations beyond 1997. I think that is a sensible proposal. As I have said, we moved an amendment, which was accepted, which tries to build on that in relation to the A and B activity, that is, the initial licences. The opportunity for niche services versus free to air is an issue that I think I have related already. We have to recognise that in time the networks will shed significant market share, as they are already a mature industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down.

—Yes, I will not be long. In any event, pay TV is an industry that sees the beginning of a proliferation of niche services, which will include information data and interactive services, in addition to pure entertainment. The program menu for the consumer will be far more extensive, and the consumer will choose rather than have it chosen, as is now the case. The networks are thus keen to protect their investment and seek to have a significant role in order to spread the investment and capture the migrating market. The Parliament is giving them the opportunity to be involved in this new industry. I think, in principle, that is a correct decision. So our goal, of course, is to ensure that new players can in fact play, and that there are not barriers to entry that are such that only current networks can play, which effectively exclude others. That is one of the issues that I am relating to in the second reading amendment.

PARA.TAB: There is pressure on time, and I understand that many of my colleagues who wanted to speak will not be able to speak for very long. That is why, as the principal respondent—if that is the right way to describe my position on behalf of the Opposition—I have taken a little bit more time. I also want to refer briefly to the amendment that has been circulated by the Government. It relates to codes and it is, in part, the response to the legitimate concern that all of us have about violence on television and so on.

The Bill was amended in the Senate by Senator Harradine, but the Government is seeking to amend that amendment also. As I understand the Government's amendment, it seeks to put in the positive any action by the Parliament to review the voluntary codes proposed by the industry to the Parliament. It is my view, on reading the Hansard of yesterday, that that is a reasonably sensible amendment. I sought some legal advice about that from within the Parliament today and, cursory though it is, I think it would be appropriate that I seek the leave of the to table it.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice is from the Legislative Research Service, and is an overview of the central issue that I believe the Senator Harradine amendment raises. It is not a matter of changing the sentiments of Senator Harradine. At page 3503 of the Senate Hansard of Wednesday, he made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: So it will not be a situation where only one House of the Parliament decides the issue.

My understanding of his amendment is that it can have the impact of allowing one House to respond to concerns about a code while not requiring the other House to take a positive step in support of those concerns. Broadly committed as we are to a sense of voluntary codes, we would not want to allow for a mechanism that, in a sense, would defeat them. There has been some debate about whether or not that is the interpretation that should be put on the Senator Harradine amendment. At this time I take the view, based on my advice, that the Government's amendment has some legitimacy, so we will not be dividing on it on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: There are many other issues that I want to raise, and I know that many of my colleagues who have followed this debate at a distance also want to raise some matters. I come back to my fundamental point that this industry needs to be allowed to have an open-architecture approach to technology. It needs to be competitive in all its aspects, but it also needs to be able to start. There are long-run investments required and it is a risky business; there is no doubt about that. It will be difficult in the current economic climate for this industry to start, but significant benefits will flow from it and we recognise those benefits.

We have consistently argued the case for pay television for many years. In the past we have introduced private members' Bills in an effort to establish pay television in this country. When people look back at this debate, they will see that it involves a reasonably momentous decision. I do not know whether we will finally get this Bill through. If we do, it will be a start. It is not as constructive as we would want it to be, but I believe we are taking a genuine and constructive approach in allowing this legislation to pass. We have argued consistently that it needs to be better than it is. Previously we have successfully held it up to make the Government focus on many more issues. Some of them have been picked up, but not all of them.

I wish well all those who will be participating in this industry, because we want the industry to be successful. But let us keep consumers in mind, because they are the ones who need to benefit from this industry. They will benefit best if this industry is not limited artificially by the intrusion of a government which is trying to pick technological winners or particular operators as winners, and if we allow as broad as possible a regime to develop in the terms of the second reading amendment that I have moved. I hope that later tonight this Bill will not come back here again.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to second the amendment. The honourable member for Bass has echoed all of the sentiments I feel about this very vital amendment and I am happy to second it. I reserve my right to speak.

—I support the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill. I am mindful of the number of Government members who chose to speak on this Bill and who, because of the time frame, have been cut short. It is a very important piece of legislation because it will carry Australia into the next century, with the enormous complexities and various technologies that go hand in hand with pay television. With this legislation comes the continuation of the amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, which will lead to increased competition in telecommunications.

PARA.TAB: This Bill allows for the licensing and regulatory administration for the provision of subscription television broadcasting services—pay TV, as we like to call it—which can now be delivered using any technology: cable, microwave or satellite. The legislation also contains regulations pertaining to the licensing of individual pay TV services, as well as putting in place a specific regime for pay TV services delivered by satellite. Concerns about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's involvement have been addressed, and measures to provide consumer protection in regard to pay TV are introduced with this Bill. One of the most important aspects of this legislation is that the ban on X-rated programs and the restriction on R-rated material which is already incorporated in schedule 2 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 have been retained for all pay television broadcasting services.

Recent community concern over violence on television following the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about the amount of unnecessary and potentially damaging violence shown on television today proves that restrictions on our programming are necessary and warranted. Whether we like it or not, people equate violence on television with violent public behaviour. Mothers organisations and community and church groups have all come out in support of our Prime Minister's suggestion to restrict violence on television by airing certain programs later at night so that children are less able to be influenced by and subjected to them. The issue will recur again and again following the commencement of pay television. The Parliament should be fully aware of the number of people in our electorates who feel strongly about it.

The effect of television violence on children is an overriding community concern. Young children are less able to distinguish fantasy from reality and generally have undeveloped media literacy skills. Parents must therefore fulfil their important role as guides for their children's television viewing. However, parents need assistance in providing this guidance for their children. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal believes that this help should be given to parents through media education programs and the adoption by the industry of clear and appropriate program scheduling and classification practices.

There is confusion in the community between the classification system for television and those for cinema films and videos. There will also need to be a classification system for programs shown on pay TV. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal said in its 1990 report to the Parliament that adoption of a similar standard of classification for cinema, video and television could encourage more permissive programming on TV. This in turn could create too great a tolerance of aggression. The ABT therefore did not support a common system of classification at that time. However, within the framework of the current classification system, adults have the right to make their own decisions about what they view on television, provided that children are protected from unsuitable and possibly harmful material. Therefore, a uniform industry-wide code should be adopted. Our Prime Minister's recent request for the industry to move in this direction is certainly a step towards achieving this code.

Australian society has become increasingly concerned about the level of violence on TV as the level of violence in real life has itself appeared to increase. The number of horrifying massacres occurring in our suburbs has contributed to a growing belief that Australian society contains unexpected elements of extreme violence. The attention devoted by all forms of the media to violence and violent crime has added to a widespread feeling that violence is a major problem in Australian society. Coupled with this feeling is the assumption that in some way there is a connection between violent behaviour and the violence portrayed and presented in the media, particularly on television.

While the responsibility for what is shown on television now relies on television broadcasters, the Government and consumers, with the advent of pay television restrictions on violent programs will be difficult. Therefore, it is up to the Parliament to consider and investigate every avenue available in an effort to protect children from potentially harmful material on pay television.

It is also up to the industry to take into consideration community concerns and respect these concerns when organising its programs. If the television networks have a legitimate interest in pay television, they should prove now that they are prepared to reflect community attitudes through their free to air programming.

I am pleased that our Government has taken the issue of violence on television in hand. I am particularly happy that the newly created Australian Broadcasting Authority will soon commence Australia-wide research into community attitudes towards levels of violence and depictions of sex to allow it to devise appropriate classifications for pay television. I am also pleased that our Prime Minister has succeeded in his negotiations with the television industry in coming up with a proposal regarding programming classification which should be supported by this Parliament. According to the proposal, the M and the MA categories, which will replace the AO which is currently used for television, are an excellent idea. The timeslot for M category films will be 8.30 p.m., while the MA programs will be aired at 9 p.m.

The Australian Broadcasting Authority will monitor the utilisation of the new classification system and ensure that television stations suitably modify material for broadcast within the appropriate codes under the self-regulatory framework. This new system will mean that for the first time AO-type films will be more appropriately classified and the 8.30 timeslot will see softer material telecast than is presently aired under the current system of classification.

The networks have also agreed, I am pleased to say, to the Prime Minister's request that the sexual, violent and bad language content of movies is described so consumers can make an informed decision about what they are going to watch. The average American child sees 8,000 murders and 100,000 other acts of violence on television by the time he or she leaves primary school. We do not want a situation like that occurring in Australia. Our Prime Minister's proposal is a step towards the prevention of these sorts of statistics becoming the norm in our country. A review of the classification system is long overdue, and I am sure the Prime Minister's proposal will receive general support from the industry and the community.

I support the legislation before the House and trust that the classification system adopted in regard to pay television will take into consideration the current debate over violence on TV and the proposal put forward by the Prime Minister, which will ensure the protection of our children from harmful and overly violent programming.

Again, I am mindful of the time allocated for me to speak on this very important piece of legislation. I commend the Bill to the House and I certainly commend the Minister for providing this legislation, which has now finally become a reality.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 4—Page 12, proposed paragraph 128(1) (b), line 27, before "the other House", insert "otherwise than as mentioned in subsection (2),".
Page 12, proposed subsection 128(1), line 30, omit "the day on", insert "the 28th day after the day on".
Page 13, proposed subsection 128(3), lines 1 to 8, omit the subsection.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government opposed the amendment to section 128 of the Broadcasting Services Act in the Senate and still opposes it. It is of grave concern to the Government that under the amendment a program standard or code of practice could be amended without being formally considered by either House. The Senate's amendment fundamentally compromises the arm's length position of broadcasting from politics and the independence of the regulator; that is, the Australian Broadcasting Authority. It takes the powers over standards away from the community through public consultation and the ABA and weakens the new body we have just established.

PARA.TAB: It is an underlying principle of the Broadcasting Services Act that the regulation of broadcasting be carried out by the ABA, the expert body, on Parliament's behalf with parliamentary oversight in certain areas, such as program standards. The amendment makes a mockery of the concept of supervised, guided industry self-regulation and allows industry to wriggle out of its responsibilities to take full account of community attitudes.

Notices introduced under the amendment could potentially have serious financial implication for broadcasters and, without the guaranteed scrutiny by at least one House, could lead to the market reassessing the risks associated with investment in the broadcasting industry. The amendment also overrides the power of the independent regulator and could be viewed by some as the Parliament indicating that the regulator's decision should be subject to change by Parliament without even Parliament needing to consider the changes. It hardly demonstrates that the Parliament has confidence in the regulator.

However, if the Opposition is to persist with this, the Government will not let it be a basis to reject the pay TV legislation. Unfortunately, Senator Harradine's draft got it wrong. In the interests of good law, we therefore move our amendment to fix it up. However, recognising the intention of the Opposition and the Democrats, the Government's amendment No. 1 ensures that at least one House votes on the motion to amend. Amendment No. 2 provides a 28-day period for the industry to make the necessary changes to comply with the amendment, otherwise broadcasters would be required instantly to conform with the changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reiterate some of the remarks that I made earlier. The issue here is as I outlined. But I have to say that I disagree with the section in the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Martin) where he talks about the amendment making a `mockery of the concept of supervised, guided industry self-regulation'. I think the intent was not to undermine that broad issue; the intent was to give the Parliament a role.

PARA.TAB: The issue of the amendment addresses the effectiveness of that role, such as that it will not give to one House in preference to another an opportunity to make a decision about an action it might propose to take and exclude the opportunity for the other House to so act. Generally speaking, the Houses should be required to take a positive action with regard to any action that is proposed. It ought not to be, therefore, something occasioned to change without one of the Houses actually taking a positive step; in other words, if one of the Houses takes no action, the proposal from the other House becomes the decision of the Parliament.

These matters are extremely important to many members and, indeed, to the industry. I think it is important that we try to get it right and that we do not establish a precedent in the legislation. I understand that if this amendment had gone through in the form proposed it would be somewhat unusual and deny the opportunity of the Parliament in both Houses to act in a concerted, positive way to address a concern that it might have about a legitimate issue relating to voluntary codes. It would be, in my view, very rare for this to happen and, indeed, that was the point that was made in the Senate. But we need to ensure that both Houses are effectively involved.

There is, as I said earlier, some dispute about this issue. That may continue in debate in the Senate. I would be a brave man if I could predict the outcome in that chamber on any matter, as I know the Senate seldom listens to anything that we might say here, but I hope my remarks might be a guide. We will wait with interest to see what happens. I quote from the bottom of the paper that I tabled:

SPEECH.PARA: An amendment is a positive act, which makes a positive change, and it is arguable that amendments should only be made upon a positive vote of the House.

That is, of either House. I think that is the genus of the argument that I put which I understand, in the main, is the argument that the Parliamentary Secretary is trying to put here when we take the politics out of his statement.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In a statement to the Parliament on 15 September 1992, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) outlined the Government's reform strategy for spectrum management. That statement followed the Government's acceptance of the 1991 report on spectrum management by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

The Radiocommunications Bill 1992 and related legislation gives effect to those changes. The new Bill will replace the existing Radiocommunications Act 1983. As well as including the reform measures outlined in the Minister's earlier statement, the Bill incorporates provisions from existing legislation which are not being substantially changed, although the opportunity has been taken to modernise the drafting of the legislation. While the Bill is fairly technical in nature, it represents a significant reform measure which complements and extends the Government's reforms in telecommunications and broadcasting.

I do not propose to go into a detailed description of all the features of the Bill. Instead I would like to concentrate on some of the more significant and innovative changes being introduced. Members wishing further detail should consult the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Bill and the Minister's second reading speech made to the Senate on 12 November 1992.

Perhaps the most innovative change being introduced in the Bill is the introduction of a market-based system of spectrum management in selected areas of the spectrum. It was perhaps the key recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report and is a major feature of the new legislation.

The new market-based system of licensing contained in part 3.2 of the Bill represents a radical departure from the traditional approach of licensing the operation of specified devices. The cornerstone of the new system will be a new type of licence, to be called a `spectrum licence', which will provide explicit and continuing rights to spectrum access in defined parts of the spectrum in defined geographic areas. These licences will be freely tradeable and will be able to be split or amalgamated to suit the needs of users. Spectrum licences will be issued for fixed periods of up to 10 years, which will provide a more secure term for users. Introduction of the market-based approach will occur selectively and progressively, under the control of the Minister. Other spectrum will remain under the current administrative system.

Once the Minister has designated a part of the spectrum for conversion to the market-based system, part 2.2 of the Bill provides for two processes as to how spectrum licences are to be issued. Firstly, conversion plans will be developed by the new Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) being established by the Bill, to convert existing apparatus licences to spectrum licences. Secondly, marketing plans will be developed for the sale of spectrum licences for unencumbered spectrum by auction, tender or for a pre-determined or negotiated price. In line with the recommendations of the Committee report, spectrum access rights will not be perpetual. The market-based system will not apply to broadcasting services bands used for AM-FM radio and VHF-UHF television. These bands will continue to be planned by the Australian Broadcasting Authority under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

The Committee identified two areas of potential concern with a market-based system—interference and access by non-commercial users. Special attention has been given to these issues. The SMA will be able to designate frequency bands for exclusive use by public or community services anywhere in the spectrum. Special provisions are also included to ensure public or community services have access to spectrum within the market system. To ensure that spectrum can be resumed when this would be in the public interest, the Bill allows the SMA to purchase spectrum licences in the open market or to compulsorily acquire spectrum licences subject to payment of just compensation.

I now want to turn to some of the other changes being introduced in this Bill. The Bill provides for an updated, more flexible scheme for determining technical standards and other forms of technical regulation. It provides for the making of agreements with Standards Australia for the drafting of standards and technical licence specifications, for recognition of overseas standards without the need for additional type testing of equipment and for devolution of compliance testing of equipment to recognised laboratories.

The SMA will in future issue apparatus licences. The Government recognises that changes are also required in this area. The current system of approximately 130 licence categories, with a wide disparity in the level of fees paid, needs to be made simpler, more rational and more equitable. One of the first tasks of the new SMA will be to undertake a review of the existing administrative licensing and pricing system, following an opportunity for public input. Until a new scheme is in place these fees will continue to be levied under the tax Acts, but the level of the fee will in future be determined by the SMA through the use of disallowable instruments.

Other changes will allow the SMA to determine classes of apparatus licences, thereby streamlining the licensing process; will increase the maximum period of such licences to five years; will introduce an explicit renewal procedure into the legislation; and will allow class licensing of low-powered devices and services. Further changes will allow the SMA to make arrangements with banks and post offices for the collection of licence fees and charges. This should be of particular benefit to users in country areas.

The success of the reforms contained in this Bill will depend on having an efficient and effective organisation to implement them. The SMA is to be established as a separate statutory agency within the transport and communications portfolio and will have a structure similar to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Customs Service and similar bodies. Like those agencies it will operate within the legal umbrella of the Commonwealth. It will not be a statutory authority with its own body corporate.

In conclusion, I would add that the measures included in this Bill provide for the most comprehensive reform of spectrum management ever undertaken in Australia. They will provide Australia with a system of spectrum management appropriate for a modern communications based economy, one better able to respond to a rapidly changing international communications environment. I present the explanatory memorandum and the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Radiocommunications Bill is the principal Bill in a package of legislation. But, due to mechanisms that operate between the two Houses, to a large extent debate has already taken place on the additional Bills that go with this package; namely, a range of taxation Bills. Taxation Bills have to be initiated in the lower House, so they were dealt with here the other day. On that occasion I spoke at some length and I used some detailed graphs to illustrate what this debate was all about. I shall not be doing that tonight.

PARA.TAB: It is important for the record to relate the coalition's view on this piece of legislation. I accept the statement by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) that this is a major change, and indeed it is. But it has its genesis in a report by the Bureau of Transport and Communication Economics of some time ago which discussed how we ought to deal with the issue of spectrum. It was felt in that report that a more open market-based regime that enabled a more efficient allocation by allowing market pressures to determine access to available spectrum ought to be in operation. It viewed the prospect, in essence, somewhat like a land titles issue, that people ought to be able to trade in spectrum space, that different uses could be made of certain areas of the spectrum from time to time, and that once someone had the use of a spectrum space it ought not automatically always stay as that particular use.

Further, as more competing technologies and services emerge, they ought to be given the opportunity to access the spectrum because it is finite in its application; it is a renewable resource and there is limited space. For example, television takes up a very large space on the spectrum, so other competing services such as mobile phones are not able necessarily to get the spectrum space they need. Therefore, we have to move people off the spectrum space to enable those new services to operate.

The process of getting people off is a long and lengthy one. Generally speaking, in this country we have an equipment-type approach—we wait until the relevant equipment runs down and it is not such an economic burden when people are asked to move it off. This spectrum has been managed by governments for a long period. The proposal is trying to convert certain areas of the spectrum to a market-based approach in order to allow the spectrum to have more open access in a bidding-type process. In that sense, we welcome it, but I do have reservations. I expressed some of those the other day. I tabled a brief paper to accompany some of my remarks because I take the view that this is but a small first step that responds in part to the BTCE report and the subsequent report by HORSCOTCI—a House of Representatives committee—of which the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the former Minister, was Chairman. I note that he is in the House, and I assume he will speak. My colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was also a member of the Committee.

The recommendations of that Committee did not go as far as the BTCE report. It felt that a more measured approach was required. Those recommendations are reflected in this legislation. It was a bipartisan report, and we are also offering our support for this Bill, but with reservations. The reservations primarily concern whether or not the structures both in place under the Telecommunications Act and the Broadcasting Services Act, and as proposed under this Bill, are such as to provide for emerging technologies and services. It should be remembered that this proposal, which establishes the Spectrum Management Authority, will not have an all-encompassing role in determining all spectrum because the Broadcasting Services Act provides that the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the successor in title and function to the old ABT, will now have a broadcasting planning role; that is, it will be determining the allocation of FM spectrum space, AM spectrum space, television spectrum space and indeed space on the spectrum for satellite services which we talked about recently in terms of pay television.

There is a split function between the allocation of spectrum. In the medium to longer term, I wonder whether or not this is the best way to deal with it. I think those issues are a long way off. I do not, by my remarks, indicate that there is any proposal to change dramatically what is being put forward here, although there are some reservations that many would hold. We have to remember that the Parliament has taken the view that it has reserved areas of spectrum for television and it creates a barrier to other operators because the licence that is given to television operators is exclusive to their use. In time, as we see a change in delivery of services, particularly in the data, information and entertainment modes, there will be probably other competing users for the spectrum.

One of the features of this whole area is that we are getting an interesting move in that those who are existing users of wire-like technology—that is, telecommunications companies that run messages on wires into people's homes—are increasingly starting to use the airwaves or spectrum space to provide services, such as mobile phones. What we are seeing on the broadcasting side is that broadcasting and entertainment services are increasingly going to use optic fibre to go into the home; in other words, wire will take services into the home and therefore it will give people greater choice. It is interactive, which means that a message can be sent in and I can send a message out; I can do my home shopping and home banking, and so on. But as those technologies emerge—and the Saunderson committee some years ago made the observation that the optimal way of delivering entertainment to the home was by optic fibre; it is just expense and the state of that technology that is limiting it at the present time—it is interesting to see the change that is taking place. I think most of the work in this area recognises that dramatic change is taking place in all of these areas. It is how we respond to that that is going to be extremely important in the future.

I have had some responses to the legislation from various interest groups. The response is not universal in welcoming the Act, but I take the view that it is a small step in the right direction. It identifies clearly in an Act a better way of managing the spectrum. It is easier and more understandable. It is an area that is not visited regularly, but it has a profound impact on the delivery of so many services. I would argue—along, I am sure, with the Minister—that it will have an increasing impact. Therefore, we must start to focus on how we are going to deal with it.

With this regime that is being proposed with the Spectrum Management Agency and its new licensing regime—under the existing licensing regime there are some 90 different transmission-type licences that people can apply for—we do not want to see developing a stronger regulatory regime to ensure a better financial return to government. This new market-based licensing system ought not be seen as a fund-raising proposal. What has to be the centrepiece—it was the centrepiece of the recommendation of the HORSCOTCI report—is to have better and more efficient utilisation of the spectrum space. That is what has to drive this reform. It ought not be seen as just a fund-raising exercise. I hope, as we get into more detail and see how the Bill is actually implemented, that we do not get diverted by that. I would point out that the SMA does not start until, I think, 1 July 1993, so the capacity for any Minister in the future to review aspects of this model will be open. All the major areas of concern for users are effectively external to the Act. The SMA, which in some ways is like Austel, requires ministerial direction.

I said the other day that there are disallowance instruments throughout the legislation. I think that such instruments ought to be in legislation, particularly legislation of a technical type, so that the Parliament does not become totally divorced from the process of overviewing the legislation that it puts in place. It probably would be rare that the Parliament would respond to documents that are lodged in terms of their disallowance, but I think it is increasingly going to be important and, as I said the other night, the legislative processes and forms which we pursue in this chamber are important. Too few take a detailed role in it, and the committee procedures of this chamber have fallen off in the short period that I have been here. Detailed committee consideration of clauses of Bills is denied, and I think that is a shame.

There will, increasingly, be disallowable instruments that ought to enjoy the scrutiny of the Parliament. Indeed, to the credit of the Clerks on this side of the Parliament, they now issue a list of documents that have a disallowable function attached to them for members who want to scrutinise more closely the activity of the Executive and the regulatory authorities which are created by Acts such as this.

There are lots of comments that could be made about the clauses. Radio emission covers everything from the sun to pocket flashlights. We want to make sure that the definition that reflects the objects of clause 3 is more appropriate, that is, that it relates to management of what needs managing rather than creating a power base to take over areas that do not require management. That might be a little unfair, but what we are trying to say is that we do not want areas that do not actually require management to be picked up by the SMA and the new regime in a management sense. This is not to be a proposal that requires even more regulatory overview. On the contrary, it should require less. That is the very essence of a market based scheme that is proposed. It will be up to the Minister to determine the area of the spectrum that will be subject to the market scheme. That being the case, I signal that, if I were the Minister, I would want to accelerate that process of identifying areas that ought to be subject to the market system.

But there will be limitations and one of those limitations is the physical properties of the spectrum itself. One would have to take account of that. There is no compulsion on the SMA to consult and no remedial action for errors. The penalties are not in line with the value of either the equipment or services that may transgress the Act. For example, there is a penalty of $150,000 for the use of an electric garage door opener that is not approved. A sliding scale is needed. That penalty would seem to be inappropriate, but some of those areas could be dealt with a little later and perhaps, in this place or in another place, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) or his Department could give me a little more information about those types of issues. I do not have an electric garage door opener—and my understanding is that that is probably a poor example because I do not think it would be subject to the Act—but a fine of $150,000 in such a case would be ludicrous. It does not seem that that would be the case, and the advisers in the box may be able to clear that matter up. I do not think that that would be the intent of the legislation, but I just make the point about draconian penalties for usage. Some may be justified, of course, but others may not for the level of the infringement. I just point out that we would not wish to have a penalty regime based on the revenue that it might generate but which is not in proportion to the offence that might be committed.

A lot of other things could be said, but I think that is probably sufficient at this stage, given that dinner awaits some of us. The points that I have made are encapsulated in the view that I stated at the commencement of my speech, that we believe that this legislation should pass. We believe that the Radiocommunications Consultative Council is an example of the consultative process that ought to be adopted, and I will certainly watch that with interest.

I welcome the disallowable instruments proposal, but I do wonder and have concerns about whether or not the totality of this Act and the way it is put together, in conjunction with the Broadcasting Services Act and the Telecommunications Act, in fact goes far enough. I suspect that in time this issue will need to be revisited. It has been a bit like the Broadcasting Services Act earlier in the year. We saw a total rewrite of that Act for the first time in 50 years, to try to reflect the dramatic changes that are taking place in broadcasting. This Bill tries to reflect the dramatic changes that have to take place in spectrum management. It is a start, a beginning. It gives us a focus on the issue. The Parliament has had an active involvement in its preparation but, like so much legislation, it can always be better and it should always enjoy the detailed scrutiny of the Parliament. It has not necessarily enjoyed it here.

This is a complex area and the number of speakers on the speakers list reflects the fact that it is not something that honourable members take a lot of time to pursue. But it is something that each and every one of us knows touches all of our homes and our lives, so in that sense it is a very important piece of legislation. It is unique. It does not go as far as the New Zealand model and it is not as detailed as the New Zealand legislation, but it is a step in the right direction.

I look forward to hearing the remarks of the honourable member for Shortland, who was Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure which was the genesis of the recommendations that are reflected in this Bill. As I have said, the coalition will allow this Bill to pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in this debate and to say that, whilst I share some of the views expressed by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), I am a bit puzzled by some of his comments. The shortage of time for debate is not a result of a decision of ours; it is the result of a deadline set by the Senate—by his colleagues and the Australian Democrats. Those opposite need to be reminded of that on every occasion. I have great worries when I see the operations of this House being determined repeatedly by the other place. One day those opposite will rue having allowed that to happen; but that is for another discussion.
—When we control both Houses it will be okay.

—If the honourable member means that the coalition would abolish the other place, that is a good idea. I do not share the views of the honourable member for Bass in terms of this being a small step. It is not a small step; it is a major step. If we look back to the original Act—almost to the time of Federation; shortly after Federation—from the outset it was always said that the spectrum had a finite capacity. But, on every occasion on which it was stressed that it had a finite capacity and that we could not make greater use of it, technology came to the rescue. It has been like a piece of elastic. Even though it had a finite length, we have been able to stretch it further and further as technology has enabled us to make much better use of it.

PARA.TAB: The contradiction I find in the words of my colleague opposite is in respect of using the introduction of a mixed market and administrative system, and the marketing aspects being used simply as a fund raising exercise. This seems to me to be in contradiction with what the Opposition is saying, because it wants to move to a free market in almost every other area. This is a very important step forward to introduce a market component in how we manage the spectrum. There is no other way.

With my colleagues the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), who both played a very important part in the preparation of our report, we came very much to the conclusion quickly that there is no way in which a group of bureaucrats sitting in an office somewhere in Canberra can divine the value of a piece of spectrum. There is only one way to establish that value and that is through the market process. It is not possible, given the complexity of use of the total spectrum, to move rapidly into that, so we took what we believe was a very important step in making the recommendation that is being adopted in this legislation.

I also express, on behalf of the Committee, our appreciation of the very strong support given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) at the time the report was processed, even though it is almost a year afterwards. We are very happy with the response from Government and are very pleased with the collaborative effort of both Opposition and Government members in bringing this report forward. Communications are an essential element of micro-economic reform, and modern industrial countries depend very much on good communications. All forms of communication either do or can use a radio frequency spectrum in some way.

When we came to office in 1983 we suffered from an antiquated radio spectrum management legislation which went back almost to 1905. We set about updating and modernising that legislation through the Radiocommunications Act 1983, but there have been rapid changes in the nine years since. Whilst the 1983 Act introduced many improvements, it did not change the manner in which the frequencies were assigned or the way in which services and licences were regulated.

Overall, the thrust of the Radiocommunications Bill has been to convert an inflexible, administratively based system of spectrum management to one where, for commercial users, spectrum access has become a tradable commodity. It also provides protection for non-commercial users of the frequency spectrum, and it recognises that the Government cannot abdicate its role in protecting the radio frequency spectrum, nor its international obligations and responsibilities.

As the honourable member for Bass said, it is a very technical area, and there are rapid changes taking place in communications technology and innovations in service provision. But the Bill, and its predecessors earlier this week, will enable Australia to position itself for rapid technological change. We can be in a position to reap the benefits associated with the communications revolution. It is forward-looking legislation. Sure, it will obviously have to be adapted in time in light of experience, but the most important step to take is the step being taken in this Bill. That is why I am pleased to see the support of the Opposition for the legislation, even with its qualifications.

If there is rapid growth in demand, we can take full advantage of the opportunities as they arise. But if the growth does not occur we have not lost anything; so we have the best of both worlds. The existing system would not be able to cope with demand as it arose, so the value of the spectrum lies in its actual and potential exploitation for a range of public, private and commercial information purposes. The developments in radiocommunications technology, the advances in optical fibre and the use of computers in intelligent networks are all breaking down the old barriers and expanding the means of delivering all manner of services.

One of the simplest descriptions of the process of change put to us in the course of the inquiry was from Mr Nicholas Negroponte of MIT's media laboratory. I have said this in the House before, but I repeat it because it is so succinct. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What currently goes through wires, chiefly voice, will move to the air; what currently goes through the air, chiefly video, will move to wires. The phone will become wireless, as mobile as a watch and as personal as a wallet; computer video will run over fibre optic cables in switched digital systems as convenient as the telephone is today.
It is essential that Australia be in the position of ensuring that advantage can be taken of the potential benefits offered in maximising the use of the airwaves.

PARA.TAB: The recommendations of the Committee to a large extent have been adopted by the Government in a package of legislation that concludes with tonight's Bill. But the problem overall is that the process involving the acquisition of new equipment by users renders existing equipment obsolete. The only way of achieving access to that new equipment is to allow users time or tenure in which to gradually change over to new spectrum frequencies and to have certainty of occupancy of that spectrum. As I said earlier, there is a value attaching to occupancy of certain segments of the spectrum, and the only way to determine that is through the process of the market.

In this legislation it is not a case of the Government providing a response to the BTCE report.
