The BTCE report was one of the pieces of information that was examined by the Committee in the course of its inquiry. A great deal of work was done by officers of the Department of Transport and Communications. Again in this debate I would like to express my appreciation and that of my Committee colleagues to Mr David Hartley and Ms Gwen Andrews. Over and over again they responded to the many requests that we made.

As I said earlier, it is quite a technical area. To get answers and an understanding of what the spectrum is about and how it functions and the uses that can be made of it, we had to continually go back to people in the Department to draw upon the information, skills and knowledge available there. Both those officers gave us a great deal of help. Also, Colin Knowles at times was very helpful. The Department's assistance was invaluable.

The report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and its virtual adoption by Government, is an excellent example to everyone outside this place of how committees of the Parliament can achieve progress and solve problems. This problem was never going to be solved by the Department alone or by a Minister alone. I believe this is a classic example of what bipartisanship in the Parliament can achieve and of what committees of the Parliament can achieve.

The Bills will enable Australia to position itself for rapid technological change. Australia will be in a position to reap the benefits associated with the communications revolution. The Bills are forward looking. I would anticipate, in response again to the honourable member for Bass, that the problem will be, five years down the track, that a future Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee of this House will review progress that has been made with the new legislation and with the new system.

I believe that an appropriate course to follow, as the changes in the legislation we are putting through this week need to be considered, will be for the Committee to carry out that review. It should again take in public input, and examine that in an impartial forum where the facts can be tested in a manner in which they cannot be tested in the House. I look forward to that happening some time in the future.

I believe that the sale of the spectrum will generate revenues that will enable the Department and the agency to move forward with people who want to move from other parts of the spectrum. There will be resources available. Currently we have people who have few resources, particularly in the non-commercial sector, who would like to move but cannot afford to. The ultimate result will enable people to get value from the piece of spectrum they occupy, if they want to—it will be their decision—and to provide funds to help other people to move. The purpose of the whole exercise has to be how to achieve the most efficient use of the spectrum.

I said earlier that, almost from the outset—from the first radios and the first Act—it was said that the spectrum is finite. It is finite. But the technology development is ongoing. We will be able to put more and more onto the same given segment of spectrum. That is the case now as we look at digital compression in television and at the reversals that are going on. As I said earlier, what goes by air now will go by wire, and what goes by wire will go by air. I strongly support the legislation. I thank my colleagues who shared with me the task of reviewing what was happening with the spectrum. The preparation of this report was quite detailed work, and difficult, but we are very proud of the result. We are very pleased to see that it has the support of both sides of the House. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to join my colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) in supporting the Radiocommunications Bill. I acknowledge the view of the Opposition, and the positive view of the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). It is very important legislation, as the honourable member for Shortland indicated.

PARA.TAB: I compliment the Department of Transport and Communications on the move towards a Bill and an explanatory memorandum which are in plain English. When a person in the marketplace uses the legislation, it will be very readily understood. I commend the Department for the flow chart of a mechanism by which a section of the Act will apply. We ought to be doing this with more of our legislation. It is a very commendable step.

This comes back to the work of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The Committee takes large pieces of information from the community at large and makes them bite-sized so that we can end up with legislation. This is a perfect example of the House at work. There is a committee of the House; the committee looks at the detail, and the legislation that comes up embodies the work of the committee so that we end up with something that reflects the community's position. As the honourable member for Shortland said, it is very readily understood.

It is a pleasure to pick up this Bill and look at it, because we can make sense of it. We ought to strive for that in this Parliament. It is the outcome of an effective relationship between committees, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who is at the table, knows through his banking inquiry.

We ought to say to the community at large that this Parliament does that very well—better than any other parliament in Australia. There is the committee work—looking at a distinctive body of knowledge, opinion and problems—and then there is the legislative process. With the professional expertise of the people in the Department we can come up with something that makes substantial sense. I feel proud to be a member of a parliament which can actually do that.

It is not just a question of members of parliament being fed by a remote bureaucracy. That is not the case here. As the honourable member for Shortland said, we have legislation which embodies these things. For people like me and the Clerks who take an interest in the function of Parliament, this is the legislative process at its best. I want to put that on the record. If we can work towards this goal in areas such as tax law we will be achieving a great deal. We should give credit where it is due. I cannot claim much credit in this instance, but I acknowledge what has occurred.

I want to talk particularly about the spectrum matter which was referred to. This concerns a radio station in Western Australia which will be seeking a special narrow cast licence. Currently this radio station has the burden of carrying racing programs and talk-back programs and there clearly is a conflict. Under this process a special narrow cast licence will allow a much better outcome without the need for a full hearing process. I am hopeful that radio station 6PR will end up with the 882 spot on the AM band and with 1206 AM under the special narrow cast licence. I do not want to presume what the ABA will do about this matter, but I am putting forward my views: I think that would be a very good outcome. We would get proper coverage of current affairs; news; racing, which is important for revenue; sport and other matters.

I also want to mention the question of accuracy in communication. When we talk about electronic communication, it is very rewarding that because of the nature of the medium very often what is said is what is conveyed to the listener or viewer. I want to contrast this with what can happen in newspapers where there can be contrived inaccuracy in communication. We have had some debate in this place in relation to broadcasting and the right of commercial television stations to put on air violent material at certain times of the day. A very productive debate has been going on about the broadcasting policy that we are debating here tonight.

I was concerned to read in today's West Australian an article entitled `More young to see violent TV'. The article says that because of the negotiations and the Government's decision more young people than before will see violent television programs. As a contrived article, this is one of the most inaccurate that one could ever imagine. I am not making a partisan political point; I am talking about the media's responsibility to the public at large.

This article is littered with internal inconsistencies. It talks about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) having to back down, yet it also talks about—as do the FACTS people—the self-regulation in the industry. So how could the Prime Minister have backed down when there is self-regulation in the industry? That is an example of the great inconsistencies in this article.

A chart is provided with the article which talks about television viewing habits in Perth. The chart has no source and it would not see the light of day in this Parliament. But it has been published in a newspaper. It purports to talk about children watching television, but in fact refers to `thousands of people' watching television. This is a totally inaccurate and disreputable article which does no credit to the newspaper. Wendy Pryer, the young woman whose name appears in the byline, must feel somewhat badly done by because of what her editors have done. It is a great shame.
The article goes on to talk about when people watch television and the age range of people watching television. The article states:

Figures provided by the Australian Broadcasting Authority show that at 8.30pm about 35 per cent of television viewers are children—and that at 9pm they still make up about 25 per cent of the audience.
But by 9.30pm—the time slot Mr Keating initially favoured for violent movies—the number of children watching television falls to 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister was right—the percentage of children viewing television falls from 35 per cent to 15 per cent. But if we change the timeslot from 8.30 p.m. to 9 p.m. and the number of children watching television falls from 35 per cent to 25 per cent, how could more children be watching television?

PARA.TAB: I raise this matter in the context of this debate because we all have to be aware of issues such as this. A newspaper has abrogated its responsibility because it is not telling the truth in this article—in fact, it is quite misleading. In the context of what we are trying to do in debates such as this, I think our colleagues in the media also have a responsibility to report accurately. In this case, it is a shame because the article could have been better; it does not reflect well upon the newspaper.

I want to put these comments on record, Madam Deputy Speaker, and I appreciate your courtesy in letting me do this because it is something which I feel strongly about. We have a responsibility to be thorough, and the graph is not only not sourced but also misleading and the article is internally contradictory. We are having a debate—and we are trying to get the community to debate this too—about pay TV, free to air television and radio broadcasting.

This article purports to say that more young people will see violent TV when in fact, over time, this Parliament ought to act to ensure that more young people will see less violent TV. I think that is a view which all honourable members share. I appreciate the opportunity to put these remarks on record because obviously this is something which I feel very strongly about. I hope the newspaper concerned will do me and this Parliament the courtesy of correcting the record. I clearly support the legislation. I thank the House and I thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Martin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 provides for the saving of regulations made, instruments granted or various actions commenced under the Radiocommunications Act 1983 which is to be replaced by the proposed Radiocommunications Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: The transitional provisions included in the Bill deem various instruments made under the 1983 Act to have been made under the new Act. For example, clause 4 saves transmitter licences in force under the 1983 Act and continues them in force as if they had been issued by the Spectrum Management Agency established under the new Act. Consultation procedures which have been undertaken under the 1983 Act for the purposes of making certain instruments will be deemed to have been done under the corresponding provisions of the new Act.

The Bill also provides for consequential amendments to a number of other Acts by replacing outdated references to the 1983 Act. These consequential amendments are set out in the schedule. The Bill also includes amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 to allow Austel to include in standards made under that Act matters related to interference to radiocommunications. This will avoid the need for issuing separate technical standards under the 1992 Act.

The Bill also repeals the Radiocommunications Act 1983, the Radiocommunications (Frequency Reservation Certificate Tax) Act 1983 and the Radiocommunications (Temporary Permit Tax) Act 1983. Frequency reservation certificates and temporary permits will no longer be required under the new radiocommunications licensing scheme provided for under the Radiocommunications Act 1992. The decision to abolish frequency reservation certificates implements one of the recommendations of the report on spectrum management prepared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. As a transitional measure, clause 7 allows existing certificates to continue, but these will not be re-issued upon their expiry.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purpose of the provisions in more detail. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Martin) read a third time.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! Stop the clock. The honourable member for Wide Bay will resume his seat. Honourable members on my right will behave themselves as they should.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), and after that lengthy interlude I follow the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) who spent most of his time being very critical of the actions of the Kennett Government. He failed to acknowledge at any time that the Kennett Government has been forced to take drastic action in that State because of the appalling legacy of debt that was left behind by the previous Labor Government. That is pretty much the history of Labor when it comes to managing money. The debacle in Victoria is matched by what is going on in South Australia and the troubles in Western Australia. In a sense, we are also seeing some of that at the Federal level with the introduction of the Appropriation Bills this evening.

PARA.TAB: These Bills demonstrate yet again that Labor has no capacity to manage a Budget, and that Labor cannot be trusted with money. These Bills put to death for all time the One Nation statement. Its fundamental strategy has failed. The Government is withdrawing funds from the railway projects and the electricity project has not even got off the ground. The One Nation statement has dismally failed. The Government is getting out of those projects because its mates in the unions would not agree to any kind of reasonable development of the railway system. Those opposite are backing out and putting the money into short term artificial job creation projects—projects which will not create any national wealth, which will do nothing to restore our national economy, and which are designed with only one purpose: to shorten the unemployment queues slightly with an election in mind.

The Government quickly brings forward these projects that were planned over longer periods with an election target date in mind. With that kind of attitude, these Bills need to be seen for the threadbare nature in which they really stand. The Bills are extraordinary in that they were announced before the Senate had approved the Budget Bills. In spite of the giggling Ministers, the fact is that the Government's Budget strategy was in disarray before the Bills even got through the Senate. That demonstrates the incapacity of this Government to develop a consistent fiscal approach to the economy. It is no wonder that we therefore have the disaster at present.

This Government's record in economic affairs can be traced through a line of failed Budgets, failed mini-Budgets, failed economic statements, failed Building a competitive Australia statement and now, once and for all, the total failure of the One Nation statement. They have all been flops. They have provided no direction and no leadership. This flurry of statements, this pretence of activity, has done nothing to restore our national economy.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rants and raves in Question Time, he is covering up an unemployment queue that has grown to one million. He is covering up a Budget deficit admitted to be $13.4 billion, but obviously most observers believe it to be significantly worse than that. The Australian people do not need to be told that our country is facing serious economic trouble with a $160 billion debt, our national productivity has reached an abysmally low level, and we have been overtaken by countries around the world as we slide down the productivity index.

I was impressed with some of the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall), who referred to the state of the Heinz company in Australia at present. Heinz is moving to acquire the Watties interests in New Zealand because it has looked at the world scene and knows that it is more efficient to produce goods in that country than it is in ours. What a tragedy that is for Australian industry and for Australian producers.

Heinz was able to report that the oncosts in New Zealand are less than half of the oncosts in this country. To employ someone in New Zealand costs 64 per cent of what it costs to employ someone in Australia. In Australia, payroll tax is 7 per cent; in New Zealand it is nought. Workers compensation in Australia is 7 per cent; in New Zealand it is 3 per cent. Superannuation in Australia is 4 per cent; in New Zealand it is 2 per cent. New Zealanders get three weeks annual leave; Australians get four. New Zealanders work a 40-hour week, whereas Australians work a 36 1/4-hour week. What is most important, they are able to negotiate flexible working arrangements, which we have been unable to achieve in this country.

The telling point was the statement which the honourable member for McMillan repeated. When Heinz was asked whether it would look at constructing a greenfields factory in Australia, the answer was, `No, it would be more economically sensible to do it in New Zealand'. So, that is where our economy has slid under the program that has been put forward by this Government over recent years. But that is not the end of it. The one million unemployed are the symptom of this economic mismanagement, as well as the one-third of adult Australians now receiving some kind of social security benefit and the one-third or more of youth who are unemployed. Yet, in spite of the fact that this Government, the biggest taxing government in our history, despite the fact that the Labor Government has trebled income taxes, multiplied fuel tax six times, increased indirect tax threefold, it has still produced a Budget deficit of $13.4 billion, the biggest in our national history.

While we sit here debating this Bill, the Government is running up a loss of $1.5m every hour of the financial year. Sadly, what that means is that every Australian worker will have to pay at least $2,000 extra in tax at some time in the future just to pay off this year's Budget deficit. It is about time the Government came out and started telling the Australian people how it will collect that $2,000 from every individual Australian worker just to pay off this year's deficit. That is a really telling challenge that it must answer if it is going to retain any kind of credibility. So, instead of providing real answers to the national economy, it comes out again with yet another revision of yet another one of its mini statements through these Appropriation Bills.

The fact that 11.3 per cent of our work force is unemployed is a demonstration of the magnitude of our national tragedy. Of course, many others have given up altogether looking for work. When we look at the Government's attempts over recent times to try to salvage the economy of the country, it is really a litany of disasters.

In this particular program, it has given up altogether any attempts to try to fundamentally restore the national economy or to do anything about rebuilding the infrastructure. This recommitment of expenditure is to boost additional artificial work creation schemes—programs that last only as long as the taxpayer continues to pay the wages bill. What is left—a few community improvements which are appreciated by those who have them, but no fundamental restructuring or improvement in our national economic base.

When we look at the major element of this new program, it involves providing major subsidies to large employers who are prepared to engage an extra 100 people who have been out of work for six months or more. Those subsidies are up to $5,000 per employee. This is a typical approach of this Labor Government to national problems. This ALP Government has a solution involving big business, big unions and big mates. It has altogether lost sight of the fact that it is small business

SPEECH.PARA: that employs most Australians. Our future recovery is critically dependent upon the confidence of small business. It is because small businesses lack the confidence to employ that our unemployment rate is as bad as it is. What these measures will, in fact, ensure is that small business will have to pay higher taxes to fund the subsidies for large business, which will further put aside any chances of a national recovery.

PARA.TAB: The other interesting element is the decision of the Government to advance spending on the local capital works program. It announced $55m as being allocated for this purpose. I got a call very quickly from a council which was keen to get its share of this extra money that was announced as a part of these particular measures. But, of course, there is no extra money at all. It is just an accountant's trick, bringing forward a little bit of additional money that was programmed to be spent later. As the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) told us in Question Time, local government was very good at this job creation scheme and got on to it quicker than the Government expected. That just reflected its lack of understanding of local government. Local government is always able to respond very quickly, particularly when somebody gives it money. It is pretty quick to put its hand up and want more. It is very good at creating those sorts of jobs very quickly.

I think it is important that, if people are going to be out of work for long periods of time, they do have some opportunity to exercise their time in a productive way. These kinds of programs at least contribute something to the communities that benefit but, more importantly, they provide an opportunity for workers to maintain their work skills and to retain the work ethic. That is very important for people facing long periods of unemployment. So it was not surprising that local government was able to respond very quickly and promptly to this opportunity to create jobs in local communities.

Many people in local government are very concerned about the way in which this particular funding has been handed out. It has, of course, gone to those local authorities with above average levels of unemployment. The Government's strategy in that regard has obviously been shot to pieces by an announcement also in this latest mini-Budget that it is going to spend a significant amount of money on employment creation projects in Canberra, such as the redevelopment of the old Parliament House. Canberra has only half the national average unemployment and yet it is to get one of the biggest grants that have been handed out in these schemes anywhere. So there is a great degree of inconsistency there and I can fully understand the feelings of local authorities which have missed out on this chance to participate in the local capital works program because they are half a per cent under the national average of unemployment, when they look at Canberra being given this generous allocation, even though its unemployment rate is so very much lower.
The Maryborough City Council within my own electorate was one to take up this cause. It wrote to the Prime Minister expressing its concern that:

SPEECH.PARA: the unemployed in local authority areas such as Maryborough, where numbers are slightly lower than the national average, were totally ignored in the recently announced unemployment grants to local authorities. Council believes that the unemployed, no matter where they live, must be considered and the fact that they live in an area of lower unemployment than the national average should not be a reason why they do not receive some assistance.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps there needs to be a bit more imaginative consideration of the whole question of unemployment relief and the payment of unemployment benefits. Council believes that there is no productivity in the existing method of paying unemployment benefits. All of Australia would benefit if some productivity could be realised from the billions of dollars already paid out in benefits. It is suggesting therefore that it is time that some alternatives to the handout system were addressed. Initiatives such as channelling benefit payments through local authorities could see a vast improvement in the nation's productivity at no extra cost to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is backing a cause that is very popular in local government, namely some kind of a work for unemployment benefit scheme. Local government has demonstrated that it can work through the implementation of the local capital works program. If the Government needs any further illustration, it need look no further than the Aboriginal program, the community development program, which provides work for unemployment benefit type projects around Australia.

PARA.TAB: That scheme has worked particularly well in Aboriginal communities. I give by way of an example two communities, one in my own electorate and one outside. Cherbourg declined to take up this particular program when it was first offered. The Woorabinda settlement eagerly embraced this program and has been actively involved in it. Hundreds of people have now left Cherbourg to go to Woorabinda so that they can participate in the program and Cherbourg is anxious to be included in the scheme now as well. So it has worked extremely well in Aboriginal communities. They have noticed the improvements that have been provided through the scheme and they have noticed the improvement in attitude amongst the people who were previously developing a welfare mentality.

If the principle works well in Aboriginal communities, if it works for the Government in the local capital works program, I can see no logical reason why it cannot be applied more universally. Of course, in Fightback, we do promise to provide some additional work experience to people who are long term unemployed. We are keen on the idea of providing community service. I think that many people who are unemployed and have been unemployed for a long period would like to participate in a program of this kind. I hope that, eventually, we can see a widespread national scheme of providing work for people in return for their unemployment benefit payments.

One of the ironies associated with the extension of these artificial jobs into areas where there are high levels of unemployment is that, in many of the areas where these job creation schemes are being undertaken, there are large numbers of jobs that the unemployed will not take. There was a banner headline in the Maryborough Chronicle yesterday which read, `Jobless shun crops'. The situation is that there are hundreds of jobs available picking crops in the Bundaberg, Maryborough, Gympie and Mundubbera areas, and there is no-one available to take them on. Crops are being ploughed into the ground because people will not take on these picking jobs. There are many examples. On Tuesday a case was reported on the ABC of a farmer who required 50 tomato pickers. The CES sent 250 names to the farmer and only two people turned up. There is another story from a farmer who rang my office a few days ago. He has had to abandon 10 acres of button squash and five acres of zucchinis because he could not get the crop picked. The CES referred people to him. He got 56 calls and only one person turned up.

All of these people find it much more comfortable to receive the unemployment benefit than to go out and do the picking jobs. I am told that each year in Mundubbera in the citrus season there are a thousand jobs that go unfilled because no-one will come to help with the work. Yet people are collecting unemployment benefit and lining up for special jobs under the capital works program. The article in the Chronicle made a particularly interesting observation from one farmer who had to abandon his crops of snow peas and zucchinis. He said this about getting somebody from the unemployment queue to come and work:

SPEECH.PARA: "If they did do some picking, they would only work until they raised $60 or so a fortnight so they didn't jeopardise their dole.

Their priority is to do just enough work to earn a few dollars to supplement their dole payment but not enough to get themselves out of the unemployment cycle. There is something immoral about farmers ploughing their vegetables into the field, and oranges being left to fall off the trees, while we are creating artificial job programs in these communities. We need to come to grips with these very important issues and make sure that, when jobs are available, those who are unemployed take up those jobs, earn the income that is available from them and contribute constructively to the community.

PARA.TAB: I appeal to the Government to carefully administer the social security programs and ensure that the CES recognises the important role that farmers and others who have got jobs that need to be filled can play when there are large pools of unemployed who are available but not willing to work. We are told that the CES will not even list a lot of these positions because they do not fit their criteria in relation to the award arrangements and the fact that they are only part time jobs, temporary jobs, and not full time positions. Those sorts of rules should not be allowed to get in the way of achieving what is best for the people concerned and what is best for the country as a whole.

One of the other measures included in these Appropriation Bills is the advance of some additional funds for the black spot program. It is good to see some additional funding trickling through to roads from this Government over the last year or two. After all, the Government has multiplied its receipts from fuel excise by six times, so it is appropriate that there should be more money for roads. But, in practice, the Government has frozen road funding for most of its term in office. Only in recent times has there been any additional expenditure for roads. Is it any wonder that we need to spend more money on black spots? There are so many more black spots because of all of the neglect over the past decade.

The frightening thing about the Government's projections for road funding—and the Budget documents confirm these numbers—is that in 1994-95 there will actually be fewer dollars available for road funding than were spent in 1983-84. So in spite of the passage of more than a decade the Government is going to spend less than it did at that time. There is a small, short term boost now, but no plans for any continuing proper funding of our national road system.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as I mentioned earlier, our country is in serious economic difficulty. This Government is making these superficial changes at this time to try to patch up a Budget statement that has failed, a One Nation statement that has failed, and these measures will fail too. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I need to inform you that I am under considerable pressure from my colleagues to speak at short length this evening because of the lateness of the hour. So I will keep to the promise that I will speak for only a couple of minutes. I would imagine that the listening audience around the House and out there in the nation has somewhat diminished. If I speak for only a couple of minutes, and the other side agrees, we may not even have an adjournment debate. It is the end of a very long session, and I am sure we are all worn out.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, at a time when we are debating Appropriations, I would like to make some remarks about some of those expenditures that come through the Department for which I have some responsibility, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer, in particular, to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, whose job it is to keep the statistics that measure the health of the nation, as well as the vital statistics about how it is we deliver health services. I have had an interest in this area for some time. It is particularly important that we establish an independent authority to measure these things. As we all know, politicians are somewhat subject to improper use of statistics by lobby groups, which serve them up in the newspapers all the time as proof that a particular program, subject or whatever ought to receive more Commonwealth funds. We are somewhat susceptible to that pressure when it gets easy publicity.

I will just take the House through some favourite social statistics of mine in the health area that might, if they go unchecked, cause a government to spend money that it might not otherwise find necessary to spend. They are favourites of mine. There are three deliberate errors, I would suggest, that are made on behalf of groups or lobbyists or organisations, or whatever, that want to demonstrate that their area of need is more important than anyone else's.

There is the old problem of double counting. A couple of years ago there was a headline in the Courier-Mail which said that one in four children in Queensland lives in poverty. That riled me somewhat because, firstly, I knew it to be untrue, and, secondly, I knew the source of the data. The data was what we call WELSTAT information, which is basically a collection of data for a lot of agencies that give out emergency relief funds; it is Commonwealth money. The problem is, though, it counts the same family two, three, four, five or six times. In other words, if one family goes to six different agencies in the course of a six-month period, or a year or whatever, it is counted separately. A family may even go to two agencies on the same day. There is no way that those statistics could properly measure child poverty in my State, or in any State. There was an abuse of those statistics. I was in contact with the groups that held those statistics just to make sure that I was correct in my assumptions that they were double and triple counting. I was correct. That sort of nonsense does not go on any more with those figures. So we are not subject to those sorts of figures.

I am very pleased that recently we have extended the role of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare to pick up the role of the measurement of welfare. We will be going into the measurement in areas such as child welfare, where we will be talking about such crucial things as adoptions, child maltreatment, children in care, juvenile offenders, as well as some measurement of income, poverty, inter-child-care, disability services, aged care and so on.

The other statistic I see from time to time that is a misuse of social statistics—I will have to be very careful that my words are not misinterpreted—is what I will call an improperly wide definition of a problem. We will get a statistic that will read something like: one in four women are subjected to sexual abuse at some stage. On the surface, that may be a reasonable thing; the statistics may be accurate. But the trouble is that the definition of `sexual abuse' will often range from rape through to bad language. You get a wide definition of events that have almost nothing in common and, if you add up all of the so-called abuses within that incredibly wide definition, it may be possible to get a figure that one in four women are subject at some stage to a form of sexual abuse.

What I suggest occurs here is that anyone's normal sense of what is sexual abuse or what is the improper treatment of women is stretched to such an extent that the whole statistic lacks credibility. What do we do when we read that sort of statistic? We walk away from it. We do not believe it. We are not interested in the topic. Social statistics need to be couched in such a way that they have an amount of credibility that will make the reader want to inquire further and to believe that it is a decent area of endeavour that we should be interested in and should devote Commonwealth funds to it.

The third common way of misrepresenting needs through social statistics is to take a measurement across a person's lifetime. To some extent, I am putting together these notions; they are not perfect by any means. Something like one in four Australians will be subjected to a bout of mental illness at some time in their lives. These statistics compress all the possibilities of a bout of mental illness—and I suspect that is a wide definition—to one point in time. For instance, many old people will be subjected to some definition of a bout of mental illness, because the process of ageing, as I understand it, does cause some depression. Anyone in his or her entire lifespan of 60, 70 or 80 years might have one incident of this event called mental depression. Representing this in a single statistic at one point in time is trying to represent something that happens at one point in time to millions of people across seven or eight decades.

By all these different means of building a case through the use of social and health statistics, I find that as a politician I am subjected to the pressure of those sorts of statistics. People lobby me on the basis of this sort of representation of their argument. I am very wary of those sorts of representations and arguments brought to Government by people presuming that their case is more important than anyone else's.

On the basis of that illustration, I compliment the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare on its work. In some ways, its job is to be the umpire of many of these sorts of measurements; to give us something that is credible, predictable and properly measured across a whole range of statistics in the area of health, and now welfare, in Australian society so that I, as an individual member, or the Deputy Speaker or honourable members opposite, have a reference point to which to refer to see whether any of the often improperly but popularly recognised data has any validity. I say that by way of bringing to the attention of the House the considerable amount of money that we devote to the proper gathering of statistics, which we believe are very valuable tools, in order that we spend taxpayers' money properly. I again congratulate the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare on its work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I think everyone wants to go home. I do not see any Government members lining up to speak after me and I do not want to be blamed for keeping everyone here any later than necessary. As I was listed to speak, I will fulfil that obligation, albeit briefly. These Appropriation Bills come in the shadow of the now totally discredited One Nation statement and the 1992-93 Budget, which was introduced in August.

PARA.TAB: As Kerry O'Brien observed on Lateline, the Government laboured mightily to come up with a document that would match Fightback. The transcript of the Lateline program makes very interesting reading. I think it should be compulsory reading. The only pity about it is that it was on Lateline and not on the 7.30 Report or something in prime time. There was a suggestion that we could make it available on the parliamentary network so that at least all members of parliament could make themselves familiar with the performance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

Kerry O'Brien asked the Prime Minister, `After nine months, how many of the fundamental assumptions of the One Nation statement remain true?'. The Prime Minister was not able to answer that. He went on to make a complete fool of himself by his inability to answer not only that question but also every other question that Kerry O'Brien put to him. It became fairly obvious that, although in Question Time he gets away with bluster, obfuscation, abuse and exaggeration—and just about everything else—on this occasion he could not escape from Kerry O'Brien.

As Kerry O'Brien pointed out to the Prime Minister, the One Nation growth forecast for the economy was 4.75 per cent. He pointed out that in June this was revised downwards to 4 per cent. In August, six months later, because the Budget came out, it was down to 3 per cent. Three wrong estimates in nine months! The Prime Minister did not have any answer for that. That was early in the interview. From there on the Prime Minister's performance on Lateline was all downhill.

Next Kerry O'Brien asked him about job creation—a pretty important question to ask the Prime Minister in these circumstances. Kerry O'Brien observed that job creation figures were predicated on those growth projections. He made the reasonable assumption that the growth projections were now thrown out and wanted to know how the job creation figures stacked up. Kerry O'Brien pointed out that there had been 30,000 jobs created from February to October under the One Nation statement, but unfortunately there were 65,000 additional unemployed. In other words, there was a net loss of 35,000 in employment generation.

Kerry O'Brien asked the Prime Minister, `Doesn't that put something of a hole in your projections that there would be between 150,000 and 200,000 jobs created by One Nation?'. `Not at all', said the Prime Minister. This was a really tough one for him to get out of, but it was fairly obvious that he was not able to answer that question—nor could he answer it; it is an impossible question to answer. Presumably, in February when One Nation was released the Prime Minister stood up in this place and said, `Here we have the answer. We are going to create between 150,000 and 200,000 jobs in a year'. I am not sure whether he meant the year from February 1992 to February 1993. Perhaps he meant the next financial year. Either way, his progress to date is minus 35,000. He is not doing too well, and things will have to pick up awfully quickly. These Appropriation Bills are about the Government re-ordering priorities and spending money as quickly as it can to create a few more temporary jobs before the election. It is interesting that the whole program ends on 31 May. That is what the Appropriation Bill says. The timing is significant.

Both One Nation and the Budget brought down in August are now completely discredited. These Bills are an admission of that. These Bills represent a further indictment of this Government's mismanagement of the Australian economy—not only in recent years, but perhaps over the last 10 years. It created the recession through mismanagement and now it is rushing in to try to fix it up with mickey mouse job creation schemes—schemes that are only aimed at getting people off the dole until the election. That is what these Bills are all about. We do not oppose them because they are Budget Bills, but we certainly think the whole thing is laughable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was asked what he was doing and how he felt that fiscal stimulus should apply. Of course, he quoted an eminent source that said fiscal stimulus was fine provided, to put it clearly, a government did not waste the money; in other words, that it put it into some grand infrastructure scheme. He said that that is where this Government differed from those that got into RED schemes and all those things of the past where people painted rocks white and certainly escalated the pine forest industry because they put up pine rails wherever they could, built footpaths where people never walked, et cetera. That is what he told us this afternoon during Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Tonight we are debating Bills that take money away from those infrastructure projects, those rail extension projects and those electricity grid projects, and put it into painting rocks. Why? The Treasurer, in delivering these speeches, is at pains to say that that is not what is going to happen, but it is very clear that it is. He talks about labour market programs and all that old-fashioned dogma where the Government, in its desperation to retain office, wants to just spend money. The pity of it is that it is money the nation does not have.

Any money that this Government borrows today is borrowed from overseas. Of course, Government members would stand up—I have heard Bob Hawke and the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as Treasurer say this—and say that this Government has very low foreign borrowings. Well, we know that. We know that the Commonwealth does not have to borrow overseas unless it is trying to fill some gap in some foreign currency requirements. It borrows on the local markets. Those who give the Commonwealth the money go and borrow it overseas. They must borrow it overseas for the simple fact that we owe the world $185,000m. While we have that level of debt overseas, there are clearly no net savings here in Australia. They might be there for minutes; they come and go.

It borrows money to fund this rock painting exercise and these pine rails. We heard the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) today telling us how he had got his new schemes in place and how successful they were. Of course they were successful. Every local authority said, `We will take the money'. That is not surprising. But I have seen how it is being spent around my electorate, and I have to tell honourable members that it will do nothing for the national economy at all. People will walk a little less distance to a public toilet—that is convenient—but I am afraid that what they do there will not expand our export effort. It is as simple as that. That is what the money is being spent on. It is not creating real jobs. In some cases, it will create no jobs at all.

When I was told in the town of Geraldton of the money that would be spent there, I suggested that maybe they could get some of the final year apprentices in that town to go and build these toilet blocks, because those kids are currently on the scrap heap. They have been retrenched, particularly final year apprentices. This is the problem all around Australia. People have been retrenched because under the current award system their wages are very nearly that of a full tradesman. Of course, as the pressure has gone onto business and it has lacked the turnover because of the `recession we had to have', business has turned around and said, `Well, which apprentice should we retrench—the one that has just started on very low wages or the one that is on very high wages?'. It has retrenched the one on high wages.

Some of these apprentices are only months away from completing their indentures. I have evidence because of constituents who have come to my office. Parents have gone back to some of those employers and said, `Look, we understand your position. We understand that you do not have the financial resources in this recessionary period to keep paying our son at this rate. At what rate would you employ him—$200, $100, $50, nothing? We are prepared to back our child so that he can complete his indentures'. They have two problems: first, they would like to see their child conclude and become a tradesman; and, second, if their child does not conclude by a certain time, all the time put in to date has been lost. There is a finite period in which a person must complete his indentures as an apprentice.

The employers have said, `Look, we would love to help, but it so happens that we have this rigid structure in Australia, this award system, that prevents us from doing that. We either pay your child the appropriate wage or nothing. So take him back home to the scrap heap'. That is the situation. So those kids cannot even be employed to build the toilets with this money that the Government is wasting. It is a tragedy, it is an outrage, and it is a joke.

The unemployment figures keep growing. The Prime Minister, who had been running around the countryside, started telling us that he was not really borrowing money to make Australians feel good and then spending it; he was not really doing it for that purpose. He said that there was a higher authority. He had woken up in the middle of the night, a flash of light had come through the window and a voice had said, `I'm the OECD and I'm here to tell you, Prime Minister, to go out and borrow money. Go out and run Budget deficits and spend it'. That is what he was telling us. He told us that day after day.

He said, of course, that the American people have endorsed this by a vote. That would have been a great economic decision. One candidate said, `I'll fix all your problems' and the other said, `Well, I have to be a bit careful in making that promise because I happen to be the Government', and they voted for the fellow who said he had the miracle cure. Somehow or other that became a great economic decision of the 100 million voters of America. Of course, when we get down to tintacks, the same OECD that the Prime Minister said had given him the authority to borrow more money and put Australia's children further into debt—and please remember Mr Deputy Speaker, that you and I, unfortunately, do not have all that much time left on this earth and we have only a limited amount of that debt to repay; it is the 15-and 16-year-olds and younger who are going to have to pay off the debts that this Government has contracted on their behalf—said to America after the vote of the people that it did not advise it to go further into government budget deficit because it could not afford it; it was too far in already. Of course, when it spoke to America, it was speaking to Australia.

Last year, in terms of these Appropriation Bills and things, the Government said that it would borrow about $4 billion, not an astounding amount. We probably could have done without that sort of debt, that extra expenditure. But at the end of the financial year it was $10 billion. It was $10 billion because the Government's discredited Tax Commissioner wrote it some letters and said, `This is how much money I can screw out of the Australian people'. He failed; he did not deliver. The Government did not have the money. So its first Budget deficit was $10 billion.

It stuck to its expenditures. It did not delay them; it did not slow them down. It came to us this time and said, `Well, here is a new Budget. It is $13,500m overdrawn'. There is a deficit of $13,500m. That makes $23,500m. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister get up every day and say, `This is our solution to unemployment. We are going to borrow our way out of trouble. We will keep spending, we will keep applying this Government stimulus and, of course, we will turn around the unemployment problem'.

The Government says that its unemployment problems would be fewer than the coalition's. But I want to know just how much more money it thinks it has to borrow. Is it another $20,000m? I have young children and two grandchildren. I would really like to know what standard of living they can expect in the future as they pay off this debt. But so far the unemployment keeps rising.

Just across the ocean there is a little country called New Zealand. There are only three million people there. They now own half the brewing capacity of Australia. Whether we should or not, we tend to associate Australians with beer. In my State we used to have a product called Swan and another one called Emu Export. They now have the invisible word `Kiwi' in front of them. They are Kiwi Emu Export and Kiwi Swan Lager because they are owned by the New Zealanders. The Chief Executive Officer of Lion Nathan addressed businessmen in Perth the other day, and he said, `You are 10 times behind us. We are knocking spots off you'. We used to have bilateral trade under CER, the closer economic relationship, where New Zealand had 39 per cent of the business and we had the rest. It now has nearly 46 per cent of the business. Every year it gets more and we get less.

During the 90-second statements today, I raised the sorts of frauds that members of parliament practise on the people they claim to represent. I know what working people want. They want a living wage. They are not really very concerned with the complexity of how they get it. They want to know how much they will get and, more particularly, how much they will get after tax.

These blokes opposite are running around saying, `Of course, if you let this coalition govern you, it is going to change the laws relating to industrial relations. As a result, you are going to be like New Zealand workers, because they have had all their rights taken away'. The New Zealand contracts law is much more deregulatory, if you like, than anything that has been proposed in our Jobsback policy.

Notwithstanding all that deregulation, it is interesting to look at the statistics presented by reputable statisticians; in other words, the government statistician in each place. I would not dare criticise statisticians in this place because the Government would say, `You should never attack public servants; they are honourable people'. Using the government statisticians' figures, we find that in the last 12 months, since this market has been deregulated in New Zealand, New Zealand workers have seen the real value of their wages increased by one per cent. These wonderfully protected workers in Australia have the benefit of these trade union bureaucrats, who all end up here. Their wages and buying power in real terms have dropped half a per cent.

If one looks more closely at the finer numbers, one finds that a New Zealand worker, since he has been deregulated and no longer had the `protection' of his trade union bureaucrat, has had an increase in the buying power of his wage packet. At the same time, under the system we have here, the wages have fallen. The wife of the worker goes down to the supermarket and comes back with less whatever is in the pay packet. One wonders how much longer the workers of Australia will put up with that.

As I drew to the attention of the House today, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) is running around putting out a document to try to justify his case against these irrefutable odds. We never hear the Prime Minister, the Treasurer or the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) mention New Zealand any more. Have you noticed that, Mr Deputy Speaker? New Zealand has become a no word in this place. We used to get it poked at us day after day. We never hear about it any more.

The honourable member for Canning is a bit slow. He still puts it out in his electorate. To make it look a bit better, he converts New Zealand dollars into Australian dollars. But he overlooks the fact that, if he buys Thursday's New Zealand paper, because Thursday is an advertising day for supermarkets, lays the advertising out on this desk and compares the price of products in New Zealand, in New Zealand dollars, including the GST, with the price Australians are paying in Australian dollars, he will see that they are identical, give or take a few cents. The New Zealand worker gets for his New Zealand dollar exactly the same product value as the Australian gets for his Australian dollar. So why would those opposite practise that fraud on the people and readjust the New Zealand currency to Australian currency? They do it because they want to mislead the people. They are not prepared to tell them the truth.

It gets worse. Today the Treasurer also got up and told us that the Government's sales tax does not cascade. We do not have to wonder for very long why the current Treasurer took nine years to get an economics degree. We do not have to wonder for very long why he had to be shipped from the University of Western Australia to Roseworthy College to get a diploma. It is because he was not very bright. Academically he did not really make it. He is standing up here trying to tell us about his new sales tax legislation.

By the way, honourable members should have a good look at this booklet before me. A lot of people in their electorates would like to have one, but they cannot get them. It probably would have been designed 12 months ago while Government members were writing 1,500 pages of legislation. The Senate gave approval for the issue of this because it passed the legislation on 30 September. I see race books printed in my electorate in 24 hours. Those opposite could not get this out in three months.

The legislation will apply from 1 January. A couple of hundred thousand of the documents have to go to farmers. Where are all the farmers at the moment? They are out harvesting their crops. When a thing of that size comes in a big envelope, they will probably think it is a Christmas sales catalogue. There is a chance that half of them will chuck it in the bin. But if they get to open it, fill out the form and send it back by 30 December, the Government will say, `We may not have had time to issue the necessary registration number you need to get the new exemption. But don't you worry about that. We'll give you the exemption anyway. You just tell your supplier that you've sent in your application form'. There are two little problems with that. I do not believe there is anything in the new Act which allows the Government to give an exemption. I believe that farmers and everybody else will have to pay the cash for the sales tax and that they will have to recover it if they can.

It is interesting that today the Prime Minister waxed lyrical about poor little sporting organisations. He was desperately worried that they might be caught up in the GST. Again, that was fraud by omission. The documents on the GST are quite clear. Anybody with a turnover under $50,000 does not have to report it under GST. They do not have to do all the book work that almost brought the Prime Minister to tears, as he described all these little treasurers around the place. They just do not have to be involved. They will pick up a little GST at 15 per cent for the things they buy. The Minister might like to tell us what a little small sporting club actually buys. But they do not have to report a turnover under $50,000. Any sporting equipment that they buy will no longer have sales tax on it.

I am now getting representations associated with this new scheme that say that kids who feed their ponies are going to have to pay 20 per cent tax on their prepared stockfeed. I believe that is to be the case. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns): what exemption are those kids going to get? Horses are a thing that generally create great character in a child. They cannot kick it under the bed like a cricket bat or a football. But the Government is going to tax the food that those kids feed their horses with. Some of them will lose their horses as a result of that. So much for the crocodile tears of the Prime Minister!

But this document is not available. Farmers have not got it. It is an administrative mess. One wonders why the Government has to borrow all this money. It is because we have a Treasurer who does not know how to run his Department. When he was asked the first question about it, he did not even know what was going on. He came back to the Parliament later and produced a press release from his Commissioner. But he is yet to explain to the Parliament how, under the legislation he passed through this place, the Government can give exemption to people. He has yet to explain how a retailer will be protected if he sells something free of sales tax on the word of someone who says, `I've sent my form in. Believe me; trust me'. How stupid can you get!

That is the way this country is being run today. It is being run by a Prime Minister who has not sold Qantas yet, but he has spent the money. If he achieves the sale, Australia ends up with no airline and no money. Yet the Government asks us to give it extra money. It is just so silly that a Treasurer who took nine years to get an economics degree is running the country and really not knowing what he is doing and not knowing anything about the administration of his Department or what is happening out there. He tells us that he can collect a billion dollars. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1992-93 and Appropriation Bill (No.4) 1992-93 I wish to comment on the social as well as financial implication of the Bills. The costs involved in financing the substantial labour market programs and local capital works programs in the Bills must reflect, in part, bungled economic policies at a national level which, when combined with the $29.5 billion being paid out to State, Territory and local governments in 1992-93, is a timely reminder of the incredible financial disasters which State Labor governments have inflicted on the Australian people over the same period.

PARA.TAB: At the core of these disasters lies the foul-up of the decade, the inept deregulation of the financial system, of which the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in his former capacity as Treasurer, was the principal architect. This provided a stimulus for a range of debacles, from the $3.1 billion black hole in the State Bank of South Australia, which has seen former Premier John Bannon summarily dispatched to oblivion—and rightly so—to the now increasingly publicised offshore rorting of the tax system.

In my own State of Victoria, successive Auditor-General's reports have exposed a damning list of illegal, improper and artificial financing transactions made to disguise the true extent of Labor's damage to Victoria. Not so long ago we had the royal commission report into Tricontinental, the merchant banking arm of what was the State Bank of Victoria, revealing accumulated losses of $2.4 billion. No one was held responsible, and no charges were laid. This is disgracefully typical of the lack of accountability for the disasters of the 1980s. Labor's maladministration and gross incompetence in governing Victoria, now legendary, was the major cause of the decisive outing of Premier Kirner and her Government in the 3 October election. It is now the awesome task of the Kennett Government to implement such unpalatable and difficult measures as are necessary to redress the dire economic circumstances of my own State of Victoria.

Most recently, the findings of the royal commission into Western Australia Inc. have uncovered massive rorts involving Labor notables, past and present, particularly ex-Premier Brian Burke. It seems likely that at the Western Australian State election early in 1993, Premier Lawrence will suffer the same very well-deserved fate as Premier Kirner in Victoria. It is interesting that recently, since the obvious failures of economic rationalism have been revealed, Labor Party high flyers—notably the Prime Minister—have been surreptitiously distancing themselves from the very policies which they implemented in the 1980s. Those policies are now proven failures and are a terrible indictment of Australia's lost 10 years under the Prime Minister and his predecessor.

The very desperate measures contained in these Appropriation Bills now before us illustrate aptly the extent to which economic rationalist policies of the 1980s have adversely affected the lives of Australian people. Even the 1992-93 Budget briefing papers provided by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) acknowledge `that a return to full employment will not be easily or quickly achieved'. That would have to be the understatement of this decade.

The provisions of these Bills now before us may be properly termed the anatomy of despair. Moreover, labour market and training measures contained in the Treasurer's Budget briefing papers, which involve the outlay of $768m in 1992-93, $665.8m in 1993-94, $430.8m in 1994-95, and $108.9m in 1995-96, not only illustrate the enormity of the unemployment problem but also are evidence of the numbers of hidden unemployed which do not appear in official Department of Social Security statistics. Mr Terry McCrann, in the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 18 February 1992, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly, then, we could say that unemployment was really pushing 2 million or just over 20 %. But that is not what the official numbers say.

A survey published in the Herald-Sun of Friday, 13 March 1992, carried out by Ballarat University College for the Brotherhood of St Laurence, found that one in five workers in that city were unemployed in September 1991. The research has raised serious questions about the methods used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to determine the unemployment rate.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, on 25 August 1992 the Melbourne Herald-Sun published findings of a supplementary ABS survey which painted the bleak picture of 1,971,800 Australians, or 21.2 per cent of the work force, aged between 15 and 69 years, having been unemployed at some time during the year to March 1992. The comment made by Sara Dowse in an Australian Society article of June 1991 is worth noting. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The current situation says a great deal about the inroads economic rationalism has made on our national psyche and government that we can feel satisfied about levels of unemployment which would have been unacceptable in the previous decade and considered cataclysmic in the 1960's, when a rate of 2% in 1963 nearly brought down the Menzies Government.
In an article in Executive Action of May-June 1992 entitled `The welfare state or the bureaucratic state', Mr Marcus L'Estrange sums up Labor's attitude towards unemployment. He said:

If only the unemployed would retrain, sign a Newstart agreement, join a job club, obtain a doctorate in literacy/numeracy/job application skills, all would be well, cry Ministers Dawkins/Beazley and Baldwin. Jobs will come forth like water in a desert.

The human face of the jobless statistics and measures introduced to cope with them—unemployment benefits, job training schemes and so on, as well as the labour market and capital works programs encompassed in these Bills—is one of utter misery in both urban and rural areas.

PARA.TAB: Organisations such as the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Citizens Advice Bureaus run by volunteers—partly State funded but largely operated on donations from the public—are also stretched to the limit. The Salvation Army has actually published some of its heart-rending case histories in a book appropriately entitled Hard times. Mr P. Norden, the policy officer of Melbourne Catholic Social Services, wrote in a letter to the Age of 20 October 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: Not since the Great Depression of the 1930's has there been such a prolonged and wide-ranging demand on local community organisations to respond to the needs of people who are hungry, who are homeless, who are in despair because of unemployment and the extent of poverty in our community.

When contacted, a spokesman from Lifeline in Melbourne was reluctant to comment on the recession as it affected the Lifeline service. That is understandable. However, according to an article in the Melbourne Age of 15 October, the Reverend Dr Gordon Moyes, the superintendent of Sydney's Wesley Mission, invited the Prime Minister to listen anonymously `to the heartbeat of the nation'. He criticised the Prime Minister for saying that the recession had ended. Dr Moyes said that the increased calls to Lifeline proved that people were still suffering. Dr Moyes said:
He's talking to the wrong people. The people he is talking to are the survivors.

Ms Jean McCaughey, principal researcher for the Australian Institute of Family Studies, commented on a study undertaken in 1991 at the request of Hanover Welfare Services, a Victorian non-government welfare organisation concerned about the increasing number of families with children seeking assistance with basic housing needs. Ms McCaughey said:

If the 1980's was seen to be the decade of youth homelessness in Australia, the present increase in the numbers of family groups seeking emergency accommodation suggests an alarming new pattern of homeless people in the 1990's.

The article appears in the AIFS journal Family Matters of 13 December 1991. The study found that frequent moves necessitated by economic circumstances had a very destabilising effect on families including children. These are a few of the quotations obtained from family members during the study:
1. The kids at school used to pick on us. They'd call us names like maggots because mum couldn't afford to buy us nice clothes and we were always sort of untidy going to school.
2. I was at so many schools I can't remember. I used to like school but all the problems at home reflected on it. I had to leave at 15 because mum and dad couldn't afford it.
3. We shifted a dozen times. If we couldn't move our furniture, we'd just sell the bloody lot for whatever we could get and buy again.
Despite such obvious disadvantages, Ms McCaughey commented:
On the whole, though, it is remarkable that their personal resources enabled so many families to maintain warm and close relationships through all their vicissitudes.

Advocacy is an important element of help for homeless people. It is needed with public housing authorities, with government departments (particularly the Department of Social Security) . . . Unfortunately the study showed that the requirements and methods of government services tend to increase pressures on families and make things more difficult for them at the very point that they are most vulnerable.

PARA.TAB: According to another article in the same journal of 30 April 1992, co-authored by Peter McDonald and Helen Brownlee, both of the AIFS, unemployment statistics do not tell the whole story of the recession, although the figures are alarming enough. In November 1991 there were 187,000 couples with children—9.3 per cent of all—where neither parent was employed; there were 211,000 sole parents—53 per cent of all—who were not employed. In total, about 710,000 dependent children and 585,000 parents lived in families in which no parent was employed. Not all parents were actively looking for work. Some were sick and some were caring for others. Many were discouraged job seekers who had given up looking for work after many unsuccessful attempts.

Finally, in Family Matters of August 1992, AIFS Director, Don Edgar, in an article `Families in unemployment', wrote of 10,000 people contacting the Brotherhood of St Laurence in Melbourne, since February, seeking clothing and furniture, compared with 5,800 during the same period last year. He instanced 1,100 families per month seeking food vouchers and accommodation at the Salvation Army's Family Welfare Centre in Bourke Street, Melbourne. Recently, the number has soared to 1,600 families a month. Victoria's 64 citizens advice bureaus have received 17,500 calls for emergency relief in the first three months of this year, compared with 12,000 for the same period last year.

Australians in rural areas are also suffering pain and despair due to the recession. But because of the complex and variable nature of farming and because of the lack of the kind of survey work done in city areas, the enormous difficulties are harder to pinpoint. Small to medium farmers contacted in Victoria and South Australia—some of whom are in danger of having to leave their land because of failure to pay mortgages and so on—see their problems as emanating from the incompetent and destructive deregulation of the banking system during the 1980s. Many were actively encouraged to borrow sums for farm improvement and so on at the most enormous interest rates. One South Australian quoted interest rates of up 30 per cent being charged to farmers during the 1980s.

Some farmers' children are eligible for Austudy but, even so, there are financial difficulties because so many students from the rural areas must be educated in the city. There is asset testing of the family allowance for properties worth over $600,000 regardless of income. Rural counsellor, Sue Grimmer, from the Western District of Victoria, told of the great difficulties of her clients. She quoted the example of one married couple who were living on $50 per week. She said that they `didn't starve because they killed their own sheep to eat', but life was still very grim for them.

A major feature article written by Steve Cooper for the Victorian Weekly Times of 26 August this year has predicted that as many as one in five farmers will leave the land during the next five years. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government says 25,000 of the nation's 125,615 farmers are at risk financially or are unviable in the long term.

The catalyst will be the revamping of the Federal Government's rural adjustment scheme to include extra aid for farmers who are forced off the land. The Minister responsible, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), took a hard line when introducing a new drought policy in August this year. He said, `There is no point in prolonging the inevitable for the farmer who will never make it'. To ease the pain of change, it is believed that increased financial incentives of up to $50,000 will be offered to help farmers adjust off the land. At present the figure is an amount of up to $35,000.

PARA.TAB: Meanwhile, some farmers have grouped themselves into organisations such as the Australia First campaign and Bank Watch Action groups to make certain that no farming family has to leave its property if it does not wish to do so. Farmers are ashamed and angry. One farmer's wife commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Country people are very proud. They are ashamed now that they find it difficult to pay their way.

A young man who was hoping to be able to take over the property of his parents was concerned about the break-up of rural communities and their loss of services. A South Australian farmer made perhaps the most telling point when he said:
The Government is saying that we have to go. But to where? To the city to join the ranks of the unemployed? I intend to stay on my land.

The human face behind the statistics of the Department of Social Security makes it clear that we need a new vision for Australia. Such a vision must not only encompass the requisite economic, industry, industrial relations and other policy elements vital to the restoration of prosperity, but also look to giving back dignity and confidence to those Australians cast aside over the last decade in so cavalier a manner. Only a Federal Liberal-National Party government, with a purposeful and imaginative program applied with commonsense and compassion, can provide that vision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the House are Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). I can understand some of the concerns the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred), who preceded me, was expressing about his electorate in the State of Victoria. I remind him that I think all of us can relate stories similar to that.

PARA.TAB: What we should be doing in this House, and throughout this country, if we wish to promote and project what is good in this place, is a little more positive reporting. Let us get on with the job, most certainly. Let us also be aware of the problems that are of concern in the electorates at large. But, most particularly, let us at times lend that helping hand by taking positive steps with positive action.

The Appropriation Bills that we are debating in this House tonight go beyond this. As the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) stated when he introduced the Bills into the House, the Government's One Nation statement was specifically designed to revitalise our nation's key economic infrastructures. Some of the steps that have been taken in that One Nation statement have far-reaching ramifications. It has always been, and will be, a document providing long term solutions.

I was very pleased when Cabinet realistically, in examining what was happening with the expenditure of money since the presentation of the One Nation statement, decided to reallocate some of the money to areas such as local government, as was mentioned by the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) in the House today and previously. It has been proven that at a local level there is the wherewithal, and certainly the expertise, but most particularly—with aid money being paid over and above what has been raised through rate revenue—the ability, to get on quickly with the job.

Many people on both sides of this House have been very critical of that, but particularly in the Opposition. It has been said that we are buying votes by expending part of that appropriation money on local government. I completely disagree with that. When we see the works now being done—not only throughout my State but throughout Australia—we see the multiplying effect associated with the expenditure of that dollar. And that happens very quickly. It is putting solid work into those communities. The benefits are immediate. We are seeing those communities grow and expand because of the input of that money. In other words, they are being kick-started.

I feel dejected at times when I look at how some of the money has been reallocated.
