We hear continual harping from the Opposition about where money is not being spent, how badly it is being spent or where it should be spent. For once I would like the Opposition to congratulate this Government on what we have been able to do in the training field, particularly with our unemployed people, by at least providing facilities and by making available—through our Jobstart, Job Search and Jobskill programs—the opportunity for those people to learn and to acquire extra skills so that when the economy does pick up, as it is slowly doing now, they will have the expertise to go out into the community and make a worthwhile contribution.

It is rather ironic, when we talk about contributions of individuals and, collectively, of small and medium to large business, that we had today a special ceremony in this House. Austrade requested Ministers to re-present awards—awards that had already been presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last Friday—to businesses throughout Australia who were winners in specific areas of small business.

It gave me a great deal of pleasure to be able to be part of that and to congratulate one particular industry within my electorate of Prospect. We heard that originally it had become one of the five finalists to be awarded the Commonwealth Bank small to medium manufacturing award, hoping against all hopes, of course, that it would win or at least be one of the finalists. I believe it reached that category throughout the country. But not only did it win; it also won the DHL Worldwide Express exporter of the year award. This is a very small industry, founded 18 years ago in my electorate, which has now expanded to two manufacturing plants to become the exporter of the year.

It was interesting to hear the history associated with this company. In the 1981-82-83 recession period the company admitted that it made a mistake: it decided, when the economy was going down and when business was going flat in that period, to put off men. But it put off men who had expertise and skills, and it took the company many years to put back such a fine team. Today it also admitted that another mistake it made was not to put enough money into research. The company not only had to get a better product, but it had to get a more competitive product, and a product that would be available on the export markets.

I know this particular industry. The export manager, a very young man of only 28, actually started work with that company, and he is proud to say that he started by sweeping the floors. He worked his way up to understand and to appreciate what the company was all about, and he is now the export manager. I am talking about Cryofab Industries. It manufactures very large storage containers for liquid gas and nitrogen. Very early on, when it started restructuring, the company decided that the limited number of customers it had in Australia was not enough to keep it going and to have expansion, so it went offshore. Now it has large export markets in the Far East, Asia and China.

Four to five years ago it started to build up its export activity. It started with the princely sum of $58,000 one year and thought that was marvellous. It has already passed $4 1/2m, and it hopes to have over $6m in export trade next year. It is a company that has been able to work with its employees. When it opened its second plant within my electorate—it has one in Smithfield and one in Wetherall Park—it allowed its employees to take shares in the company. So it is a company that has expanded with skills, expertise and foresight.

It is interesting to note too that the general manager has been with this company for some 16 years. We ought to praise this. These are not the words of government, not the words of an elected representative—even though I repeat them here tonight—but the words of the people out there on the ground, in the field, getting on with the job, getting the exports, and admitting that they have been assisted all the way with Austrade and congratulating Austrade for the assistance it has given. But even Austrade said, `We can only provide that assistance. We cannot provide the expertise that this particular company has, and we certainly cannot give it the money it has been able to obtain with those markets. That has come from its own resilience and its own hard work'.

This is what we are about in this country. We are seeing small business grow. The opportunities are being provided in these bad times at least to retrain our people. Most particularly, we are out there as a government providing the help and assistance needed in the export industry. In particular, we are encouraging business, as I have just mentioned. This is very gratifying.

The Minister, who is at the table, has come out to the western suburbs of Sydney that I represent—which I like to call part of Sydney's greater west—for the launch of a particular Jobskill campaign. It was a very successful launch with something like 180 people in attendance on about five days notice. We wanted to tell them what Jobskill was all about. I believe it is a very invigorating electorate. People are keen to take on board what is available to them. They are prepared to work, and to work hard. The success of Cryofab is a story that needs to be repeated in the community at large.

When we look at where government is going, we have to start telling our people what has been achieved—whether in the area of child-care or whether in the area of retention in education—and how and where the money is being spent. Too often we go to communities where people say, `Oh, yes, but what does the Federal Government really do for me as far as child-care is concerned?'. We then tell them, `Well, of course, you are paying only very small fees and you are able to have your child at that child-care centre because of the subsidies coming, firstly, from capital grants and, secondly, from ongoing recurrent funding from the Federal Government'.

Recently I was talking to a group of retired citizens, the majority of whom would be on the pension, who said, `Yes, but what else does the Government do for me?'. I said to one person, `Did you have pharmaceutical treatment today; did you go to the chemist?'. The answer was yes. I asked, `Do you realise you paid only a small amount of money for that particular script?'. They did not realise that. People have to be told that pharmaceutical benefits are being subsidised by the Federal Government.

People have to be reminded about Medicare. People think now that it is automatically there; that they have the opportunity to go to a doctor with a card which they provide to him; therefore, they are not charged. They do not realise, until they are told again and again, where that money is coming from. That is part of the overall Budget that is coming from the Federal Government, which is dispersed through the States to the individual to make that person's life a little easier.

Medicare would not be there if it were left to self-interest groups. A certain mentality seems to be coming out in a lot of the coalition speeches delivered in this House. We hear how the Fightback package will be the great saviour. But when one examines it, one finds nothing which will assist people in the long term. There is no clear, quick fix to what is wrong with Australia today. Australia has to be encouraged and coached along.

In times like these when we are going through ups and downs—at the moment we are a little down, but we are certainly climbing up—I always think of a child and of helping him with his first steps. Australia has been through it all; it does not have to be helped with its first steps, but it has to be encouraged. There has to be a lot more active encouragement from its elected representatives. I think also the pessimism has to go from this country and there has to be optimism, particularly from the leaders.

By providing optimism we are also providing encouragement. A lot of people out there need encouragement. Sometimes they only need a hand to assist them to take the first step. Cryofab Industries needed to reassess where it was going. We as a government, through Austrade, were there with a little bit of expertise to give it a helping hand so that it was able to establish itself. By doing that, it is now able to employ more than 70 people and it will continue to expand because it has had that little bit of help.

I believe also that the programs we have put into place—particularly our Jobstart and Jobskill programs because I have been so closely involved with them at a local level with employers—are wonderful schemes. I am a little distressed at times when one or two of our employers use and abuse the schemes, but no matter what we do that will always occur. Let us not judge or prejudge a program because of one or two cases.

Surely we have gone past the stage when people would come in here and say, `Oh, yes, I know of a case where so and so is getting the pension and should not be getting that and they are not really separated, they are really living together' and would therefore maintain that no-one should be assisted because of that individual case which they knew about. We still hear that sort of thing. I say to those people today, `Don't talk about that one case. If you feel that way, report it. But, most particularly, commend and congratulate the other nine who are receiving assistance and doing it so well'.

Through our programs we are training the youth of today to enter the work force and retraining older people to get back into the work force. We should sing loudly the praises and the achievements of those who are getting there. We should sing loudly the praises of companies such as Cryofab which have achieved because they have got off their backsides and have been prepared to take the risks and take on a team of highly motivated and highly sensitive workers who are prepared to do the job. That is what 99 per cent of the people in this country are like. Perhaps we should assist the other one per cent to take that first step.

I believe sincerely that we as elected leaders in this country—when one looks around this place one sees that there are only 148; or 147 at the moment because one is absent—should be there to give advice when it is needed. I think we should be giving a lot more encouragement and, by doing that, we will not only see the dollars that the Government is spending going a lot further but also see individual achievement coming through a lot quicker.

I commend the Government on these Appropriation Bills and on the way in which this money has been handled. I particularly commend the Government for all of the programs which have been put into place through its very positive thinking. It has get-up and go, the ability to get on with the job and the ability to be revitalised time in, time out. I think we now have a government which is shaping up for the future and which will take us into the twenty-first century. We have the ideas, the get-up and go, the know-how and, most particularly, we have the people who are willing to do the implementation. I commend the Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 have been passed by the Senate and the Bill has been returned to this House. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, again this year you have done me the great honour of judging some school essays, and I thank you most sincerely for that.
—It is always a pleasure to assist the honourable member for Ballarat.

—Thank you very much, I appreciate it. The theme this year was: `What it means to me to be an Australian!'. The winner of the junior school prize was Claire Cannon, Year 6, St Francis Xavier College. You gave honourable mentions to Kim James, Grade 6, Forest Street Primary School, aged 12; Taryn Krause, Grade 6, St Patricks Primary School, Stawell; and Matthew Rieniets, Grade 5, Mount Prospect Primary School, aged 11. You gave an encouragement award to Dean Dalgleish, Grade 3, of the Napoleons Primary School.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the senior school prize, you chose Claire Thomas, who is in year 11 at Sebastopol Secondary College. Honourable mentions were given to Aimee Heuzenroeder from Ballarat and Queens Anglican Grammar School, Shane Begbie from Ballarat and Queens Anglican Grammar School and Aja Bongiorno from Loreto College. I will read these essays to the House. The first one is from Claire Cannon. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: As Australians, we are indeed citizens of "The Lucky Country". We have a wealth of natural resources that many countries lack—vast, open spaces; beautiful countryside, and a multi-cultural society. Living in a society such as this teaches us that people from other countries may look a little different, speak a different language, but, deep down, they're the same as us.

Being an Australian means we should help and respect all immigrants. Most of us are descended from foreign families, or may have been born overseas. When we, or our ancestors arrived here, Australia may have been unfamiliar, and possibly, frightening. The sight of a friendly face would have dispelled doubt or fear.

The only TRULY Australian people are the Aborigines. We should have respect for them and their culture. It is a challenge for us who may not truly understand the Aborigines, and for the Aborigines, who may not truly understand us, to be reconciled. It will be hard to do, but if we make allowances and greet each other with open minds, it can be accomplished.

Being Australian also means we should stand by our flag and for what it represents. In the current flag debate, my opinion is that our flag is just about perfect. The Southern Cross is an Australian symbol, and as Australia was originally a British colony, the Union Jack is appropriate. All our flag really needs, I think, is some reference to the Aborigines, the indigenous people of Australia.

As Australians we have rights such as the right to vote; the right to stand for election in Federal, State or Local Government, and more. Many people do not have these rights in their countries because of their sex, religion or beliefs.

As a young Australian, I am proud of the history of our country. Our soldiers have fought bravely in several wars; our government has always been democratic; and the rights of individuals have been respected. The pioneers who settled this vast country did so with a sense of hope and adventure, and that is how we must face the current recession—with a sense of hope and adventure. Along with that, we should be creative and try to think of ideas to help us pull through. We should be supportive towards one another and, above all, have respect for the land that has given us so much, and still has more to give.
I am proud to be Australian!
The second essay is from Claire Thomas, the winner of the senior section for Sebastopol Secondary College. It reads:

PARA.TAB: Australia is home. There is security in this knowledge and pride in our individual heritage and culture. Australia meets the needs of a vast diversity of people, united only by their love for their country. The composition of Australian society is unlike any other; it is distinctive in its heritage of all who search for a better life. Throughout her short history, Australia has been home to immigrants, and continues to be so. Australia has a quality that attracts people, and the capacity to fulfil their dreams.

It becomes a matter of course for loyalty to influence the manner in which we view our land and tongue. Despite the values, principles and morals affecting our own society, our involvement with society arouses feelings of belonging and provides something we can always call our own. Australia is ours, and despite what we may do to our country, this will always be so.

Do Australians really have so much to be particularly proud of? Is Australia free of the incidents of which it accuses other countries? Does Australia really have a glorious past? These are questions that all communities can answer, and Australians, even in their relative youth, have a belief in their country's attributes and the motivation to act upon them. To a student, there are dreams that may well be realised; there are opportunities available; there is the potential to cater for the fulfilment of all.

I cannot answer for all, but for many Australians the title implies a relatively free and relaxed lifestyle, the availability of technologies and opportunities to maximize life experiences and the feeling of belonging, understanding and appreciating, which generates loyalty. On the other hand the realities of discrimination, unemployment and poverty cannot be ignored. But one's place of birth is one's domain, and being Australian means I naturally follow the supportive thinking patterns of an Australian, even when this may seem hypocritical. No matter what Australia is held to have done, I am a part of her and her history.

To be an Australian is to be identified with sun swept plains, bronzed countryside, white washed beaches, freedom of speech and personal rights. To be an Australian is to share the good and bad times with other Australians. To be an Australian is to live richly or poorly, happily or sadly, passively or actively. Above all, to be an Australian is to be proud. Being Australian doesn't just mean stereotype of the "big bronzed Aussie" or the "blond sheila". Every Australian person is unique. Being Australian means having the personal freedom to be an individual.

The flag cannot alter Australia's uniqueness and independence. The status of republic or monarchy cannot alter the fact that we are Australian. No matter what political changes occur, Australia remains Australian and its people maintain allegiance to their homeland. To a young person the flag does not hold the power it does for older generations. Nor does the possibility of republicanism create feelings of betrayal to our Queen. For those who will soon play a greater role in their community, the things of importance are the preservation of their homeland and the people who belong here. In this context, Australia is not so much a physical feature with physical attributes as it is a significant emotional attachment. It is this which makes us proud to be Australian, and truly makes Australia home.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABC has been under siege in recent years. It has been under siege from the same forces that have waged war on the Australian community through the 1980s. It is under siege from both the Government's funding cuts and the threats of even bigger funding cuts from the Opposition. It has had a steady pressure to increase commercialisation and a reduction of capacity to make programs.

PARA.TAB: The treatment of the ABC is one of the reasons people are consistently deserting the major parties. With the concentration of media ownership and the commercial censorship that exists in this country now, the ABC is one of the main sources of public information and, as such, it is one of the cornerstones of our democracy.

In addition to the external pressures, the ABC, like all major bureaucracies, has many internal problems. Nothing illustrates the problems of bureaucracy more than the present efforts to get rid of Margaret Throsby. To about a quarter of Australia's people, Margaret Throsby is the personification of ABC radio, the voice of Sydney. After 26 years, the ABC without Margaret Throsby would be a little like Sydney without the Harbour Bridge. Perhaps that is a bad analogy now that the Harbour Bridge has been leased to Kumagai Transfield. It is probably more like Paris without the Eiffel Tower.

It is almost unthinkable that some nameless bureaucrat in the ABC can be allowed to take Margaret Throsby off the air. Even worse is the fact that the ABC board could even contemplate such an action. The crime, of which she is supposed to be accused, is that she is taking part in advertisements for the Macquarie Bank. At a time when the Government is corporatising and commercialising almost every institution in the country from Telecom down to the smallest school, I think this reeks of a double standard and, frankly, pettiness. Other ABC personalities have done ads for years: Wendy Harmer, H.G. Nelson, Roy Slaven and Maggie Tabberer. So why pick on Throsby?

Margaret Throsby is a contract employee. She was told before she started the ads that this would not affect her contract. Her ratings are higher than they have ever been; there have been no public complaints whatsoever. She breaches nothing in the code of ethics of the AJA. She has informed the board that she will quite happily comply with whatever policy it decides on doing advertisements at its next meeting in December. Even David Hill accepts the situation.

In spite of all this, she has been pressured and victimised. The pressure has been on to get her to stand down without pay for the last couple of weeks. Now she has been told that there will be no contract next year when she finishes in December. Margaret Throsby has been a Sydney institution. She has informed and given pleasure to millions over the last quarter of a century. I think this Parliament, and particularly every member representing the people of Sydney, should try to prevent the injustice that is being done in the name of petty bureaucracy and perhaps the tall poppy syndrome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grave concerns about the continuing criminal penetration of the meat industry led to the establishment by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, ABCI, in 1991 of the Jodphur Probe, which in respect of information obtained by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, AQIS, later reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst this infiltration appeared to be happening in several states, the Victorian meat industry appears to be where most activity is taking place with allegations of fraud and drug importation occurring.
Similarly in the Weekly Times of 23 October 1991, Steve Cooper reporting on meat industry prosecutions for a wide range of offences said:

Federal Resources Minister Alan Griffiths is concerned enough to favour strengthening the `fit and proper person' legislative powers and broadening the regulations to take in the domestic meat industry.

Where did all these serious expressions of concern eventually leave the meat industry? It would appear, on present indications, not terribly advanced. The Weekly Times reporter, David Gorrie, in an article of 11 November 1992 headed `Smorgon buys back the farm' said:
The sale of four works in Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia by the Angliss Group to Melbourne's Smorgon family could represent the start of an Australian beef industry revival.
Later, in that same article, he said:
It would also make the group the second largest Australian meat processor with 15 per cent market share.
The report on Probe Jodphur is less laudatory of the Smorgon group. Paragraph 3.1 states:

In the late 1960s amongst the numerous legitimate operators within the Victorian meat industry, a group run by the Rotstein Brothers was identified as having interests in several boning rooms and abattoirs. Those brothers had alleged associations with known criminals and were supposedly developed as an extension of the Smorgons group who were one of the biggest operators in the industry at the time.
Of the next decade, in paragraph 3.3, the report says:

In the mid-1970s another group allegedly run by Norbert Boehm emerged. At that time the meat industry was experiencing some economic problems yet this group who had connections back to the Rotsteins had expanded to the degree that by the end of the decade they were a major force in the industry as part of Steiger operations.
Then, of the 1980s, in paragraph 3.10 it is stated:

Smorgon Consolidated Industries came under the notice of the Royal Commission with the chief executive Jack Morris being called as a witness. Allegations had been made concerning large scale false halal certification practices but Morris refused to answer questions on the grounds of self-incrimination and the allegations were subsequently never addressed at length.

Jack Morris is still today managing director of Smorgon Consolidated Industries. It might be added that document H of the 1982 Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry headed by Mr Justice Woodward dealt with these allegations in some detail. Mr Justice Woodward commented:
These matters could only excite suspicion that the meatworks had something to hide.

Moreover, Smorgon Consolidated Industries, through its company Pacific Meat Supply Pty Ltd, was convicted under the Contravention of Secret Commissions Act in the Melbourne Magistrates Court on 20 February 1986 and ordered to pay $4,000 into the court poor box, as shown on the relevant documentation. The charge was strangely changed from the original conspiracy to defraud, again as documented.

PARA.TAB: In view of the Federal Labor Government's steps to supposedly strengthen the fit and proper person requirements, I would like to know from the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) how the Smorgon Group, with its extraordinary record and associations over a long period, was able to take over the Angliss Group unchallenged. In conclusion, I seek leave to table the documents I have referred to throughout this adjournment speech.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: Do officers of the Australian Public Service who are sent to remote areas on a short term basis qualify for an educational costs allowance of up to $11 000 per annum for board and tuition; if so, (a) what are the qualifying criteria, (b) what constitutes remote areas, (c) how many officers obtain the allowance in each State and (d) is the allowance subject to means and assets testing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1 (a) Officers who move on permanent transfer or term transfer (usually for between 2 and 3 years) may be eligible for Education Costs Allowance. The allowance covers the cost of board (up to a maximum of $6812 per annum less a maximum officer contribution of up to $1615) and tuition (up to a maximum of $6718 per annum less a maximum officer contribution of $135) for children in their final two years of secondary schooling who remain at the officer's former locality.
(b) This allowance is not limited to remote localities.
(c) In DEET two officers receive the allowance (one in Queensland and one in Canberra).
(d) No.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 12 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) the successor to the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications (COPQ); if so, what is the difference between them.
(2) Was NOOSR staffed with key personnel from COPQ.
(3) Did COPQ staff continue to assess overseas qualifications as NOOSR staff.
(4) What has NOOSR achieved since its establishment.
(5) What Government funding does NOOSR receive.
(6) How many overseas trained qualified immigrants from (a) non-English speaking and (b) Commonwealth countries are not practising in the professions for which they are trained.

(7) How many overseas trained (a) engineers, (b) doctors, (c) dentists, (d) medical specialists, (e) architects, and (f) tradesmen have not had their qualifications recognised in Australia and are unable to practise here in their field.
(8) What are NOOSR's assessing criteria.
(9) Is NOOSR or its agents required to disclose its investigations of overseas architectural schools.
(10) How are professional immigrants seeking recognition of their qualifications assisted by the Government other than through bridging courses.

(11) Are academic architectural qualifications from Ghana, India, Kenya and Sri Lanka recognised in Australia butthose from Germany, France, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Italy are not; if so why.
(12) Was a thorough reform of the recognition process announced with the establishment of NOOSR.

(13) Is it a fact that qualifications from 15 architectural schools from 11 countries, which were ArchitectsAccreditation Council of Australia (AACA) individually-approved qualifications until 1989, are no longer acceptable in Australia; if so, why.
(14) Has the successor to the Bauhaus, the cradle of modern architecture, been eliminated from the AACA list of individually-approved qualifications.

(15) Do immigrants from certain former Eastern European states find it easier to obtain professional recognition in Australia than do immigrants from leading Western countries who have been in Australia much longer; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. NOOSR was set up to co-ordinate the implementation of the Migrant Skills Reform Strategy as announced in the Government's Ministerial statement issued by the Hon John Dawkins in 1989 entitled Migrant Skills:Improving Recognition Processes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) NOOSR has coordinated the implementation of the Government's Migrant Skills Reform Strategy as set out in the answer to (1) above. Achievements against the strategy were detailed in a Progress Report compiled by the National Advisory Committee on Skills Recognition (NACSR) and tabled in Parliament in 1991.
(5) Running costs—$2,781,886.00
Innovative grants—2,173,000.00
Evaluation, Research and Development—220,000.00
(6) No data is available.
(7) No data is available.

(8) Under the NOOSR umbrella, assessments of overseas qualifications in dentistry, dietetics, occupational therapy, pharmacy, physiotherapy, podiatry and veterinary science are made by formal examination. NOOSR provides comparative assessments against Australian requirements of qualifications in a variety of occupations, including architecture, radiography and computing, for migration purposes and social welfare and technical occupations for both migration and domestic purposes. NOOSR has also published general educational qualifications assessment guidelines and provides general academic and technical educational assessments using these guidelines. They are published in the Country Education Profiles and in the Compendium of Technical Qualifications: a Summary.
(9) No, but any requests for access to documents would be considered.

(10) Assistance is provided to all eligible overseas trained professionals under the full range of labour market and training programs offered by DEET, and in addition under special programs such as Jobtrain Bridging for overseas trained professionals and courses funded at higher education institutions by the NOOSR Innovative Mainstreaming Fund. Further, NOOSR offers direct assessment services as outlined in 8 above and a general information and referral service by phone and in writing, as well as producing an extensive range of information publications and pamphlets on skills recognition.

(11) The recognition of architectural qualifications is not dependent on the country of study of the applicant, nor on the specific institution of study but upon the particular content of individual study programs.
(13) & (14) Architects Accreditation Council of Australia (AACA) is an independent organisation not responsible to the Government.
(15) No data is available.
